A reverend man that grazed his cattle nigh, Sometime a blusterer that the ruffle knew Of court, of city, and had let go by The swiftest hours observed as they flew, Towards this afflicted fancy fastly drew; And, privileged by age, desires to know In bri The Duke of Lancaster, and Westmerland:Against the Welsh himselfe, and Harrie Monmouth. To say ay and no tothese particulars is more than to answer in a catechism. --Speak thou, boy:Perhaps thy childishness will move him moreThan can our reasons. I am about it, but indeed my invention Comes from my pate as birdlime does from frieze; It plucks out brains and all. That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit out ofthe 'Hundred Merry Tales. Kill, kill, kill, kill, kill him![AUFIDIUS and the CONSPIRATORS draw, and kill CORIOLANUS,whofalls. I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise alodging, and say he lies here or he lies there, were to lie in mineown throat. Nothing but a Colossus can do thee that frendshipSay thy prayers, and farewell Fal. If the cat will after kind, So be sure will Rosalinde. Be innocent of the knowledge, dearest chuck,Till thou applaud the deed. I saw Mark Antony offer hima crown (yet 'twas not a crown neither, 'twas one of these coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once. I myself have all the other:And the very ports they blow,All the quarters that they knowI' the shipman's card. Nay, you were better speak first; and when you were gravell'd for lack of matter, you might take occasion tokiss. Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell: For certain she is dead, and by strange manner. The forest Enter JAQUES and LORDS, in the habit of foresters JAQUES. I do beseech youLet me o'erleap that custom; for I cannotPut on the gown, stand naked, and entreat them,For my wounds' sake to give their suffrage: please youThat I may pass this doing. And thou hast talk'dOf Sallies, and Retires; Trenches, Tents,Of Palizadoes, Frontiers, Parapets,Of Basiliskes, of Canon, Culuerin,Of Prisoners ransome, and of Souldiers slaine,And all the current of a headdy fight. Well, I will for refuge straight to Bristow Castle. I give away myself for you and dote upon the exchange. 'Tis so: and as war in some sort, may be said to be a ravisher,so it cannot be denied but peace is a great maker of cuckolds. A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester. But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar's house, Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine How to cut off some charge in legacies. Thus it goes: If it do come to pass That any man turn ass, Leaving his wealth and ease A stubborn will to please, Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame; Here shall he see Gross fools as he, An if he will come to me. Doubly divorc'd! Bad men, you violate A twofold marriage-'twixt my crown and me, And then betwixt me and my married wife. You know the very road into his kindnessAnd cannot lose your way. No, by my soul, she was not; Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me; But always hath been just and virtuous In anything that I do know by her. Prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I willget again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker'spen and hang me up at the door of a brothel house for the sign of blind Cupid. Now to you: If on my credit you dare build so far To make your speed to Dover, you shall find Some that will thank you, making just report Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow The King hath cause to plain. Old Time the clock-setter, that bald sexton Time, Is it as he will? Well then, France shall rue. And must we be divided? Must we part? KING RICHARD. A servant that he bred, thrill'd with remorse, Oppos'd against the act, bending his sword To his great master; who, thereat enrag'd, Flew on him, and amongst them fell'd him dead; But not without that harmful stroke which since Hath pluck'd him after. He'll go along o'er the wide world with me; Leave me alone to woo him. O hateful error, melancholy's child, Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men The things that are not? O error, soon conceived, Thou never comest unto a happy birth, But kill'st the mother that engender'd thee! TITINIUS. Old John of Gaunt, time-honoured Lancaster, Hast thou, according to thy oath and band, Brought hither Henry Hereford, thy bold son, Here to make good the boist'rous late appeal, Which then our leisure would not let us hear, Against the Duke of Norfolk,  Besides, our nearness to the King in love Is near the hate of those love not the King. Well said, old mole! canst work i?the earth so fast? A worthy pioner!?nce more remove, good friends. His industryis vp-staires and down-staires, his eloquence the parcellof a reckoning. He takes her up, and declines his head upon her neck: lays him down upon a bank of flowers: she, seeing him asleep, leaves him. Now, this extremity Hath brought me to thy hearth: not out of hope,Mistake me not, to save my life; for ifI had fear'd death, of all the men i' the worldI would have 'voided thee; but in mere spite,To be full quit of those my banishers,Stand I before th Good even, good Master What-ye-call't; how do you,sir? Two o'clock is your hour? ORLANDO. Who knows if Donalbain be with his brother?LENNOX. At every house I'll call; I may command at most. Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashionis? how giddily 'a turns about all the hot-bloods betweenfourteen and five-and-thirty? sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers in the reechy painting, sometime like god Bel'spriests in t I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honor. I am nohonest man if there be any good meaning toward you. It is my only suit, Provided that you weed your better judgments Of all opinion that grows rank in them That I am wise. Jove, Jove! this shepherd's passion Is much upon my fashion. But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic;And manhood is call'd foolery when it stands Against a falling fabric. The one, to save the money that he spends in tiring; the other, that at dinner they should not drop in his porridge. Thus play I in one person many people, And none contented. Do'st thou so hunger for my emptie Chayre,That thou wilt needes inuest thee with mine Honors,Before thy howre be ripe? O foolish Youth!Thou seek'st the Greatnesse, that will ouer-whelme thee. Therefore, beseech you,--You that will be less fearful than discreet;That love the fundamental part of stateMore than you doubt the change on't; that preferA noble life before a long, and wishTo jump a body with a dangerous physicThat's sure of death wi By mytroth, we that have good wits have much to answer for: we shall be flouting; we cannot hold. Sirrah, get thee to Plashy, to my sister Gloucester; Bid her send me presently a thousand pound. --Now, Mars, I pr'ythee, make us quick in work,That we with smoking swords may march from henceTo help our fielded friends!--Come, blow thy blast. Do'st thou heare Hal, neuer call a true peece ofGold a Counterfeit: thou art essentially made, withoutseeming so Prince. Therefore be gone Without our grace, our love, our benison. The messengers from our sister and the King Corn. But I pray, sir, why am I beaten?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as far as day doesnight; it's spritely, waking, audible, and full of vent. This hand of yours requires A sequester from liberty, fasting, and prayer, Much castigation, exercise devout, For here's a young and sweating devil here That commonly rebels. Enter Desdemona, Iago, and Attendants. Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remains Some scar of it; lean upon a rush, The cicatrice and capable impressure Thy palm some moment keeps; but now mine eyes, Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not; Nor, I am sure, there is not force in eyes  No; It is thyself, mine own self's better part; Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart, My food, my fortune, and my sweet hope's aim, My sole earth's heaven, and my heaven's claim. 'Tis strange that they should so depart from home, And not send back my messenger. Would it not grieve a woman to be overmaster'd with a piece ofvaliant dust? to make an account of her life to a clod of waywardmarl? No, uncle, I'll none. Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves That they are not the first of fortune's slaves, Nor shall not be the last; like silly beggars Who, sitting in the stocks, refuge their shame, That many have and others must sit there; And in this thought t Was? SALISBURY. And Falstaffe, you caried your Guts away as nimbly, withas quicke dexteritie, and roared for mercy, and still ranneand roar'd, as euer I heard Bull-Calfe. Nay, you might keep that check forit, till you met your wife's wit going to your neighbour's bed. Yet for your part, it not appeares to me,Either from the King, or in the present Time,That you should haue an ynch of any groundTo build a Griefe on: were you not restor'dTo all the Duke of Norfolkes Seignories,Your Noble, and right well-remembred FatherFor know, Iago, But that I love the gentle Desdemona, I would not my unhoused free condition Put into circumscription and confine For the sea's worth. A dear happiness to women! They would else have beentroubled with a pernicious suitor. Faith, that was not so well; yet would I knew That stroke would prove the worst! What needed then that terrible dispatch of it intoyour pocket? The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself. But though they jump not on a just account As in these cases, where the aim reports, 'Tis oft with differenceyet do they all confirm A Turkish fleet, and bearing up to Cyprus. Heralds, from off our tow'rs we might behold From first to last the onset and retire Of both your armies, whose equality By our best eyes cannot be censured. A devil in an everlasting garment hath him; One whose hard heart is button'd up with steel; A fiend, a fairy, pitiless and rough; A wolf, nay worse, a fellow all in buff; A back-friend, a shoulder-clapper, one that countermands The passages of alleys, c Titinius, if thou lovest me, Mount thou my horse and hide thy spurs in him, Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops And here again, that I may rest assured Whether yond troops are friend or enemy. Enter the conspirators, Cassius, Casca, Decius, Cinna, Metellus Cimber, and Trebonius. If my offense be of such mortal kind That nor my service past nor present sorrows Nor purposed merit in futurity Can ransom me into his love again, But to know so must be my benefit; So shall I clothe me in a forced content And shut myself up in some ot [Within] If thy name be called Luce -Luce, thou hast answer'd him well. I know his eye doth homage otherwhere; Or else what lets it but he would be here? KING RICHARD. 'Tis not the trial of a woman's war, The bitter clamour of two eager tongues, Can arbitrate this cause betwixt us twain; The blood is hot that must be cool'd for this. Now counterfeit to swoon; why, now fall down; Or, if thou canst not, O, for shame, for shame, Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers. Enter ENGLISH HERALD, with trumpet ENGLISH HERALD. For all the Countrey, in a generall voyce,Cry'd hate vpon him: and all their prayers, and loue,Were set on Herford, whom they doted on,And bless'd, and grac'd, and did more then the King. I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and sogood a continuer. It seems you know not, then, so much as we: The Cardinal Pandulph is within at rest, Who half an hour since came from the Dauphin, And brings from him such offers of our peace As we with honour and respect may take, With purpose presently to leave this  Wake Duncan with thy knocking! IAGO. Gives him aletter. To vouch this is no proof, Without more certain and more overt test Than these thin habits and poor likelihoods Of modern seeming do prefer against him. An thou hadst been set i' th' stocks for that question, thou'dst well deserv'd it. Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay The first departing of the King for Ireland. Can you tell if Rosalind, the Duke's daughter, bebanished with her father? CHARLES. I had a thing to say But I will fit it with some better time. Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead! Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets. For, if I hang,old Sir Iohn hangs with mee, and thou know'st hee's noStarueling. Pr'ythee, peace!I dare do all that may become a man;Who dares do more is none. The weight of this sad time we must obey, Speak what we feel, not what we ought to say. Ely HouseEnter JOHN OF GAUNT, sick, with the DUKE OF YORK, etc. Poore fellow neuer ioy'd since the price of oatsrose, it was the death of him 2. Lay on our royal sword your banish'd hands; Swear by the duty that you owe to God, Our part therein we banish with yourselves, To keep the oath that we administer: You never shall, so help you truth and God, Embrace each other's love in banishment; Nor  Exeunt all but Antony. So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee, With urging helpless patience would relieve me; But if thou live to see like right bereft, This fool-begg'd patience in thee will be left. Do not doubt, Cassio, But I will have my lord and you again As friendly as you were. Nay, but fellow, fellow,--[Enter CORIOLANUS with AUFIDIUS. Can you remember any of the principal evils that helaid to the charge of women? Hot. Ourself, and Bushy, Bagot here, and Green, Observ'd his courtship to the common people; How he did seem to dive into their hearts With humble and familiar courtesy; What reverence he did throw away on slaves, Wooing poor craftsmen with the craft of smil Caius Marcius wasA worthy officer i' the war; but insolent,O'ercome with pride, ambitious past all thinking,Self-loving,--SICINIUS. He that beguil'd you in aplain accent was a plain knave, which, for my part, I will not be, though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to't. Enter Borachio and Conrade. She told her, while she kept it, 'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father Entirely to her love, but if she lost it Or made a gift of it, my father's eye Should hold her loathed and his spirits should hunt After new fancies. I would he had! 'Twas you incens'd the rabble;--Cats, that can judge as fitly of his worthAs I can of those mysteries which heavenWill not have earth to know. Though I could wishYou were conducted to a gentle bath,And balms applied to you, yet dare I neverDeny your asking: take your choice of thoseThat best can aid your action. There's comfort yet; they are assailable;Then be thou jocund: ere the bat hath flownHis cloister'd flight, ere to black Hecate's summons,The shard-borne beetle, with his drowsy hums,Hath rung night's yawning peal, there shall be doneA deed of dreadful noI am not yet of Percies mind, the Hotspurreof the North, he that killes me some sixe or seauendozen of Scots at a Breakfast, washes his hands, and saiesto his wife; Fie vpon this quiet life, I want worke. Yet once again proclaim it publicly, If any friend will pay the sum for him, He shall not die; so much we tender him. I pretheecall in Falstaffe, Ile play Percy, and that damn'd Brawneshall play Dame Mortimer his wife. He's mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a horse's health, a boy's love, or a whore's oath. Sirrah, if thy captain knew I were here he would use me withestimation. I am Robert Shallow (Sir) a poore Esquire of thisCountie, and one of the Kings Iustices of the Peace:What is your good pleasure with me? Bard. Confusion now hath made his masterpiece!Most sacrilegious murder hath broke opeThe Lord's anointed temple, and stole thenceThe life o' the building. --Advance, brave Titus:They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts,Which makes me sweat with wrath. Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed? OTHELLO. Not to be tempted, would she be immured, And now to tempt all liberty procured. Here is the man, this Moor, whom now, it seems, Your special mandate for the state affairs Hath hither brought. Yes, that I will; and wherefore will I do it? I tore them from their bonds, and cried aloud 'O that these hands could so redeem my son, As they have given these hairs their liberty!' But now I envy at their liberty, And will again commit them to their b Here do I throw down this, If he may be repeal'd to try his honour. The queen his mother Lives almost by his looks; and for myself,?My virtue or my plague, be it either which,?She? so conjunctive to my life and soul, That, as the star moves not but in his sphere, I could not but by her. Will you be patient? Will you stay awhile? I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it. You holy clergymen, is there no plot To rid the realm of this pernicious blot? ABBOT. Rich honesty dwells like a miser, sir, in a poor house; as yourpearl in your foul oyster. Look you pale, mistress? Do you perceive the gastness of her eye? Nay, if you stare, we shall hear more anon. But my Lads, my Lads, to morrow morning, byfoure a clocke early at Gads hill, there are Pilgrimes goingto Canterbury with rich Offerings, and Traders ridingto London with fat Purses. Enter King Duncan, Malcolm, Donalbain, Lennox,with Attendants, meeting a bleeding Soldier. But we must win your Grace to go with us To Bristow Castle, which they say is held By Bushy, Bagot, and their complices, The caterpillars of the commonwealth, Which I have sworn to weed and pluck away. Good uncle, let this end where it begun; We'll calm the Duke of Norfolk, you your son. But to the girdle do the gods inherit, Beneath is all the fiend's. By this hand, if I were nowby this Rascall, I could braine him with his Ladies Fan. Ay, and a bold one, that dare look on thatWhich might appal the devil. Yea, and so vs'd it, that were it heere apparant,that thou art Heire apparant. This union shall do more than battery can To our fast-closed gates; for at this match With swifter spleen than powder can enforce, The mouth of passage shall we fling wide ope And give you entrance; but without this match, The sea enraged is not half so 'Tis very true: my grief lies all within; And these external manner of laments Are merely shadows to the unseen grief That swells with silence in the tortur'd soul. Speak briefly, then;For we are peremptory to dispatchThis viperous traitor: to eject him henceWere but one danger; and to keep him hereOur certain death: therefore it is decreedHe dies to-night. When thou ran'st vp Gads-Hill in the Night, tocatch my Horse, if I did not thinke that thou hadst beenean Ignis fatuus, or a Ball of Wild-fire, there's no Purchasein Money. They allrunaway, leauing the booty behind them. She never reprehended him but mildly, When he demean'd himself rough, rude, and wildly. And as I truly fight, defend me heaven! MARSHAL. Here is better than the open air; take it thankfully. What wilt thou do? thou wilt not murder me??Help, help, ho! Pol. Upon a lie seven times removedbear your body more seeming, Audreyas thus, sir. Pray God we may make haste, and come too late! ALL. My Lord, you told me you would tell the rest, When weeping made you break the story off, Of our two cousins' coming into London. But wherefore doe I tell these Newes to thee?Why, Harry, doe I tell thee of my Foes,Which art my neer'st and dearest Enemie?Thou, that art like enough, through vassall Feare,Base Inclination, and the start of Spleene,To fight against me vnder Percies payAnd that Count Claudio did mean, upon his words, to disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and not marry her. A little water clears us of this deed:How easy is it then! Your constancyHath left you unattended. Have you the heart? When your head did but ache, I knit my handkerchief about your brows The best I had, a princess wrought it me And I did never ask it you again; And with my hand at midnight held your head; And, like the watchful minutes to the hour,  Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly; forthough she's as like this as a crab's like an apple, yet I can tell what I can tell. There was it;--For which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him. --Hark!--I laid their daggers ready;He could not miss 'em. Has he, masters? I fear there will a worse come in his place. My young remembrance cannot parallelA fellow to it. But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladieshave lost? LE BEAU. O Cassius! Far from this country Pindarus shall run, Where never Roman shall take note of him. Let me see, about Michaelmas next I shalbe Poin. Your noble Tullus Aufidius will appear well inthese wars, his great opposer, Coriolanus, being now in norequest of his country. Then is there mirth in heaven, When earthly things made even Atone together. ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOMMERCIALLY. Here is the guess of their true strength and forces By diligent discovery; but your haste Is now urg'd on you. Where is he wounded?--[To theTRIBUNES, who come forward. I sin in envying his nobility;And were I anything but what I am,I would wish me only he. When I strike my foot Upon the bosom of the ground, rush forth And bind the boy which you shall find with me Fast to the chair. It was (my Lord) who lin'd himself with hope,Eating the ayre, on promise of Supply,Flatt'ring himselfe with Proiect of a power,Much smaller, then the smallest of his Thoughts,And so with great imagination(Proper to mad men) led his Powers to death,And ( I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, Lay down my soul at stake. I told him gently of our greeuances,Of his Oath-breaking: which he mended thus,By now forswearing that he is forsworne,He cals vs Rebels, Traitors, and will scourgeWith haughty armes, this hatefull name in vs. Re-enter Titinius, with Messala. This is strange now: do you two know how you are censured here inthe city, I mean of us o' the right-hand file? Hold, hold, for shame! OTHELLO. Husband, I'll dine above with you to-day, And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks. But doth he know that I am in this forest, and inman's apparel? Looks he as freshly as he did the day he wrestled? CELIA. When we consider The importancy of Cyprus to the Turk, And let ourselves again but understand That as it more concerns the Turk than Rhodes, So may he with more facile question bear it, For that it stands not in such warlike brace, But altogether lacks  He hath commission from thy wife and me To hang Cordelia in the prison and To lay the blame upon her own despair That she fordid herself. Here's a good world! Knew you of this fair work? Beyond the infinite and boundless reach Of mercy, if thou didst this deed of death, Art thou damn'd, Hubert. I see a strange Confession in thine Eye:Thou shak'st thy head, and hold'st it Feare, or Sinne,To speake a truth. Is this a holiday? What, know you not, Being mechanical, you ought not walk Upon a laboring day without the sign Of your profession? Speak, what trade art thou? FIRST COMMONER. Is this the noble Moor whom our full Senate Call all in all sufficient? This the nature Whom passion could not shake? whose solid virtue The shot of accident nor dart of chance Could neither graze nor pierce? IAGO. But now I know thy mind: thou dost suspect That I have been disloyal to thy bed And that he is a bastard, not thy son. Let them go on;This mutiny were better put in hazardThan stay, past doubt, for greater:If, as his nature is, he fall in rageWith their refusal, both observe and answerThe vantage of his anger. I know not what you mean by that, but I am sure Caesarfell down. Come, come, you are a fool, And turn'd into the extremity of love. So I do; but, i' faith, I should have been a woman by right. Marry, and did, sir; namely, no time torecover hair lost by nature. For this last,Before and in Corioli, let me say,I cannot speak him home: he stopp'd the fliers;And by his rare example made the cowardTurn terror into sport: as weeds beforeA vessel under sail, so men obey'd,And fell below his stem: his sword,--death's  "He was a wight of high renown, And thou art but of low degree. Out of my sight, and never see me more! My nobles leave me; and my state is braved, Even at my gates, with ranks of foreign pow'rs; Nay, in the body of the fleshly land, This kingdom, this confine of blood and breath, Hostility and civil tumult reigns B They say Edgar, his banish'd son, is with the Earl ofKent in Germany. [Drum afar off] Hark, our drumsAre bringing forth our youth! we'll break our wallsRather than they shall pound us up: our gates,Which yet seem shut, we have but pinn'd with rushes;They'll open of themselves. He is compos'd and fram'd of treachery, And fled he is upon this villany. Enter, with Drum and Colours, Edmund, Regan, Gentleman, andSoldiers. O my gentle Hubert, We owe thee much! Within this wall of flesh There is a soul counts thee her creditor, And with advantage means to pay thy love; And, my good friend, thy voluntary oath Lives in this bosom, dearly cherished. Rest, rest, perturbed spirit!?o, gentlemen, With all my love I do commend me to you: And what so poor a man as Hamlet is May do, to express his love and friending to you, God willing, shall not lack. Nay, I thinke rather, you are more beholdingto the Night, then to the Fernseed, for your walking inuisible Gad. Exeunt [Lear and Cordelia, guarded]. Exit HUBERT withPETER O my gentle cousin, Hear'st thou the news abroad, who are arriv'd? BASTARD. Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee To make the base earth proud with kissing it. Arm you against your other enemies, I'll make a peace between your soul and you. Stand from him Fellow; wherefore hang'st vpon him? Host. Case ye, case ye; on with your Vizards, there'smony of the Kings comming downe the hill, 'tis goingto the Kings Exchequer Fal. Now cannot I strike him, if I should be hang'd Prin. What Ostler, come away, and be hangd: comeaway 2. --By the elements,If e'er again I meet him beard to beard,He's mine or I am his: mine emulationHath not that honour in't it had; for whereI thought to crush him in an equal force,--True sword to sword,--I'll potch at him some way,Or wrath or craft may geI did suppose it should be on constraint; But, heaven be thank'd, it is but voluntary. My Lord, these Griefes shall be with speed redrest:Vpon my Life, they shall. ) I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviours tolove, will, after he hath laugh'd at such shallow follies inothers, become the argument of his own scorn by falling in love; andsuch a man is ClaudiI warrant you, with pure love and troubled brain, hehath ta'en his bow and arrows, and is gone forthto sleep. I am glad on't: then we shall ha' means to ventOur musty superfluity. The grappling vigour and rough frown of war Is cold in amity and painted peace, And our oppression hath made up this league. This shall make Our purpose necessary and not envious, Which so appearing to the common eyes, We shall be call'd purgers, not murderers. Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put it in practice. Sweet mistress-what your name is else, Iknow not, Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not Than our earth's wonder-more than earth, divine. Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby, Bloody with spurring, fiery-red with haste. You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor. The west yet glimmers with some streaks of day:Now spurs the lated traveller apace,To gain the timely inn; and near approachesThe subject of our watch. With courtesy and with respect enough, But not with such familiar instances, Nor with such free and friendly conference, As he hath used of old. I would I were a Weauer, I could sing all manner ofsongs. Shall she come in? were't good? I think she stirs again. Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? Where is Bagot? What is become of Bushy? Where is Green? That they have let the dangerous enemy Measure our confines with such peaceful steps? If we prevail, their heads shall pay for it. If you think other, Remove your thought; it doth abuse your bosom. Believe then, if you please, that I can do strange things. My duty cannot suffer T' obey in all your daughters' hard commands. It was an answer: how apply you this?MENENIUS. Then they fled Into this abbey, whither we pursu'd them; And here the Abbess shuts the gates on us, And will not suffer us to fetch him out, Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence. Seuen? why there were but foure, euen now Falst. He was perfumed like a Milliner,And 'twixt his Finger and his Thumbe, he heldA Pouncet-box: which euer and anonHe gaue his Nose, and took't away againe:Who therewith angry, when it next came there,Tooke it in Snuffe. Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark: for we'llHear nought from Rome in private. Alack,You are transported by calamityThither where more attends you; and you slanderThe helms o' th' state, who care for you like fathers,When you curse them as enemies. O heat, dry up my brains! tears seven times salt, Burn out the sense and virtue of mine eye!?By heaven, thy madness shall be paid by weight, Till our scale turn the beam. A cry within, "A sail, a sail!" Gunsheard. As I guess, Marcius,Their bands in the vaward are the Antiates,Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius,Their very heart of hope. But (by your leaue) it neuer yet did hurt,To lay downe likely-hoods, and formes of hope L. Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this: Brutus had rather be a villager Than to repute himself a son of Rome Under these hard conditions as this time Is like to lay upon us. That nature which contemns it origin Cannot be bordered certain in itself. Alack, the night comes on, and the bleak winds Do sorely ruffle. Countrymen, My heart doth joy that yet in all my life I found no man but he was true to me. A double blessing is a double grace; Occasion smiles upon a second leave. All these bold Feares,Thou seest (with perill) I haue answered:For all my Reigne, hath beene but as a SceneActing that argument. He did receive his letters, and is coming, And bid me say to you by word of mouth O Caesar! Sees the body. The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself, And with uplifted arms is safe arriv'd At Ravenspurgh. A good Sherris-Sack hath a two-foldoperation in it: it ascends me into the Braine, dryesme there all the foolish, and dull, and cruddie Vapours,which enuiron it: makes it apprehensiue, quicke, forgetiue,full of nimble, fierie, and delectable shapes; whi Ay, sir; that soaks up the King? countenance, his rewards, his authorities. Doe I? yea, in very truth doe I, if it were an AspenLeafe: I cannot abide Swaggerers. Keep your fellows' counselsand your own, and good night. Her boat hath a leak, And she must not speak Why she dares not come over to thee. Neither to you nor any one; having no witness to confirm myspeech. I think he is; but a greater soldier than he you wot on. But, soft, who wafts us yonder?Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANAADRIANA. Exceedingly, my lord; it is very sultry,?s ?were? cannot tell how. Are my discourses dull? Barren my wit? If voluble and sharp discourse be marr'd, Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard. The Earle of Hereford was reputed thenIn England the most valiant Gentleman. Then crushing penury Persuades me I was better when a king; Then am I king'd again; and by and by Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke, And straight am nothing. He says, for Brutus' sake, He finds himself beholding to us all. I told him of the army that was landed: He smil'd at it. --The honoured godsKeep Rome in safety, and the chairs of justiceSupplied with worthy men! plant love among's!Throng our large temples with the shows of peace,And not our streets with war!FIRST SENATOR. I feare my BrotherMortimer doth stirre about his Title, and hath sentfor you to line his enterprize. The barbarous Scythian, Or he that makes his generation messes To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom Be as well neighbour'd, pitied, and reliev'd, As thou my sometime daughter. Keep then fair league and truce with thy true bed; I live dis-stain'd, thou undishonoured. I like not such grinninghonour as Sir Walter hath: Giue mee life, which if I cansaue, so: if not, honour comes vnlook'd for, and ther's anend. Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomorrow? CASCA. Deny to speak with me? They are sick? they are weary? They have travell'd all the night? Mere fetches The images of revolt and flying off! Fetch me a better answer. We'll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors. Now, pray, sir, get you gone:You have done a brave deed. You say true:Why what a caudie deale of curtesie,This fawning Grey-hound then did proffer me,Looke when his infant Fortune came to age,And gentle Harry Percy, and kinde Cousin:O, the Diuell take such Couzeners, God forgiue me,Good Vncle tell your tale,  Our Army is dispers'd:Like youthfull Steeres, vnyoak'd, they tooke their courseEast, West, North, South: or like a Schoole, broke vp,Each hurryes towards his home, and sporting place West. '"All my offences that abroad you see Are errors of the blood, none of the mind; Love made them not; with acture they may be, Where neither party is nor true nor kind. Well: Peace be with him, that hath made vs heauy Ch. Fathers that wear rags Do make their children blind; But fathers that bear bags Shall see their children kind. Listening their fear, I could not say "Amen,"When they did say, "God bless us. '"Lo, all these trophies of affections hot, Of pensived and subdued desires the tender, Nature hath charged me that I hoard them not, But yield them up where I myself must render That is, to you, my origin and ender; For these, of force, must your oblat No, when light-wing'd toys Of feather'd Cupid seel with wanton dullness My speculative and officed instruments, That my disports corrupt and taint my business, Let housewives make a skillet of my helm, And all indign and base adversities Make head again Must he lose The name of king? A God's name, let it go. And did you leave him in this contemplation? SECOND LORD. Very true, Sir: and I come to draw you outby the Eares Host. I will tell you why; so shall my anticipation prevent your discovery, and your secrecy to the king and queen moult no feather. 'Tis well' that thou hast cause; But thou shouldst please me better wouldst thou weep. I have done no more toCaesar than you shall do to Brutus. No, sure, my lord, my mother cried; but then there was astar danc'd, and under that was I born. I might as yet have been a spreading flower, Fresh to myself, if I had self-applied Love to myself, and to no love beside. Not so; but I answer you right painted cloth, fromwhence you have studied your questions. So well that what you bid me undertake, Though that my death were adjunct to my act, By heaven, I would do it. Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND, and others, with the prisoners Uncle, you say the Queen is at your house; For God's sake, fairly let her be entreated. I will not leave him now till Cassio Be call'd to him. I'll fight with none but thee, for I do hate theeWorse than a promise-breaker. As dissolute as desperate; yet through both I see some sparks of better hope, which elder years May happily bring forth. [Enter CORIOLANUS, with drum and colours; a crowd of Citizenswith him. A noble ship of Venice Hath seen a grievous wreck and sufferance On most part of their fleet. You are straight enough in theshoulders, you care not who sees your backe: Call youthat backing of your friends? a plague vpon such backing:giue me them that will face me. You say he din'd at home: the goldsmith here Denies that saying. Caesar, thou art revenged, Even with the sword that kill'd thee. Is this the promise that you made your mother? COMINIUS. Doe not thinke so, you shall not finde it so:And Heauen forgiue them, that so much haue sway'dYour Maiesties good thoughts away from me:I will redeeme all this on Percies head,And in the closing of some glorious day,Be bold to tell you, that I am your S Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing. Do you know me, sir? Dog. Hero and Margaret have by this playedtheir parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite one another when they meet. Who is it thou dost call usurper, France? CONSTANCE. And welcome more common; for that'snothing but words. So we'll live, And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out And take upon 's the mystery of things, As if we we I sent your GraceThe parcels, and particulars of our Griefe,The which hath been with scorne shou'd from the Court:Whereon this Hydra-Sonne of Warre is borne,Whose dangerous eyes may well be charm'd asleepe,With graunt of our most iust and right desires; The affair cries haste, And speed must answer't: you must hence tonight. I am invited, sir, to certain merchants, Of whom I hope to make much benefit; I crave your pardon. Come, go we to the king: This must be known; which, being kept close, might move More grief to hide than hate to utter love. Now, the next day Was our sea-fight; and what to this was sequent Thou know?t already. Madam, an if my brother had my shape And I had his, Sir Robert's his, like him; And if my legs were two such riding-rods, My arms such eel-skins stuff'd, my face so thin That in mine ear I durst not stick a rose Lest men should say 'Look where three-far Let go thy hold when agreat wheel runs down a hill, lest it break thy neck withfollowing it; but the great one that goes upward, let him draw theeafter. What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue? I cannot speak to her, yet she urg'd conference. News, friends: our wars are done, the Turks are drown'd. A public place[Enter MENENIUS, COMINIUS, SICINIUS and BRUTUS, and others. 'Tis she is subcontracted to this lord, And I, her husband, contradict your banes. Out, dunghill! They fight. Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy? Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord, That sets the word itself against the word! Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land; The chopping French we do not understand. Nay, pray thee come; Or if thou wilt hold longer argument, Do it in notes. Wel, you must now speake Sir Iohn Falstaffe faire,Which swimmes against your streame of Quality Ch. If hee swagger, let him not come here: I mustliue amongst my Neighbors, Ile no Swaggerers: I amin good name, and fame, with the very best: shut thedoore, there comes no Swaggerers heere: I haue notliu'd all this while, to haue swaggering now: shut thedo On my knees I beg That you'll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food. Besides this nothing that he so plentifully gives me,the something that nature gave me his countenance seems to takefrom me. Bell, book, and candle, shall not drive me back, When gold and silver becks me to come on. Bring me but to the very brim of it, And I'll repair the misery thou dost bear With something rich about me. Poor bird! thou'dst never fear the net nor lime,The pit-fall nor the gin. He bears the sentence well, that nothing bears But the free comfort which from thence he hears; But he bears both the sentence and the sorrow That, to pay grief, must of poor patience borrow. Alack! I am afraid they have awak'd,And 'tis not done: the attempt, and not the deed,Confounds us. O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender abody, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory. O horror, horror, horror! Tongue nor heartCannot conceive nor name thee!MACBETH, LENNOX. Here standeth Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk, On pain to be found false and recreant, Both to defend himself, and to approve Henry of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby, To God, his sovereign, and to him disloyal, Courageously and with a free desire Attend --Condition?What good condition can a treaty findI' the part that is at mercy?--Five times, Marcius,I have fought with thee; so often hast thou beat me;And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounterAs often as we eat. Draw, you rogue, or I'll so carbonado your shanks! Draw, you rascal! Come your ways! Osw. Since I was man, Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder, Such groans of roaring wind and rain, I never Remember to have heard. I have, since I was three year old, convers'd with a magician, most profound in his art and yet notdamnable. There is division (Although as yet the face of it be cover'd With mutual cunning) 'twixt Albany and Cornwall; Who have (as who have not, that their great stars Thron'd and set high?) servants, who seem no less, Which are to France the spies and speculat --Sons, kinsmen, thanes,And you whose places are the nearest, know,We will establish our estate uponOur eldest, Malcolm; whom we name hereafterThe Prince of Cumberland: which honor mustNot unaccompanied invest him only,But signs of nobleness, like stars,He will (forsooth) haue all my Prisoners:And when I vrg'd the ransom once againeOf my Wiues Brother, then his cheeke look'd pale,And on my face he turn'd an eye of death,Trembling euen at the name of Mortimer Wor. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, LORDS, ORLANDO, CHARLES, and ATTENDANTS FREDERICK. Our flesh and blood is grown so vile, my lord, That it doth hate what gets it. Anon sir, pray you stay a little, my Lord Prin. Look to her, Moor, if thou hast eyes to see; She has deceived her father, and may thee. The great contention of the sea and skies Parted our fellowshipBut, hark! a sail. Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou! Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword; I fear thee not. If I had thee in Lipsbury Pinfold, I would make thee carefor me. Stay, you imperfect speakers, tell me more:By Sinel's death I know I am Thane of Glamis;But how of Cawdor? The Thane of Cawdor lives,A prosperous gentleman; and to be kingStands not within the prospect of belief,No more than to be Cawdor. Why, then your uncle, and the Prince, and Claudio Have been deceived; for they swore you did. Wel, the truth is (sir Iohn) you liue in great infamy Fal. To you, my lord, I come-what lord you will From the most gracious regent of this land, The Duke of York, to know what pricks you on To take advantage of the absent time, And fright our native peace with self-borne arms. If thou shouldst not be glad, I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb, Sepulchring an adultress. This house is little; the old man and 's people Cannot be well bestow'd. I'll tell thee, Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando. Another general shout! I do believe that these applauses are For some new honors that are heap'd on Caesar. Hark, the Duke's trumpets! I know not why he comes. Whence are you, sir? Has the porter his eyes in his head that hegives entrance to such companions? Pray, get you out. Yes, I thanke your pretty sweet wit for it: butlooke you pray, (all you that kisse my Ladie Peace, athome) that our Armies ioyn not in a hot day: for if I takebut two shirts out with me, and I meane not to sweatextraordinarily:if it bee a hot day, if I  The reason why the sevenstars are no moe than seven is a pretty reason. Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench; A brace of draymen bid God speed him well And had the tribute of his supple knee, With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends'; As were our England in reversion his, And he our subjects' next degree in hope. Then leave her, sir; for, by the pow'r that made me, I tell you all her wealth. Peradventure this is not Fortune's work neither, but Nature's, who perceiveth our natural wits too dull to reasonof such goddesses, and hath sent this natural for our whetstone;for always the dullness of the fool is the whetstone of the wits. You have been a scourge to her enemies; you have been a rod toher friends: you have not indeed loved the common people. Know we have divided In three our kingdom; and 'tis our fast intent To shake all cares and business from our age, Conferring them on younger strengths while we Unburthen'd crawl toward death. Now, citizens of Angiers, ope your gates, Let in that amity which you have made; For at Saint Mary's chapel presently The rites of marriage shall be solemniz'd. Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be med'cinable tome. Thou monstrous slanderer of heaven and earth! CONSTANCE. I had thought, my lord, to have learn'd his health ofyou. This palt'ringBecomes not Rome; nor has CoriolanusDeserv'd this so dishonour'd rub, laid falselyI' the plain way of his merit. If you do not make him be hang'd among you,the gallowes shall be wrong'd Prince. Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that's neither known of thee nor knows thee! Kent. --My mother, you wot wellMy hazards still have been your solace: andBelieve't not lightly,--though I go alone,Like to a lonely dragon, that his fenMakes fear'd and talk'd of more than seen,--your sonWill or exceed the common or be caughtWith cautelous baI prethee Harry withdraw thy selfe, thou bleedesttoo much: Lord Iohn of Lancaster, go you with him P. He holds me well, The better shall my purpose work on him. I hop? thou shouldst have been my Hamlet? wife; I thought thy bride-bed to have deck?, sweet maid, And not have strew? thy grave. Sound, trumpet! Ver. I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar, And things unluckily charge my fantasy. I prethee now deliuer them, like a man of thisWorld Pist. Sweet love, I see, changing his property, Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate. The palaceEnter DUKE FREDERICK, OLIVER, and LORDS FREDERICK. [aside] If I find him comforting the King, it will stuffhis suspicion more fully. But say, I prithee, is he coming home? It seems he hath great care to please his wife. Marry then, sweet Wagge, when thou art King,let not vs that are Squires of the Nights bodie, bee call'dTheeues of the Dayes beautie. Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves,than that Caesar were dead to live all freemen? As Caesar lovedme, I weep for him; as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was valiant, I honor him; but as he was ambitious, I slew him. Your highness' partIs to receive our duties: and our dutiesAre to your throne and state, children and servants;Which do but what they should, by doing everythingSafe toward your love and honor. Wherefore? Enter Lear in a chair carried by Servants. Hubert, the utterance of a brace of tongues Must needs want pleading for a pair of eyes. I am sorry, sir, that I have hind'red you; But I protest he had the chain of me, Though most dishonestly he doth deny it. Now let thy friendly hand Put strength enough to't. Nay, an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be look'd to. It cannot be that Desdemona should long continue her love to the Moorput money in thy pursenor hehis to her. "Fear not, till Birnam woodDo come to Dunsinane;" and now a woodComes toward Dunsinane. Brutus and Cassius Are levying powers; we must straight make head; Therefore let our alliance be combined, Our best friends made, our means stretch'd; And let us presently go sit in council, How covert matters may be best disclosed, And open perils sure We must haue bloodie Noses, and crack'd Crownes,And passe them currant too. [Within] Ay, when fowls have no feathers and fish have no fin. Tut, tut, good enough to tosse: foode for Powder,foode for Powder: they'le fill a Pit, as well as better:tush man, mortall men, mortall men Westm. So you shall; But O, what damned minutes tells he o'er Who dotes, yet doubts, suspects, yet strongly loves! For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues, We were encount'red by a mighty rock, Which being violently borne upon, Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst; So that The wren goes to't, and the small gilded fly Does lecher in my sight. Have more than thou showest, Speak less than thou knowest, Lend less than thou owest, Ride more than thou goest, Learn more than thou trowest, Set less than thou throwest; Leave thy drink and thy whore, And keep in-a-door, And thou shalt have more Than  Why? Shal. If to preserve this vessel for my lord From any other foul unlawful touch Be not to be a strumpet, I am none. If I could get mee a wife in the Stewes, Iwere Mann'd, Hors'd, and Wiu'd. Quoit him downe (Bardolph) like a shoue-groatshilling: nay, if hee doe nothing but speake nothing, heeshall be nothing here Bard. But I shall see The winged vengeance overtake such children. The appellant in all duty greets your Highness, And craves to kiss your hand and take his leave. Come, let's make haste; she'll soon be back again. Comfort, my liege, why looks your Grace so pale? KING RICHARD. That Cassio loves her, I do well believe it; That she loves him, 'tis apt and of great credit. Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes; For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change. Hath the fellow any wit that told you this? Ant. Revoke thy gift, Or, whilst I can vent clamour from my throat, I'll tell thee thou dost evil. You common cry of curs! whose breath I hateAs reek o' the rotten fens, whose loves I prize As the dead carcasses of unburied menThat do corrupt my air,--I banish you;And here remain with your uncertainty!Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts!Your eneHe that will think to live till he be old, Give me some help!O cruel! Have mind upon your health, tempt me no farther. Good signior, you shall more command with years Than with your weapons. Away, and mock the time with fairest show:False face must hide what the false heart doth know. Fair and noble hostess,We are your guest tonight. This naughty man Shall fact to face be brought to Margaret, Who I believe was pack'd in all this wrong, Hir'd to it by your brother. Why then, take no note of him, but let him go, andpresently call the rest of the watch together and thank God you are ridof a knave. That every like is not the same, O Caesar, The heart of Brutus yearns to think upon! I cannot bringMy tongue to such a pace. She leansme out at her mistress' chamber window, bids me a thousand times good night--I tell this tale vilely; I should first tell theehow the Prince, Claudio and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John, saw afar off in the orc And then for her To win the Moor, were't to renounce his baptism, All seals and symbols of redeemed sin, His soul is so enfetter'd to her love, That she may make, unmake, do what she list, Even as her appetite shall play the god With his weak function. Thought and affliction, passion, hell itself, She turns to favour and to prettiness. Enter KING JOHN, ELINOR, BLANCH, the BASTARD, PEMBROKE, and others KING JOHN. If I gave them all my living, I'ld keep my coxcombsmyself. Your Grace of Yorke, in heauen's name thenforward Bish. I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious talein telling it and deliver a plain message bluntly. O the blest gods! so will you wish on me When the rash mood is on. Away you Starueling, you Elfe-skin, you driedNeats tongue, Bulles-pissell, you stocke-fish: O for brethto vtter. Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into sedges. Not till God make men of some other metal than earth. What if it tempt you toward the flood, my lord, Or to the dreadful summit of the cliff That beetles o?r his base into the sea, And there assume some other horrible form Which might deprive your sovereignty of reason,39 And draw you into madness? think o [rises] Never, Regan! She hath abated me of half my train; Look'd black upon me; struck me with her tongue, Most serpent-like, upon the very heart. My brother Robert, old Sir Robert's son? Colbrand the giant, that same mighty man? Is it Sir Robert's son that you seek so? LADY FAULCONBRIDGE. O, untimely death! Death! He dies. Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd? Thy sheep be in the corn; And for one blast of thy minikin mouth Thy sheep shall take no harm. He bears himself more proudlier,Even to my person, than I thought he wouldWhen first I did embrace him: yet his natureIn that's no changeling; and I must excuseWhat cannot be amended. Well, sir, what answer made the belly?MENENIUS. Bear mine to him, and so depart in peace; Be thou as lightning in the eyes of France; For ere thou canst report I will be there, The thunder of my cannon shall be heard. Silence that dreadful bell; it frights the isle From her propriety. The Duke be here to-night? The better! best! This weaves itself perforce into my business. Why? Wherefore ask you this? IAGO. It will have blood; they say, blood will have blood:Stones have been known to move, and trees to speak;Augurs, and understood relations, haveBy magot-pies, and choughs, and rooks, brought forthThe secret'st man of blood. Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss ofyour marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him towear it. Grant that, and then is death a benefit; So are we Caesar's friends that have abridged His time of fearing death. Your Grace shall pardon me, I will not back: I am too high-born to be propertied, To be a secondary at control, Or useful serving-man and instrument To any sovereign state throughout the world. In good time, sir, what's that?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Merely awry: when he did love his country,It honour'd him. Heaven lay not my transgression to my charge! Thou art the issue of my dear offence, Which was so strongly urg'd past my defence. Say, Scroop, where lies our uncle with his power? Speak sweetly, man, although thy looks be sour. A public place[Enter MENENIUS, SICINIUS, and BRUTUS. If I could bear it longer and not fall To quarrel with your great opposeless wills, My snuff and loathed part of nature should Burn itself out. Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear, My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear. O brave Iago, honest and just, That hast such noble sense of thy friend's wrong! Thou teachest me. At my TentThe Dowglas is, and I beseech your Grace,I may dispose of him King. Therefore (my Harrie)Be it thy course to busie giddy MindesWith Forraigne Quarrels: that Action hence borne out,May waste the memory of the former dayes. Wee see which way the streame of Time doth runne,And are enforc'd from our most quiet there,By the rough Torrent of Occasion,And haue the summarie of all our Griefes(When time shall serue) to shew in Articles;Which long ere this, wee offer'd to the King,Tribunes! patricians! citizens!--What, ho!--Sicinius, Brutus, Coriolanus, Citizens! CITIZENS. Which some suppose the soul's frail dwelling-house, Doth by the idle comments that it makes Foretell the ending of mortality. I may say so in this respect, for that he hathdevoted and given up himself to the contemplation, mark, anddenotement of her parts and graces. Ile haue it so, a little Charge will doe it Glend. Inquire at London, 'mongst the taverns there, For there, they say, he daily doth frequent With unrestrained loose companions, Even such, they say, as stand in narrow lanes And beat our watch and rob our passengers, Which he, young wanton and effeminate  Edmund, I think, is gone, In pity of his misery, to dispatch His nighted life; moreover, to descry The strength o' th' enemy. [Within] Nor to-day here you must not; come again when you may. If it hath ruffian'd so upon the sea, What ribs of oak, when mountains melt on them, Can hold the mortise? What shall we hear of this? SECOND GENTLEMAN. Bid them come forth and hear me, Or at their chamber door I'll beat the drum Till it cry sleep to death. Sir, he is rash and very sudden in choler, and haply may strike at you. I doubt it is no other but the main,?His father? death and our o?rhasty marriage. Why, e?n so: and now my Lady Worm?; chapless, and knocked about the mazard with a sexton? spade: here? fine revolution, an we had the trick to see?. Come, wilt thou see me ride?And when I am a horsebacke, I will sweareI loue thee infinitely. Away Bardolfe, Sadle my Horse,Master Robert Shallow, choose what Office thou wiltIn the Land, 'tis thine. You or any man living may be drunk at some time, man. Almost a mile; but he does usually,So all men do, from hence to the palace gateMake it their walk. A miserable world! As I do live by food, I met a fool, Who laid him down and bask'd him in the sun, And rail'd on Lady Fortune in good terms, In good set termsand yet a motley fool. What's the matter? here be foure of vs, haueta'ne a thousand pound this Morning Prince. It would be euery mans thought: and thou arta blessed Fellow, to thinke as euery man thinkes: neuer amans thought in the world, keepes the Rode-way betterthen thine: euery man would thinke me an Hypocrite indeede. Were you in doubt, sir, that you ask'd her? Leon. Thou marshall'st me the way that I was going;And such an instrument I was to use. Come and be hang'd, hast no faith in thee?Enter Gads-hill. Why shall the people giveOne that speaks thus their voice?CORIOLANUS. Royal Lear, Whom I have ever honour'd as my king, Lov'd as my father, as my master follow'd, As my great patron thought on in my prayers Lear. I will lay trust upon thee, and thou shalt find a dearer father in my love. Quick, quick; fear nothing; I'll be at thy elbow. Yet I'll not shed her blood, Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow And smooth as monumental alabaster. If that the Dauphin there, thy princely son, Can in this book of beauty read 'I love,' Her dowry shall weigh equal with a queen; For Anjou, and fair Touraine, Maine, Poictiers, And all that we upon this side the sea Except this city now by us besieg'd F Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain. Lucius, who's thatknocks? Re-enter Lucius with Ligarius. Now, sir, young Fortinbras, Of unimproved mettle hot and full, Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there, Shark? up a list of lawless resolutes, For food and diet, to some enterprise That hath a stomach in?; which is no other,?As it doth well appear  All the pictures fairest lin'd Are but black to Rosalinde. I cannot speak Any beginning to this peevish odds; And would in action glorious I had lost Those legs that brought me to a part of it! OTHELLO. Ay, I know who 'tis; he hath no interest in me in the world; here comes the man you mean. Against my will I am sent to bid You come in to dinner. None but libertines delight in him; and the commendation is not in his wit, butin his villany; for he both pleases men and angers them, andthen they laugh at him and beat him. Your husband, he is gone to save far off, Whilst others come to make him lose at home. The queen desires you to use some gentle entertainment to Laertes before you fall to play. Exit SILVIUS Enter OLIVER OLIVER. She would have made Hercules have turn'd spit, yea, and have cleft his club tomake the fire too. Machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves. Great Glamis! Worthy Cawdor!Greater than both, by the all-hail hereafter!Thy letters have transported me beyondThis ignorant present, and I feel nowThe future in the instant. Worcester is stolne away by Night: thy Fathers Beard isturn'd white with the Newes; you may buy Land nowas cheape as stinking Mackrell Prin. Hoppedance cries in Tom's belly for two white herring. We will heal up all, For we'll create young Arthur Duke of Britaine, And Earl of Richmond; and this rich fair town We make him lord of. Cousin: of many menI doe not beare these Crossings: Giue me leaueTo tell you once againe, that at my BirthThe front of Heauen was full of fierie shapes,The Goates ranne from the Mountaines, and the HeardsWere strangely clamorous to the frighted fields:T That she is bound in honour still to do What you in wisdom still vouchsafe to say. The King himselfe: who Dowglas grieues at hartSo many of his shadowes thou hast met,And not the very King. If thou beest not damn'd forthis, the devil himself will have no shepherds; I cannot see elsehow thou shouldst scape. Then let us take a ceremonious leave And loving farewell of our several friends. A sailor's wife had chestnuts in her lap,And mounch'd, and mounch'd, and mounch'd:--"Give me," quoth I:"Aroint thee, witch!" the rump-fed ronyon cries. I will go losemyself, And wander up and down to view the city. Honour is a meere Scutcheon, and soends my Catechisme. Do'st thou heare Hal? Thou know'st in the stateof Innocency, Adam fell: and what should poore IackeFalstaffe do, in the dayes of Villany? Thou seest, I hauemore flesh then another man, and therefore more frailty. I know you all, and will a-while vpholdThe vnyoak'd humor of your idlenesse:Yet heerein will I imitate the Sunne,Who doth permit the base contagious cloudesTo smother vp his Beauty from the world,That when he please againe to be himselfe,Being wanted, h All but Metellus Cimber, and he's gone To seek you at your house. What say'st thou to a Hare, or the Melanchollyof Moore Ditch? Fal. So did he me: and he no more remembers his mother now than aneight-year-old horse. --We do here pronounce,Upon the part o' the people, in whose powerWe were elected theirs, Marcius is worthyOf present death. We are two lions litter'd in one day, And I the elder and more terrible. --You, worthy uncle,Shall with my cousin, your right-noble son,Lead our first battle: worthy Macduff and weShall take upon's what else remains to do,According to our order. Should you do so, my lord, My speech should fall into such vile success Which my thoughts aim not at. Some honest Christian trust me with a gage That Norfolk lies. No abuse (Hall) on mine Honor, no abuse Prince. By this day, she's a fair lady! I do spy some marks of love in her. My legs can keep no measure in delight, When my poor heart no measure keeps in grief; Therefore no dancing, girl; some other sport. O, for two special reasons; Which may to you, perhaps, seem much unsinew?, But yet to me they are strong. Snare, we must Arrest Sir Iohn Falstaffe Host. I am glad of it: a knavish speech sleeps in a foolish ear. This day, great Duke, she shut the doorsupon me, While she with harlots feasted in my house. I do despise them,For they do prank them in authority,Against all noble sufferance. In following him, I follow but myself; Heaven is my judge, not I for love and duty, But seeming so, for my peculiar end. Peace, sirrah! You beastly knave, know you no reverence? Kent. Therefore, give out you are of Epidamnum, Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate. In such a time as this it is not meet That every nice offense should bear his comment. Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor voke pass. And sweetens, in the suff'ring pangs it bears, The aloes of all forces, shocks and fears. But it isno matter, this poore shew doth better: this doth inferrethe zeale I had to see him Shal. I have heard it said thefittest time to corrupt a man's wife is when she's fallen outwith her husband. Calpurnia here, my wife, stays me at home; She dreamt tonight she saw my statue, Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts, Did run pure blood, and many lusty Romans Came smiling and did bathe their hands in it. It is the shameful work of Hubert's hand; The practice and the purpose of the King; From whose obedience I forbid my soul Kneeling before this ruin of sweet life, And breathing to his breathless excellence The incense of a vow, a holy vow, Never to tast But, woe the while! Our fathers' minds are dead, And we are govern'd with our mothers' spirits; Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish. Let it not gall your patience, good Iago, That I extend my manners; 'tis my breeding That gives me this bold show of courtesy. Exit JAQUES ROSALIND. It is but eight yeeres since,This Percie was the man, neerest my Soule,Who, like a Brother, toyl'd in my Affaires,And layd his Loue and Life vnder my foot:Yea, for my sake, euen to the eyes of RichardGaue him defiance. What, vpon compulsion? No: were I at theStrappado, or all the Racks in the World, I would nottell you on compulsion. The summe of all,Is, that the King hath wonne: and hath sent outA speedy power, to encounter you my Lord,Vnder the Conduct of yong LancasterAnd Westmerland. Have you the chain about you?ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. To you I am bound for life and education; My life and education both do learn me How to respect you; you are the lord of duty, I am hitherto your daughter. And you are come in very happy time To bear my greeting to the senators And tell them that I will not come today. Your Brooches, Pearles, and Owches: For toserue brauely, is to come halting off: you know, to comeoff the Breach, with his Pike bent brauely, and to Surgeriebrauely; to venture vpon the charg'd-Chambersbrauely Host. Ascend his throne, descending now from him And long live Henry, fourth of that name! AUMERLE. What have you done, my lord, with the dead body? Ham. His answer was, he would unto the stews, And from the common'st creature pluck a glove And wear it as a favour; and with that He would unhorse the lustiest challenger. His tongue is now a stringless instrument; Words, life, and all, old Lancaster hath spent. Good Master Corporate Bardolph, stand myfriend, and heere is foure Harry tenne shillings in FrenchCrownes for you: in very truth, sir, I had as lief be hang'dsir, as goe: and yet, for mine owne part, sir, I do not care;but rather, because I am vnwilling I cannot think my sister in the least Would fail her obligation. Do grace to Caesar's corse, and grace his speech Tending to Caesar's glories, which Mark Antony, By our permission, is allow'd to make. Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes, Misprizing what they look on; and her wit Values itself so highly that to her All matter else seems weak. Now, now, you stars that move in your right spheres, Where be your pow'rs? Show now your mended faiths, And instantly return with me again To push destruction and perpetual shame Out of the weak door of our fainting land. I say the Earth did shake when I was borne Hotsp. He were an excellent man that were made just in themidway between him and Benedick. I then, all-smarting, with my wounds being cold,(To be so pestered with a Popingay)Out of my Greefe, and my Impatience,Answer'd (neglectingly) I know not what,He should, or should not: For he made me mad,To see him shine so briske, and smell so sweet,AndSo did I, I'll be sworn: he is simply the rarest man i' theworld. If you will come to me (For now I spy a danger), I entreat you To bring but five-and-twenty. Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it. I am come To bid my king and master aye good night. 'Tis call'd the evil:A most miraculous work in this good king;Which often, since my here-remain in England,I have seen him do. My name is Caius Marcius, who hath doneTo thee particularly, and to all the Volsces,Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness mayMy surname, Coriolanus: the painful service,The extreme dangers, and the drops of bloodShed for my thankless country, are requI do beseech your Grace to pardon me; It is a matter of small consequence Which for some reasons I would not have seen. What an arm he has! He turned me about with his finger and histhumb, as one would set up a top. The King hath call'd his Parliament,My Lord Ch. What's the business,That such a hideous trumpet calls to parleyThe sleepers of the house? speak, speak!MACDUFF. Fortune is merry, And in this mood will give us anything. What's the matter with thee now? EMILIA. By men of Epidamnum he and I And the twin Dromio, all were taken up; But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth By force took Dromio and my son from them, And me they left with those of Epidamnum. Blood hath been shed ere now, i' the olden time,Ere humane statute purg'd the gentle weal;Ay, and since too, murders have been perform'dToo terrible for the ear: the time has been,That, when the brains were out, the man would die,And there an end; but noI knew what you would prove; my friends told me as much, and I thought no less. What is thy sentence, then, but speechless death, Which robs my tongue from breathing native breath? KING RICHARD. What, are there no posts dispatch'd for Ireland? How shall we do for money for these wars? Dauy. Hostesse, clap to the doores: watch to night,pray to morrow. Iwas the other day talking on the sea bank with certain Venetians,and thither comes the bauble, and, by this hand, she falls methus about my neck OTHELLO. A most poor man, made tame to fortune's blows, Who, by the art of known and feeling sorrows, Am pregnant to good pity. Why, Sir Iohn, my Face does you no harme Falst. God and our right! Bora. To wake a Wolfe, is as bad as to smell a Fox Iu. Yong Prince Iohn,And Westmerland, and Stafford, fled the Field. Some dear cause Will in concealment wrap me up awhile. Soft! let me see:?We?l make a solemn wager on your cunnings,?I ha?: When in your motion you are hot and dry,?As make your bouts more violent to that end,?And that he calls for drink, I?l have prepar? him A chalice for the nonce; whereon but sipping, If  Why, to keep one's eyes of either side's nose, that whata man cannot smell out, 'a may spy into. --Thou sure and firm-set earth,Hear not my steps, which way they walk, for fearThy very stones prate of my whereabout,And take the present horror from the time,Which now suits with it. The cause is in my will: I will not come, That is enough to satisfy the Senate. Though Cassio did some little wrong to him, As men in rage strike those that wish them best, Yet surely Cassio, I believe, received From him that fled some strange indignity, Which patience could not pass. Never such a pow'r For any foreign preparation Was levied in the body of a land. Soon at five o'clock, Please you, I'll meet with you upon the mart, And afterward consort you till bed time. Confirm'd, confirm'd! O, that is stronger made Which was before barr'd up with ribs of iron! Would the two princes lie? and Claudio lie, Who lov'd her so that, speaking of her foulness, Wash'd it with tears? Hence from her! let her die. The ladies, her attendants of her chamber, Saw her abed, and in the morning early They found the bed untreasur'd of their mistress. What newes Lord Bardolfe? Eu'ry minute nowShould be the Father of some Stratagem;The Times are wilde: Contention (like a HorseFull of high Feeding) madly hath broke loose,And beares downe all before him L. Resolve me with all modest haste which way Thou mightst deserve or they impose this usage, Coming from us. Is it his use? it hath beenThe untimely emptying of the happy throne,And fall of many kings. My Lord (your Sonne) had onely but the Corpes,But shadowes, and the shewes of men to fight. [To France] For you, great King, I would not from your love make such a stray To match you where I hate; therefore beseech you T' avert your liking a more worthier way Than on a wretch whom nature is asham'd Almost t' acknowledge hers. In the meantime, Let me be thought too busy in my fears As worthy cause I have to fear I am And hold her free, I do beseech your honor. [Exeunt Benedick and Leonato. 'Tis his main hope:For where there is advantage to be given,Both more and less have given him the revolt;And none serve with him but constrained things,Whose hearts are absent too. That's the scene that I would see, which will be merely adumb show. They are sheep and calves which seek out assurance in that. This purse of ducats I receiv'd from you, And Dromio my man did bring them me. Measureless liar, thou hast made my heartToo great for what contains it. Lechery, sir,it provokes and unprovokes; Claud. Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain; Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman, And I, to blame, have held him here too long. Ah, my good lord, what have I seen to-night! King. I am the Prince of Wales, and thinke not Percy,To share with me in glory any more:Two Starres keepe not their motion in one Sphere,Nor can one England brooke a double reigne,Of Harry Percy, and the Prince of Wales Hot. Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum;See him pluck Aufidius down by the hair;As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him:Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus:--'Come on, you cowards! you were got in fearThough you were born in Rome:' You are wel encountred here (my cosin Mowbray)Good day to you, gentle Lord Archbishop,And so to you Lord Hastings, and to all. O' my troth, I looked upon him o' Wednesday, half an hourtogether: has such a confirmed countenance. I am Sir, vnder the King, in some Authority Pist. O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven!
