[Enter a Gentleman. Come Brother Iohn, full brauely hast thou fleshtthy Maiden sword Iohn. Be thou my witness that, against my will, As Pompey was, am I compell'd to set Upon one battle all our liberties. This man said, sir, that Don John the Prince'sbrother was a villain. O, neverShall sun that morrow see!Your face, my thane, is as a book where menMay read strange matters:--to beguile the time,Look like the time; bear welcome in your eye,Your hand, your tongue: look like the innocent flower,But be the serpent under't. I haue a whole Schoole of tongues in this belly ofmine, and not a Tongue of them all, speakes anie otherword but my name: and I had but a belly of any indifferencie,I were simply the most actiue fellow in Europe:my wombe, my wombe, my wombe vndoes mee. Will you, with those infirmities she owes, Unfriended, new adopted to our hate, Dow'r'd with our curse, and stranger'd with our oath, Take her, or leave her? Bur. And though wee here fall downe,Wee haue Supplyes, to second our Attempt:If they mis-carry, theirs shall second them. What I should think of this cannot tell: But this I think, there's no man is so vain That would refuse so fair an offer'd chain. Well, for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks and make no boast of it;and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there isno need of such vanity. Away with me, all you whose souls abhor Th' uncleanly savours of a slaughter-house; For I am stifled with this smell of sin. I had rather liueWith Cheese and Garlick in a Windmill farre,Then feede on Cates, and haue him talke to me,In any Summer-House in Christendome Mort. You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life That should be in a Roman you do want, Or else you use not. Beshrew him for't! How comes this trick upon him? DESDEMONA. With half that face would he have all my land: A half-fac'd groat five hundred pound a year! ROBERT. Go you down that way towards the Capitol; This way will I. I knew you must be edified by the margent ere you had done. And I heare moreouer, his Highnesse is falne intothis same whorson Apoplexie Iust. Ha! What is't thou say'st, Her voice was ever soft, Gentle, and lowan excellent thing in woman. Give ear, sir, to my sister; For those that mingle reason with your passion Must be content to think you old, and so But she knows what she does. --Will you hence,Before the tag return? whose rage doth rendLike interrupted waters, and o'erbearWhat they are used to bear. He hath indeed better bett'red expectation than you must expect of me totell you how. Thy valiantness was mine, thou suck'dst it from me;But owe thy pride thyself. Enter Henry Prince of Wales, Sir Iohn Falstaffe, and Pointz. What wilt thou do, thou peevish officer? Hast thou delight to see a wretched man Do outrage and displeasure to himself?OFFICER. So with me:--My birthplace hate I, and my love's uponThis enemy town. I have professed me thy friend, and I confess meknit to thy deserving with cables of perdurable toughness; I couldnever better stead thee than now. I could tell you more news too: Marullus and Flavius, forpulling scarfs off Caesar's images, are put to silence. What a case am I in then, that am neither a good epilogue, norcannot insinuate with you in the behalf of a good play! I am not furnish'd like a beggar; therefore to beg will not become me. What, is my Richard both in shape and mind Transform'd and weak'ned? Hath Bolingbroke depos'd Thine intellect? Hath he been in thy heart? The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw And wounds the earth, if nothing else, with rage To be o'erpow'r'd; and wilt Near or far off, well won is still well shot; And I am I, howe'er I was begot. You may not pass; you must return: our generalWill no more hear from thence. Here, thou incestuous, murderous, damned Dane, Drink off this potion. So shaken as we are, so wan with care,Finde we a time for frighted Peace to pant,And breath shortwinded accents of new broilsTo be commenc'd in Stronds a-farre remote:No more the thirsty entrance of this Soile,Shall daube her lippes with her owne childr So out went the candle, and we were left darkling. And, gentle master, I receiv'd no gold; But I confess, sir, that we were lock'd out. He that dependsUpon your favours swims with fins of lead,And hews down oaks with rushes. let me not vnderstand you then, speake it inWelsh Glend. It was, as I have seen it in his life, A sable silver?. But thebottom of the news is, our general is cut i' the middle, and butone half of what he was yesterday; for the other has half, by theentreaty and grant of the whole table. Well, sit we down, And let us hear Bernardo speak of this. So many journeys may the sun and moon Make us again count o?r ere love be done! But, woe is me, you are so sick of late, So far from cheer and from your former state. So will I turn her virtue into pitch, And out of her own goodness make the net That shall enmesh them all. My lord, my lord, I'll prove it on his body if he dare, Despite his nice fence and his active practice, His May of youth and bloom of lustihood. I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with my prayers;but I cannot go thither. Your Meanes is very slender, and your wast great Fal. O, such a Day,(So fought, so follow'd, and so fairely wonne)Came not, till now, to dignifie the TimesSince C?rs Fortunes Nor. What should such fellows as I do crawling between earth and heaven? We are arrant knaves, all; believe none of us. If my Tongue cannot entreate you to acquit me: will you commandme to vsemy Legges? And yet that were but light payment, to Dance out ofyour debt:Buta good Conscience, will make any possible satisfaction, and sowill I. [To NORTHUMBERLAND] Noble lord, Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle; Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver: Henry Bolingbroke On both his knees doth kiss King Richard's hand, And sends allegiance  God's my life, where's the sexton? Let him write down the Prince's officer coxcomb. I did so; and went further, which is nowOur point of second meeting. O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me! Even daughter, welcome in no less degree. [Enter CORIOLANUS, in mean apparel, disguised and muffled. Most monstrous! Know'st thou this paper? Gon. For when his head-strong Riot hath no Curbe,When Rage and hot-Blood are his Counsailors,When Meanes and lauish Manners meete together;Oh, with what Wings shall his Affections flyeTowards fronting Perill, and oppos'd Decay? War. A nun of winter's sisterhood kisses not more religiously; the very iceof chastity is in them. Enter, with Drum and Colours, the Powers of Franceover the stage, Cordelia with her Father in her hand, and exeunt. I have brought Count Claudio, whom yousent me to seek. Now in respect it is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but inrespect it is not in the court, it is tedious. What is the matter,That being pass'd for consul with full voice,I am so dishonour'd that the very hourYou take it off again?SICINIUS. That monster custom, who all sense doth eat, Of habits evil, is angel yet in this,?That to the use of actions fair and good He likewise gives a frock or livery That aptly is put on. Are we not beaten? Is not Angiers lost? Arthur ta'en prisoner? Divers dear friends slain? And bloody England into England gone, O'erbearing interruption, spite of France? LEWIS. Be not afraid, though you do see me weapon'd; Here is my journey's end, here is my butt And very sea-mark of my utmost sail. O world, thy slippery turns! Friends now fast sworn,Whose double bosoms seems to wear one heart,Whose hours, whose bed, whose meal and exerciseAre still together, who twin, as 'twere, in loveUnseparable, shall within this hour,On a dissension of a doit, Draw, you whoreson cullionly barbermonger! draw! Osw. Come, ladies, go To meet at London London's King in woe. I tell thee she is; and therefore make her grave straight: the crowner hath sat on her, and finds it Christian burial. Therefore, thou happy father, Think that the clearest gods, who make them honours Of men's impossibility, have preserv'd thee. I'll make a voyage to the Holy Land, To wash this blood off from my guilty hand. O Hal, I prethee giue me leaue to breath awhile:Turke Gregory neuer did such deeds in Armes, as I hauedone this day. I doe remember him at Clements Inne,like a man made after Supper, of a Cheese-paring. I have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows. And is olde Double dead?Enter Bardolph and his Boy. My comfort is that heaven will take our souls, And plague injustice with the pains of hell. Then comes the time, who lives to see't, That going shall be us'd with feet. My villany they have upon record, which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame. An open place wear Swinstead AbbeyEnter the BASTARD and HUBERT, severally HUBERT. So I told him, my Lord; and I said, I heard yourGrace say so: and (my Lord) hee speakes most vilely ofyou, like a foule-mouth'd man as hee is, and said, heewould cudgell you Prince. Give me that man That is not passion? slave, and I will wear him In my heart? core, ay, in my heart of heart, As I do thee. A lean cheek, which you have not; a blue eye andsunken, which you have not; an unquestionable spirit, which you havenot; a beard neglected, which you have not; but I pardon you forthat, for simply your having in beard is a younger brother'srevenue. We may guess by this whatyou are, being a man. Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, Hath not old custom made this life more sweet Than that of painted pomp? Are not these woods More free from peril than the envious court? Here feel we not the penalty of Adam, The seasons' difference; as the icy f Hath homely age th' alluring beauty took From my poor cheek? Then he hath wasted it. No, I defy all counsel, all redress, But that which ends all counsel, true redress Death, death; O amiable lovely death! Thou odoriferous stench! sound rottenness! Arise forth from the couch of lasting night, Thou hate and terror to prosperity, And I wi An excellent colour: your chestnut was ever the onlycolour. I prethee Iack be quiet, the Rascall is gone: ah,you whorson little valiant Villaine, you Host. He apprehends a World of Figures here,But not the forme of what he should attend:Good Cousin giue me audience for a-while,And list to me Hot. This is a subtle whore, A closet lock and key of villainous secrets. Why, this is flatperjury, to call a prince's brother villain. Call Claudio and some other of my men, I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent. 'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose. Here (Pistol) I chargeyou with a Cup of Sacke: doe you discharge vpon mineHostesse Pist. Tut, neuer feare me, I am as vigilant as a Cat, tosteale Creame Prince. If lusty love should go in quest of beauty, Where should he find it fairer than in Blanch? Will you againe vnknitThis churlish knot of all-abhorred Warre?And moue in the obedient Orbe againe,Where you did giue a faire and naturall light,And be no more an exhall'd Meteor,A prodigie of Feare, and a PortentOf broached MischeefI am now of all humors, that haue shewed themselueshumors, since the old dayes of goodman Adam, tothe pupill age of this present twelue a clock at midnight. There is an old poor man Who after me hath many a weary step Limp'd in pure love; till he be first suffic'd, Oppress'd with two weak evils, age and hunger, I will not touch a bit. Here doth hee wish his Person, with such PowersAs might hold sortance with his Qualitie,The which hee could not leuie: whereuponHee is retyr'd, to ripe his growing Fortunes,To Scotland; and concludes in heartie prayers,That your Attempts may ouer-liue thI have a good eye, uncle; I can see a church by daylight. He had none:His flight was madness: when our actions do not,Our fears do make us traitors. Marry, I?l teach you: think yourself a baby; That you have ta?n these tenders for true pay, Which are not sterling. Alas the heavy day! Why do you weep? Am I the motive of these tears, my lord? If haply you my father do suspect An instrument of this your calling back, Lay not your blame on me. How now! What means death in this rude assault? Villain, thy own hand yields thy death's instrument. Whence com'st thou? what wouldst thou? thy name?Why speak'st not? speak, man: what's thy name?CORIOLANUS. Ay, amen! What the vengeance, could he not speak 'em fair?[Re-enter BRUTUS and SICINIUS, with the rabble. Some tender money to me, some invite me, Some other give me thanks for kindnesses, Some offer me commodities to buy; Even now a tailor call'd me in his shop, And show'd me silks that he had bought for me, And therewithal took measure of my body. My lord shall never rest; I'll watch him tame and talk him out of patience; His bed shall seem a school, his board a shrift; I'll intermingle everything he does With Cassio's suit. My Daughter weepes, shee'le not part with you,Shee'le be a Souldier too, shee'le to the Warres Mort. Why should I not? Doth he not deserve well? Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with LORDS ROSALIND. Who talks within there? Ho, open the door!DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. For my sake be comfortable; hold death awhile at the arm's end. Truly to speak, and with no addition, We go to gain a little patch of ground That hath in it no profit but the name. The codpiece that will house Before the head has any, The head and he shall louse: So beggars marry many. So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure. O, but they say the tongues of dying men Enforce attention like deep harmony. I should to Plashy too, But time will not permit. White his shroud as the mountain snow, [Enter King. But such officers do the king best service in the end: he keeps them, like an ape, in the corner of his jaw; first mouthed, to be last swallowed: when he needs what you have gleaned, it is but squeezing you, and, sponge, you shall be dry again. A colour I feare, that you will dye in, Sir Iohn Fal. A soldier's a man; O, man's life's but a span; Why then let a soldier drink. And once dispatch'd him in an embassy To Germany, there with the Emperor To treat of high affairs touching that time. How fearful And dizzy 'tis to cast one's eyes so low! The crows and choughs that wing the midway air Show scarce so gross as beetles. I can suckmelancholy out of a song, as a weasel sucks eggs. Neither call the giddiness of it in question, thepoverty of her, the small acquaintance, my sudden wooing, nor hersudden consenting; but say with me, I love Aliena; say with her thatshe loves me; consent with both that we may enjoy each other. Brother, the King hath made your Nephew mad Wor. We should have else desir'd your good advice,--Which still hath been both grave and prosperous,--In this day's council; but we'll take to-morrow. This admiration, sir, is much o' th' savour Of other your new pranks. And is't not pity, O my grieved friends! That we, the sons and children of this isle, Were born to see so sad an hour as this; Wherein we step after a stranger-march Upon her gentle bosom, and fill up Her enemies' ranks-I must withdraw and weep Upon the Harke, how hard he fetches breath: search hisPockets. Marry, once before hewon it of me with false dice; therefore your Grace may well say I have lost it. I shall hereafter, my thrice gracious Lord,Be more my selfe King. What then? what rests? Try what repentance can: what can it not? Yet what can it when one cannot repent? O wretched state! O bosom black as death! O limed soul, that, struggling to be free, Art more engag?! Help, angels! Make assay: Bow, stubborn knees; But have you never found my brother's way To the forfended place? Edm. Through all the Kingdomes that acknowledge Christ,Thrice hath the Hotspur Mars, in swathing Clothes,This Infant Warrior, in his Enterprises,Discomfited great Dowglas, ta'ne him once,Enlarged him, and made a friend of him,To fill the mouth of deepe DefianThe heauens were all on fire, the Earth didtremble Hotsp. Come, come; sans compliment, what news abroad? HUBERT. That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time And drawing days out that men stand upon. I'll put't in proof, And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law, Then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill! Enter a Gentleman [with Attendants]. Good name in man and woman, dear my lord, Is the immediate jewel of their souls. Must I bouge? Must I observe you? Must I stand and crouch Under your testy humor? Yours, and your Sonnes. And these does she apply for warnings and portents And evils imminent, and on her knee Hath begg'd that I will stay at home today. If I can fasten but one cup upon him, With that which he hath drunk tonight already, He'll be as full of quarrel and offense As my young mistress' dog. Such men as he be never at heart's ease Whiles they behold a greater than themselves, And therefore are they very dangerous. Some reasons of this double coronation I have possess'd you with, and think them strong; And more, more strong, when lesser is my fear, I shall indue you with. So slides he down upon his grained bat, And comely distant sits he by her side; When he again desires her, being sat, Her grievance with his hearing to divide. O, let us pay the time but needful woe, Since it hath been beforehand with our griefs. With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?LUCIANA. You must needes learne, Lord, to amend this fault:Though sometimes it shew Greatnesse, Courage, Blood,And that's the dearest grace it renders you;Yet oftentimes it doth present harsh Rage,Defect of Manners, want of Gouernment,Pride, Haughtinesse, OpinionApproach the chamber, and destroy your sightWith a new Gorgon:--do not bid me speak;See, and then speak yourselves. She that doth call me husband, even my soul Doth for a wife abhor. Exeunt Iago andAttendants. Rouse up thy youthful blood, be valiant, and live. O Westmerland, thou art a Summer Bird,Which euer in the haunch of Winter singsThe lifting vp of day. Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall, And by the doom of death end woes and all. These growing feathers pluck'd from Caesar's wing Will make him fly an ordinary pitch, Who else would soar above the view of men And keep us all in servile fearfulness. Let them assemble;And, on a safer judgment, all revokeYour ignorant election: enforce his prideAnd his old hate unto you: besides, forget notWith what contempt he wore the humble weed;How in his suit he scorn'd you: but your loves,Thinking upon his serviTeach it but how, And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good. What? MESSALA. A pox of this Gowt, or a Gowt of this Poxe:for the one or th' other playes the rogue with my greattoe: It is no matter, if I do halt, I haue the warres for mycolour, and my Pension shall seeme the more reasonable. Your virtue isTo make him worthy whose offence subdues him,And curse that justice did it. This tempest will not give me leave to ponder On things would hurt me more. There is a Historie in all mens Liues,Figuring the nature of the Times deceas'd:The which obseru'd, a man may prophecieWith a neere ayme, of the maine chance of things,As yet not come to Life, which in their SeedesAnd weake beginnings lye entreasured:Su Thou art a fellow of a good respect; Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it. Doe thou amend thy Face, and Ile amend thyLife: Thou art our Admirall, thou bearest the Lanternein the Poope, but 'tis in the Nose of thee; thou art theKnight of the burning Lampe Bard. --You tribunesTo the people,--Coriolanus, patience:--Speak, good Sicinius. Why may not hee rise aswell as I: Nothing confutes me but eyes, and no-bodiesees me. Anon, I wot not by what strong escape, He broke from those that had the guard of him, And with his mad attendant and himself, Each one with ireful passion, with drawn swords, Met us again and, madly bent on us, Chas'd us away; till, raising of more aid, Hark! Ver. If you do find him, pray you give him this; And when your mistress hears thus much from you, I pray desire her call her wisdom to her. Enter SIR OLIVER MARTEXT Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met. --Therefore be it known,As to us, to all the world, that Caius MarciusWears this war's garland: in token of the which,My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him,With all his trim belonging; and from this time,For what he did before Corioli, call him, So I, to find a mother and a brother, In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself. Despair thy charm;And let the angel whom thou still hast serv'dTell thee, Macduff was from his mother's wombUntimely ripp'd. Ipray you, how many hath he kill'd and eaten in these wars? But how many hath he kill'd? For indeed I promised to eat all of his killing. But he, as loving his own pride and purposes, Evades them, with a bumbast circumstance Horribly stuff'd with epithets of war, And, in conclusion, Nonsuits my mediators; for, "Certes," says he, "I have already chose my officer. O, speak to me no more; These words like daggers enter in mine ears; No more, sweet Hamlet. Thou monstrous injurer of heaven and earth, Call not me slanderer! Thou and thine usurp The dominations, royalties, and rights, Of this oppressed boy; this is thy eldest son's son, Infortunate in nothing but in thee. Thou goest to Coventry, there to behold Our cousin Hereford and fell Mowbray fight. Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn. [Snatching a weapon and killing one] Go thou and fill another room in hell. Come hither, fellow; Which way hast thou been? SOOTHSAYER. But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year elderthan this, who yet is no dearer in my account. So shall you have a shorter journey to your desires by themeans I shall then have to prefer them, and the impediment most profitably removed, without the which there were noexpectation of our prosperity. I'll devil-porter it no further: I had thought to have let insome of all professions, that go the primrose way to theeverlasting bonfire. And heere is my speech: stand aside Nobilitie Hostesse. 'Tis no matter; ne'er a fantastical knave of them all shall flout me out of my calling. I thank my liege that in regard of me He shortens four years of my son's exile; But little vantage shall I reap thereby, For ere the six years that he hath to spend Can change their moons and bring their times about, My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted  He was a man, take him for all in all, I shall not look upon his like again. To have a thousand with red burning spits Come hizzing in upon 'em Edg. To do what service am I sent for hither? YORK. Then all together They fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence, And in a dark and dankish vault at home There left me and my man, both bound together; Till, gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder, I gain'd my freedom, and immediately Ran hither to your What had he done, to make him fly the land?ROSS. Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself. Make lesse thy body (hence) and more thy Grace,Leaue gourmandizing; Know the Graue doth gapeFor thee, thrice wider then for other men. Do'st thou speake like a King? doe thou standfor mee, and Ile play my Father Falst. Now, gods, stand up for bastards! Enter Gloucester. Consent to pay thee that I never had! Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou dar'st. True, and they are to meddle with none but the Prince's subjects. What trust is in these Times?They, that when Richard liu'd, would haue him dye,Are now become enamour'd on his graue. Peace! Here comes my sister, reading; stand aside. It is here, Hamlet: Hamlet, thou art slain; No medicine in the world can do thee good; In thee there is not half an hour of life; The treacherous instrument is in thy hand, Unbated and envenom?: the foul practice Hath turn? itself on me; lo, here I lie, King Richard, he is in the mighty hold Of Bolingbroke. To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now, Whose state and honour I for aye allow. 'Tis Aufidius,Who, hearing of our Marcius' banishment,Thrusts forth his horns again into the world;Which were inshell'd when Marcius stood for Rome,And durst not once peep out. A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say'Wit, whither wilt?' ROSALIND. )I should reioyce now, at this happy newes,And now my Sight fayles, and my Braine is giddie. Truly, by your office you may; but I think they that touch pitch will be defil'd. Bless thee from whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking! Do poor Tom somecharity, whom the foul fiend vexes. What is the King but fiue & twenty thousand? Hast. Marcus Luccicos, is not he in town? FIRST SENATOR. I will, sir, flatter my sworn brother, thepeople, to earn a dearer estimation of them; 'tis a conditionthey account gentle: and since the wisdom of their choice israther to have my hat than my heart, I will practise theinsinuating nod and be off to them O Cassio, whence came this? This is some token from a newer friend. He is our subject, Mowbray; so art thou: Free speech and fearless I to thee allow. on a band, but on a stronger thing, A chain, a chain. My lord, I will be rul?; The rather if you could devise it so That I might be the organ. Dead for a ducat, dead! [Makes a pass through the arras. Take you some company, and away to horse! Inform her full of my particular fear, And thereto add such reasons of your own As may compact it more. " Moor, she was chaste; she loved thee, cruel Moor; So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true; So speaking as I think, I die, I die. Change places and,handy-dandy, which is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast seen a farmer's dog bark at a beggar? Glou. [To Don John] Let me bid you welcome, my lord. But that's all one, they'le findeLinnen enough on euery Hedge. Hie, good Sir Michell, beare this sealed BriefeWith winged haste to the Lord Marshall,This to my Cousin Scroope, and all the restTo whom they are directed. Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would fly?THIRD CITIZEN. Those that are good manners atthe court are as ridiculous in the country as the behaviour ofthe country is most mockable at the court. Come, my dear love, The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue; That profit's yet to come 'tween me and you. Will you be bound for nothing? Be mad, good master; cry 'The devil!'LUCIANA. Alas, how is? with you, That you do bend your eye on vacancy, And with the incorporal air do hold discourse? Forth at your eyes your spirits wildly peep; And, as the sleeping soldiers in the alarm, Your bedded hairs, like life in excrements, Start up an Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage, Disclaiming here the kindred of the King; And lay aside my high blood's royalty, Which fear, not reverence, makes thee to except. Hall to thee, lady! And the grace of heaven, Before, behind thee, and on every hand, Enwheel thee round! DESDEMONA. Dead?hee would haue clapt in the Clowt at Twelue-score, andcarryed you a fore-hand Shaft at foureteene, and foureteeneand a halfe, that it would haue done a mans heartgood to see. A street leading to the TowerEnter the QUEEN, with her attendants QUEEN. O, do not do your cousin such a wrong! She cannot be so much without true judgment (Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is priz'd to have) as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick. The servants of the Duke? And my lieutenant? The goodness of the night upon you, friends! What is the news? CASSIO. The citizens of Corioli have issued,And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle:I saw our party to their trenches driven,And then I came away. O, now you weep, and I perceive you feel The dint of pity. I whipt me behind the arras and there heard itagreed upon that the Prince should woo Hero for himself, and having obtain'd her, give her to Count Claudio. Go in with me, and councell euery manThe aptest way for safety, and reuenge:Get Posts, and Letters, and make Friends with speed,Neuer so few, nor neuer yet more need. There is a litter ready; lay him in't And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet Both welcome and protection. Brave soldier, pardon me That any accent breaking from thy tongue Should scape the true acquaintance of mine ear. Where one on his side fights, thousands will fly. Why, anything; An honorable murtherer, if you will, For nought did I in hate, but all in honor. Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile, And touch thy instrument a strain or two? LUCIUS. Soone after that, depriu'd him of his Life:And in the neck of that, task't the whole State. Were I my father, coz, would I do this? ORLANDO. I haue a Gammon of Bacon, and two razes ofGinger, to be deliuered as farre as Charing-crosse 1. I doe heerewalke before thee, like a Sow, that hath o'rewhelm'd allher Litter, but one. Let me desire your company: he must come,Or what is worst will follow. How now, my lord! why do you keep alone,Of sorriest fancies your companions making;Using those thoughts which should indeed have diedWith them they think on? Things without all remedyShould be without regard: what's done is done. Look Lucius, here's the book I sought for so; I put it in the pocket of my gown. Ay, marry, why was be sent into England? 1 Clown. Again! Second trumpet. No? Why, 'tis a plain case: he that went, like a bass-viol, in a case of leather; the man, sir, that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a sob, and rest them; he, sir, that takes pity on decayed men, and give them suits of durance; he that sets up his I cannot, nor I will not hold me still; My tongue, though not my heart, shall have his will. Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing. Even by the rule of that philosophy By which I did blame Cato for the death Which he did give himselfI know not how, But I do find it cowardly and vile, For fear of what might fall, so to prevent The time of lifearming myself with patience To stay the p The gentlemanthat danc'd with her told her she is much wrong'd by you. ' Hum! I know younot: In Ephesus I am but two hours old, As strange unto your town as to your talk, Who, every word by all my wit being scann'd, Wants wit in all one word to understand. Why, ?is a loving and a fair reply: Be as ourself in Denmark. Noble tribunes,It is the humane way: the other courseWill prove too bloody; and the end of itUnknown to the beginning. O, call back yesterday, bid time return, And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men! Shal. If YOU went in pain, master, this 'knave'would go sore. Is Bushy, Green, and the Earl of Wiltshire dead? SCROOP. Put money in thy purse; followthou the wars; defeat thy favor with an usurped beard. Well, that is the dowry of his wife; 'tis none ofhis own getting. Reputation, reputation, reputation! O, I have lost my reputation! I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is bestial. Because we come to do you service andyou think we are ruffians, you'll have your daughter covered witha Barbary horse; you'll have your nephews neigh to you; you'llhave coursers for cousins, and gennets for germans. O that a man should speak those words to me! BASTARD. So that, I say,He has borne all things well: and I do think,That had he Duncan's sons under his key,--As, an't please heaven, he shall not,--they should findWhat 'twere to kill a father; so should Fleance. What art thouThat counterfeit'st the person of a King? King. So tell your Cousin, and bring me word,What he will do. But, by your favour, How near's the other army? Gent. Enter, with Drum and Colours, Cordelia, Doctor, and Soldiers. O, if it should, how would thy guttes fall aboutthy knees. Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was soslain? Kent. I know not that; but such a handkerchief I am sure it was your wife'sdid I today See Cassio wipe his beard with. What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you avoid the house. I'll speak a prophecy ere I go: When priests are more in word than matter; When brewers mar their malt with water; When nobles are their tailors' tutors, No heretics burn'd, but wenches' suitors; When every case in law is right, No squire in debt nor no Their cheer is the greaterthat I am subdued. This way the King will come; this is the way To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower, To whose flint bosom my condemned lord Is doom'd a prisoner by proud Bolingbroke. And the ecstasyhath so much overborne her that my daughter is sometime afeard shewill do a desperate outrage to herself. The lists at CoventryEnter the LORD MARSHAL and the DUKE OF AUMERLE MARSHAL. But who comes here? Enter PERCY Welcome, Harry. Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily; Let not our looks put on our purposes, But bear it as our Roman actors do, With untired spirits and formal constancy. Thou shalt get kings, though thou be none:So all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!FIRST WITCH. O, these men, these men! Dost thou in conscience thinktell me, Emilia That there be women do abuse their husbands In such gross kind? EMILIA. Not to disprayse me? and call me Pantler, andBread-chopper, and I know not what? Fal. Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst beenwise. Arise, arise! Awake the snorting citizens with the bell, Or else the devil will make a grandsire of you. Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him! Reg. According to the fool's bolt, sir, and such dulcet diseases. And why not the swift foot of Time? Had not that beenas proper? ROSALIND. Speak then, Prince Dauphin; can you love this lady? LEWIS. Cousin Aumerle, How far brought you high Hereford on his way? AUMERLE. I might ask you for your commission; butI do takethee, Orlando, for my husband. For heaven sake, Hubert, let me not be bound! Nay, hear me, Hubert! Drive these men away, And I will sit as quiet as a lamb; I will not stir, nor wince, nor speak a word, Nor look upon the iron angrily; Thrust but these men away, and I'll forgive you, W Wherefore, bold peasant, Dar'st thou support a publish'd traitor? Hence! Lest that th' infection of his fortune take Like hold on thee. I am ioyned with no Foot-land-Rakers, No Long-staffesix-penny strikers, none of these madMustachio-purple-hu'd-Maltwormes,but with Nobility, and Tranquilitie;Bourgomasters, and great Oneyers, such as can holde in,such as will strike sooner then speake; aBut once he slander'd me with bastardy; But whe'er I be as true begot or no, That still I lay upon my mother's head; But that I am as well begot, my liege Fair fall the bones that took the pains for me! Compare our faces and be judge yourself. Excellent wretch! Perdition catch my soul, But I do love thee! and when I love thee not, Chaos is come again. The time was once when thou unurg'd wouldst vow That never words were music to thine ear, That never object pleasing in thine eye, That never touch well welcome to thy hand, That never meat sweet-savour'd in thy taste, Unless I spake, or look'd, or touc I give you welcome with a powerless hand, But with a heart full of unstained love; Welcome before the gates of Angiers, Duke. A Randeuous, a Home to flye vnto,If that the Deuill and Mischance looke biggeVpon the Maydenhead of our Affaires Wor. The chariest maid is prodigal enough If she unmask her beauty to the moon: Virtue itself scopes not calumnious strokes:33 The canker galls the infants of the spring Too oft before their buttons be disclos?: And in the morn and liquid dew of youth Contag Look, where he stands and glares! The king's a-bed:He hath been in unusual pleasure andSent forth great largess to your officers:This diamond he greets your wife withal,By the name of most kind hostess; and shut upIn measureless content. Proud Bolingbroke, I come To change blows with thee for our day of doom. SCENE 1KING JOHN's palaceEnter KING JOHN, QUEEN ELINOR, PEMBROKE, ESSEX, SALISBURY, andothers,with CHATILLON KING JOHN. This speech of yours hath mov'd me, And shall perchance do good; but speak you on; You look as you had something more to say. Would I could answerThis comfort with the like! But I have wordsThat would be howl'd out in the desert air,Where hearing should not latch them. Now go to the door, and stay there till we call. I marry her! What? A customer! I prithee, bear somecharity to my wit; do not think it so unwholesome. How say you now? Is not your husband mad?ADRIANA. Where is the Duke my father with his power? KING RICHARD. Is there not charms By which the property of youth and maidhood May be abused? Have you not read, Roderigo, Of some such thing? RODERIGO. Be't their comfortWe are coming thither: gracious England hathLent us good Siward and ten thousand men;An older and a better soldier noneThat Christendom gives out. I'll look no more, Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight Topple down headlong. For God's sake let us sit upon the ground And tell sad stories of the death of kings: How some have been depos'd, some slain in war, Some haunted by the ghosts they have depos'd, Some poison'd by their wives, some sleeping kill'd, All murder'd-for withi Good morrow, fair ones; pray you, if you know, Where in the purlieus of this forest stands A sheep-cote fenc'd about with olive trees? CELIA. But speak you this with asad brow? or do you play the flouting Jack, to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter? Claud. No mind that's honestBut in it shares some woe; though the main partPertains to you alone. The King, I can tell you, lookes for vs all: we must awayall to Night Falst. O my lord, When you went onward on this ended action, I look'd upon her with a soldier's eye, That lik'd, but had a rougher task in hand Than to drive liking to the name of love; But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts Have left their places vacant, So, to our tent;Where, ere we do repose us, we will writeTo Rome of our success. I will weepfor nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will do that whenyou are dispos'd to be merry; I will laugh like a hyen, and thatwhen thou are inclin'd to sleep. Exit LE BEAU Thus must I from the smoke into the smother; From tyrant Duke unto a tyrant brother. You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?ALL. Though this knavecame something saucily into the world before he was sent for, yetwas his mother fair, there was good sport at his making, and the whoreson must be acknowledged. If to his Men, I would currie withMaister Shallow, that no man could better command hisSeruants. ExitBASTARD ELINOR. Poor Tom, that eats the swimming frog, the toad, thetodpole, the wall-newt and the water; that in the fury of his heart,when the foul fiend rages, eats cow-dung for sallets, swallowsthe old rat and the ditch-dog, drinks the green mantle of the standing  If he should do so,He leaues his backe vnarm'd, the French, and WelchBaying him at the heeles: neuer feare that L. I dare assure thee that no enemy Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus; The gods defend him from so great a shame! TOUCHSTONE. London hath receiv'd, Like a kind host, the Dauphin and his powers. Why then, God's soldier be he!Had I as many sons as I have hairs,I would not wish them to a fairer death:And, so his knell is knoll'd. I am a Knight, Sir:And my Name is Colleuile of the Dale Falst. Well, march we on,To give obedience where 'tis truly ow'd:Meet we the medicine of the sickly weal;And with him pour we, in our country's purge,Each drop of us. Did these bones cost no more the breeding but to play at loggets with ?m? mine ache to think on?. Even she--Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero. A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch, Past speaking of in a king! Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe. " Here will I stand till Caesar pass along, And as a suitor will I give him this. Little are we beholding to your love, And little look'd for at your helping hands. Then after to her father will I break, And the conclusion is, she shall be thine. For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth, Action, nor utterance, nor the power of speech, To stir men's blood. Fortune, that arrant whore, Ne'er turns the key to th' poor. All that follow their noses are ledby their eyes but blind men, and there's not a nose amongtwenty but can smell him that's stinking. In my rights By me invested, he compeers the best. Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back know youthe reason? Gent. Now, by yond marble heaven, In the due reverence of a sacred vow Kneels. O, what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily do,not knowing what they do! Bene. --What's the matter, you dissentious roguesThat, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion,Make yourselves scabs?FIRST CITIZEN. Exeunt [Don Pedro, Claudio, and Leonato]. I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke, But here I am to speak what I do know. O, well flown, bird!i' th' clout, i' th' clout! O, thou thinkest To serve me last, that I may longest keep Thy sorrow in my breast. The forestEnter ROSALIND and CELIA ROSALIND. No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man, Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no tide No, not that name was given me at the font But 'tis usurp'd. Stop in your wind, sir; tell me this, Ipray: Where have you left the money that I gave you?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I'll not be long behind; though I be old, I doubt not but to ride as fast as York; And never will I rise up from the ground Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. O most lame and impotent conclusion! The fairest grant is the necessity. Herein I teach youHow you shall bid God ild us for your pains,And thank us for your trouble. I dare swear he is no hypocrite, but prays from his heart. All's done, all's won, here breathles lies the king Hot. The Prince and Count Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached alley in mine orchard, were thus muchoverheard by a man of mine: the Prince discovered to Claudio that he lovedmy niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it this night ina dance, and if he f Post back with speed and tell him what hath chanced. We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll diewith him. O, are you come, Iago? You have done well, That men must lay their murthers on your neck. Since that my beauty cannot please his eye, I'll weep what's left away, and weeping die. And thy dear judgment out! Go, go, my people. No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!SECOND CITIZEN. Sessa! Come, march to wakes and fairs andmarket towns. Yonder they lie; the poor oldman, their father, making such pitiful dole over them that all the beholders take his part with weeping. I would not have your free and noble nature Out of self-bounty be abused. Iacke Falstaffe with my Familiars:Iohn with my Brothers and Sister: & SirIohn, with all Europe. But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear As all the metal in your shop will answer. It is a letter from mybrother that I have not all o'er-read; and for so much as I have perus'd, I find it not fit for your o'erlooking. To a rope's-end, sir; and to that end am I return'd. --Had he not resembledMy father as he slept, I had done't. How do you, Cassio? O, a chair, a chair! GRATIANO. Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich, being poor; Most choice, forsaken; and most lov'd, despis'd! Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon. 141 Faith, if he be not rotten before he die,?s we have many pocky corses now-a-days that will scarce hold the laying in,?e will last you some eight year or nine year: a tanner will last you nine year. Ah, foul shrewd news! Beshrew thy very heart! You will be shamed forever. What since thou swor'st is sworn against thyself And may not be performed by thyself, For that which thou hast sworn to do amiss Is not amiss when it is truly done; And being not done, where doing tends to ill, The truth is then most done not doing it;  There? letters seal?: and my two schoolfellows,?Whom I will trust as I will adders fang?,?They bear the mandate; they must sweep my way And marshal me to knavery. [aside] An he had been a dog that should have howl'dthus, they would have hang'd him; and I pray God his bad voice bodeno mischief. Patience, good lady! CONSTANCE. A bloody deed!?lmost as bad, good mother, As kill a king and marry with his brother. Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome, No Rome of safety for Octavius yet; Hie hence, and tell him so. I dare not speak much further:But cruel are the times, when we are traitors,And do not know ourselves; when we hold rumourFrom what we fear, yet know not what we fear,But float upon a wild and violent seaEach way and move. O, these eclipses do portend these divisions! Fa, sol, la,mi. Let griefConvert to anger; blunt not the heart, enrage it. I'll never care what wickedness I do, If this man come to good. The circumstance considered, good my Lord,What euer Harry Percie then had said,To such a person, and in such a place,At such a time, with all the rest retold,May reasonably dye, and neuer riseTo do him wrong, or any way impeachWhat then he said, so he v What is it she does now? Would he deny his letter? I never got him. I have this while with leaden thoughts been press'd; But I shall in a more continuate time Strike off this score of absence. What trash is Rome, What rubbish, and what offal, when it serves For the base matter to illuminate So vile a thing as Caesar? But, O grief, Where hast thou led me? I perhaps speak this Before a willing bondman; then I know My answer must be made. I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing. I am given, sir, secretly to understand that youryounger brother, Orlando, hath a disposition to come in disguis'dagainst me to try a fall. You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not? SERVANT. Come, grin on me, and I will think thou smil'st, And buss thee as thy wife. Intended or committed was this fault? If on the first, how heinous e'er it be, To win thy after-love I pardon thee. If thou wilt needs damn thyself, do it a moredelicate way than drowning. [To Goneril] Yes, forsooth, I will hold my tongue. But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh, To offer service to the Duke of Hereford; And sent me over by Berkeley, to discover What power the Duke of York had levied there; Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh. The sorrow that delivers us thus chang'dMakes you think so. Falstaffe, Haruey, Rossill, and Gads-hill, shallrobbe those men that wee haue already way-layde, yourselfe and I, wil not be there: and when they haue the booty,if you and I do not rob them, cut this head from myshoulders Prin. You may, indeed, say so; For 'twas that hand that gave away my heart. No, good my lord; let's fight with gentle words Till time lend friends, and friends their helpful swords. But who comes here? O time's extremity, Hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue In seven short years that here my only son Knows not my feeble key of untun'd cares? Fly, good Fleance, fly, fly, fly!Thou mayst revenge. What bastard doth not? Who will go with me? I will proclaim my name about the field. And you say you will have her when I bring her? ORLANDO. Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig, and recover the lost hair of another man. Ay, in the catalogue ye go for men;As hounds, and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs,Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are cleptAll by the name of dogs: the valu'd fileDistinguishes the swift, the slow, the subtle,The house-keeper, the hunter, everyThough in the trade of war I have slain men, Yet do I hold it very stuff o' the conscience To do no contrived murther. You may think perchance that I think youare in love. Anhonest soul, i' faith, sir, by my troth he is, as ever broke bread;but God is to be worshipp'd; all men are not alike, alas, good neighbour! Leon. So befall my soul As this is false he burdens me withal!LUCIANA. Your Honours' pardon:I had rather have my wounds to heal againThan hear say how I got them. Come on, our queen; to-morrow must we part; Be merry, for our time of stay is short. My wretchedness unto a row of pins, They will talk of state, for every one doth so Against a change: woe is forerun with woe. If I have known her, You will say she did embrace me as a husband, And so extenuate the forehand sin. When I have pluck'd the rose, I cannot give it vital growth again, It must needs wither; I'll smell it on the tree. O, throw away the worser part of it, And live the purer with the other half. Will you dispatch ushere under this tree, or shall we go with you to your chapel? MARTEXT. Hapless, Aegeon, whom the fates have mark'd To bear the extremity of dire mishap! Now, trust me, were it not against our laws, Against my crown, my oath, my dignity, Which princes, would they, may not disannul, My soul should sue as advocate for thee. Our scene is alt'red from a serious thing, And now chang'd to 'The Beggar and the King. Now, by this light, were I to get again, Madam, I would not wish a better father. It was he That made the overture of thy treasons to us; Who is too good to pity thee. So much the worse, if your owne Rule be true Iohn. Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beatsher heart, tears her hair, prays, curses--'O sweet Benedick! Godgive me patience!' Leon. O, had it been a stranger, not my child, To smooth his fault I should have been more mild. Which of you two did dine with me to-day?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. How now, daughter and cousin! Are you crept hitherto see the wrestling? ROSALIND. His heart's his mouth:What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent;And, being angry, does forget that everHe heard the name of death. I'faith, i'faith; and both in a tune, like twogipsies on a horse. Villain, thou liest; for even her verywords Didst thou deliver to me on the mart. Now unto thy bones good night! Yearly will I do this rite. Why do you speak too, 'Why blame you me to love you?' ORLANDO. Come hither Harrie, sit thou by my bedde,And heare (I thinke, the very latest CounsellThat euer I shall breath: Heauen knowes, my Sonne)By what by-pathes, and indirect crook'd-wayesI met this Crowne: and I my selfe know wellHow troublesome it sate vpon mWhat need you five-and-twenty, ten, or five, To follow in a house where twice so many Have a command to tend you? Reg. Nor do not saw the air too much with your hand, thus, but use all gently: for in the very torrent, tempest, and, as I may say, whirlwind of passion, you must acquire and beget a temperance that may give it smoothness. Once more, good-night: And when you are desirous to be bles?,106 I?l blessing beg of you. Now for the bare-pick'd bone of majesty Doth dogged war bristle his angry crest And snarleth in the gentle eyes of peace; Now powers from home and discontents at home Meet in one line; and vast confusion waits, As doth a raven on a sick-fall'n beast, Th Let every man be master of his timeTill seven at night; to make societyThe sweeter welcome, we will keep ourselfTill supper time alone: while then, God be with you![Exeunt Lady Macbeth, Lords, Ladies, &c. Twice did he turn his back, and purpos'd so; But kindness, nobler ever than revenge, And nature, stronger than his just occasion, Made him give battle to the lioness, Who quickly fell before him; in which hurtling From miserable slumber I awak'd. That rises like the issue of a king,And wears upon his baby brow the roundAnd top of sovereignty?ALL. O Maiestie!When thou do'st pinch thy Bearer, thou do'st sitLike a rich Armor, worne in heat of day,That scald'st with safetie: by his Gates of breath,There lyes a dowlney feather, which stirres not:Did hee suspire, that light and weightlesse dowlnePerfo If it shall please you to make me a wholesome answer, I will do your mother? commandment: if not, your pardon and my return shall be the end of my business. I were butlittle happy if I could say how much. Most certain of one mother, mighty king That is well knownand, as I think, one father; But for the certain knowledge of that truth I put you o'er to heaven and to my mother. Here I stand your slave, A poor, infirm, weak, and despis'd old man. That lord that counsell'd thee To give away thy land, Come place him here by me Do thou for him stand. That by proscription and bills of outlawry Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus Have put to death an hundred senators. Where is it? taken from vs, it is: a hundredvpon poore foure of vs Prince. There are no faces truerthan those that are so wash'd. This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen. I task the earth to the like, forsworn Aumerle; And spur thee on with fun as many lies As may be halloa'd in thy treacherous ear From sun to sun. Content, and the argument shall be, thy runingaway Fal. Let me have a surgeon; I am cut to th' brains. Did you perceiveHe did solicit you in free contemptWhen he did need your loves; and do you thinkThat his contempt shall not be bruising to youWhen he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodiesNo heart among you? Or had you tongues to cryAgainst the rectorWhy, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours,Will you undo yourselves?FIRST CITIZEN. Though Birnam wood be come to Dunsinane,And thou oppos'd, being of no woman born,Yet I will try the last. Your virtues, gentle master, Are sanctified and holy traitors to you. You minion, you, are these your customers? Did this companion with the saffron face Revel and feast it at my house to-day, Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut, And I denied to enter in my house?ADRIANA. Could you not have told him,As you were lesson'd,--when he had no power,But was a petty servant to the state,He was your enemy; ever spake againstYour liberties, and the charters that you bearI' the body of the weal: and now, arrivingA place of potency aWhy, here in Denmark: I have been sexton here, man and boy, thirty years. The great man down, you mark his favourite flies, The poor advanc? makes friends of enemies; And hitherto doth love on fortune tend: For who not needs shall never lack a friend; And who in want a hollow friend doth try, Directly seasons him his enemy. Stand all apart, And show fair duty to his Majesty. My brother Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul Whom fair befall in heaven 'mongst happy souls! May be a precedent and witness good That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood. Two things are to bedone: My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress I'll set her on; Myself the while to draw the Moor apart, And bring him jump when he may Cassio find Soliciting his wife. Let it doe something (my good Lord) that maydoe me good, and call it what you will Iohn. O good Horatio, I?l take the ghost? word for a thousand pound! Didst perceive? Hor. Beshrew your heart,(Faire Daughter) you doe draw my Spirits from me,With new lamenting ancient Ouer-sights. Did you and he consent in Cassio's death? OTHELLO. How long a time lies in one little word! Four lagging winters and four wanton springs End in a word: such is the breath of Kings. What Antony shall speak, I will protest He speaks by leave and by permission, And that we are contented Caesar shall Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies. Yet I am sworn, and I did purpose, boy, With this same very iron to burn them out. You would say so, master, if your garmentswere thin. Our holy lives must win a new world's crown, Which our profane hours here have thrown down. And, father Cardinal, I have heard you say That we shall see and know our friends in heaven; If that be true, I shall see my boy again; For since the birth of Cain, the first male child, To him that did but yesterday suspire, There was not such a gracio '--Let the VolscesPlough Rome and harrow Italy: I'll neverBe such a gosling to obey instinct; but stand,As if a man were author of himself,And knew no other kin. I thinke there's no man speakes better Welsh:Ile to Dinner Mort. How have I been behaved, that he might stick The small'st opinion on my least misuse? Re-enter Emilia with Iago. Master Gowre, shall I entreate you with mee todinner? Gow. Let us haste to hear it, And call the noblest to the audience. Why then your browne Bastard is your onelydrinke: for looke you Francis, your white Canuas doubletwill sulley. O proper stuff!This is the very painting of your fear:This is the air-drawn dagger which, you said,Led you to Duncan. On's brows: Menenius, he comes the third time home with the oakengarland. Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast; And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt? For sleeping England long time have I watch'd; Watching breeds leanness, leanness is an gaunt. What's that to thee? Why may I not demand Of thine affairs as well as thou of mine? BASTARD. I did not see you since you sent me hence, Home to the Centaur, with the gold you gave me. 'Tis not tenne yeeres gone,Since Richard, and Northumberland, great friends,Did feast together; and in two yeeres after,Were they at Warres. Give me the ocular proof; Or, by the worth of man's eternal soul, Thou hadst been better have been born a dog Than answer my waked wrath! IAGO. How now, nuncle? Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters! Lear. For since you loue me not,I will not loue my selfe. How stand I, then, That have a father kill?, a mother stain?, Excitements of my reason and my blood, And let all sleep? while, to my shame, I see The imminent death of twenty thousand men That, for a fantasy and trick of fame, Go to their graves like be 'Blessing on your good heart, and so shee is bymy troth Fal. Well, see to live; I will not touch thine eye For all the treasure that thine uncle owes. Why, hark you![Trumpets and hautboys sounded, drums beaten, aand shoutingwithin. Who I? I defie thee: I was neuer call'd soin mine owne house before Falst. The people will remain uncertain whilst'Twixt you there's difference: but the fall of eitherMakes the survivor heir of all. 'Tis holy sport to be a little vain When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife. I will prophesy he comes to tell me of the players; mark it. Now sir, the sound that tells what hour it is Are clamorous groans which strike upon my heart, Which is the bell. How say you then; would heart of man once think it??But you?l be secret? Hor. We shall find a time, Audrey; patience, gentleAudrey. There is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for hisvalor, and death for his ambition. O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thoudidst know how many fathom deep I am in love! But it cannot besounded; my affection hath an unknown bottom, like the Bay ofPortugal. Now, by the sky that hangs above our heads, I like it well. It is a mindThat shall remain a poison where it is,Not poison any further. My lord, my answer is-'to Lancaster'; And I am come to seek that name in England; And I must find that title in your tongue Before I make reply to aught you say. If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have hishead on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is. What now, my son! Have I not ever said How that ambitious Constance would not cease Till she had kindled France and all the world Upon the right and party of her son? This might have been prevented and made whole With very easy arguments of love, Which  To please the King, I did; to please myself I cannot do it; yet I know no cause Why I should welcome such a guest as grief, Save bidding farewell to so sweet a guest As my sweet Richard. Here come I from our Princely Generall,To know your Griefes; to tell you, from his Grace,That hee will giue you Audience: and whereinIt shall appeare, that your demands are iust,You shall enioy them, euery thing set off,That might so much as thinke you ETherefore omit him not: blunt not his Loue,Nor loose the good aduantage of his Grace,By seeming cold, or carelesse of his will. There will she hide her To listen our propose. Laertes, I must commune with your grief, Or you deny me right. But, in the beaten way of friendship, what make you at Elsinore? Ros. Much deserv'd on his part, and equally rememb'red by Don Pedro. It is but change, Titinius, for Octavius Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power, As Cassius' legions are by Antony. By my soul, nor I! And yet, to satisfy this good old man, I would bend under any heavy weight That he'll enjoin me to. If thou dost slander her and torture me, Never pray more; abandon all remorse; On horror's head horrors accumulate; Do deeds to make heaven weep, all earth amazed; For nothing canst thou to damnation add Greater than that. Friend,Art thou certain this is true? is't most certain?SECOND MESSENGER. To-morrow is Saint Valentine? day All in the morning bedtime, And I a maid at your window, To be your Valentine. It must be by his death, and, for my part, I know no personal cause to spurn at him, But for the general. But, O, how bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man's eyes! By so much the moreshall I to-morrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for. If I affect it more,Then as your Honour, and as your Renowne,Let me no more from this Obedience rise,Which my most true, and inward duteous SpiritTeacheth this prostrate, and exteriour bending. A goodly house: the feast smells well; but IAppear not like a guest. Speak to him, ladies; see if you can move him. Quickly send (Be brief in't) to the castle; for my writ Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia. No, my good lord; for that is not forgot Which ne'er I did remember; to my knowledge, I never in my life did look on him. Twice for one step I'll groan, the way beingshort, And piece the way out with a heavy heart. Sweet Knight, I kisse thy Neaffe: what? wee haueseene the seuen Starres Dol. The murmuring surge That on th' unnumb'red idle pebble chafes Cannot be heard so high. Make all our trumpets speak; give them all breath,Those clamorous harbingers of blood and death. There's no news at the court, sir, but the old news;that is, the old Duke is banished by his younger brother the newDuke; and three or four loving lords have put themselves intovoluntary exile with him, whose lands and revenues enrich the new Duke; ther It is a damned and a bloody work; The graceless action of a heavy hand, If that it be the work of any hand. We learn no other but the confident tyrantKeeps still in Dunsinane, and will endureOur setting down before't. He's here in double trust:First, as I am his kinsman and his subject,Strong both against the deed: then, as his host,Who should against his murderer shut the door,Not bear the knife myself. Mischief, thou art afoot, Take thou what course thou wilt. Beside the charge, the shame, imprisonment, You have done wrong to this my honest friend; Who, but for staying on our controversy, Had hoisted sail and put to sea to-day. Then there is no true lover in the forest, elsesighing every minute and groaning every hour would detect the lazyfoot of Time as well as a clock. Enter [Edmund the] Bastard solus, [with a letter]. When we our betters see bearing our woes, We scarcely think our miseries our foes. Alas, my lord, Your wisdom is consumed in confidence. I will upon all hazards well believe Thou art my friend that know'st my tongue so well. Not that Adam that kept the Paradise, but that Adam that keeps the prison; he that goes in the calf's skin that was kill'd for the Prodigal; he that camebehind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty. Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he sweats not to overthrow your Almain; he gives your Hollandera vomit ere the next pottle can be filled. Forty let it be,My Father and Glendower being both away,The powres of vs, may serue so great a day. Are you sick, Hubert? You look pale to-day; In sooth, I would you were a little sick, That I might sit all night and watch with you. I would thinke thee a most Princely hypocrite Prin. Marry, patience, Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen, And nothing of a man. Join with the present sickness that I have; And thy unkindness be like crooked age, To crop at once a too long withered flower. She cannot love, Nor take no shape nor project of affection, She is so self-endeared. For in a Theame so bloody fac'd, as this,Coniecture, Expectation, and SurmiseOf Aydes incertaine, should not be admitted Arch. I was born free as Caesar, so were you; We both have fed as well, and we can both Endure the winter's cold as well as he. Doulas, filthy Doulas: I haue giuen themaway to Bakers Wiues, and they haue made Boulters ofthem Hostesse. Go, signify as much, while here we march Upon the grassy carpet of this plain. Indeed! is't true? OTHELLO. Hero was in this manner accus'd, in this manner refus'd, and upon the grief of this suddenly died. I am an ass indeed; you may prove it by my long 'ears. Fair day, adieu! Which is the side that I must go withal? I am with both: each army hath a hand; And in their rage, I having hold of both, They whirl asunder and dismember me. And why rail I on this commodity? But for because he hath not woo'd me yet; Not that I have the power to clutch my hand When his fair angels would salute my palm, But for my hand, as unattempted yet, Like a poor beggar raileth on the rich. Weepe not, sweet Queene, for trickling tearesare vaine Hostesse. This, from thee, will I to mine leaue,As 'tis left to me. But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again, and the man inblood, they will out of their burrows, like conies after rain,and revel all with him. A good wit will make vse of any thing: I will turne diseasesto commodity. Go we to our tent:The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis timeIt should be look'd to: come. And live you yet? [To VALERIA]--O my sweet lady, pardon. Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain, But makes one pardon strong. The Money shall be pay'd backe againe with aduantage. One Angelo, a goldsmith; do you know him?ADRIANA. Boy! Love, and be silent. I could myselfTake up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the two tribunes. I have heard of your paintings too, well enough; God hath given you one face, and you make yourselves another: you jig, you amble, and you lisp, and nickname God? creatures, and make your wantonness your ignorance. What, has this thing appear? again to-night? Ber. Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wrong'dHero? Beat. Lovecools, friendship falls off, brothers divide. Now we have shown our power,Let us seem humbler after it is doneThan when it was a-doing. And Duncan's horses,--a thing most strange and certain,--Beauteous and swift, the minions of their race,Turn'd wild in nature, broke their stalls, flung out,Contending 'gainst obedience, as they would makeWar with mankind. On Wednesday next we solemnly set down Our coronation. Why heareye my Masters, was it for me to kill the Heire apparant?Should I turne vpon the true Prince? Why, thou knowestI am as valiant as Hercules: but beware Instinct, the Lionwill not touch the true Prince: Instinct is a great matter. Carlisle, this is your doom: Choose out some secret place, some reverend room, More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life; So as thou liv'st in peace, die free from strife; For though mine enemy thou hast ever been, High sparks of honour in thee have If it be honour in your wars to seemThe same you are not,--which for your best endsYou adopt your policy,--how is it less or worseThat it shall hold companionship in peaceWith honour as in war; since that to bothIt stands in like request?CORIOLANUS. ' My son Edgar! Speak; Recover breath; tell us how near is danger, That we may arm us to encounter it. You have told them home,And, by my troth, you have cause. Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands, Unless thou bring'st them with thee. Let our old acquaintance be renewed: peraduentureI will with you to the Court Falst. Only get the learned writerto set down our excommunication, and meet me at the jail. I have a way to will their loves again; Bring them before me. He had, my lord; and that it was which caus'dOur swifter composition. Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt With modest warrant. O, my fear interprets! What, is he dead? OTHELLO. Five shillings to one on't with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him! Marry, not without the Prince be willing; for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and itis an offence to stay a man against his will. But whate'er I be, Nor I, nor any man that but man is, With nothing shall be pleas'd till he be eas'd With being nothing. What I should deny (As this I would; ay, though thou didst produce My very character), I'ld turn it all To thy suggestion, plot, and damned practice; And thou must make a dullard of the world, If they not thought the profits of my death Were very pregna And well he might so do, For well I know he was unnatural. And yesterday the bird of night did sit Even at noonday upon the marketplace, Howling and shrieking. Here's a goodly tumult: Ile forsweare keepinghouse, before Ile be in these tirrits, and frights. Upon what bargain do you give it me?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. In Syracuse was I born, and wed Unto a woman, happy but for me, And by me, had not our hap been bad. Fare you well, Falstaffe: I, in my condition,Shall better speake of you, then you deserue. Put on two Leather Ierkins, and Aprons, andwaite vpon him at his Table, like Drawers Prin. Then here will be old Vtis: it will be an excellentstratagem 2. Tell me, how if my brother, Who, as you say, took pains to get this son, Had of your father claim'd this son for his? I understand a fury in your words, But not the words. I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me; Lend me thy handkerchief. It is the cowish terror of his spirit, That dares not undertake. In his behalfe, Ile empty all these Veines,And shed my deere blood drop by drop i'th dust,But I will lift the downfall MortimerAs high i'th Ayre, as this Vnthankfull King,As this Ingrate and Cankred Bullingbrooke Nor. Let that suffice, most Forcible Feeble Feeble. Exeunt KING, QUEEN, BUSHY, AUMERLE, GREEN, and BAGOT NORTHUMBERLAND. Poor naked wretches, wheresoe'er you are, That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm, How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides, Your loop'd and window'd raggedness, defend you From seasons such as these? O, I have ta'en Too little care of this!  My boon I make it that you know me not Till time and I think meet. I did not then entreat to have her stay; It was your pleasure, and your own remorse; I was too young that time to value her, But now I know her. he hath won, that hath he fortified; So hot a speed with such advice dispos'd, Such temperate order in so fierce a cause, Doth want example; who hath read or heard Of any kindred action like to this? KING PHILIP. Neither his daughter, if we judge by manners; But yet, indeed, the smaller is his daughter; The other is daughter to the banish'd Duke, And here detain'd by her usurping uncle, To keep his daughter company; whose loves Are dearer than the natural bond o --This man, Aufidius,Was my beloved in Rome: yet thou behold'st!AUFIDIUS. O, would the deed were good! For now the devil, that told me I did well, Says that this deed is chronicled in hell. At sixteen years,When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he foughtBeyond the mark of others; our then dictator,Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight,When with his Amazonian chin he droveThe bristled lips before him: he bestridAn o'erpress'd Roman an We pray you, for your own sake, to embrace yourown safety and give over this attempt. Enter EXTON, with attendants, hearing a coffin EXTON. You have heard of the news abroadI meanthe whisper'd ones, for they are yet but ear-kissing arguments? Edm. Against my soul's pure truth why labour you To make it wander in an unknown field? Are you a god? Would you create me new? Transform me, then, and to your pow'r I'll yield. May I be so converted and seewith these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not. We are not the first Who with best meaning have incurr'd the worst. O death, made proud with pure and princely beauty! The earth had not a hole to hide this deed. Now, Bagot, freely speak thy mind What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death; Who wrought it with the King, and who perform'd The bloody office of his timeless end. Who was it that thus cried? Why, worthy thane,You do unbend your noble strength to thinkSo brainsickly of things. I will tell you;If you'll bestow a small,--of what you have little,--Patience awhile, you'll hear the belly's answer. Constant you are,But yet a woman: and for secrecie,No Lady closer. Those of his chamber, as it seem'd, had done't:Their hands and faces were all badg'd with blood;So were their daggers, which, unwip'd, we foundUpon their pillows:They star'd, and were distracted; no man's lifeWas to be trusted with them. Butwhat praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving woman indeed, onethat in the authority of her merit did justly put on the vouch ofvery malice itself? IAGO. Why sir? Did I say you were an honest man? Settingmy Knight-hood, and my Souldiership aside, I hadlyed in my throat, if I had said so Ser. I'll notexpostulate with her, lest her body and beauty unprovide my mind again. Yet doth he giue vs bold aduertisement,That with our small coniunction we should on,To see how Fortune is dispos'd to vs:For, as he writes, there is no quailing now,Because the King is certainely possestOf all our purposes. Thou wilt be like a lover presently And tire the hearer with a book of words. Will you sterner be Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops? Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN, at a distance PHEBE. Do, child, go to it grandam, child; Give grandam kingdom, and it grandam will Give it a plum, a cherry, and a fig. Wilt thou be fast to my hopes, if I depend on theissue? IAGO. The King, your Father, is at Westminster,And there are twentie weake and wearied Postes,Come from the North: and as I came along,I met, and ouer-tooke a dozen Captaines,Bare-headed, sweating, knocking at the Tauernes,And asking euery one for Sir Iohn Fa I am the last of noble Edward's sons, Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first. You, Lord Arch-bishop,Whose Sea is by a Ciuill Peace maintain'd,Whose Beard, the Siluer Hand of Peace hath touch'd,Whose Learning, and good Letters, Peace hath tutor'd,Whose white Inuestments figure Innocence,The Doue, and very blessed Spirit of Peace. Enter ROBERT FAULCONBRIDGE and PHILIP, his bastard brother What men are you? BASTARD. [Enter Fortinbras, the English Ambassadors, and others. Will you go? ExeuntACT V. Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousandducats. I have a letter guessingly set down, Which came from one that's of a neutral heart, And not from one oppos'd. Let me unkiss the oath 'twixt thee and me; And yet not so, for with a kiss 'twas made. What say'st thou Kate? what wold'st thou haue with me? La. Enter, [masked,] Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, and Balthasar. I am (my Lord) but as my Betters are,That led me hither: had they beene rul'd by me,You should haue wonne them dearer then you haue Falst. Marry, sir, be better employed, and be nought awhile. But where's my fool? I have not seen him this two days. What saies Monsieurremorse? What sayes Sir Iohn Sacke and Sugar:Iacke? How agrees the Diuell and thee about thy Soule,that thou soldest him on Good-Friday last, for a Cup ofMadera, and a cold Capons legge? Prin. Are we all ready? What is now amiss That Caesar and his Senate must redress? METELLUS. My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd. Where shall we take a purse to morrow, Iacke? Fal. And that well mightAdvise him to a caution, to hold what distanceHis wisdom can provide. The Riuer hath thrice flow'd, no ebbe betweene:And the old folke (Times doting Chronicles)Say it did so, a little time beforeThat our great Grand-sire Edward sick'd, and dy'de War. I do not bid the Thunder-bearer shoot Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove. Enter Dogberry and his compartner [Verges], with the Watch. How subiect wee old men are to this vice of Lying?This same staru'd Iustice hath done nothing butprate to me of the wildenesse of his Youth, and theFeates hee hath done about Turnball-street, and euerythird word a Lye, duer pay'd to the hearer, then theTSay, didst thou speak with him? Know'st thou his mind?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. It will not let you eat, nor talk, nor sleep, And, could it work so much upon your shape As it hath much prevail'd on your condition, I should not know you, Brutus. There was a pretty redness in his lip, A little riper and more lusty red Than that mix'd in his cheek; 'twas just the difference Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask. Lo you, here she comes! [Enter Lady Macbeth, with a taper. She must change foryouth; when she is sated with his body, she will find the error ofher choice. Why bear you these rebukes, and answer not?ADRIANA. ' O indistinguish'd space of woman's will! A plot upon her virtuous husband's life, And the exchange my brother! Here in the sands Thee I'll rake up, the post unsanctified Of murtherous lechers; and in the mature time With this ungracious paper strike thI learn in this letter that Don Pedro of Arragon comesthis night to Messina. Heere comes my Seruant Trauers, whom I sentOn Tuesday last, to listen after Newes. God save your good worships! Marciusis coming home; he has more cause to be proud. Messala, I have here received letters That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power, Bending their expedition toward Philippi. There is none of my uncle's marks upon you; he taughtme how to know a man in love; in which cage of rushes I am sureyou are not prisoner. Ah, Gaunt, his blood was thine! That bed, that womb, That mettle, that self mould, that fashion'd thee, Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest, Yet art thou slain in him. Sweet remembrancer!--Now, good digestion wait on appetite,And health on both!LENNOX. But till that time I do receive your offer? love like love, And will not wrong it. What a fool art thou, A ramping fool, to brag and stamp and swear Upon my party! Laer. Nay, 'tis for me to be patient; I am in adversity. Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous. By all the blood that ever fury breath'd, The youth says well. I cannot believe that in her; she's full of mostblest condition. Call up her father, Rouse him, make after him, poison his delight, Proclaim him in the streets, incense her kinsmen, And, though he in a fertile climate dwell, Plague him with flies. There is a cliff, whose high and bending head Looks fearfully in the confined deep. In the base court? Come down? Down, court! down, king! For night-owls shriek where mounting larks should sing. Let's away, And get our jewels and our wealth together; Devise the fittest time and safest way To hide us from pursuit that will be made After my flight. I trust we shall, If not fill up the measure of her will, Yet in some measure satisfy her so That we shall stop her exclamation. Caesar's better parts Shall be crown'd in Brutus. There thou shouldst be;By this great clatter, one of greatest noteSeems bruited. What, foure? thou sayd'st but two, euen now Falst. Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues; Let every eye negotiate for itself And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood. That I am guiltless of your father? death, And am most sensibly in grief for it, It shall as level to your judgment pierce As day does to your eye. Not a whit: I lacke some of thy instinct Falst. But, good lieutenant, is your general wived?
