Mend your speech a little, Lest it may mar your fortunes. Why, very well then; you must not think then that I am drunk. O worthy fool! One that hath been a courtier, And says, if ladies be but young and fair, They have the gift to know it; and in his brain, Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit After a voyage, he hath strange places cramm'd With observation, the which Why, horns; which such as you are fain to bebeholding to your wives for; but he comes armed in his fortune, andprevents the slander of his wife. My Lord, I will steepe this Letter in Sack, and make himeate it Prin. Here, take this Purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues Have humbled to all strokes. If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee To bind our loves up in a holy band; For others say thou dost deserve, and I Believe it better than reportingly. But for all this, thou shalt have as many dolours for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year. Behold, his eye, As bright as is the eagle's, lightens forth Controlling majesty. Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing!When I desir'd their leave that I might pity him, they took fromme the use of mine own house, charg'd me on pain of perpetual displeasure neither to speak of him, entreat for him, norany way sustai What should the wars do with these jigging fools? A sin prevailing much in youthful men Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing. [Aside] His words do take possession of my bosom. O that there were some virtue in my tears, That might relieve you! KING JOHN. Good-night; and better healthAttend his majesty!LADY MACBETH. But to stand stained with Trauaile, and sweatingwith desire to see him, thinking of nothing else, puttingall affayres in obliuion, as if there were nothing els to beedone, but to see him Pist. Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome,And occupations perish!CORIOLANUS. These promises are faire, the parties sure,And our induction full of prosperous hope Hotsp. Then but forbear your food a little while, Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn, And give it food. O, that a man might know The end of this day's business ere it come! ROSALIND. To do this is within the compass of man's wit, andtherefore I will attempt the doing it. Belike then, my Appetite was not Princelygot: for (in troth) I do now remember the poore Creature,Small Beere. Farewell therefore Hero! 'Tis all men's office to speak patience To those that wring under the load of sorrow, But no man's virtue nor sufficiency To be so moral when he shall endure The like himself. Saue thy Grace, King Hall, my Royall Hall Pist. Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from him lastnight. Repentat idle times as thou mayst, and so farewell. There is two more called then your number:you must haue but foure heere sir, and so I pray you go inwith me to dinner Fal. Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself. Enter BUSHY Bushy, what news? Landlord of England art thou now, not King. The DUKE'S palaceEnter DUKE FREDERICK, with LORDS FREDERICK. I, that nowRefus'd most princely gifts, am bound to beg Of my lord general. My Father, my Vnckle, and my selfe,Did giue him that same Royaltie he weares:And when he was not sixe and twentie strong,Sicke in the Worlds regard, wretched, and low,A poore vnminded Out-law, sneaking home,My Father gaue him welcome to the shore:And wheI Care not for my spirits, if my legs were notweary. The weird sisters, hand in hand,Posters of the sea and land,Thus do go about, about:Thrice to thine, and thrice to mine,And thrice again, to make up nine:--Peace!--the charm's wound up. O, God defend my soul from such deep sin! PANDULPH. I do not think so; since he went into France I have been in continual practice: I shall win at the odds. How ill this taper burns! Ha, who comes here? Make me, that nothing have, with nothing griev'd, And thou with all pleas'd, that hast an achiev'd. Alas, poor Duke! the task he undertakes Is numb'ring sands and drinking oceans dry. But your reason was not substantial, why there is no time to recover. They do discharge their shot of courtesy Our friends at least. Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE How now, sir, is your merry humour alter'd? As you love strokes, so jest with me again. Give me your hand;Conduct me to mine host: we love him highly,And shall continue our graces towards him. You have told me shehath received them and returned me expectations and comforts ofsudden respect and acquaintance; but I find none. Thou art a soul in bliss; but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead. I could anger her to the heart: shee was then aBona-Roba. Your answer, sir, is enigmatical; But, for my will, my will is, your good will May stand with ours, this day to be conjoin'd In the state of honourable marriage; In which, good friar, I shall desire your help. Let every soldier hew him down a bough,And bear't before him; thereby shall we shadowThe numbers of our host, and make discoveryErr in report of us. Nay, he's a thief too: have you not heard men say That Time comes stealing on by night and day? If 'a be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way, Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day?Re-enter LUCIANA with a purseADRIANA. Why, Hal, 'tis my Vocation Hal: 'Tis no sin for aman to labour in his Vocation Pointz. But words are words; I never yet did hear That the bruised heart was pierced through the ear. Sweet Earle, diuorce not wisedom from your Honor Mor. He shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we asmerry as the day is long. But 'tis strange:And oftentimes to win us to our harm,The instruments of darkness tell us truths;Win us with honest trifles, to betray'sIn deepest consequence. For mine own part,When I said banish him, I said 'twas pity. Fie, Cousin Percy, how you crosse my Father Hotsp. I am sorry For your displeasure, but all will sure be well. You know your office, brother: You must be father to your brother's daughter, And give her to young Claudio. What a full fortune does the thick-lips owe, If he can carry't thus! IAGO. O gentle lady,'Tis not for you to hear what I can speak:The repetition, in a woman's ear,Would murder as it fell. A man may fish with the worm that hath eat of a king, and eat of the fish that hath fed of that worm. Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep; Farewell to thee too, Strato. My way is now to hie home to his house, And tell his wife that, being lunatic, He rush'd into my house and took perforce My ring away. Or to be naked with her friend in bed An hour or more, not meaning any harm? OTHELLO. Why should we, in the compass of a pale, Keep law and form and due proportion, Showing, as in a model, our firm estate, When our sea-walled garden, the whole land, Is full of weeds; her fairest flowers chok'd up, Her fruit trees all unprun'd, her hedges You see (my good Wenches) how men ofMerit are sought after: the vndeseruer may sleepe, whenthe man of Action is call'd on. At first the infant, Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms; Then the whining school-boy, with his satchel And shining morning face, creeping like snail Unwillingly to school. It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely accus'd, thePrince and Claudio mightily abus'd, and Don John is the author ofall, who is fled and gone. Sirs, cover the while; theDuke will drink under this tree. Yet here, Laertes! aboard, aboard, for shame! The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail, And you are stay? for. A man that all his time Hath founded his good fortunes on your love, Shared dangers with you OTHELLO. O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth, That I am meek and gentle with these butchers! Thou art the ruins of the noblest man That ever lived in the tide of times. And this man Is now become a god, and Cassius is A wretched creature and must bend his body If Caesar carelessly but nod on him. A very reverent body; ay, such a one as a man may not speak of without he say 'Sir-reverence. If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people,I may be heard, I would crave a word or two;The which shall turn you to no further harmThan so much loss of time. Go on, And see wheer Brutus be alive or dead, And bring us word unto Octavius' tent How everything is chanced. What should I do? I confess it is my shame to be sofond, but it is not in my virtue to amend it. Re-enter Messala, with Brutus, young Cato, and others. Lord, I couldnot endure a husband with a beard on his face. O, they take the part of a better wrestler thanmyself. I pray you, one of you question yond man If he for gold will give us any food; I faint almost to death. To solemnize this day the glorious sun Stays in his course and plays the alchemist, Turning with splendour of his precious eye The meagre cloddy earth to glittering gold. And Fellow's, Soldiers, Friends,Better consider what you haue to do,That I that haue not well the gift of Tongue,Can lift your blood vp with perswasion. O, this is the poison of deep grief; it springs All from her father? death. I pray you, daughter, sing, or express yourself in a morecomfortable sort; if my son were my husband, I should freelierrejoice in that absence wherein he won honour than in theembracements of his bed where he would show most love. My Lord, Sir Iohn Vmfreuill turn'd me backeWith ioyfull tydings; and (being better hors'd)Out-rod me. Thy loue isworth a Million: thou ow'st me thy loue Host. Doe me no slander, Dowglas: by my Life,And I dare well maintaine it with my Life,If well-respected Honor bid me on,I hold as little counsaile with weake feare,As you, my Lord, or any Scot that this day liues. When I am cold he heats me with beating; when I am warm he cools me with beating. But till that time Come not thou near me; and when that time comes, Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not; As till that time I shall not pity thee. You are now within a foot Of th' extreme verge. O Lear, Lear, Lear! And yet not so; since I am sure my love's More richer than my tongue. O! grief hath chang'd me since you saw me last; And careful hours with time's deformed hand Have written strange defeatures in my face. 'My mistress, sir,' quoth I; 'Hang up thy mistress; I know not thy mistress; out on thy mistress. Now, by my life, this day grows wondrous hot; Some airy devil hovers in the sky And pours down mischief. [Enter, with drum and colours, Malcolm, old Siward, Macduff, &c. There was a time when all the body's membersRebell'd against the belly; thus accus'd it:--That only like a gulf it did remainI' the midst o' the body, idle and unactive,Still cupboarding the viand, never bearingLike labour with the rest; where th' other For Lord Hamlet, Believe so much in him, that he is young; And with a larger tether may he walk Than may be given you: in few, Ophelia, Do not believe his vows; for they are brokers,?Not of that dye which their investments show,36 But mere implorators o Look, I draw a sword against conspirators; When think you that the sword goes up again? That handkerchief thou speak'st of I found by fortune and did give my husband, For often with a solemn earnestness, More than indeed belong'd to such a trifle, He begg'd of me to steal it. No, Leonato, I never tempted her with word too large, But, as a brother to his sister, show'd Bashful sincerity and comely love. If the balance of our lives had not one scale of reason to poise another of sensuality, the blood and basenessof our natures would conduct us to most preposterousconclusions. And, I think, if my breast had not been made of faith, and my heart of steel, She had transform'd me to a curtal dog, and made me turn i' th'wheel. Here, stand behind this bulk; straight will he come. And I'll keep him so That he shall not offend your Majesty. Of thy deep duty more impression showThan that of common sons. Your royal presences be rul'd by me: Do like the mutines of Jerusalem, Be friends awhile, and both conjointly bend Your sharpest deeds of malice on this town. But if these, As I am sure they do, bear fire enough To kindle cowards and to steel with valor The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen, What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress? MOWBRAY. Then comes my fit again: I had else been perfect;Whole as the marble, founded as the rock;As broad and general as the casing air:But now I am cabin'd, cribb'd, confin'd, bound inTo saucy doubts and fears. How? the Prince is a Iacke, a Sneake-Cuppe:and if hee were heere, I would cudgell him like a Dogge,if hee would say so. Even now we hous'd him in the abbey here, And now he's there, past thought of human reason. I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so proper. Where the dead body is bestow?, my lord, We cannot get from him. As I was then aduised by my learned Councel, inthe lawes of this Land-seruice, I did not come Iust. What do you think Of marching to Philippi presently? BASTARD. Sonnes to Henry the Fourth, & brethren to Henry 5. Nay, I hear nothing: his mother and his wifeHear nothing from him. They call drinking deepe, dyingScarlet; and when you breath in your watering, thenthey cry hem, and bid you play it off. In Parthia did I take thee prisoner, And then I swore thee, saving of thy life, That whatsoever I did bid thee do, Thou shouldst attempt it. Search every acre in the high-grown field And bring him to our eye. Vex not yourself, nor strive not with your breath; For all in vain comes counsel to his ear. She is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then; forI have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamt ofunhappiness and wak'd herself with laughing. Let's to the Capitol:--would half my wealthWould buy this for a lie!SICINIUS. But then I saw no harm, and then I heard Each syllable that breath made up between them. We hear not of him, neither need we fear him;His remedies are tame i' the present peaceAnd quietness of the people, which beforeWere in wild hurry. I am a scribbled form drawn with a pen Upon a parchment, and against this fire Do I shrink up. Your silence most offends me, and to be merry bestbecomes you, for out o' question you were born in a merry hour. Enter PANDULPH KING PHILIP. I jest not; I willmake it good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare. Something that hath a reference to my state: No longer Celia, but Aliena. "--Then fly, false thanes,And mingle with the English epicures:The mind I sway by, and the heart I bear,Shall never sag with doubt nor shake with fear. We meet, like men, that had forgot to speake War. And, England, if my love thou hold?t at aught,?As my great power thereof may give thee sense, Since yet thy cicatrice looks raw and red After the Danish sword, and thy free awe Pays homage to us,?hou mayst not coldly set Our sovereign process; which im 
'Where is the thousand marks I gave thee, villain?' 'The pig' quoth I 'is burn'd'; 'My gold!' quoth he. --Come, put mine armour on; give me my staff:--Seyton, send out. You look pale and gaze And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder To see the strange impatience of the heavens. For certain, sir, he is not: I have a fileOf all the gentry: there is Siward's sonAnd many unrough youths, that even nowProtest their first of manhood. Wilt thou suffer them To make a rescue?OFFICER. Indeed, your drums, being beaten, will cry out; And so shall you, being beaten. Well, sir, I'll bring you to our master Lear And leave you to attend him. What shall I say? To safeguard thine own life The best way is to venge my Gloucester's death. Ay, my good lord: safe in a ditch he bides,With twenty trenched gashes on his head;The least a death to nature. I muse my motherDoes not approve me further, who was wontTo call them woollen vassals, things createdTo buy and sell with groats; to show bare headsIn congregations, to yawn, be still, and wonder,When one but of my ordinance stood upTo speak of peace or Westeale as in a Castle, cocksure: we haue the receit of Fernseede,we walke inuisible Cham. My mother dead! Re-enter HUBERT HUBERT. What,shall we be merry? shall we haue a Play extempory Prin. The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be notwooed in good time. Though I could scape shot-free at London, I fearthe shot heere: here's no scoring, but vpon the pate. Thou art a boil, A plague sore, an embossed carbuncle In my corrupted blood. Nor earth to me give food, nor heaven light! Sport and repose lock from me day and night! To desperation turn my trust and hope! An anchor? cheer in prison be my scope! Each opposite that blanks the face of joy Meet what I would have well, and it destro With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enoughin his purse, such a man would win any woman in the world--if 'a could get her good will. Indeed, my lord, The melancholy Jaques grieves at that; And, in that kind, swears you do more usurp Than doth your brother that hath banish'd you. Fare-thee-well!These evils thou repeat'st upon thyselfHave banish'd me from Scotland. But, in the verity of extolment, I take him to be a soul of great article, and his infusion of such dearth and rareness as, to make true diction of him, his semblable is his mirror, and who else would trace him, his umbrage, nothing more. Enter Cassio and certain Officers with torches. Our fraughtage, sir, I have convey'd aboard; and I have bought The oil, the balsamum, and aqua-vitx. Thrift, thrift, Horatio! The funeral bak? meats Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables. I pledge your Grace:And if you knew what paines I haue bestow'd,To breede this present Peace,You would drinke freely: but my loue to ye,Shall shew it selfe more openly hereafter Bish. Ay, that's the way; Dull not device by coldness and delay. Was this ambition? Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, And sure he is an honorable man. O perjured woman! Thou dost stone my heart, And makest me call what I intend to do A murther, which I thought a sacrifice. Please you to march;And four shall quickly draw out my command,Which men are best inclin'd. You urg'd me as a judge; but I had rather You would have bid me argue like a father. Great business must be wrought ere noon:Upon the corner of the moonThere hangs a vaporous drop profound;I'll catch it ere it come to ground:And that, distill'd by magic sleights,Shall raise such artificial sprites,As, by the strength of their illusion,ShIf he say so, may his pernicious soul Rot half a grain a day! He lies to the heart. My heart's subdued Even to the very quality of my lord. Away, my friends! New flight, And happy newness, that intends old right. Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises, Which is a great way growing on the south, Weighing the youthful season of the year. There is something in the wind, that wecannot get in. Why, what's the matter? BRABANTIO. Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong For the whole world. I lov? Ophelia; forty thousand brothers Could not, with all their quantity of love, Make up my sum. Avoid then, fiend! What tell'st thou meof supping? Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress; I conjure thee to leave me and be gone. There is no fear in him-let him not die, For he will live and laugh at this hereafter. If he break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fearand trembling. I thank you, general,But cannot make my heart consent to takeA bribe to pay my sword: I do refuse it;And stand upon my common part with thoseThat have beheld the doing. But how shal we part with them in setting forth? Poyn. It is too late; the life of all his blood Is touch'd corruptibly, and his pure brain. Consider this:--he has been bred i' the warsSince 'a could draw a sword, and is ill school'dIn bolted language; meal and bran togetherHe throws without distinction. Which dreams, indeed, are ambition; for the very substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream. You have displaced the mirth, broke the good meeting,With most admir'd disorder. She isat the court, and no less beloved of her uncle than his own daughter; and never two ladies loved as they do. Exeunt DUKE, train, and LE BEAU CELIA. That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again, Repair to the senate-house. I told him you were coming: His answer was, 'The worse. No, no (my Lord) note this: the King is wearieOf daintie, and such picking Grieuances:For hee hath found, to end one doubt by Death,Reuiues two greater in the Heires of Life. I am he that is so love-shak'd; I pray you tell meyour remedy. They will scarcelybelieve this without trial. I beseech your Maiesty make vp,Least your retirement do amaze your friends King. But in these casesWe still have judgement here; that we but teachBloody instructions, which being taught, returnTo plague the inventor: this even-handed justiceCommends the ingredients of our poison'd chaliceTo our own lips. Your statue spouting blood in many pipes, In which so many smiling Romans bathed, Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck Reviving blood, and that great men shall press For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance. O mysweet Harry sayes she, how many hast thou kill'd to day?Giue my Roane horse a drench (sayes hee) and answeres,some fourteene, an houre after: a trifle, a trifle. England, impatient of your just demands, Hath put himself in arms. Not all the dukes in wat'rish Burgundy Can buy this unpriz'd precious maid of me. I am glad to see you well: Horatio,?r I do forget myself. Murder, as hating what himself hath done, Doth lay it open to urge on revenge. I shall between this and supper tell you most strange thingsfrom Rome; all tending to the good of their adversaries. So then the Volsces stand but as at first;Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make roadUpon's again. If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell whoshould down. Name not the god, thou boy of tears,--CORIOLANUS. Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not shipp'd? GREEN. Alas, my lord, what may you mean by that? OTHELLO. A servingman, proud in heart and mind; that curl'd myhair, wore gloves in my cap; serv'd the lust of my mistress' heartand did the act of darkness with her; swore as many oaths as Ispake words, and broke them in the sweet face of heaven; one that slept  Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd,Who is the sink o' the body,--MENENIUS. Enter Sir John the Bastard and Conrade, his companion. Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on thewindy side of care. God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is exceedingheavy. He knows not what he says; and vain is it That we present us to him. I pray you do not fall in love with me, For I am falser than vows made in wine; Besides, I like you not. The king, sir, hath wager? with him six Barbary horses: against the which he has imponed, as I take it, six French rapiers and poniards, with their assigns, as girdle, hangers, and so: three of the carriages, in faith, are very dear to fancy, very respo If I should pay your worship those again, Perchance you will not bear them patiently. What say these young ones? What say you, my niece? BLANCH. Is he not jealous? DESDEMONA. She must have change, she must; therefore put moneyin thy purse. Are yet two Romans living such as these? The last of all the Romans, fare thee well! It is impossible that ever Rome Should breed thy fellow. [Seats herself on theground] Here I and sorrows sit; Here is my throne, bid kings come bow to it. Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known, Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back, For I will slay myself. The rest is labor, which is not us'd for you:I'll be myself the harbinger, and make joyfulThe hearing of my wife with your approach;So, humbly take my leave. '--O, a kissLong as my exile, sweet as my revenge;Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, that kissI carried from thee, dear; and my true lipHath virgin'd it e'er since. I kneel'd before him;'Twas very faintly he said 'Rise'; dismissed meThus, with his speechless hand: what he would do,He sent in writing after me; what he would not,Bound with an oath to yield to his conditions:So that all hope is vain,Unless his noble m O shame! where is thy blush? Rebellious hell, If thou canst mutine in a matron? bones, To flaming youth let virtue be as wax, And melt in her own fire: proclaim no shame When the compulsive ardour gives the charge, Since frost itself as actively doth bu I have some marks of yours upon my pate, Some of my mistress' marks upon my shoulders, But not a thousand marks between you both. Bless thee, good man's son,from the foul fiend! Five fiends have been in poor Tom at once:of lust, as Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness; Mahu,of stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of mopping and mowing, who since possesses chambermaids I see a good amendment of life in thee: FromPraying, to Purse-taking Fal. Who was the Thane lives yet;But under heavy judgement bears that lifeWhich he deserves to lose. If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son, As you have whisper'd faithfully you were, And as mine eye doth his effigies witness Most truly limn'd and living in your face, Be truly welcome hither. SCENE 1A street before a prioryEnter SECOND MERCHANT and ANGELOANGELO. I tell thee, fellow,Thy general is my lover: I have beenThe book of his good acts, whence men have readHis fame unparallel'd, haply amplified;For I have ever verified my friends,--Of whom he's chief,--with all the size that verityWould without lapsing suBoth which we doubt not, but your MaiestieShall soone enioy King. Will you put out mine eyes, These eyes that never did nor never shall So much as frown on you? HUBERT. My gracious Lord, my Father,This sleepe is sound indeede: this is a sleepe,That from this Golden Rigoll hath diuorc'dSo many English Kings. Oh yet, for heauens sake, go not to these Warrs;The Time was (Father) when you broke your word,When you were more endeer'd to it, then now,When your owne Percy, when my heart-deereHarry,Threw many a Northward looke, to see his FatherBring vp his Powres: Contending with the fretful elements; Bids the wind blow the earth into the sea, Or swell the curled waters 'bove the main, That things might change or cease; tears his white hair, Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage, Catch in their fury and m Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy foot; My life thou shalt command, but not my shame: The one my duty owes; but my fair name, Despite of death, that lives upon my grave To dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have. '"When thou impressest, what are precepts worth Of stale example? When thou wilt inflame, How coldly those impediments stand forth, Of wealth, of filial fear, law, kindred, fame! Love's arms are peace, 'gainst rule, 'gainst sense, 'gainstshame. ' Well, this was Signior Benedick thatsaid so. [Exeunt Leonato and Messenger. For do but stand upon the foaming shore, The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds; The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane, Seems to cast water on the burning bear, And quench the guards of the ever-fixed pole. So had you need; I scarce can speak to thank you for myself. Had I so lauish of my presence beene,So common hackney'd in the eyes of men,So stale and cheape to vulgar Company;Opinion, that did helpe me to the Crowne,Had still kept loyall to possession,And left me in reputelesse banishment,A fellow of no marke, norStay but a little: for my Cloud of DignitieIs held from falling, with so weake a winde,That it will quickly drop: my Day is dimme. Ay, my good lord; your royal preparationMakes us hear something. And I could sing, would weeping do me good, And never borrow any tear of thee. [Enter Banquo, preceeded by Fleance with a torch. I tellhim we shall stay here at the least a month, and he heartly prays some occasion may detain us longer. But at this hour the house doth keep itself; There's none within. Would you would bear your fortune like a man! OTHELLO. Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy. Prince Iohn, your Sonne, doth kisse your Graces Hand:Mowbray, the Bishop, Scroope, Hastings, and all,Are brought to the Correction of your Law. Then was that Noble WorcesterToo soone ta'ne prisoner: and that furious Scot,(The bloody Dowglas) whose well-labouring swordHad three times slaine th' appearance of the King,Gan vaile his stomacke, and did grace the shameOf those that turn'd their backe For mine own partno offense to the general, nor anyman of qualityI hope to be saved. Watch you tonight; for the command, I'll lay't uponyou. Have you heard of no likely wars toward 'twixt the twoDukes of Cornwall and Albany? Edm. But soft, who haue we heere?Did you not tell me this Fat man was dead? Prin. --Yes, yes, yes; the Senate has lettersfrom the general, wherein he gives my son the whole name of thewar: he hath in this action outdone his former deeds doubly. Ah sirra (quoth-a) we shall doe nothing but eate,and make good cheere, and praise heauen for the merrieyeere: when flesh is cheape, and Females deere, and lustieLads rome heere, and there: so merrily, and euer amongso merrily Fal. I would the state of time had first beene whole,Ere he by sicknesse had beene visited:His health was neuer better worth then now Hotsp. Our hostess keeps her state; but, in best time,We will require her welcome. Let but the commons hear this testament Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read And they would go and kiss dead Caesar's wounds And dip their napkins in his sacred blood, Yea, beg a hair of him for memory, And, dying, mention it within their wills, Bequ The other motive, Why to a public count I might not go, Is the great love the general gender bear him; Who, dipping all his faults in their affection, Would, like the spring that turneth wood to stone, Convert his gyves to graces; so that my arrows, Too Let us after him,Whose care is gone before to bid us welcome:It is a peerless kinsman. I do beseech your Majesty impute his words To wayward sickliness and age in him. 89 This world is not for aye; nor ?is not strange That even our loves should with our fortunes change; For ?is a question left us yet to prove, Whether love lead fortune, or else fortune love. Come, where is this young gallant that is so desirousto lie with his mother earth? ORLANDO. [Exit an Attendant. Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world one manbut he will wear his cap with suspicion? Shall I never see a bachelor of threescore again? Go to, i' faith! An thou wiltneeds thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it and sighaway Sundays. 'Tis not in thee To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train, To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes, And, in conclusion, to oppose the bolt Against my coming in. At this time We sweat and bleed: the friend hath lost his friend; And the best quarrels, in the heat, are curs'd By those that feel their sharpness. Will your Grace command me any service to the world'send? LEPIDUS. By heaven, lady, you shall have no cause To curse the fair proceedings of this day. I would the gods had nothing else to doBut to confirm my curses! Could I meet 'emBut once a day, it would unclog my heartOf what lies heavy to't. O, that thou wert not, poor distressed soul!ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. But what talk we of fatherswhen there is such a man as Orlando? CELIA. But it is doubtful yet Whether Caesar will come forth today or no, For he is superstitious grown of late, Quite from the main opinion he held once Of fantasy, of dreams, and ceremonies. True is it that we have seen better days, And have with holy bell been knoll'd to church, And sat at good men's feasts, and wip'd our eyes Of drops that sacred pity hath engend'red; And therefore sit you down in gentleness, And take upon command what he Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus,yet nature finds itself scourg'd by the sequent effects. Tell me, my daughters (Since now we will divest us both of rule, Interest of territory, cares of state), Which of you shall we say doth love us most? That we our largest bounty may extend Where nature doth with merit challenge. Enter [Oswald the] Steward. Heaven bless the isle ofCyprus and our noble general Othello! Exeunt. Your servants everHave theirs, themselves, and what is theirs, in compt,To make their audit at your highness' pleasure,Still to return your own. Sirrah, if any ask you for your master, Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter. Thus Rosalinde of many parts By heavenly synod was devis'd, Of many faces, eyes, and hearts, To have the touches dearest priz'd. Because that I familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool and chat with you, Your sauciness will jest upon my love, And make a common of my serious hours. If you miscarry, Your business of the world hath so an end, And machination ceases. Robert Shallow:Master Sure-card as I thinke? Shal. I am thinking, brother, of a prediction I read this otherday, what should follow these eclipses. This is the strangest Tale that e're I heard Prin. Do, young sir; your reputation shall not therefore be misprised: we will make it our suit to the Duke that the wrestling might not go forward. I haue checkt him for it, and the yong Lion repents:Marry not in ashes and sacke-cloath, but in newSilke, and old Sacke Iust. Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope hisdoublet and offered them his throat to cut. There is a dish of Lether-coats for you Shal. Besides, his picture I will send far and near, that all the kingdom May have due note of him, and of my land, Loyal and natural boy, I'll work the means To make thee capable. A field of battle between the Roman and the Volsciancamps. His noble kinsman-most degenerate king! But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing, Yet seek no shelter to avoid the storm; We see the wind sit sore upon our sails, And yet we strike not, but securely perish. How is't with you, my lord? OTHELLO. Call't not a plot:The people cry you mock'd them; and of late, When corn was given them gratis, you repin'd;Scandal'd the suppliants for the people,--call'd themTime-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness. The sun of heaven, methought, was loath to set, But stay'd and made the western welkin blush, When English measure backward their own ground In faint retire. I thinke this is the most villanous house in alLondon rode for Fleas: I am stung like a Tench 1. O Lord sir, Ile be sworne vpon all the Books inEngland, I could finde in my heart Poin. You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin; Had you first died, and he been thus trod down, He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay. My due, from thee, is this Imperiall Crowne,Which (as immediate from thy Place, and Blood)Deriues it selfe to me. Where are you Sir Iohn? Come, off with your Boots. O Spartan dog, More fell than anguish, hunger, or the sea! Look on the tragic loading of this bed; This is thy work. How often he had met you, sword to sword;That of all things upon the earth he hatedYour person most; that he would pawn his fortunesTo hopeless restitution, so he mightBe call'd your vanquisher. Enter Leonato and the Constable [Dogberry] and the Headborough[verges]. By the pricking of my thumbs,Something wicked this way comes:--Open, locks, whoever knocks![Enter Macbeth. O, you and I have heard our fathers say There was a Brutus once that would have brook'd The eternal devil to keep his state in Rome As easily as a king. To conclude: this drudge or diviner laid claim to me; call'd me Dromio; swore I was assur'd to her; told me what privy marks I had about me, as, the mark of my shoulder, the mole in my neck, the great wart on my left arm, that I, amaz'd, ran from her as The children thus dispos'd, my wife and I, Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd, Fast'ned ourselves at either end the mast, And, floating straight, obedient to the stream, Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought. [ROSALIND swoons] CELIA. Three, they say; but 'tis thought of every one Coriolanus willcarry it. This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the Duke Instantly know, and of that letter too. So bee gone,We will not now be troubled with reply,We offer faire, take it aduisedly. There,?y blessing with thee! No faith, proud mistress, hope not after it; 'Tis not your inky brows, your black silk hair, Your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream, That can entame my spirits to your worship. God forgive us our sins! Gentlemen, let's lookto our business. I amsorry for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and herguardian. Good Cousin be aduis'd, stirre not to night Vern. Some must go off; and yet, by these I see,So great a day as this is cheaply bought. How should I your true love know From another one? By his cockle bat and?staff And his sandal shoon. Then thus: I have from Le Port Blanc, a bay In Brittany, receiv'd intelligence That Harry Duke of Hereford, Rainold Lord Cobham, That late broke from the Duke of Exeter, His brother, Archbishop late of Canterbury, Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston, In this point charge him home, that he affectsTyrannical power: if he evade us there,Enforce him with his envy to the people;And that the spoil got on the AntiatesWas ne'er distributed. Searching the window for a flint I found This paper thus seal'd up, and I am sure It did not lie there when I went to bed. Know I these men that come along with you? CASSIUS. I have a daughter,?ave whilst she is mine,?Who, in her duty and obedience, mark, Hath given me this: now gather, and surmise. I said thou hadst a fine wit: 'True,' said she, 'a fine little one. It is said: 'Many a man knows noend of his goods. How he solicits heaven,Himself best knows: but strangely-visited people,All swoln and ulcerous, pitiful to the eye,The mere despair of surgery, he cures;Hanging a golden stamp about their necks,Put on with holy prayers: and 'tis spoken,To the succeeding Shall I? content: This Chayre shall bee myState, this Dagger my Scepter, and this Cushion myCrowne Prin. I am settled, and bend upEach corporal agent to this terrible feat. You see this fellow that is gone before; He is a soldier fit to stand by Caesar And give direction. Saturne and Venus this yeere in Coniunction?What sayes the Almanack to that? Poin. May be he will not touch young Arthur's life, But hold himself safe in his prisonment. England, shall giue him Office, Honor, Might:For the Fift Harry, from curb'd License pluckesThe muzzle of Restraint; and the wilde DoggeShall flesh his tooth in euery Innocent. Talke not of dying, I am out of feareOf death, or deaths hand, for this one halfe yeare. What letters hast there?I can but thanke you Mess. They bore him barefac? on the bier Hey no nonny, nonny, hey nonny And on his grave rain? many a tear. It is well said, Sir; and it is well said, indeede,too: Better accommodated? it is good, yea indeede isit: good phrases are surely, and euery where very commendable. Thanks, noble peer! The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear. Enter the King, Northumberland, Worcester, Hotspurre, Sir WalterBlunt,and others. Farewell, Monsieur Traveller; look you lisp and wear strange suits, disable all the benefits of your own country,be out of love with your nativity, and almost chide God formaking you that countenance you are; or I will scarce think you have swam in a go Then with the losers let it sympathize,For nothing can seeme foule to those that win. O Gentlemen, the time of life is short;To spend that shortnesse basely, were too long. In faith, too much; I find it still when I have list to sleep. 'Tis very true Lord Bardolfe, for indeedIt was yong Hotspurres case, at Shrewsbury L. Do, with like timorous accent and dire yell As when, by night and negligence, the fire Is spied in populous cities. Swearest thou, vngracious Boy? henceforthne're looke on me: thou art violently carryed away fromGrace: there is a Deuill haunts thee, in the likenesse of afat old Man; a Tunne of Man is thy Companion: Whydo'st thou conuerse with that Trunke of Humors, t By computation and mine host's report I could not speak with Dromio since at first I sent him from the mart. <Exeunt ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUSDROMIO OF SYRACUSE. If sir, you come with news from the Court, I take it, thereis but two wayes, either to vtter them, or to concealethem. I hope, for my brother's justification, he wrote this butas an essay or taste of my virtue. Take heed o' th' foul fiend; obey thy parents: keep thyword justly; swear not; commit not with man's sworn spouse; setnot thy sweet heart on proud array. I pr'ythee now, my son,Go to them with this bonnet in thy hand;And thus far having stretch'd it,--here be with them,--Thy knee bussing the stones,--for in such busines Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorantMore learned than the ears,--waving tWhy, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer withthy uncover'd body this extremity of the skies. By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to hearsuch a foolish song. I tell thee, Syracusian, twenty years Have I been patron to Antipholus, During which time he ne'er saw Syracuse. Thy mistress' marks! What mistress,slave, hast thou?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. And I another,So weary with disasters, tugg'd with fortune,That I would set my life on any chance,To mend it or be rid on't. That hand which had the strength, even at your door. So is he mine; and in such bloody distance,That every minute of his being thrustsAgainst my near'st of life; and though I couldWith barefac'd power sweep him from my sight,And bid my will avouch it, yet I must not,For certain friends that are both his anThe Southerne windeDoth play the Trumpet to his purposes,And by his hollow whistling in the Leaues,Fortels a Tempest, and a blust'ring day King. When we are born, we cry that we are come To this great stage of fools. 'Shall I,' says she, 'that have so oft encount'red him with scorn, write tohim that I love him?'" Leon. Nor I neither; but I can tell why a snail has a house. Tender yourself more dearly; Or,?ot to crack the wind of the poor phrase, Wronging it thus,?ou?l tender me a fool. Hide thee, thou bloody hand; Thou perjur'd, and thou simular man of virtue That art incestuous. I warrant you, that man is not aliue,Might so haue tempted him, as you haue done,Without the taste of danger, and reproofe:But doe not vse it oft, let me entreat you Worc. Yes; I think he is not a pick-purse nor a horse-stealer;but for his verity in love, I do think him as concave as covered goblet or a worm-eaten nut. Blunt, leade him hence, and see you guard him sure. Weapons, weapons, weapons![They all bustle about CORIOLANUS. Midnight, assist our moan, Help us to sigh and groan Heavily, heavily, Graves, yawn and yield your dead, Till death be uttered Heavily, heavily. Now He that made me knows I see thee ill; Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill. I know that, but I would have thee hence and here again. Nay, this was but his dream. Tush, fear not, man! We'll tip thy horns with gold, And all Europa shall rejoice at thee, As once Europa did at lusty Jove When he would play the noble beast in love. Send Colleuile, with his Confederates,To Yorke, to present Execution. Where art thou? Unlocks thedoor. Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm (his conscience) find no impediment to the contrary, to be thetrumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself. The King is kinde:And well wee know, the KingKnowes at what time to promise, when to pay. Your hand: most welcome![Exeunt CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS. Forget, forgive; conclude and be agreed: Our doctors say this is no month to bleed. ?is now the very witching time of night, When churchyards yawn, and hell itself breathes out Contagion to this world: now could I drink hot blood, And do such bitter business as the day Would quake to look on. Enter, below, Brabantio, in his nightgown, and Servants with torches. My Lord, I beseech you, giue me leaue to goethrough Gloucestershire: and when you come to Court,stand my good Lord, 'pray, in your good report Iohn. How say you, Cassio? Is henot a most profane and liberal counselor? CASSIO. [As they are going out,] enter Edgar [disguised]. As the event stamps them; but they have a good cover, they show well outward. It were as possiblefor me to say I loved nothing so well as you. <Exeunt all but ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS, DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, and DROMIO OF EPHESUSDROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I have nothing with this answer, Hamlet; these words are not mine. Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me. The shepherd knows not thunder from a taborMore than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue From every meaner man. Why??ne fair daughter, and no more, The which he loved passing well. You two are old men:tell me one thing that I shall ask you. Come, madam, and come, Richard, we must speed For France, for France, for it is more than need. I, but tis like that they will know vs by ourhorses, by our habits, and by euery other appointment tobe our selues Poy. Do! Kill thy physician, and the fee bestow Upon the foul disease. He chid the sistersWhen first they put the name of king upon me,And bade them speak to him; then, prophet-like,They hail'd him father to a line of kings:Upon my head they plac'd a fruitless crown,And put a barren sceptre in my gripe,Thence to be wrench' There are many events in the womb oftime which will be delivered. There is a tide in the affairs of men Which taken at the flood leads on to fortune; Omitted, all the voyage of their life Is bound in shallows and in miseries. They that mean virtuously and yet do so, The devil their virtue tempts and they tempt heaven. O, what a world is this, when what is comely Envenoms him that bears it! ORLANDO. He cannot flatter, he! An honest mind and plainhe must speak truth! An they will take it, so; if not, he's plain. Since his majesty went into the field, I have seen herrise from her bed, throw her nightgown upon her, unlock hercloset, take forth paper, fold it, write upon it, read it,afterwards seal it, and again return to bed; yet all thiswhile in a most fast sleepNo, Cassius, for the eye sees not itself But by reflection, by some other things. Are you a married man or a bachelor? SECOND CITIZEN. Brutus goes into the pulpit. If I trauell but foure foot by the squire further afoote, I shall breake my winde. Speak, hands, for me! Casca first, then the other Conspirators and Marcus Brutus stab Caesar. But, peace!--for from broad words, and 'cause he fail'dHis presence at the tyrant's feast, I hear,Macduff lives in disgrace. Brought you Caesar home? Why are you breathless, and why stare you so? CASCA. With many Holiday and Lady tearmeHe question'd me: Among the rest, demandedMy Prisoners, in your Maiesties behalfe. Sir Robert's son! Ay, thou unreverend boy, Sir Robert's son! Why scorn'st thou at Sir Robert? He is Sir Robert's son, and so art thou. She that was ever fair and never proud, Had tongue at will and yet was never loud, Never lack'd gold and yet went never gay, Fled from her wish and yet said, "Now I may"; She that, being anger'd, her revenge being nigh, Bade her wrong stay and her displ That you have wrong'd me doth appear in this: You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pella For taking bribes here of the Sardians, Wherein my letters, praying on his side, Because I knew the man, were slighted off. And you degenerate, you ingrate revolts, You bloody Neroes, ripping up the womb Of your dear mother England, blush for shame; For your own ladies and pale-visag'd maids, Like Amazons, come tripping after drums, Their thimbles into armed gauntlets change But let me conjure you, by the rights of our fellowship, by the consonancy of our youth, by the obligation of our ever-preserved love, and by what more dear a better proposer could charge you withal, be even and direct with me, whether you were sent for How? haz he the leysure to be sicke now,In such a iustling time? Who leades his power?Vnder whose Gouernment come they along? Mess. These profound heaves You must translate: ?is fit we understand them. The question then (Lord Hastings) standeth thusWhether our present fiue and twenty thousandMay hold-vp-head, without Northumberland: Hast. What's the boy Malcolm?Was he not born of woman? The spirits that knowAll mortal consequences have pronounc'd me thus,--"Fear not, Macbeth; no man that's born of womanShall e'er have power upon thee. Nay, not so neither: but I take him to be the greater soldier. Mistress, both man and master is possess'd; I know it by their pale and deadly looks. If he had been forgotten,It had been as a gap in our great feast,And all-thing unbecoming. There's some among you have beheld me fighting;Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me. Thou hast stolne that, which after some few howresWere thine, without offence: and at my deathThou hast seal'd vp my expectation. Hence, avaunt! ExitDesdemona. Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile; Filths savour but themselves. I'll go sleep, if I can; if I cannot, I'll rail against all the first-born of Egypt. There is so much that thou wilt kill mestraight: Kill Brutus, and be honor'd in his death. Do you not come your tardy son to chide, That, laps? in time and passion, lets go by The important acting of your dread command? O, say! Ghost. If our father carryauthority with such dispositions as he bears, this last surrender ofhis will but offend us. When he lies along,After your way his tale pronounc'd shall buryHis reasons with his body. These tedious old fools! [Enter Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion; I do repent me that I put it to you. I'll go finda shadow, and sigh till he come. One that will play the devil, sir, with you, An 'a may catch your hide and you alone. Saint George, that swing'd the dragon, and e'er since Sits on's horse back at mine hostess' door, Teach us some fence! [To AUSTRIA] Sirrah, were I at home, At your den, sirrah, with your lioness, I would set an ox-head to your lion's hide, And make a mo Let our just censuresAttend the true event, and put we onIndustrious soldiership. We shall find of him A shrewd contriver; and you know his means, If he improve them, may well stretch so far As to annoy us all, which to prevent, Let Antony and Caesar fall together. Is thy master stirring?--Our knocking has awak'd him; here he comes. As heart can thinke:There is not such a word spoke of in Scotland,At this Dreame of Feare. Fare you well; had you such a loss as I, I could give better comfort than you do. Good Doctor Pinch, you are a conjurer: Establish him in his true sense again, And I will please you what you will demand. How many ages hence Shall this our lofty scene be acted over In states unborn and accents yet unknown! BRUTUS. Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band; that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; on that thinks a man always going to bed, and says 'God give you good rest!'ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I am none of these, my lord; I beseech your pardon. No, by this heavenly light! EMILIA. But here's my husband, And so much duty as my mother show'd To you, preferring you before her father, So much I challenge that I may profess Due to the Moor, my lord. Come, be a man! Drown thyself? Drown cats and blind puppies. Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand, Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs. With all my heart Ile sit, and heare her sing:By that time will our Booke, I thinke, be drawne Glend. A letter for me! It gives me an estate of seven years'health; in which time I will make a lip at the physician: themost sovereign prescription in Galen is but empiricutic, and, tothis preservative, of no better report than a horse-drench. Shall Rome stand under one man's awe? What, Rome? My ancestors did from the streets of Rome The Tarquin drive, when he was call'd a king. Beware Of entrance to a quarrel; but, being in, Bear? that the opposed may beware of thee. Hath been! is it ended, then? Our state thinks not so;they are in a most warlike preparation, and hope to come uponthem in the heat of their division. --The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thyparticular prosperity, and love thee no worse than thy old fatherMenenius does! O my son! my son! thou art preparing fire for us;look thee, here's water to quench it. He'll watch the horologe a double set, If drink rock not his cradle. What, Oswald, ho! [To the Fool] You, sir, more knave than fool, after yourmaster! Fool. The Dauphin is preparing hitherward, Where God He knows how we shall answer him; For in a night the best part of my pow'r, As I upon advantage did remove, Were in the Washes all unwarily Devoured by the unexpected flood. My money is almostspent; I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled; and I think the issue will be, I shall have so much experience for my pains;and so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return againto Venice. Of all men else I have avoided thee:But get thee back; my soul is too much charg'dWith blood of thine already. Go tell the lords o' the city I am here:Deliver them this paper; having read it,Bid them repair to the market-place: where I,Even in theirs and in the commons' ears,Will vouch the truth of it. Go, say I sent thee forth to purchase honour, And not the King exil'd thee; or suppose Devouring pestilence hangs in our air And thou art flying to a fresher clime. And Iprythee sweet Wagge, when thou art King, as God sauethy Grace, Maiesty I should say, for Grace thou wiltehaue none Prin. I am most fortunate thus accidentally toencounter you; you have ended my business, and I will merrilyaccompany you home. Our reasons are so full of good regard That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar, You should be satisfied. Heigh-ho! sing heigh-ho! unto the green holly. That if you be honest and fair, your honesty should admit no discourse to your beauty. I have but this to say That he is not only plagued for her sin, But God hath made her sin and her the plague On this removed issue, plagued for her And with her plague; her sin his injury, Her injury the beadle to her sin; All punish'd in the person of  [Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, COMINIUS, Senators, and Patricians. There end thy brave, and turn thy face in peace; We grant thou canst outscold us. Shall I keep your hogs, and eat husks with them? What prodigal portion have I spent that I should come to suchpenury? OLIVER. This earth shall have a feeling, and these stones Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms. After, Aumerle! Mount thee upon his horse; Spur post, and get before him to the King, And beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee. Be it as you shall privately determine, Either for her stay or going. Are you not a Coward? Answer me to that, andPoines there? Prin. Yet again methinks Some unborn sorrow, ripe in fortune's womb, Is coming towards me, and my inward soul With nothing trembles. My lord, he is but even now gone hence; Here was he merry, hearing of a song. If you bea true lover, hence, and not a word; for here comes morecompany. Unkind remembrance! thou and eyeless night Have done me shame. You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have notdeserved nobly. The sea, with such a storm as his bare head In hell-black night endur'd, would have buoy'd up And quench'd the steeled fires. There, on the pendant boughs her coronet weeds Clamb?ing to hang, an envious sliver broke; When down her weedy trophies and herself Fell in the weeping brook. Ile be a Traitor then, when thou art King Prin. So holy and so perfect is my love, And I in such a poverty of grace, That I shall think it a most plenteous crop To glean the broken ears after the man That the main harvest reaps; loose now and then A scatt'red smile, and that I'll live upon. That you beat me at the mart I have your hand to show; If the skin were parchment, and the blows you gave were ink, Your own handwriting would tell you what I think. [Enter VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA; they sit down on two low stools andsew. Do not laugh at me; For (as I am a man) I think this lady To be my child Cordelia. First, the gods bless you for your tidings; next,Accept my thankfulness. Yet, 'tis the plague of great ones: Prerogatived are they less than the base; 'Tis destiny unshunnable, like death. The body is with the king, but the king is not with the body. I go to take my stand To see him pass on to the Capitol. Had you your letters from your wife, my lord? BRUTUS. Our last king, Whose image even but now appear? to us, Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway, Thereto prick? on by a most emulate pride, Dar? to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet,?For so this side of our known world esteem? him,?Did slay this  The point envenom? too!?Then, venom, to thy work. 'Tis wonderful What may be wrought out of their discontent, Now that their souls are topful of offence. So, I am free, yet would not so have been, Durst I have done my will. The deep of night is crept upon our talk, And nature must obey necessity, Which we will niggard with a little rest. Look in upon me then, and speak with me, Or, naked as I am, I will assault thee. O noble sir! Your over-kindness doth wring tears from me. I offer'd to awaken his regardFor's private friends: his answer to me was,He could not stay to pick them in a pileOf noisome musty chaff: he said 'twas folly,For one poor grain or two, to leave unburntAnd still to nose the offence. The earth hath bubbles, as the water has,And these are of them:--whither are they vanish'd?MACBETH. Stand fast; We have as many friends as enemies. Tell him I have movedmy lord on his behalf and hope all will be well. I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true; thoughI'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false. I know not how they sold themselues, but thoulike a kinde fellow, gau'st thy selfe away; and I thankethee, for thee. Barren, barren, barren: Beggers all, beggers allSir Iohn: Marry, good ayre. Good sir, be a man; Think every bearded fellow that's but yoked May draw with you. Nay, but he prated And spoke such scurvy and provoking terms Against your honor That, with the little godliness I have, I did full hard forbear him. I hope the King is not yet shipp'd for Ireland. As it is a spare life, look you, it fits my humour well; but as there is no moreplenty in it, it goes much against my stomach. 'Tis the curse of service, Preferment goes by letter and affection, And not by old gradation, where each second Stood heir to the first. Set you down this; And say besides, that in Aleppo once, Where a malignant and a turban'd Turk Beat a Venetian and traduced the state, I took by the throat the circumcised dog And smote him, thus. Another part of the forestEnter SILVIUS and PHEBE SILVIUS. My lord, will't please you to fall to? KING RICHARD. There? fennel for you, and columbines:?here? rue for you; and here? some for me:?e may call it herb of grace o?Sundays:?, you must wear your rue with a difference. Is execution done on Cawdor? Are notThose in commission yet return'd?MALCOLM. Yet, by your gracious patience, I will a round unvarnish'd tale deliver Of my whole course of love: what drugs, what charms, What conjuration, and what mighty magic For such proceeding I am charged withal I won his daughter. If they get ground, and vantage of the King,Then ioyne you with them, like a Ribbe of Steele,To make Strength stronger. Why, how now, ho! from whence ariseth this? Are we turn'd Turks, and to ourselves do that Which heaven hath forbid the Ottomites? For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl. First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people. But heaven hath a hand in these events, To whose high will we bound our calm contents. My charge was but to fetch you from the mart Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner. She knapp'd 'em o' th' coxcombswith a stick and cried 'Down, wantons, down!' 'Twas her brotherthat, in pure kindness to his horse, buttered his hay. Nay, they will be kin to vs, but they wil fetchit from Iaphet. Here's the smell of the blood still: all the perfumesof Arabia will not sweeten this little hand. Very well, my lord; Your grace has laid the odds o?the weaker side. Methinks I should know you, and know this man; Yet I am doubtful; for I am mainly ignorant What place this is; and all the skill I have Remembers not these garments; nor I know not Where I did lodge last night. Never afflict yourself to know the cause; But let his disposition have that scope That dotage gives it. Why not to him in part, and to vs all,That feele the bruizes of the dayes before,And suffer the Condition of these TimesTo lay a heauie and vnequall Hand vpon our Honors? West. A wonder, lady! Lo, upon thy wish, Our messenger Chatillon is arriv'd. He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth on't; beforeCorioli he scotched him and notched him like a carbonado. Pleaseth your Grace, to answere them directly,How farre-forth you doe like their Articles Iohn. O, where hath our intelligence been drunk? Where hath it slept? Where is my mother's care, That such an army could be drawn in France, And she not hear of it? MESSENGER. --Dear Duff, I pr'ythee, contradict thyself,And say it is not so. Thy sins are visited in this poor child; The canon of the law is laid on him, Being but the second generation Removed from thy sin-conceiving womb. The Prince of Wales stept forth before the king,And Nephew, challeng'd you to single fight Hot. I from my mistress come to you in post; If I return, I shall be post indeed, For she will score your fault upon my pate. List to your tribunes; audience: peace, I say!CORIOLANUS. This day I breathed first: time is come round, And where I did begin, there shall I end; My life is run his compass. Besides, the King hath wasted all his Rods,On late Offenders, that he now doth lackeThe very Instruments of Chasticement:So that his power, like to a Fanglesse LionMay offer, but not hold Bish. Well, I will hie And so bestow these papers as you bade me. O, I do not like that paying backe, 'tis a doubleLabour Prin. Come, come, I am a king; My masters, know you that? Gent. But, O, what form of prayer98 Can serve my turn? Forgive me my foul murder!?That cannot be; since I am still possess? Of those effects for which I did the murder,?My crown, mine own ambition, and my queen. O most gentle pulpiter! What tedious homily of lovehave you wearied your parishioners withal, and never cried 'Have patience, good people. The town is empty; on the brow o' the sea Stand ranks of people, and they cry, "A sail!" CASSIO. Which of these sorrows is he subject to?ADRIANA. See, Antony, that revels long o' nights, Is notwithstanding up. I have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftily qualified too, and behold what innovation it makes here. But make amends now: get you gone,And at the pit of AcheronMeet me i' the morning: thither heWill come to know his destiny. So should my thoughts be sever'd from my griefs, And woes by wrong imaginations lose The knowledge of themselves. To-night we hold a solemn supper, sir,And I'll request your presence. At Worcester must his body be interr'd; For so he will'd it. Look you, sir, Enquire me first what Danskers are in Paris; And how, and who, what means, and where they keep, What company, at what expense; and finding, By this encompassment and drift of question, That they do know my son, come you more nearer Than y Therefore lay hold of him;Bear him to the rock Tarpeian, and from thenceInto destruction cast him. The enemy comes on in gallant show; Their bloody sign of battle is hung out, And something to be done immediately. I found it by the barrenness, hard in the palm of the hand. A wretched soul, bruis'd with adversity, We bid be quiet when we hear it cry; But were we burd'ned with like weight of pain, As much, or more, we should ourselves complain. Censure me inyour wisdom, and awake your senses, that you may the better judge. Your lady, sir, your lady! and her sister By her is poisoned; she hath confess'd it. Say we read lectures to you,How youngly he began to serve his country,How long continued: and what stock he springs of--The noble house o' the Marcians; from whence cameThat Ancus Marcius, Numa's daughter's son,Who, after great Hostilius, here was king; The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd The shadow of your face. I pray you (Sir) then set your Knighthood andyour Souldier-ship aside, and giue mee leaue to tell you,you lye in your throat, if you say I am any other then anhonest man Fal. O that I had been writ down an ass! Exeunt. On him, on him! Look you how pale he glares! His form and cause conjoin?, preaching to stones, Would make them capable. As I do live, my honour? lord, ?is true; And we did think it writ down in our duty To let you know of it. To-day my Lord of Amiens and myself Did steal behind him as he lay along Under an oak whose antique root peeps out Upon the brook that brawls along this wood! To the which place a poor sequest'red stag, That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt, Did c So is all her Sect: if they be once in a Calme,they are sick Dol. --We'll talkwith Margaret, How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow. That nowSweno, the Norways' king, craves composition;Nor would we deign him burial of his menTill he disbursed, at Saint Colme's-inch,Ten thousand dollars to our general use. Well, Time is the old justice that examines all such offenders, and let Time try. Come, come, do you think I do not know you by yourexcellent wit? Can virtue hide itself? Go to, mum you are he. Lucilius, come, And come, young Cato; let us to the field. How comes this, Sir Iohn? Fy, what a man ofgood temper would endure this tempest of exclamation?Are you not asham'd to inforce a poore Widdowe to sorough a course, to come by her owne? Falst. The Duke of Norfolk, spightfully and bold, Stays but the summons of the appelant's trumpet. Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts, and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath given them in wit. By mine honour, I will; and when I breakthat oath, let me turn monster; therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry. He means, my lord, that we are too remiss; Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security, Grows strong and great in substance and in power. Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing?Come, sister, you shall be the priest, and marry us. Close pent-up guilts, Rive your concealing continents, and cry These dreadful summoners grace. Now, whether it be Bestial oblivion, or some craven scruple Of thinking too precisely on the event,?A thought which, quarter?, hath but one part wisdom And ever three parts coward,? do not know Why yet I live to say ?his thing? to do;?Sith I have cause, Windsor CastleEnter BOLINGBROKE as King, PERCY, and other LORDS BOLINGBROKE. I'll write to him a very taunting letter, And thou shalt bear it; wilt thou, Silvius? SILVIUS. Their armours that march'd hence so silver-bright Hither return all gilt with Frenchmen's blood. This presence knows, and you must needs have heard, How I am punish? with sore distraction. Nay, let them follow:The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thitherTo gnaw their garners. Ha! Goneril with a white beard? They flatter'd me like adog, and told me I had white hairs in my beard ere the black ones were there. Cousin of Hereford, as thy cause is right, So be thy fortune in this royal fight! Farewell, my blood; which if to-day thou shed, Lament we may, but not revenge thee dead. There's one did laugh in's sleep, and one cried, "Murder!"That they did wake each other: I stood and heard them:But they did say their prayers, and address'd themAgain to sleep. True, worthy Banquo!--he is full so valiant;And in his commendations I am fed,--It is a banquet to me. Mad let us grant him then: and now remains That we find out the cause of this effect; Or rather say, the cause of this defect, For this effect defective comes by cause: Thus it remains, and the remainder thus. I cannot draw a cart, nor eat dried oats; If it be man's work, I'll do't. Dost thou think Alexander looked o?this fashion i?the earth? Hor. O, they are our friends! But one cup; I'll drink for you. This castle hath a pleasant seat: the airNimbly and sweetly recommends itselfUnto our gentle senses. I do not ask you much; I beg cold comfort; and you are so strait And so ingrateful you deny me that. What, you have charg'd me with, that have I done, And more, much more. Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore; Be sure of it. If you please, Be't at her father's. By this time our sextonhath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. The Earle of Westmerland, seuen thousand strong,Is marching hither-wards, with Prince Iohn Hotsp. Go bid the priests do present sacrifice, And bring me their opinions of success. Another part of the forestEnter AMIENS, JAQUES, and OTHERS SONG AMIENS. To bed, to bed; there's knocking at the gate: come, come, come,come, give me your hand: what's done cannot be undone: to bed, tobed, to bed. Here's a change indeed! Exit. My gracious liege, when that my father liv'd, Your brother did employ my father much BASTARD. I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness. Then call them to our presence: face to face And frowning brow to brow, ourselves will hear The accuser and the accused freely speak. SONG Wedding is great Juno's crown; O blessed bond of board and bed! 'Tis Hymen peoples every town; High wedlock then be honoured. I say, if he would incline to thepeople, there was never a worthier man. I will to-morrow,(And betimes I will) to the weird sisters:More shall they speak; for now I am bent to know,By the worst means, the worst. <ExitSCENE 4A streetEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS with the OFFICERANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. There's none so foul and foolish thereunto, But does foul pranks which fair and wise ones do. Will't not be? LEWIS. Come, lords, away, To fight with Glendower and his complices. Woe doth the heavier sit Where it perceives it is but faintly home. The wrathful skies Gallow the very wanderers of the dark And make them keep their caves. Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world? EMILIA. Her honor is an essence that's not seen; They have it very oft that have it not. No, Caesar hath it not, but you, and I, And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness. We call a nettle but a nettle; andThe faults of fools but folly. And so to the Lie Circumstantial and the Lie Direct. Home without Bootes,And in foule Weather too,How scapes he Agues in the Deuils name? Glend. Cheerly, good Adam! Mess. Uncle, farewell; and, cousin, adieu; Your mother well hath pray'd, and prove you true. And then the justice, In fair round belly with good capon lin'd, With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, Full of wise saws and modern instances; And so he plays his part. Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires; I'll leave you. To Adriana! that is where we din'd, Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband. You swore to vs,And you did sweare that Oath at Doncaster,That you did nothing of purpose 'gainst the State,Nor claime no further, then your new-falne right,The seate of Gaunt, Dukedome of Lancaster,To this, we sware our aide: But in short space,It rain ' Then, being there alone, Left and abandoned of his velvet friends: ''Tis right'; quoth he 'thus misery doth part The flux of company. Then would you be nothing but Musicall,For you are altogether gouerned by humors:Lye still ye Theefe, and heare the Lady sing in Welsh Hotsp. At such a time I?l loose my daughter to him: Be you and I behind an arras then; Mark the encounter: if he love her not, And he not from his reason fall? thereon Let me be no assistant for a state, But keep a farm and carters. O, no; for the Duke's daughter, her cousin, so lovesher, being ever from their cradles bred together, that she wouldhave followed her exile, or have died to stay behind her. To every Roman citizen he gives, To every several man, seventy-five drachmas. What wilt thou do, renowned Faulconbridge? Second a villain and a murderer? HUBERT. If any bark put forth, come to the mart, Where I will walk till thou return to me. Amen, sir:--to my poor unworthy notice, He mocked us when he begg'd our voices. For those that could speake low, and tardily,Would turne their owne Perfection, to Abuse,To seeme like him. Happily he? the second time come to them; for they say an old man is twice a child. A very riband in the cap of youth, Yet needful too; for youth no less becomes The light and careless livery that it wears Than settled age his sables and his weeds, Importing health and graveness. Do not I know thou wouldst? Good Hubert, Hubert, Hubert, throw thine eye On yon young boy. To his good friends thus wide I?l ope my arms; And, like the kind life-rendering pelican, Repast them with my blood. Carrie Master Silence to bed: Master Shallow, myLord Shallow, be what thou wilt, I am Fortunes Steward. Now Heauen blesse that sweete Faceof thine: what, are you come from Wales? Fal. Woe that too late repents!O, sir, are you come? Is it your will? Speak, sir!Prepare my horses. 'Good den, Sir Richard!'-'God-a-mercy, fellow!' And if his name be George, I'll call him Peter; For new-made honour doth forget men's names: 'Tis too respective and too sociable For your conversion. They say there's grain enough!Would the nobility lay aside their ruthAnd let me use my sword, I'd make a quarryWith thousands of these quarter'd slaves, as highAs I could pick my lance. In faith, he's penitent; And yet his trespass, in our common reason Save that, they say, the wars must make example Out of their bestis not almost a fault To incur a private check. This is unlikely:He and Aufidius can no more atoneThan violentest contrariety. Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius, Had you a healthful ear to hear of it. Well, he may sleep inSecurity, for he hath the horne of Abundance: and thelightnesse of his Wife shines through it, and yet cannothe see, though he haue his owne Lanthorne to light him. No? How might a Prince of my great hopes forgetSo great Indignities you laid vpon me?What? Rate? Rebuke? and roughly send to PrisonTh' immediate Heire of England? Was this easie?May this be wash'd in Lethe, and forgotten? Ch. There, take it; and much thanks for my good cheer. Ah, thou, the model where old Troy did stand; Thou map of honour, thou King Richard's tomb, And not King Richard; thou most beauteous inn, Why should hard-favour'd grief be lodg'd in thee, When triumph is become an alehouse guest? KING RICHARD. The forestEnter ORLANDO, with a paper ORLANDO. Marry, well bethought: ?is told me he hath very oft of late Given private time to you; and you yourself Have of your audience been most free and bounteous; If it be so,?s so ?is put on me, And that in way of caution,? must tell you You do not understand If she should make tender of her love,'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the man (as you know all)hath a contemptible spirit. I have done the state some service, and they know't. The Lady Constance speaks not from her faith, But from her need. Villains! You did not so when your vile daggers Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar. This is themotley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest. A maid, and stuff'd! There's goodly catching of cold. Well, happiness to their sheets! Enter Edmund, with his rapier drawn, Gloucester, Cornwall, Regan, Servants. It is to be all made of fantasy, All made of passion, and all made of wishes; All adoration, duty, and observance, All humbleness, all patience, and impatience, All purity, all trial, all obedience; And so am I for Phebe. It is my cousin's duty to make cursy and say, 'Father, as it please you. I had as live have heard the night raven, come what plague could have come after it. Ah, sirrah, a body would think this was well counterfeited. So oft as that shall be, So often shall the knot of us be call'd The men that gave their country liberty. You did commit me:For which, I do commit into your hand,Th' vnstained Sword that you haue vs'd to beare:With this Remembrance; That you vse the sameWith the like bold, iust, and impartiall spiritAs you haue done 'gainst me. Then a soldier, Full of strange oaths, and bearded like the pard, Jealous in honour, sudden and quick in quarrel, Seeking the bubble reputation Even in the cannon's mouth. Let your highnessCommand upon me; to the which my dutiesAre with a most indissoluble tieFor ever knit. What wouldst thou do, old man? Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak When power to flattery bows? To plainness honour's bound When majesty falls to folly. --A heavy summons lies like lead upon me,And yet I would not sleep:--merciful powers,Restrain in me the cursed thoughts that natureGives way to in repose!--Give me my sword. Haply, for I am black And have not those soft parts of conversation That chamberers have, or for I am declined Into the vale of yearsyet that's not much She's gone. If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet,'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strikeTill one can do no more. What, think you the King shall be deposed? GARDENER. I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the contrary, if Hero would be my wife. I ambetter than thou art now: I am a fool, thou art nothing. Romans, countrymen, and lovers! Cry 'havoc!' kings; back to the stained field, You equal potents, fiery kindled spirits! Then let confusion of one part confirm The other's peace. With meditating that she must die once I have the patience to endure it now. The contents,as in part I understand them, are to blame. [Within] It seems thou want'st breaking; out upon thee, hind!DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I do know, When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul Lends the tongue vows: these blazes, daughter, Giving more light than heat,?xtinct in both, Even in their promise, as it is a-making,?You must not take for fire. What, fifty of my followers at a clap? Within a fortnight? Alb. No, here it is:Sit Cousin Percy, sit good Cousin Hotspurre:For by that Name, as oft as Lancaster doth speake of you,His Cheekes looke pale, and with a rising sigh,He wisheth you in Heauen Hotsp. Therefore, let's hence,And with our fair entreaties haste them on. Shehath bin in good case, & the truth is, pouerty hath distractedher: but for these foolish Officers, I beseech you, Imay haue redresse against them Iust. Tell mebut trulybut then speak the truth Do you not love my sister?
