Why, 'twas my care, And what loss is it to be rid of care? Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we? Greater he shall not be; if he serve God, We'll serve him too, and be his fellow so. I know youare my eldest brother; and in the gentle condition of blood, you should so know me. I vnderstand thy Kisses, and thou mine,And that's a feeling disputation:But I will neuer be a Truant, Loue,Till I haue learn'd thy Language: for thy tongueMakes Welsh as sweet as Ditties highly penn'd,Sung by a faire Queene in a Summers Bowre,With rauis That will I, for I must bear answer back How you excuse my brother, Rosalind. To his conveyance I assign my wife, With what else needful your good Grace shall think To be sent after me. O, she misus'd me past the endurance of a block! An oakbut with one green leaf on it would have answered her; my veryvisor began to assume life and scold with her. Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero, I have seen tempests when the scolding winds Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam To be exalted with the threatening c My name is Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk; Who hither come engaged by my oath Which God defend a knight should violate! Our basest beggars Are in the poorest thing superfluous. [To NORTHUMBERLAND] We are amaz'd; and thus long have we stood To watch the fearful bending of thy knee, Because we thought ourself thy lawful King; And if we be, how dare thy joints forget To pay their awful duty to our presence? If we be not, show us  More health and happiness betide my liege Than can my care-tun'd tongue deliver him. Do you not loue me?Nay, tell me if thou speak'st in iest, or no Hot. Peace, ho!--no outrage;--peace! The man is noble, and his fame folds inThis orb o' the earth. If thou canst cuckold him, thou dostthyself a pleasure, me a sport. Ay me, it is my husband! Witness you That he is borne about invisible. The King of Heaven forbid our lord the King Should so with civil and uncivil arms Be rush'd upon! Thy thrice noble cousin, Harry Bolingbroke, doth humbly kiss thy hand; And by the honourable tomb he swears That stands upon your royal grandsire's bones,  There's no artTo find the mind's construction in the face:He was a gentleman on whom I builtAn absolute trust. Kent, sir, the banish'd Kent; who in disguise Followed his enemy king and did him service Improper for a slave. Niggard of question; but, of our demands, Most free in his reply. All blest secrets, All you unpublish'd virtues of the earth, Spring with my tears! be aidant and remediate In the good man's distress! Seek, seek for him! Lest his ungovern'd rage dissolve the life That wants the means to lead it. What will ensue hereof there's none can tell; But by bad courses may be understood That their events can never fall out good. No good at all that I can do for him; Unless you call it good to pity him, Bereft and gelded of his patrimony. I am not mad-I would to heaven I were! For then 'tis like I should forget myself. Now doth it turne, and ebbe backe to the Sea,Where it shall mingle with the state of Floods,And flow henceforth in formall Maiesty. So is he now in execution Of any bold or noble enterprise, However he puts on this tardy form. And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee, Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand. I marry Sir Iohn, which I beseech you to let mehaue home with me Fal. Why not by th' hand, sir? How have I offended? All's not offence that indiscretion finds And dotage terms so. Harry, I doe not onely maruell where thou spendest thytime; but also, how thou art accompanied: For thoughthe Camomile, the more it is troden, the faster it growes;yet Youth, the more it is wasted, the sooner it weares. A plague of all Cowards still, say I Prince. You must therefore be content to slubber thegloss of your new fortunes with this more stubborn and boisterous expedition. Hark, she speaks: I will set down what comes from her, tosatisfy my remembrance the more strongly. Every day thou daffest me with some device, Iago; and rather, as it seems to me now, keepest from me allconveniency than suppliest me with the least advantage of hope. Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman Deserve as full, as fortunate a bed As ever Beatrice shall couch upon? Hero. The Volsces retire into Corioli, and MARCIUS followsthem to the gates. Hence, horrible shadow!Unreal mockery, hence![Ghost disappears. What, are you mad, that you do reason so?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. The gods give you joy, sir, heartily![Exeunt citizens. But, to Orlando: did he leave him there, Food to the suck'd and hungry lioness? OLIVER. Nay, I prithee now, with most petitionary vehemence,tell me who it is. But indeede these humble considerationsmake me out of loue with my Greatnesse. By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I found you. Shall then my father's will be of no force To dispossess that child which is not his? BASTARD. If then we shall shake off our slavish yoke, Imp out our drooping country's broken wing, Redeem from broking pawn the blemish'd crown, Wipe off the dust that hides our sceptre's gilt, And make high majesty look like itself, Away with me in post to Raven Monsieur the Challenger, the Princess calls for you. Happy are theythat hear their detractions and can put them to mending. Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give Thee o'er to harshness. And for whose death, we in the worlds wide mouthLiue scandaliz'd, and fouly spoken of Hot. I have heard you sayHonour and policy, like unsever'd friends,I' the war do grow together: grant that, and tell meIn peace what each of them by th' other loseThat they combine not there. So far be mine, my most redoubted lord, As my true service shall deserve your love. It was his bidding; therefore, good Emilia, Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu. We will not line his thin bestained cloak With our pure honours, nor attend the foot That leaves the print of blood where'er it walks. Now hear me speak with a prophetic spirit; For even the breath of what I mean to speak Shall blow each dust, each straw, each little rub, Out of the path which shall directly lead Thy foot to England's throne. But hee hath forc'd vs to compell this Offer,And it proceedes from Pollicy, not Loue West. You have lost no reputation at all, unless you repute yourself such a loser. Ned, prethee come out of that fat roome, & lendme thy hand to laugh a little Poines. and pat! he comes, like the catastrophe of the old comedy. If it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear me, I shall beseech him to befriend himself. And how doth my Cousin, your Bed-fellow?and your fairest Daughter, and mine, my God-DaughterEllen? Sil. Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion, By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations. If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call tothe nurse and bid her still it. The great rage You see is kill'd in him; and yet it is danger To make him even o'er the time he has lost. We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken upof these men's bills. You shall do marvellous wisely, good Reynaldo, Before You visit him, to make inquiry Of his behaviour. To comfort you the more, I haue receiu'dA certaine instance, that Glendour is dead. O that your Highness knew my heart in this! I never lov'd my brother in my life. An you will not be answer'd with reason, I must die. Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go? ADAM. I'll bring him the best 'parel that I have, Come on't what will. Not a peny, not a peny: you are too impatientto beare crosses. There's not a Shirt and a halfe in all myCompany: and the halfe Shirt is two Napkins tackt together,and throwne ouer the shoulders like a HeraldsCoat, without sleeues: and the Shirt, to say the truth,stolne from my Host of S[aint]. To lose itself in a fog; where being three parts melted away withrotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience' sake, tohelp to get thee a wife. O, my sweet sir, news fitting to the night, Black, fearful, comfortless, and horrible. Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip? Some bloody passion shakes your very frame. ExitGURNEY Madam, I was not old Sir Robert's son; Sir Robert might have eat his part in me Upon Good Friday, and ne'er broke his fast. He call'd me father:But what o' that? Go, you that banish'd him;A mile before his tent fall down, and kneeThe way into his mercy: nay, if he coy'dTo hear Cominius speak, I'll keep at home. I pray you be not angry with me, madam, Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick, For shape, for bearing, argument, and valour, Goes foremost in report through Italy. This kiss, if it durst speak, Would stretch thy spirits up into the air. As for the mercy Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia The battle done, and they within our power, Shall never see his pardon; for my state Stands on me to defend, not to debate. A king of beasts, indeed! If aught but beasts, I had been still a happy king of men. I pray you have a continent forbearancetill the speed of his rage goes slower; and, as I say, retirewith me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak. Put on what weary negligence you please, You and your fellows. I promise you, the effects he writes of succeed unhappily:as of unnaturalness between the child and the parent; death, dearth, dissolutions of ancient amities; divisions in state, menaces and maledictions against king and nobles; needless diffidences, b EreI leade this life long, Ile sowe nether stockes, and mendthem too. O heavy deed! It had been so with us, had we been there: His liberty is full of threats to all; To you yourself, to us, to every one. Tell her I send to her my kind commends; Take special care my greetings be delivered. But were I not the better part made mercy, I should not seek an absent argument Of my revenge, thou present. The Ottomites, reverend and gracious, Steering with due course toward the isle of Rhodes, Have there injointed them with an after fleet. Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud,violent, testy magistrates,--alias fools,--as any in Rome. --Whiles I threat, he lives;Words to the heat of deeds too cold breath gives. Well, an you be not turn'd Turk, there's no more sailingby the star. Let it be who it is, for Romans now Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors. How now, my noble friend? Since I came hither (Which I can call but now) I have heard strange news. Now then, we'll use His countenance for the battle, which being done, Let her who would be rid of him devise His speedy taking off. We do require them of you, so to use them As we shall find their merits and our safety May equally determine. Princes, and noble lords, What answer shall I make to this base man? Shall I so much dishonour my fair stars On equal terms to give him chastisement? Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd With the attainder of his slanderous lips. Where is the Liuing, clipt in with the Sea,That chides the Bankes of England, Scotland, and Wales,Which calls me Pupill, or hath read to me?And bring him out, that is but Womans Sonne,Can trace me in the tedious wayes of Art,And hold me pace in deepe expBefore my God, I might not this believe Without the sensible and true avouch Of mine own eyes. [reads from a scroll] Epitaph. And so will he do; for the man doth fear God, howsoeverit seems not in him by some large jests he will make. For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a god-kissing carrion,?ave you a daughter? Pol. Yes, by Saint Patrick, but there is, Horatio, And much offence too. Lords, giue vs leaue:The Prince of Wales, and I,Must haue some priuate conference:But be neere at hand,For wee shall presently haue neede of you. The fellow is distract, and so am I; And here we wander in illusions. He's gone into Smithfield to buy your worshipa horse Fal. So, Green, thou art the midwife to my woe, And Bolingbroke my sorrow's dismal heir. He had so, looking as it were,--would I were hanged, but Ithought there was more in him than I could think. [Leapsdown] O me! my uncle's spirit is in these stones. If I heard you rightly, The Duke hath put on a religious life, And thrown into neglect the pompous court. Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to carefor her frowning. I have been i' the market-place; and, sir, 'tis fitYou make strong party, or defend yourselfBy calmness or by absence: all's in anger. My lord, I would I might entreat your honor To scan this thing no further; leave it to time. O mistress, villainy hath made mocks with love! My husband say that she was false! OTHELLO. What is thy name, that in battel thus y crossest me?What honor dost thou seeke vpon my head? Dow. O dear Phebe, If everas that ever may be near You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy, Then shall you know the wounds invisible That love's keen arrows make. And him, O wondrous! him,O Miracle of Men! Him did you leaue(Second to none) vn-seconded by you,To looke vpon the hideous God of Warre,In dis-aduantage, to abide a field,Where nothing but the sound of Hotspurs NameDid seeme defensible: so you left him. Were I from Dunsinane away and clear,Profit again should hardly draw me here. Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy,34 But not express? in fancy; rich, not gaudy: For the apparel oft proclaims the man; And they in France of the best rank and station Are most select and generous chief in that. It is the witness still of excellency To put a strange face on his own perfection. You all did love him once, not without cause; What cause withholds you then to mourn for him? O judgement, thou art fled to brutish beasts, And men have lost their reason. [Enter three or four CONSPIRATORS of AUFIDIUS' faction. I say unto you, what he hath done famously he did it to that end:though soft-conscienced men can be content to say it was for hiscountry, he did it to please his mother, and to be partly proud;which he is, even to the altitude of his virtue. Our spoils he kick'd at;And looked upon things precious as they wereThe common muck of the world: he covets lessThan misery itself would give; rewardsHis deeds with doing them; and is contentTo spend the time to end it. Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at thenext turning. Alack, why am I sent for to a king, Before I have shook off the regal thoughts Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my knee. By this, I think, the dial points at five; Anon, I'm sure, the Duke himself in person Comes this way to the melancholy vale, The place of death and sorry execution, Behind the ditches of the abbey here. Infirm of purpose!Give me the daggers: the sleeping and the deadAre but as pictures: 'tis the eye of childhoodThat fears a painted devil. Within this hour it will be dinner-time; Till that, I'll view the manners of the town, Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings, And then return and sleep within mine inn; For with long travel I am stiff and weary. Note me this, good friend;Your most grave belly was deliberate,Not rash like his accusers, and thus answer'd:'True is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he,'That I receive the general food at firstWhich you do live upon; and fit it is,Because I am the stOur very priests must become mockers if they shall encounter suchridiculous subjects as you are. The poor world is almostsix thousand years old, and in all this time there was not anyman died in his own person, videlicet, in a love-cause. But I have heard him oft maintain it to befit that, sons at perfect age, and fathers declining, the father should be as ward to the son, and the son manage hisrevenue. I well allow the occasion of our Armes,But gladly would be better satisfied,How (in our Meanes) we should aduance our seluesTo looke with forhead bold and big enoughVpon the Power and puisance of the King Hast. God be with my old master! He would not havespoke such a word. Dost thou hear, Iago? I will be found most cunning in my patience; But (dost thou hear?) most bloody. Masters, play here, I will content your pains;Something that's brief; and bid "Good morrow, general. To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much. And so there is, but yet the King hath DrawneThe speciall head of all the Land together:The Prince of Wales, Lord Iohn of Lancaster,The Noble Westmerland, and warlike Blunt;And many moe Corriuals, and deare menOf estimation, and command in Armes Sir M. Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth, Nor with thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense; But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom, And heavy-gaited toads, lie in their way, Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet Which with usurping steps do tr In truth, la, go with me; and I'll tell you excellent newsof your husband. Which of them shall I take? Both? one? or neither? Neither can be enjoy'd, If both remain alive. But wherefore do you hold me here so long? What is it that you would impart to me? If it be aught toward the general good, Set honor in one eye and death i' the other And I will look on both indifferently. Man, more divine, the master of all these, Lord of the wide world and wild wat'ry seas, Indu'd with intellectual sense and souls, Of more pre-eminence than fish and fowls, Are masters to their females, and their lords; Then let your will attend on their The gods be good to us!--Come, masters, let's home. [Within] My liege, beware; look to thyself; Thou hast a traitor in thy presence there. Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber; Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies, Which busy care draws in the brains of men; Therefore thou sleep'st so sound. I am sorry to find you thus; I have been to seek you. So hangs and lolls and weeps upon me; so hales andpulls me. When he is return'd, Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial. Hereafter, in a better world than this, I shall desire more love and knowledge of you. Thy due, from me,Is Teares, and heauie Sorrowes of the Blood,Which Nature, Loue, and filiall tendernesse,Shall (O deare Father) pay thee plenteously. Did not you hear a cry? CASSIO. What is about to be?--I am out of breath;Confusion's near: I cannot speak. Let me be your servant; Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty; For in my youth I never did apply Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood, Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo The means of weakness and debility; Therefore my age is as a lusty wi Breathe you, my friends: well fought; we are come offLike Romans, neither foolish in our standsNor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs,We shall be charg'd again. Well could I bear that England had this praise, So we could find some pattern of our shame. I did enact Julius Caesar; I was kill? i?the Capitol; Brutus killed me. Herein all breathless lies The mightiest of thy greatest enemies, Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought. Then, good my liege, let me have what is mine, My father's land, as was my father's will. Work on, My medicine, work! Thus credulous fools are caught, And many worthy and chaste dames even thus, All guiltless, meet reproach. Were half to half the world by the ears, and heUpon my party, I'd revolt, to makeOnly my wars with him: he is a lionThat I am proud to hunt. I never did like molestation view On the enchafed flood. With this shepherdess, my sister; here in the skirtsof the forest, like fringe upon a petticoat. Marry, sir, in her buttocks; I found it outby the bogs. [aside] How should this be? Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow, Ang'ring itself and others. Andnow tell me, how doth your cousin? Beat. Nought shall make us rue, If England to itself do rest but true. This visitation Is but to whet thy almost blunted purpose. O, sir, sir, sir,I would have had you put your power well onBefore you had worn it out. May we do so? You know it is the feast of Lupercal. Away you Cut-purse Rascall, you filthy Bung,away: By this Wine, Ile thrust my Knife in your mouldieChappes, if you play the sawcie Cuttle with me. Hathyour Grace ne'er a brother like you? Your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them. I haue heard the Prince tell him, I know nothow oft, that that Ring was Copper Falst. I pray you, in your letters, When you shall these unlucky deeds relate, Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate, Nor set down aught in malice. I was prickt well enough before, if you couldhaue let me alone: my old Dame will be vndone now, forone to doe her Husbandry, and her Drudgery; you neednot to haue prickt me, there are other men fitter to goeout, then I Fal. And I can teach thee, Cousin, to shame the Deuil,By telling truth. Do you not read some tokens of my son In the large composition of this man? KING JOHN. Gracious my lord,I should report that which I say I saw,But know not how to do it. Why, Percy I kill'd my selfe, and saw thee dead Fal. To tak't again perforce! Monster ingratitude! Fool. O my mother, mother! O!You have won a happy victory to Rome;But for your son,--believe it, O, believe it,Most dangerously you have with him prevail'd,If not most mortal to him. Think upon me! Hang 'em! I would they would forget me, like the virtuesWhich our divines lose by 'em. Ile procure this fat Rogue a Charge of Foot,and I know his death will be a Match of Twelue-score. Now near enough; your leafy screens throw down,And show like those you are. So shall I, love; and so, I pray, be you:Let your remembrance apply to Banquo;Present him eminence, both with eye and tongue:Unsafe the while, that weMust lave our honors in these flattering streams;And make our faces vizards to our hearts,Disguising whaWorthy Montano, you were wont be civil; The gravity and stillness of your youth The world hath noted, and your name is great In mouths of wisest censure. [Enter, with drum and colours, Malcolm, old Siward and his Son,Macduff, Menteith, Caithness, Angus, Lennox, Ross, and Soldiers,marching. Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius, That you would have me seek into myself For that which is not in me? CASSIUS. What, will you murder me? Thou gaoler,thou, I am thy prisoner. Ile tell thee what, thou thin man in a Censor; Iwill haue you as soundly swindg'd for this, you blewBottel'dRogue: you filthy famish'd Correctioner, if yoube not swing'd, Ile forsweare halfe Kirtles Off. Rashly, And prais? be rashness for it,?et us know, Our indiscretion sometime serves us well, When our deep plots do fail; and that should teach us There? a divinity that shapes our ends, Rough-hew them how we will. O thou fond Many, with what loud applauseDid'st thou beate heauen with blessing Bullingbrooke,Before he was, what thou would'st haue him be?And being now trimm'd in thine owne desires,Thou (beastly Feeder) art so full of him,That thou prouok'st thy selfeIn most profound earnest; and, I'll warrant you, for the love of Beatrice. But that I am forbid To tell the secrets of my prison-house, I could a tale unfold whose lightest word Would harrow up thy soul; freeze thy young blood; Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres; Thy knotted and combined locks to part, And What noise is this? Not dead? not yet quite dead? I that am cruel am yet merciful; I would not have thee linger in thy pain. Enter CHATILLON KING PHILIP. Heare ye Yedward, if I tarry at home and go not,Ile hang you for going Poy. Boy! O slave!--Pardon me, lords, 'tis the first time that everI was forc'd to scold. If she live long, And in the end meet the old course of death, Women will all turn monsters. Yea, or to paint himself? for the which I hear what theysay of him. If Marcius should be join'd wi' the Volscians,--COMINIUS. And they are often tarr'd over with the surgery of our sheep; and would you have us kiss tar? The courtier's handsare perfum'd with civet. He that no more must say is listen'd more Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose; More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before. What watchful cares do interpose themselves Betwixt your eyes and night? CASSIUS. Aumerle that was But that is lost for being Richard's friend, And madam, you must call him Rudand now. Why, here walk I in the black brow of night To find you out. Pluck buthis name out of his heart, and turn him going. What is the reason of this terrible summons? What is the matter there? RODERIGO. You call honorable Boldnes, impudent Sawcinesse:If a man wil curt'sie, and say nothing, he is vertuous: No,my Lord (your humble duty reme[m]bred) I will not be yoursutor. [Music and song within, "Come away, come away" &c. Ah, do not tear away thyself from me; For know, my love, as easy mayst thou fall A drop of water in the breaking gulf, And take unmingled thence that drop again Without addition or diminishing, As take from me thyself, and not me too. Come, thou shalt go to the Warres in a Gowne:we will haue away thy Cold, and I will take such order,that thy friends shall ring for thee. Whose tongue soe'er speaks false, Not truly speaks; who speaks not truly, lies. The trumpets sound, and the KING enters with his nobles, GAUNT, BUSHY, BAGOT, GREEN, and others. I must weep, But they are cruel tears; this sorrow's heavenly, It strikes where it doth love. Were not my doors lock'd up and I shutout?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. You, cousin Hereford, upon pain of life, Till twice five summers have enrich'd our fields Shall not regreet our fair dominions, But tread the stranger paths of banishment. Nor nothing in your letters writ of her? The lords are all come back, And brought Prince Henry in their company; At whose request the King hath pardon'd them, And they are all about his Majesty. Throw down, my son, the Duke of Norfolk's gage. That he should draw his seuerall strengths togitherAnd come against vs in full puissanceNeed not be dreaded Hast. I had well hop'd thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, thatI might have cudgell'd thee out of thy single life, to makethee a double-dealer, which out of question thou wilt be if mycousin do not look exceeding narrowly to thee. The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes; And quite lost their hearts; the nobles hath he find For ancient quarrels and quite lost their hearts. If that the KingHaue any way your good Deserts forgot,Which he confesseth to be manifold,He bids you name your Griefes, and with all speedYou shall haue your desires, with interest;And Pardon absolute for your selfe, and these,Herein mis-led, by your su Not a whit, we defy augury: there? a special providence in the fall of a sparrow. Philip, make up: My mother is assailed in our tent, And ta'en, I fear. In God's name and the King's, say who thou art, And why thou comest thus knightly clad in arms; Against what man thou com'st, and what thy quarrel. Allow not nature more than nature needs, Man's life is cheap as beast's. Do you not know I am a woman? When I think, I mustspeak. If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he wavedindifferently 'twixt doing them neither good nor harm; but heseeks their hate with greater devotion than they can render ithim; and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover him theiroppositAnd heere I draw a Sword,Whose worthy temper I intend to staineWith the best blood that I can meete withall,In the aduenture of this perillous day. I wonder that thou (being, as thou say'st thou art, born under Saturn) goest about to apply a moral medicine to a mortifying mischief. Enter NORTHUMBERLAND Welcome, my lord. If that an eye may profit by a tongue, Then should I know you by description Such garments, and such years: 'The boy is fair, Of female favour, and bestows himself Like a ripe sister; the woman low, And browner than her brother. [Exeunt other Servants. Shall we not see these daughters and these sisters? Lear. O cursed, cursed slave! Whip me, ye devils, From the possession of this heavenly sight! Blow me about in winds! Roast me in sulphur! Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire! In our last conflict fourof his five wits went halting off, and now is the whole mangovern'd with one; so that if he have wit enough to keep himself warm,let him bear it for a difference between himself and his horse;for i He call'd her whore; a beggar in his drink Could not have laid such terms upon his callet. Then I, as one that am the tongue of these, To sound the purposes of all their hearts, Both for myself and thembut, chief of all, Your safety, for the which myself and them Bend their best studies, heartily request Th' enfranchisement of Arthur, whose r We'll lay before this town our royal bones, Wade to the market-place in Frenchmen's blood, But we will make it subject to this boy. Enter Desdemona with Emilia. Of what, lady? of speaking honourably? Is not marriage honourable in a beggar? Is not your lord honourable without marriage? I think you would have me say, 'saving yourreverence, a husband. I am old now, And these same crosses spoil me. No seconds? All myself? Why, this would make a man a man of salt, To use his eyes for garden waterpots, Ay, and laying autumn's dust. In your lord's scale is nothing but himself, And some few vanities that make him light; But in the balance of great Bolingbroke, Besides himself, are all the English peers, And with that odds he weighs King Richard down. Let me not hold my tongue, let me not, Hubert; Or, Hubert, if you will, cut out my tongue, So I may keep mine eyes. A crow without feather? Master, mean you so? For a fish without a fin, there's a fowl without a feather; If a crow help us in, sirrah, we'll pluck a crow together. 32 For Hamlet, and the trifling of his favour, Hold it a fashion, and a toy in blood: A violet in the youth of primy nature, Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting; The perfume and suppliance of a minute; No more. O, ay!-[Aside to Pedro] Stalk on, stalk on; the fowlsits. One more, and this the last; So sweet was ne'er so fatal. [To the Fool] And thou, his yokefellow of equity, Bench by his side. Well, maist thou haue the Spirit of perswasion;and he the eares of profiting, that what thou speakest,may moue; and what he heares may be beleeued, that thetrue Prince, may (for recreation sake) proue a false theefe;for the poore abuses of the time, wan SO, Come, help: well struck! there was blowfor blow. --When you are hearing a matterbetween party and party, if you chance to be pinched with thecolic, you make faces like mummers, set up the bloody flagagainst all patience, and, in roaring for a chamber-pot, dismissthe controversy bleeding, the more entanBring forth men-children only;For thy undaunted mettle should composeNothing but males. Faith, I must leave thee, love, and shortly too; My operant powers their functions leave to do: And thou shalt live in this fair world behind, Honour?, belov?, and haply one as kind For husband shalt thou,?P. What neede I bee so forward with him,that call's not on me? OTHELLO. If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for, if it touch not you, it comes near nobody. Thou'lt not believe With how deprav'd a qualityO Regan! Reg. do not say 'stand up'; Say 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up. If it be true, all vengeance comes too short Which can pursue th' offender. [to Claudio] Means your lordship to be married tomorrow? Pedro. But, turning these jests out of service, let us talkin good earnest. My lord, you play? once i?the university, you say? [To Polonius. Nay, lay thee down and roar; For thou hast kill'd the sweetest innocent That e'er did lift up eye. [Rising] A wicked day, and not a holy day! What hath this day deserv'd? what hath it done That it in golden letters should be set Among the high tides in the calendar? Nay, rather turn this day out of the week, This day of shame, oppression, perjury; Or Pray now, no more: my mother,Who has a charter to extol her blood,When she does praise me grieves me. Why so it would haue done at the same season,if your Mothers Cat had but kitten'd, though your selfehad neuer beene borne Glend. Then tell us, shall your city call us lord In that behalf which we have challeng'd it; Or shall we give the signal to our rage, And stalk in blood to our possession? CITIZEN. My Father Glendower is not readie yet,Nor shall wee neede his helpe these foureteene dayes:Within that space, you may haue drawne togetherYour Tenants, Friends, and neighbouring Gentlemen Glend. And yet I know not how conceit may rob The treasury of life when life itself Yields to the theft. Think it no more: For nature, crescent, does not grow alone In thews and bulk; but as this temple waxes, The inward service of the mind and soul Grows wide withal. Here, sir; I'd have beaten him like a dog, but fordisturbing the lords within. Then you will bring the chain to her yourself?ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. It is a branch and parcel of mine oath, A charitable duty of my order; Therefore depart, and leave him here with me. Was there ever any man thus beaten out ofseason, When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme nor reason? Well, sir, I thank you. Marry, he trots hard with a young maid between the contract of her marriage and the day it is solemniz'd; if the interim be but a se'nnight, Time's pace is so hard that itseems the length of seven year. Know my name is lost; By treason's tooth bare-gnawn and canker-bit. If I do grow great again,Ile grow lesse? For Ile purge, and leaue Sacke, and liuecleanly, as a Nobleman should do. He is the only man of Italy, Always excepted my dear Claudio. It shall be so, it shall be so; let him away;He's banished, and it shall be so. [Enter with drum and colours, Macbeth, Seyton, and Soldiers. I would not be a Roman, of all nations; I had as lief be acondemned man. If life did ride vpon a Dials point,Still ending at the arriuall of an houre,And if we liue, we liue to treade on Kings:If dye; braue death, when Princes dye with vs. That misbegotten devil, Faulconbridge, In spite of spite, alone upholds the day. O, how fullof briers is this working-day world! CELIA. Sir Robert could do: well-marry, to confess Could he get me? Sir Robert could not do it: We know his handiwork. Fut! I should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on mybastardizing. See how yond justice rails upon yond simple thief. March on, my fellows;Make good this ostentation, and you shallDivide in all with us. Iwill be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over hishen, more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more new-fangledthan an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey. Tear him to pieces, do it presently:--he killed my son; mydaughter; he killed my cousin Marcus; he killed my father,--SECOND LORD. What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel andmake him my waiting gentlewoman? He that hath a beard is more thana youth, and he that hath no beard is less than a man; and hethat is more than a youth is not for me; and he that is less thana man,  Portia, go in awhile, And by and by thy bosom shall partake The secrets of my heart. Speak the speech, I pray you, as I pronounced it to you,82 trippingly on the tongue: but if you mouth it, as many of your players do, I had as lief the town crier spoke my lines. Heavens make our presence and our practices Pleasant and helpful to him! Queen. So angle we for Beatrice, who even now Is couched in the woodbine coverture. God save the King! although I be not he; And yet, amen, if heaven do think him me. Fly, noble English, you are bought and sold; Unthread the rude eye of rebellion, And welcome home again discarded faith. Hee that rides at high speede, and with a Pistollkills a Sparrow flying Falst. But yesterday the word of Caesar might Have stood against the world. There's a girl goes before thepriest; and, certainly, a woman's thought runs before her actions. Look you lay home to him: Tell him his pranks have been too broad to bear with, And that your grace hath screen? and stood between Much heat and him. Now my sick fool Roderigo, Whom love hath turn'd almost the wrong side out, To Desdemona hath tonight caroused Potations pottle-deep; and he's to watch. A trade, sir, that, I hope, I may use with asafe conscience, which is indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles. Who's there? EMILIA. Very well; and could be content to give him good report for't,but that he pays himself with being proud. Fair sir, I pity her, And wish, for her sake more than for mine own, My fortunes were more able to relieve her; But I am shepherd to another man, And do not shear the fleeces that I graze. His rudeness so with his authorized youth Did livery falseness in a pride of truth. Who can be wise, amaz'd, temperate, and furious,Loyal and neutral, in a moment? No man:The expedition of my violent loveOutrun the pauser reason. I make them? Gluttonie and Diseases makethem, I make them not Falst. Examples, gross as earth, exhort me: Witness this army, of such mass and charge, Led by a delicate and tender prince; Whose spirit, with divine ambition puff ?, Makes mouths at the invisible event;117 Exposing what is mortal and unsure To all that fortu First, for his weeping into the needless stream: 'Poor deer,' quoth he 'thou mak'st a testament As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more To that which had too much. Good my friends,If you have heard your general talk of RomeAnd of his friends there, it is lots to blanksMy name hath touch'd your ears: it is Menenius. Marry, the immortall part needes a Physitian:but that moues not him: though that bee sicke, it dyesnot Prince. But I do see you're moved; I am to pray you not to strain my speech To grosser issues nor to larger reach Than to suspicion. I remember at Mile-end-Greene, when I layat Clements Inne, I was then Sir Dagonet in ArthursShow: there was a little quiuer fellow, and hee wouldmanage you his Peece thus: and hee would about,and about, and come you in, and come you in: Rah,tah, tah, wo All disconsolate, With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill. Our preparation stands In expectation of them. Then if thou hastA heart of wreak in thee, that wilt revengeThine own particular wrongs, and stop those maimsOf shame seen through thy country, speed thee straightAnd make my misery serve thy turn: so use itThat my revengeful services may proveAs benefi Do you know Where we may apprehend her and the Moor? RODERIGO. There is a thing,Harry, which thou hast often heard of, and it is knowne tomany in our Land, by the Name of Pitch: this Pitch (asancient Writers doe report) doth defile; so doth the companiethou keepest: for Harry, now I doe not speake tothee in Drinke, If she be black, and thereto have a wit, She'll find a white that shall her blackness fit. Alack, bareheaded? Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel; Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest. Come, seeling night,Scarf up the tender eye of pitiful day;And with thy bloody and invisible handCancel and tear to pieces that great bondWhich keeps me pale!--Light thickens; and the crowMakes wing to the rooky wood:Good things of day begin to droop an Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour, With martial stalk hath he gone by our watch. Do you bandy looks with me, you rascal? [Strikes him. I know you can do very little alone; for your helps are many, orelse your actions would grow wondrous single: your abilities aretoo infant-like for doing much alone. Of this matter Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made, That only wounds by hearsay. Officers, what offence have these men done? Dog. Enter KING JOHN, ARTHUR, and HUBERT KING JOHN. Some to the common pulpits and cry out "Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!" BRUTUS. If I know this, know all the world besides, That part of tyranny that I do bear I can shake off at pleasure. Besides, it were a mock Apt to be render'd, for someone to say "Break up the Senate till another time, When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams. But I have spokeWith one that saw him die: who did report,That very frankly he confess'd his treasons;Implor'd your highness' pardon; and set forthA deep repentance: nothing in his lifeBecame him like the leaving it; he diedAs one that had been studied  In lieu whereof, I pray you, bear me hence From forth the noise and rumour of the field, Where I may think the remnant of my thoughts In peace, and part this body and my soul With contemplation and devout desires. [ADAM retires] OLIVER. Hold your hand, my lord! I have serv'd you ever since I was a child; But better service have I never done you Than now to bid you hold. Who keepes the Gate heere hoa?Where is the Earle? Por. Enter Lear and Gloucester Lear. What a piece of work is man! How noble in reason! how infinite in faculties! in form and moving, how express and admirable! in action how like an angel! in apprehension, how like a god! the65 beauty of the world! the paragon of animals! Bene. You, mistress, That have the office opposite to Saint Peter, And keep the gate of hell! No, no, no life! Why should a dog, a horse, a rat, have life, And thou no breath at all? Thou'lt come no more, Never, never, never, never, never! Pray you undo this button. In what particular thought to work I know not; But, in the gross and scope of my opinion, This bodes some strange eruption to our state. How I came by the Crowne, O heauen forgiue:And grant it may, with thee, in true peace liue Prince. From henceforth bear his name whose form thoubearest: Kneel thou down Philip, but rise more great Arise Sir Richard and Plantagenet. O monstrous! eleuen Buckrom men growneout of two? Bard. Sirrah, you boy, and Bardolph, no word to yourMaster that I am yet in Towne. Old men and beldams in the streets Do prophesy upon it dangerously; Young Arthur's death is common in their mouths; And when they talk of him, they shake their heads, And whisper one another in the ear; And he that speaks doth gripe the hearer's wrist,  O you mighty gods! He kneels. He was not three leagues offwhen I left him. Concerning this, sirO well-painted passion! I am commanded home. That which upholdeth him that thee upholds, His honour. BOLINGBROKE'S camp at BristolEnter BOLINGBROKE, YORK, NORTHUMBERLAND, PERCY, ROSS, WILLOUGHBY,BUSHY and GREEN, prisoners BOLINGBROKE. Mouldie, and Bull-calfe: for you Mouldie, stayat home, till you are past seruice: and for your part, Bull-calfe,grow till you come vnto it: I will none of you Shal. I have too few to take my leave of you, When the tongue's office should be prodigal To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart. We hate alike:Not Afric owns a serpent I abhorMore than thy fame and envy. Scratches with briers,Scars to move laughter only. Thanks for that:There the grown serpent lies; the worm that's fledHath nature that in time will venom breed,No teeth for the present. As I intend to thrive in this new world, Aumerle is guilty of my true appeal. And thou wert best look to't; for if thou dost him any slight disgrace, or if he do not mightily grace himself on thee, he will practise against thee by poison,entrap thee by some treacherous device, and never leave thee till he hath ta'en thy life by s Reuenge the geering and disdain'd contemptOf this proud King, who studies day and nightTo answer all the Debt he owes vnto you,Euen with the bloody Payment of your deaths:Therefore I say Wor. He ask'd the way to Chester: And of himI did demand what Newes from Shrewsbury:He told me, that Rebellion had ill lucke,And that yong Harry Percies Spurre was cold. Whatyou want in meate, wee'l haue in drinke: but you beare,the heart's all Shal. [Within] Break any breaking here, and I'll break your knave's pate. --Let us revenge this with our pikes ere we becomerakes: for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not inthirst for revenge. Out, vile jelly! Where is thy lustre now? Glou. It is an accustomed action with her, to seem thus washing herhands: I have known her continue in this a quarter of an hour. Whiles I may scape, I will preserve myself; and am bethought To take the basest and most poorest shape That ever penury, in contempt of man, Brought near to beast. Awayyou Bottle-Ale Rascall, you Basket-hilt stale Iugler, you. Then turn your forces from this paltry siege And stir them up against a mightier task. I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair werea thought browner; and your gown's a most rare fashion, i'faith. O Gertrude, Gertrude, When sorrows come, they come not single spies, But in battalions! KING PHILIP. We are accounted poor citizens; the patricians good. ' That's as much as to say, 'Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks. --But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs:Rome and her rats are at the point of battle;The one side must have bale. Therefore, at your vantage,Ere he express himself or move the peopleWith what he would say, let him feel your sword,Which we will second. I will giue thee for it a thousand pound: Askeme when thou wilt, and thou shalt haue it Poin. My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge To keep him safely till his day of trial. What canst thou say but will perplex thee more, If thou stand excommunicate and curs'd? KING PHILIP. My lord, I will use them according to their desert. Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part To take on me to keep and kill thy heart. Ere you go, hear this,--As far as doth the Capitol exceedThe meanest house in Rome, so far my son,--This lady's husband here; this, do you see?--Whom you have banish'd does exceed you all. Therefore put you in your best array, bid your friends; for if you will be married to-morrow, you shall; andto Rosalind, if you will. My lord, I did; But answer made it none: yet once methought It lifted up it head, and did address Itself to motion, like as it would speak: But even then the morning cock crew loud, And at the sound it shrunk in haste away, And vanish? from our sight. Nay, good lieutenant! I met a fool i' th' forest, A motley fool. You are my father, for methinks in you I see old Gaunt alive. Thou are too like the spirit of Banquo; down!Thy crown does sear mine eyeballs:--and thy hair,Thou other gold-bound brow, is like the first;--A third is like the former. They say King John, sore sick, hath left the field. To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. A great perturbation in nature,--to receive at once thebenefit of sleep, and do the effects of watching-In thisslumbery agitation, besides her walking and other actualperformances, what, at any time, have you heard her say?GENTLEWOMAN. O grace! O heaven defend me! Are you a man? have you a soul or sense? God be wi' you; take mine office. That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud and loves not thecommon people. For one of them, shee is in Hell alreadie, andburnes poore Soules: for the other, I owe her Money;and whether shee bee damn'd for that, I knownot Host. This is a slave, whose easy-borrowed pride Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows. For the law of writ and the liberty, these are68 the only men. How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head? OTHELLO. Crown him that, And then, I grant, we put a sting in him That at his will he may do danger with. Farewell great heart:Ill-weau'd Ambition, how much art thou shrunke?When that this bodie did containe a spirit,A Kingdome for it was too small a bound:But now two paces of the vilest EarthIs roome enough. What, ho! Prin. Our foster nurse of nature is repose, The which he lacks. If a man do not erect in this age his owntomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than thebell rings and the widow weeps. Only their endsYou have respected; stopped your ears againstThe general suit of Rome; never admittedA private whisper, no, not with such friendsThat thought them sure of you. But I will finde him when he lyes asleepe,And in his eare, Ile holla Mortimer. Women's gentle brain Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention, Such Ethiope words, blacker in their effect Than in their countenance. Epicurism and lust Make it more like a tavern or a brothel Than a grac'd palace. I do beseech you That I may speak with you, O, good my lord! OTHELLO. On Wednesday next, Harry thou shalt set forward:On thursday, wee our selues will march. Art thou gone so? I do but stay behind To do the office for thee of revenge, And then my soul shall wait on thee to heaven, As it on earth hath been thy servant still. Ay, my mother, With all my heart I thank thee for my father! Who lives and dares but say thou didst not well When I was got, I'll send his soul to hell. Go home with it, and please your wife withal; And soon at supper-time I'll visit you, And then receive my money for the chain. But what though? Courage! As hornsare odious, they are necessary. What didst not like? And when I told thee he was of my counsel In my whole course of wooing, thou criedst, "Indeed!" And didst contract and purse thy brow together, As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain Some horrible conceit. Master Shallow, I owe you a thousand pound Shal. But, soft, I pray you, what, did Caesars wound? FOURTH CITIZEN. It is to be all made of sighs and tears; And so am I for Phebe. You shallnever take her without her answer, unless you take her without her tongue. There's little of the melancholy element in her, my lord. The ship is in her trim; the merry wind Blows fair from land; they stay for nought at an But for their owner, master, and yourself. No, no! the drink, the drink!? my dear Hamlet!?The drink, the drink!? am poison?. True to tell thee, The grief hath craz'd my wits. Indeede Ile breakethy little finger Harry, if thou wilt not tel me true Hot. Now bid me run, And I will strive with things impossible, Yea, get the better of them. Lords, you that here are under our arrest, Procure your sureties for your days of answer. Mistress, upon my life, I tell you true; I have not breath'd almost since I did see it. Stop her there! Arms, arms! sword! fire! Corruption in the place! False justicer, why hast thou let her scape? Edg. I was call'd any thing: and I would haue doneany thing indeede too, and roundly too. What three things does drink especially provoke?PORTER. Stand back, Lord Salisbury, stand back, I say; By heaven, I think my sword's as sharp as yours. Therefore, to arms! be champion of our church, Or let the church, our mother, breathe her curse A mother's curse-on her revolting son. Is it honest in deedand word? Is it a true thing? TOUCHSTONE. --You, Titus Lartius,Must to Corioli back: send us to RomeThe best, with whom we may articulateFor their own good and ours. These things, come thus to light, Smother her spirits up. Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel, Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down, And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say: Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest; Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving. That it might please you to give quiet pass Through your dominions for this enterprise, On such regards of safety and allowance As therein are set down. Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love; And thou, thrice-crowned Queen of Night, survey With thy chaste eye, from thy pale sphere above, Thy huntress' name that my full life doth sway. "Speak, strike, redress!" Am I entreated To speak and strike? O Rome, I make thee promise, If the redress will follow, thou receivest Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus! Re-enter Lucius. I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial,nor he durst not give me the Lie Direct; and so we measur'dswords and parted. Let the doors be shut upon him, that he may play the fool nowhere but in? own house. I hope I shall see an end of him; for my soul, yet I know notwhy, hates nothing more than he. Orchard of OLIVER'S houseEnter ORLANDO and ADAM ORLANDO. --My mother bows,As if Olympus to a molehill shouldIn supplication nod: and my young boy Hath an aspect of intercession whichGreat nature cries "Deny not. You Rogue, they were bound, euery man ofthem, or I am a Iew else, an Ebrew Iew Gad. So every bondman in his own hand bears The power to cancel his captivity. How long have you been a sectary astronomical? OTHELLO. First, the fair reverence of your Highness curbs me From giving reins and spurs to my free speech; Which else would post until it had return'd These terms of treason doubled down his throat. Can you, when you havepushed out your gates the very defender of them, and in a violentpopular ignorance, given your enemy your shield, think to fronthis revenges with the easy groans of old women, the virginalpalms of your daughters, or with the palsie Man's nature cannot carry Th' affliction nor the fear. If I may bee beleeued,so: if not, let them that should reward Valour, bearethe sinne vpon their owne heads. My wife comes foremost; then the honour'd mouldWherein this trunk was fram'd, and in her handThe grandchild to her blood. My heart hath melted at a lady's tears, Being an ordinary inundation; But this effusion of such manly drops, This show'r, blown up by tempest of the soul, Startles mine eyes and makes me more amaz'd Than had I seen the vaulty top of heaven Figur'd quite Why, do not your courtier's hands sweat? I am a subject, And I challenge law-attorneys are denied me; And therefore personally I lay my claim To my inheritance of free descent. Pregnancieis made a Tapster, and hath his quicke wit wasted ingiuing Recknings: all the other gifts appertinent to man(as the malice of this Age shapes them) are not woorth aGooseberry. I have us'd it, nuncle, ever since thou mad'st thydaughters thy mother; for when thou gav'st them the rod, and put'stdown thine own breeches, [Sings] Then they for sudden joy did weep, And I for sorrow sung, That such a king should play bo-peep And go t It were a delicate stratagem to shoe A troop of horse with felt. You are pictures out of doors, Bells in your parlors, wildcats in your kitchens, Saints in your injuries, devils being offended, Players in your housewifery, and housewives in your beds. Get thee gone; Buy thou a rope, and bring it home to me. --What would you have, you curs,That like nor peace nor war? The one affrights you,The other makes you proud. Come therefore, and to Thasos send his body; His funerals shall not be in our camp, Lest it discomfort us. Suffer usto famish, and their storehouses crammed with grain; make edictsfor usury, to support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome actestablished against the rich, and provide more piercing statutesdaily to chain up and restrain the poor. If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man. County Claudio, when mean you to go to church? Hero. Say that thou overheard'st us; And bid her steal into the pleached bower, Where honeysuckles, ripened by the sun, Forbid the sun to enter--like favourites, Made proud by princes, that advance their pride Against that power that bred it. Wee haue heard the Chymes at mid-night, MasterShallow Shal. I have seen the day That with this little arm and this good sword I have made my way through more impediments Than twenty times your stop. What is he whose grief Bears such an emphasis? whose phrase of sorrow Conjures the wandering stars, and makes them stand Like wonder-wounded hearers? this is I, Hamlet the Dane. O, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles, That quicken even with blowing. But if you swear by that that not, you are not forsworn; no more wasthis knight, swearing by his honour, for he never had any; or ifhe had, he had sworn it away before ever he saw those pancackesor that mustard. O, balmy breath, that dost almost persuade Justice to break her sword! Some speedy messenger bid her repair To our solemnity. I am very ill at ease, Unfit for mine own purposes. Never alone97 Did the king sigh, but with a general groan. When Pistoll lyes, do this, and figge-me, likeThe bragging Spaniard Fal. It is a high-wrought flood; BRUTUS. Look what thy soul holds dear, imagine it To lie that way thou goest, not whence thou com'st. Man but a rush against Othello's breast, And he retires. O that it could be prou'd,That some Night-tripping-Faiery, had exchang'dIn Cradle-clothes, our Children where they lay,And call'd mine Percy, his Plantagenet:Then would I haue his Harry, and he mine:But let him from my thoughts. The sweet and bitter fool Will presently appear; The one in motley here, The other found out there. Well, my good Lord: he heard of your Gracescomming to Towne. I do; and charge you in the Duke's name to obey me. The proud control of fierce and bloody war, To enforce these rights so forcibly withheld. Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet The noble Brutus, thrusting this report Into his ears. How a good Yokeof Bullocks at Stamford Fayre? Sil. Why you horson round man? what's the matter? Fal. What? drunke with choller? stay & pause awhile,Heere comes your Vnckle. And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so: He must be taught, and train'd, and bid go forth; A barren-spirited fellow, one that feeds On objects, arts, and imitations, Which, out of use and staled by other men, Begin his fashion. But who is substituted 'gainst the French,I haue no certaine notice Arch. His nature is too noble for the world:He would not flatter Neptune for his trident,Or Jove for's power to thunder. You shall close prisoner rest, Till that the nature of your fault be known To the Venetian state. He was but a fool That brought my answer back. Exeunt Desdemona andEmilia. O me, lieutenant! What villains have done this? CASSIO. Was this a face To be oppos'd against the warring winds? To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder? In the most terrible and nimble stroke Of quick cross lightning? to watchpoor perdu! With this thin helm? When we shall meet at compt, This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven, And fiends will snatch at it. left aliue, and they for the Townes end, to beg duringlife. Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass, Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron Can be retentive to the strength of spirit; But life, being weary of these worldly bars, Never lacks power to dismiss itself. If ever I return to you again, I'll bring you comfort. So would not I for your own sake, for I have many ill qualities. No more, no more,Worse then the Sunne in March:This prayse doth nourish Agues: let them come. Brothers, you mixe your Sadnesse with some Feare:This is the English, not the Turkish Court:Not Amurah, an Amurah succeeds,But Harry, Harry: Yet be sad (good Brothers)For (to speake truth) it very well becomes you:Sorrow, so Royally in you appeares,That Exeunt KING RICHARD, some Lords and a Guard BOLINGBROKE. Shall it for shame, be spoken in these dayes,Or fill vp Chronicles in time to come,That men of your Nobility and Power,Did gage them both in an vniust behalfe(As Both of you, God pardon it, haue done)To put downe Richard, that sweet louely Rose,And plantBear it coldly but till midnight, and let the issue showitself. England, bound in with the triumphant sea, Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege Of wat'ry Neptune, is now bound in with shame, With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds; That England, that was wont to conquer others, Hath made a shameful conq I never yet saw man, How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featur'd, But she would spell him backward. Nay, but to live In the rank sweat of an enseamed bed, Stew? in corruption, honeying and making love Over the nasty sty,?Queen. What, ho, Brabantio! Pol. A fox when one has caught her, And such a daughter, Should sure to the slaughter, If my cap would buy a halter. Good countrymen, let me depart alone, And, for my sake, stay here with Antony. There is my hand,You shall be as a Father, to my Youth:My voice shall sound, as you do prompt mine eare,And I will stoope, and humble my Intents,To your well-practis'd, wise Directions. Alas, alas! It is not honesty in me to speak What I have seen and known. And now about the cauldron sing,Like elves and fairies in a ring,Enchanting all that you put in. He took me by the wrist, and held me hard; Then goes he to the length of all his arm; And with his other hand thus o?r his brow, He falls to such perusal of my face As he would draw it. Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature, if itbe well used. The merciless Macdonwald,--Worthy to be a rebel,--for to thatThe multiplying villainies of natureDo swarm upon him,--from the Western islesOf kerns and gallowglasses is supplied;And fortune, on his damned quarrel smiling,Show'd like a rebel's whore. And this may help to thicken other proofs That do demonstrate thinly. He reads much, He is a great observer, and he looks Quite through the deeds of men. When they are set, enter MOWBRAY, Duke of Nor folk, in arms, defendant, and a HERALD KING RICHARD. (reads) 'If any man of quality or degree within the listsof the army will maintain upon Edmund, supposed Earl ofGloucester, that he is a manifold traitor, let him appear by the thirdsound of the trumpet. This, in the Name of Heauen, I promise here:The which, if I performe, and doe suruiue,I doe beseech your Maiestie, may salueThe long-growne Wounds of my intemperature:If not, the end of Life cancells all Bands,And I will dye a hundred thousand Deaths,EreAnd I'll be sworn upon't that he loves her; For here's a paper written in his hand, A halting sonnet of his own pure brain, Fashion'd to Beatrice. Help, uncle! When I do stare, see how the subject quakes. Come, leave your tears; a brief farewell:--he beastWith many heads butts me away. My lord, I know not what the matter is; but to myjudgment your Highness is not entertain'd with that ceremoniousaffection as you were wont. A man is master of his liberty; Time is their master, and when they see time, They'll go or come. I know not the contents; but, as I guess By the stern brow and waspish action Which she did use as she was writing of it, It bears an angry tenour. Is not this a rare fellow, my lord? He's as good at any thing, and yet a fool. I had a thing to say-but let it go: The sun is in the heaven, and the proud day, Attended with the pleasures of the world, Is all too wanton and too full of gawds To give me audience. There is none but heWhose being I do fear: and under him,My genius is rebuk'd; as, it is said,Mark Antony's was by Caesar. Shall we clap into't roundly, without hawking, or spitting, or saying we are hoarse, which are the onlyprologues to a bad voice? SECOND PAGE. By Heauen (Poines) I feele me much to blame,So idly to prophane the precious time,When Tempest of Commotion, like the South,Borne with black Vapour, doth begin to melt,And drop vpon our bare vnarmed heads. But if not, then know The peril of our curses fight on thee So heavy as thou shalt not shake them off, But in despair die under the black weight. Goes it against the main of Poland, sir, Or for some frontier? Capt. keep good quarter and good care to-night; The day shall not be up so soon as I To try the fair adventure of to-morrow. So, so, (thou common Dogge) did'st thou disgorgeThy glutton-bosome of the Royall Richard,And now thou would'st eate thy dead vomit vp,And howl'st to finde it. Art thou not asham'd? But Sirrah, henceforthLet me not heare you speake of Mortimer. I have charged thee not to haunt about my doors. Then yield thee, coward,And live to be the show and gaze o' the time:We'll have thee, as our rarer monsters are,Painted upon a pole, and underwrit,"Here may you see the tyrant. The Queen returns, finds the King dead, and makes passionate action. Know'st thou not the Duke Hath banish'd me, his daughter? ROSALIND. I will deny thee nothing, Whereon, I do beseech thee, grant me this, To leave me but a little to myself. The yearly course that brings this day about Shall never see it but a holiday. Vengeance! plague! death! confusion! Why, Gloucester, Gloucester, I'ld speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife. But were I Brutus, And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue In every wound of Caesar that should move The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny. Stand from him, giue him ayre:Hee'le straight be well Clar. Know we this face or no? CASSIO. As thick as hailCame post with post; and every one did bearThy praises in his kingdom's great defense,And pour'd them down before him. Others there are Who, trimm'd in forms and visages of duty, Keep yet their hearts attending on themselves, And throwing but shows of service on their lords Do well thrive by them; and when they have lined their coats Do themselves homage. Exit Balthasar [with Musicians]. It seem'd in mee,But as an Honour snatch'd with boyst'rous hand,And I had many liuing, to vpbraideMy gaine of it, by their Assistances,Which dayly grew to Quarrell, and to Blood-shed,Wounding supposed Peace. O, Spare me not, my brother Edward's son, For that I was his father Edward's son; That blood already, like the pelican, Hast thou tapp'd out, and drunkenly carous'd. Most necessary ?is that we forget To pay ourselves what to ourselves is debt: What to ourselves in passion we propose, The passion ending, doth the purpose lose. Most sweet voices!--Better it is to die, better to starve, Than crave the hire which first we do deserve. How long shall I be patient? Ah, how long Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong? Leon. So that, dear lords, if I be left behind, A moth of peace, and he go to the war, The rites for which I love him are bereft me, And I a heavy interim shall support By his dear absence. Whenhee was naked, hee was, for all the world, like a forkedRadish, with a Head fantastically caru'd vpon it with aKnife. How now? This milky gentleness and course of yours, Though I condemn it not, yet, under pardon, You are much more at task for want of wisdom Than prais'd for harmful mildness. Enter HUBERT [Aside] Hubert, what news with you? PEMBROKE. Some good man bear him carefully from hence; I'll fetch the general's surgeon. A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd With letters of your love to her at large. Butthese are all lies: men have died from time to time, and worms have eaten them, but not for love. Nay, anthou canst not smile as the wind sits, thou'lt catch coldshortly. And if it sort not well, you may conceal her, As best befits her wounded reputation, In some reclusive and religious life, Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries. Adam?Carson?Aimee?Echo?Alan?Moore?Albert?Schweitzer?Albert?Einstein?Alec?Baldwin?Alexandra?Paul?Alice?Walker?Alicia?Silverstone?Alison?Lohman?Ally?Sheedy?Alyssa?Milano?Amber?Valletta?Amber?Benson?Amy?Ray?Anastasia?Ashley?Andre?3000?Andreas?Cahling?AndrewGood Master Doctor, see him safe convey'd Home to my house. O, is that all? TOUCHSTONE. It is a pretty youthnot very pretty; But, sure, he's proud; and yet his pride becomes him. I cannot strike at wretched kerns, whose armsAre hired to bear their staves; either thou, Macbeth,Or else my sword, with an unbatter'd edge,I sheathe again undeeded. As I learn'd, The night before there was no purpose in them Of this remove. You know my father hath no child but I, nor none is liketo have; and, truly, when he dies thou shalt be his heir; forwhat he hath taken away from thy father perforce, I will renderthee again in affection. Come, come, you are well understood to be a perfecter giberfor the table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol. I am glad I have found this napkin; This was her first remembrance from the Moor. Thou said'stO, it comes o'er my memory, As doth the raven o'er the infected house, Boding to allhe had my handkerchief. Therefore sirra, with a new wound in your thighcome you along me. Sir, this gentleman Steps in to Cassio and entreats his pause. How stiff is my vile sense, That I stand up, and have ingenious feeling Of my huge sorrows! Better I were distract. " Now, in the names of all the gods at once, Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed That he is grown so great? Age, thou art shamed! Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods! When went there by an age since the great flood But it was famed with mHe gives the web and the pin, squints the eye, and makes the harelip; mildews the whitewheat, and hurts the poor creature of earth. I do follow here in the chase, not like a hound that hunts, but one that fills up the cry. But as the Deuill would haue it, three mis-begottenKnaues, in Kendall Greene, came at my Back, andlet driue at me; for it was so darke, Hal, that thou could'stnot see thy Hand Prin. Good faith, a little one; not past a pint, as I am a soldier. It may be so; but yet my inward soul Persuades me it is otherwise. Great Dunsinane he strongly fortifies:Some say he's mad; others, that lesser hate him,Do call it valiant fury: but, for certain,He cannot buckle his distemper'd causeWithin the belt of rule. Now I change my mind, And partly credit things that do presage. For that he has,--As much as in him lies,--from time to timeEnvied against the people, seeking meansTo pluck away their power; as now at lastGiven hostile strokes, and that not in the presenceOf dreaded justice, but on the ministersThat do distribute it;I embrace it freely; And will this brother? wager frankly play. He that's comingMust be provided for: and you shall putThis night's great business into my despatch;Which shall to all our nights and days to comeGive solely sovereign sway and masterdom. I will, my Lord: there are two GentlemenHaue in this Robberie lost three hundred Markes Prince. O my poore Kingdome (sicke, with ciuill blowes)When that my Care could not with-hold thy Ryots,What wilt thou do, when Ryot is thy Care?O, thou wilt be a Wildernesse againe,Peopled with Wolues (thy old Inhabitants. Marry, that should you, if I were your mistress; or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit. And truly, I'll devise some honest slanders To stain my cousin with. Down on your knees, And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love; For I must tell you friendly in your ear: Sell when you can; you are not for all markets. Titinius is enclosed round about With horsemen, that make to him on the spur; Yet he spurs on. Exchange me for a goat When I shall turn the business of my soul To such exsufflicate and blown surmises, Matching thy inference. It may be so: if he haue robb'd these men,He shall be answerable: and so farewell She. Ile haue the Currant in this place damn'd vp,And here the smug and Siluer Trent shall runne,In a new Channell, faire and euenly:It shall not winde with such a deepe indent,To rob me of so rich a Bottome here Glend. How far is't call'd to Forres?--What are theseSo wither'd, and so wild in their attire,That look not like the inhabitants o' the earth,And yet are on't?--Live you? Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius, And mayst be honor'd, being Cato's son. Sure, these are but imaginary wiles, And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here. ExeuntEXECUTIONERS ARTHUR. I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard, Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke, Fulfill your pleasure. Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner, Or, for my diamond, the chain you promis'd, And I'll be gone, sir, and not trouble you. They did so; to the amazement of mine eyes,That look'd upon't. I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of Rosalind,I am that he, that unfortunate he. Honour, high honour, and renown, To Hymen, god of every town! DUKE SENIOR. I thought the King had more affected the Duke of Albanythan Cornwall. The consequence is, then, thy jealous fits Hath scar'd thy husband from the use of wits. There hath been in Rome strange insurrections: the peopleagainst the senators, patricians, and nobles. Iacke, meet me tomorrow in the Temple HallAt two a clocke in the afternoone,There shalt thou know thy Charge, and there receiueMoney and Order for their Furniture. Your master, Pindarus, In his own change, or by ill officers, Hath given me some worthy cause to wish Things done undone; but if he be at hand, I shall be satisfied. Kent banish'd thus? and France in choler parted? Edm. Some good I mean to do, Despite of mine own nature. But who comes here? TITINIUS. One woman is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yetI am well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all graces bein one woman, one woman shall not come in my grace. Do so, and let no man abide this deed But we the doers. I would it were bed time Hal, and all well Prin. Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field, Streaming the ensign of the Christian cross Against black pagans, Turks, and Saracens; And, toil'd with works of war, retir'd himself To Italy; and there, at Venice, g Why do you speak so faintly? ROSALIND. O masters! If I were disposed to stir Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I should do Brutus wrong and Cassius wrong, Who, you all know, are honorable men. If he dote on her upon this, I will never trust my expectation. You have seen Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears Were like, a better way. Troilushad his brains dash'd out with a Grecian club; yet he did what he could to die before, and he is one of the patterns of love. Now, when the Lords and Barons of the RealmePerceiu'd Northumberland did leane to him,The more and lesse came in with Cap and Knee,Met him in Boroughs, Cities, Villages,Attended him on Bridges, stood in Lanes,Layd Gifts before him, proffer'd him their OaOf so high and plenteous wit and invention IAGO. What an eye she has! So foul a sky clears not without a storm. Poor and content is rich, and rich enough; But riches fineless is as poor as winter To him that ever fears he shall be poor. But, ah, I will not! It doth amaze me A man of such a feeble temper should So get the start of the majestic world And bear the palm alone. How now, you secret, black, and midnight hags!What is't you do?ALL. Silvius, the time was that I hated thee; And yet it is not that I bear thee love; But since that thou canst talk of love so well, Thy company, which erst was irksome to me, I will endure; and I'll employ thee too. Your If is the only peace-maker; much virtue in If. Wretched though I seem, I can produce a champion that will prove What is avouched there. O my liege, Pardon me, if you please; if not, I, pleas'd Not to be pardoned, am content withal. The time hath been, Would you have been so brief with him, he would Have been so brief with you to shorten you, For taking so the head, your whole head's length. Sweetest nut hath sourest rind, Such a nut is Rosalinde. Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue, Doubly portcullis'd with my teeth and lips; And dull, unfeeling, barren ignorance Is made my gaoler to attend on me. Dowglas is liuing, and your Brother, yet:But for my Lord, your Sonne North. Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw The smallest fear or doubt of her revolt; For she had eyes and chose me. Very well (my Lord) very well: rather an't pleaseyou) it is the disease of not Listning, the malady of notMarking, that I am troubled withall Iust. Enter [at one door] Leonato and [at another door, Antonio] an oldman,brother to Leonato. Brutus, I do observe you now of late; I have not from your eyes that gentleness And show of love as I was wont to have; You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand Over your friend that loves you. ?oubt thou the stars are fire;58 Doubt that the sun doth move; Doubt truth to be a liar; But never doubt I love. I' the shoulder and i' the left arm; there will be largecicatrices to show the people when he shall stand for his place. What dost thou mean? IAGO. --'Look, sir,--my wounds;--I got them in my country's service, whenSome certain of your brethren roar'd, and ranFrom the noise of our own drums. Not one amongst us, save yourself, but saysHe us'd us scornfully: he should have show'd usHis marks of merit, wounds received for's country. Then, worthy Marcius,Attend upon Cominius to these wars. Thou canst not say I did it: never shakeThy gory locks at me. Iohn Falstaffe Knight: (Euery man mustknow that, as oft as hee hath occasion to name himselfe:)Euen like those that are kinne to the King, for they neuerpricke their finger, but they say, there is som of the kingsblood spilt. The next news is, I have to London sent The heads of Salisbury, Spencer, Blunt, and Kent. But jealous souls will not be answer'd so; They are not ever jealous for the cause, But jealous for they are jealous. Thou bring'st me happinesse and Peace(Sonne Iohn:)But health (alacke) with youthfull wings is flowneFrom this bare, wither'd Trunke. O nuncle, court holy water in a dry house is better thanthis rain water out o' door. O, well begg'd!Were he the butcher of my son, he shouldBe free as is the wind. Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt prove a notable argument. O Lewis, stand fast! Queen. Then pause not; for the present time's so sick That present med'cine must be minist'red Or overthrow incurable ensues. What ill request did Brutus make to thee? DARDANIUS. What, keep a week away? seven days and nights? Eight score eight hours? and lovers' absent hours, More tedious than the dial eight score times? O weary reckoning! CASSIO. O heaven! How got she out? O treason of the blood! Fathers, from hence trust not your daughters' minds By what you see them act. I will attend my husband, be his nurse, Diet his sickness, for it is my office, And will have no attorney but myself; And therefore let me have him home with me. This act, so evilly borne, shall cool the hearts Of all his people and freeze up their zeal, That none so small advantage shall step forth To check his reign but they will cherish it; No natural exhalation in the sky, No scope of nature, no distemper'd  [Beats the KEEPER] KEEPER. 'Tis true, fair daughter, and this blessed day Ever in France shall be kept festival. My father hath a power; inquire of him, And learn to make a body of a limb. What devil was? That thus hath cozen? you at hoodman-blind? Eyes without feeling, feeling without sight, Ears without hands or eyes, smelling sans all, Or but a sickly part of one true sense Could not so mope. O Gertrude, come away! The sun no sooner shall the mountains touch But we will ship him hence: and this vile deed We must with all our ma jesty and skill Both countenance and excuse. Now, our joy, Although the last, not least; to whose young love The vines of France and milk of Burgundy Strive to be interest; what can you say to draw A third more opulent than your sisters? Speak. Husband, I cannot pray that thou mayst win; Uncle, I needs must pray that thou mayst lose; Father, I may not wish the fortune thine; Grandam, I will not wish thy wishes thrive. How now, wit! Fal. We will ourself in person to this war; And, for our coffers, with too great a court And liberal largess, are grown somewhat light, We are enforc'd to farm our royal realm; The revenue whereof shall furnish us For our affairs in hand. And say, what store of parting tears were shed?
