I'll prove it onthy heart, Ere I taste bread, thou art in nothing less Than I have here proclaim'd thee. I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife. Mistress, 'respice finem,' respect your end;or rather, to prophesy like the parrot, 'Beware the rope's-end. I am a very foolish fond old man, Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less; And, to deal plainly, I fear I am not in my perfect mind. The night has been unruly: where we lay,Our chimneys were blown down: and, as they say,Lamentings heard i' the air, strange screams of death;And prophesying, with accents terrible,Of dire combustion and confus'd events,New hatch'd to the woeful time: theStraight satisfy yourself: If she be in her chamber or your house, Let loose on me the justice of the state For thus deluding you. Where is his Sonne,The nimble-footed Mad-Cap, Prince of Wales,And his Cumrades, that daft the World aside,And bid it passe? And will you give me leave? ALL. I pray you, sir, go forth, And give us truth who 'tis that is arrived. [Within] Let him walk from whence he came, lest he catch cold on's feet. Or, when he doom'd this beauty to a grave, Found it too precious-princely for a grave. Choler!Were I as patient as the midnight sleep,By Jove, 'twould be my mind!SICINIUS. I have two nights watched with you, but can perceive notruth in your report. So did I too, and he swore he would marry her tonight. I think it is not meet Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar, Should outlive Caesar. Come, I charge youboth go with me: for the man is dead, that you and Pistollbeate among you Dol. Which done, she took the fruits of my advice; And he, repulsed,? short tale to make,?Fell into a sadness; then into a fast; Thence to a watch; thence into a weakness;59 Thence to a lightness; and, by this declension, Into the madness wherein now he rave My gracious Lord, you looke beyond him quite:The Prince but studies his Companions,Like a strange Tongue: wherein, to gaine the Language,'Tis needfull, that the most immodest wordBe look'd vpon, and learn'd: which once attayn'd,Your Highnesse knowes, co Who dares receive it other,As we shall make our griefs and clamor roarUpon his death?MACBETH. My lord, in the base court he doth attend To speak with you; may it please you to come down? KING RICHARD. If it be true that good wine needs no bush, 'tis true that a goodplay needs no epilogue. He said he had wounds, which he could show in private;And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn,'I would be consul,' says he; 'aged customBut by your voices, will not so permit me;Your voices therefore:' when we granted that,Here was, 'I thank you for yoThe evil that men do lives after them, The good is oft interred with their bones; So let it be with Caesar. Say on (my Lord of Westmerland) in peace:What doth concerne your comming? West. A very forward March-chick! How came you to this? Bora. But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter; Or rather a disease that's in my flesh, Which I must needs call mine. If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him, I spurn thee like a cur out of my way. O, let me have no subject enemies When adverse foreigners affright my towns With dreadful pomp of stout invasion! Be Mercury, set feathers to thy heels, And fly like thought from them to me again. I?l warrant you: Fear me not:?ithdraw; I hear him coming. The Poisoner with some three or four Mutes, comes in again, seeming to lament with her. It hath it originall from much greefe; from studyand perturbation of the braine. Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart, Crying "Long live! Hail, Caesar!" CASSIUS. So please your Majesty That we may wake the King? He hath slept long. Yet she must die, else she'll betray more men. I begin to find an idle and fond bondage in the oppression of aged tyranny, whosways, not as it hath power, but as it is suffer'd. ' So that my errand, due unto my tongue, I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders; For, in conclusion, he did beat me there. Sir, if you'd save your life, fly to your house:The plebeians have got your fellow-tribuneAnd hale him up and down; all swearing, ifThe Roman ladies bring not comfort homeThey'll give him death by inches. An he should, it were an alms to hang him! She's an excellent sweet lady, and (out of all suspicion) she isvirtuous. LayA fault on us, your tribunes; that we labour'd,--No impediment between,--but that you must Cast your election on him. They are; and Bolingbroke Hath seiz'd the wasteful King. She and the Duke her husband! Enter, with Drum and Colours, Albany, Goneril, Soldiers. Exeunt Desdemona andEmilia. It shall do well: but yet do I believe The origin and commencement of his grief Sprung from neglected love. To what base uses we may return, Horatio! Why may not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander till he find it stopping a bung-hole? Hor. Tell him, so please him come unto this place, He shall be satisfied and, by my honor, Depart untouch'd. What then became of them I cannot tell; I to this fortune that you see me in. Who sets me else? By heaven, I'll throw at all! I have a thousand spirits in one breast To answer twenty thousand such as you. Caesar shall forth: the things that threaten'd me Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see The face of Caesar, they are vanished. The very spirit of Plantagenet! I am thy grandam, Richard: call me so. The courtEnter the KING, with BAGOT and GREEN, at one door;and the DUKE OF AUMERLE at another KING RICHARD. Exeunt [Dogberry and Verges]. SONG Blow, blow, thou winter wind, Thou art not so unkind As man's ingratitude; Thy tooth is not so keen, Because thou art not seen, Although thy breath be rude. What I believe, I'll wail;What know, believe; and what I can redress,As I shall find the time to friend, I will. Faith, we met, and found the quarrel was upon the seventh cause. This is not Brutus, friend, but, I assure you, A prize no less in worth. We two alone will sing like birds i' th' cage. Horatio says ?is but our fantasy, And will not let belief take hold of him Touching this dreaded sight, twice seen of us: Therefore I have entreated him along With us to watch the minutes of this night; That, if again this apparition come17 He may appro Rejoice, you men of Angiers, ring your bells: King John, your king and England's, doth approach, Commander of this hot malicious day. Do not think, gentlemen, I am drunk: this is my ancient, this is my right hand, and this is my left. O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels. At that sad stop, my lord, Where rude misgoverned hands from windows' tops Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head. It cannot be (my Lord:)Rumor doth double, like the Voice, and Eccho,The numbers of the feared. Then if he says he loves you, It fits your wisdom so far to believe it As he in his particular act and place May give his saying deed; which is no further Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal. [aside] I should think this a gull but that thewhite-bearded fellow speaks it. Run, run, Orlando; carve on every tree, The fair, the chaste, and unexpressive she. He said sir, the water it selfe was a good healthywater: but for the party that ow'd it, he might haue morediseases then he knew for Fal. While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred. I giue it you, and will maintaine my word:And thereupon I drinke vnto your Grace Hast. O, I am press'd to death through want of speaking! He hath a stern look but a gentle heart. Silence, Ile giueyou a health for that anon Shal. Firm and irrevocable is my doom Which I have pass'd upon her; she is banish'd. The Duke, my husband, and my children both, And you the calendars of their nativity, Go to a gossips' feast, and go with me; After so long grief, such nativity!DUKE. Welcome hither:I have begun to plant thee, and will laborTo make thee full of growing. Is't lost? is't gone? speak, is it out o' the way? DESDEMONA. To be thus is nothing;But to be safely thus:--our fears in Banquo. If that it be the work of any hand! We had a kind of light what would ensue. I have five hundred crowns, The thrifty hire I sav'd under your father, Which I did store to be my foster-nurse, When service should in my old limbs lie lame, And unregarded age in corners thrown. O Villain, thou hast stol'n both mine office and my name! The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame. Enter Publius, Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca, Trebonius, and Cinna. The orchard at Swinstead AbbeyEnter PRINCE HENRY, SALISBURY, and BIGOT PRINCE HENRY. Can he be angry? I have seen the cannon, When it hath blown his ranks into the air And, like the devil, from his very arm Puff'd his own brother. Some trumpet summon hither to the walls These men of Angiers; let us hear them speak Whose title they admit, Arthur's or John's. ; in whose name myself Attach thee as a traitorous innovator,A foe to the public weal. But look where sadly the poor wretch comes reading. But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on the sensible Benedick's head? Claud. To-morrow then I will expect your coming; To-night I take my leave. Anchud ha' bin zwagger'd out of my life, 'twould not ha' bin zolong as 'tis by a vortnight. Did'st thou? Lord, Lord, how the world is giuento Lying? I graunt you I was downe, and out of breath,and so was he, but we rose both at an instant, and foughta long houre by Shrewsburie clocke. Marry, this is miching mallecho; it means mischief. I prithee, let thy wife attend on her, And bring them after in the best advantage. Thou liest, thou shag-haar'd villain!FIRST MURDERER. And Princes all, beleeue me, I beseech you:My Father is gone wilde into his Graue,(For in his Tombe, lye my Affections)And with his Spirits, sadly I suruiue,To mocke the expectation of the World;To frustrate Prophesies, and to race outRotten Opinion, whoThink what you will, we seize into our hands His plate, his goods, his money, and his lands. I do protest I never lov'd myself Till now infixed I beheld myself Drawn in the flattering table of her eye. Talk with a man out at a window!-a proper saying! Bene. Had it pleased heaven To try me with affliction, had they rain'd All kinds of sores and shames on my bare head, Steep'd me in poverty to the very lips, Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes, I should have found in some place of my soul A drop of pat Ha? CORIN. Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays, and all. Thou ow'st the worm no silk, thebeast no hide, the sheep no wool, the cat no perfume. Thrust him downe stayres? know we not GallowayNagges? Enter a Servant. Let? further think of this; Weigh what convenience both of time and means May fit us to our shape: if this should fail, And that our drift look through our bad performance. My lord, the first time that I ever saw him Methought he was a brother to your daughter. How much better is it to weep atjoy than to joy at weeping! Beat. The trumpets, sackbuts, psalteries, and fifes,Tabors and cymbals, and the shouting Romans,Make the sun dance. 73 Yet I, A dull and muddy-mettled rascal, peak, Like John-a-dreams, unpregnant of my cause, And can say nothing; no, not for a king Upon whose property and most dear life A damn? defeat was made. Well, to the latter end of a Fray, and the beginningof a Feast, fits a dull fighter, and a keene Guest. I swear 'tis better to be much abused Than but to know't a little. A crowd of people, among them Artemidorus and the Soothsayer. Let your study Be to content your lord, who hath receiv'd you At fortune's alms. They love not poison that do poison need, Nor do I thee. And, noble uncle, I beseech your Grace Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye. I do attend here on the general; And think it no addition, nor my wish, To have him see me woman'd. Hail to your Grace! Prince. You touch'd my vein at first: the thorny point Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show Of smooth civility; yet arn I inland bred, And know some nurture. It is his hand, my lord; but I hope his heart is not inthe contents. Why, what a poxe haue I to doe with my Hostesseof the Tauerne? Fal. Open your Eares: For which of you will stopThe vent of Hearing, when loud Rumor speakes?I, from the Orient, to the drooping West(Making the winde my Post-horse) still vnfoldThe Acts commenced on this Ball of Earth. By the kind gods, 'tis most ignobly done To pluck me by the beard. If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself, take thought and die for Caesar. What if I do obey? Is it not past two o'clock? And here much Orlando! CELIA. O, let us have him, for his silver hairs Will purchase us a good opinion, And buy men's voices to commend our deeds. 'Shall'!O good, but most unwise patricians! why,You grave but reckless senators, have you thusGiven Hydra leave to choose an officer,That with his peremptory 'shall,' being butThe horn and noise o' the monster, wants not spiritTo say he'll turn your currEngland, thou hast not sav'd one drop of blood In this hot trial more than we of France; Rather, lost more. I prethee Tom, beate Cuts Saddle, put a fewFlockes in the point: the poore Iade is wrung in the withers,out of all cesse. Yes, Cassius, and from henceforth, When you are overearnest with your Brutus, He'll think your mother chides, and leave you so. Ay, sir: there are a crew of wretched soulsThat stay his cure: their malady convincesThe great assay of art; but, at his touch,Such sanctity hath heaven given his hand,They presently amend. Take thy fair hour, Laertes; time be thine, And thy best graces spend it at thy will!?But now, my cousin Hamlet, and my son?Ham. Why that was well said: A good heart's worthGold. I'll beg one boon, And then be gone and trouble you no more. I would thou could'st stammer, that thou mightst pour this conceal'dman out of thy mouth, as wine comes out of narrow-mouth'd bottle either too much at once or none at all. I heard him swear,Were he to stand for consul, never would heAppear i' the market-place, nor on him putThe napless vesture of humility;Nor, showing, as the manner is, his woundsTo the people, beg their stinking breaths. One that was a woman, sir; but, rest her soul, she? dead. Therefore, merchant, I'll limit thee this day To seek thy help by beneficial hap. Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty? Bene. How hard it is for women to keep counsel! Art thou here yet? LUCIUS. O, let my sovereign turn away his face And bid his ears a little while be deaf, Till I have told this slander of his blood How God and good men hate so foul a liar. Come, come, go in with me: 'tis with my MindeAs with the Tyde, swell'd vp vnto his height,That makes a still-stand, running neyther way. And you, my noble Prince, With other princes that may best be spar'd, Shall wait upon your father's funeral. Thou that threw'st dust vpon his goodly headWhen through proud London he came sighing on,After th' admired heeles of Bullingbrooke,Cri'st now, O Earth, yeeld vs that King againe,And take thou this (O thoughts of men accurs'd)``Past, and to Come, seemes bIt is but as a Body, yet distemper'd,Which to his former strength may be restor'd,With good aduice, and little Medicine:My Lord Northumberland will soone be cool'd King. All my engagements I will construe to thee, All the charactery of my sad brows. Well said, good Womans Tailour: Well saydeCouragious Feeble: thou wilt bee as valiant as the wrathfullDoue, or most magnanimous Mouse. Enter CONSTANCE Look who comes here! a grave unto a soul; Holding th' eternal spirit, against her will, In the vile prison of afflicted breath. She robs thee of thy name; And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous When she is gone. And why, sir, must they so? The why is plain as way to parish church: He that a fool doth very wisely hit Doth very foolishly, although he smart, Not to seem senseless of the bob; if not, The wise man's folly is anatomiz'd Even by the squand'ring glance No more of that good Master Shallow: Nomore of that Shal. Then the liars and swearers are fools: for there are liarsand swearers enow to beat the honest men and hang up them. I twice five hundred, and their friends to piece 'em. Of all the wonders that I yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear Seeing that death, a necessary end, Will come when it will come. Not in this land shall he remain uncaught; And founddispatch. O, come, go in,And take our friendly senators by the hands;Who now are here, taking their leaves of me,Who am prepar'd against your territories,Though not for Rome itself. Here, friend, is another purse; in it a jewel Well worth a poor man's taking. Exit SERVINGMAN Gentlemen, will you go muster men? If I know how or which way to order these affairs Thus disorderly thrust into my hands, Never believe me. I am not valiant neither, But every puny whipster gets my sword. Away! the foul fiend follows me! Through the sharphawthorn blows the cold wind. And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine. O, stand up bless'd!Whilst, with no softer cushion than the flint,I kneel before thee; and unproperlyShow duty, as mistaken all this whileBetween the child and parent. O, now you look like Hubert! All this while You were disguis'd. "I call'd my love false love; but what said he then? Sing willow, willow, willow. Yet stay awhile, Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse Into the marketplace. ' IfI do not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not loveher, I am a Jew. An if I do not, may my hands rot of And never brandish more revengeful steel Over the glittering helmet of my foe! ANOTHER LORD. There's hell, there's darkness, there's the sulphurous pit; burning, scalding, stench, consumption. I have seen better faces in my time Than stands on any shoulder that I see Before me at this instant. Enter BOLINGBROKE, the DUKE OF YORK, With other LORDSand attendants BOLINGBROKE. Farewell Kinsman: Ile talke to youWhen you are better temper'd to attend Nor. Marry, do I, sir; and I came to acquaint you with a matter. Only make trial what your love can doFor Rome, towards Marcius. Then you must say 'I take thee, Rosalind, for wife. As much good stay with thee as go with me! DUCHESS. What in theworld he is That names me traitor, villain-like he lies. The spirit of my father growsstrong in me, and I will no longer endure it; therefore allow me such exercises as may become a gentleman, or give me the poor allottery my father left me by testament; with that I will gobuy my fortunes. O, to what purpose dost thou hoard thy words, That thou returnest no greeting to thy friends? BOLINGBROKE. 'Tis more then time: And (my most Noble Lord)I heare for certaine, and do speake the truth:The gentle Arch-bishop of Yorke is vpWith well appointed Powres: he is a manWho with a double Surety bindes his Followers. I prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold Can in this desert place buy entertainment, Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed. From seventeen years till now almost four-score Here lived I, but now live here no more. I take my leave before I have begun, For sorrow ends not when it seemeth done. But which of you was by(You Cousin Neuil, as I may remember)When Richard, with his Eye, brim-full of Teares,(Then check'd, and rated by Northumberland)Did speake these words (now prou'd a Prophecie:)Northumberland, thou Ladder, by the whichMy Cousin Bul Who knocks so lowd at doore? Looke to thedoore there, Francis?Enter Peto. How now, brother Edmund? What serious contemplation areyou in? Edm. Good King, that must approve the common saw, Thou out of heaven's benediction com'st To the warm sun! Approach, thou beacon to this under globe, That by thy comfortable beams I may Peruse this letter. It is the base (though bitter) disposition ofBeatrice that puts the world into her person and so gives me out. Behold yond simp'ring dame, Whose face between her forks presageth snow, That minces virtue, and does shake the head To hear of pleasure's name. Shut your mouth, dame, Or with this paper shall I stop it. And here's another, whose warp'd looks proclaim What store her heart is made on. When euer yet was your Appeale deny'd?Wherein haue you beene galled by the King?What Peere hath beene suborn'd, to grate on you,That you should seale this lawlesse bloody BookeOf forg'd Rebellion, with a Seale diuine? Bish. To thee and thine hereditary ever Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom, No less in space, validity, and pleasure Than that conferr'd on Goneril. Consider further,That when he speaks not like a citizen, You find him like a soldier: do not takeHis rougher accents for malicious sounds,But, as I say, such as become a soldier,Rather than envy you. King John, this is the very sum of all: England and Ireland, Anjou, Touraine, Maine, In right of Arthur, do I claim of thee; Wilt thou resign them and lay down thy arms? KING JOHN. O, I have heard him speak of that same brother; And he did render him the most unnatural That liv'd amongst men. Take leave, and part; for you must part forthwith. 'For further I could say this man's untrue, And knew the patterns of his foul beguiling; Heard where his plants in others' orchards grew; Saw how deceits were gilded in his smiling; Knew vows were ever brokers to defiling; Thought characters and words m Sir Iohn, I prythee leaue the Prince & me alone,I will lay him downe such reasons for this aduenture, thathe shall go Fal. He that has a house to put 's head in has a goodhead-piece. Blasts and fogs upon thee! Th' untented woundings of a father's curse Pierce every sense about thee!Old fond eyes, Beweep this cause again, I'll pluck ye out, And cast you, with the waters that you lose, To temper clay. What are you then determined to do? BRUTUS. Come, I will goe drinke with you, but I cannottarry dinner. Thou say'st well, and it holds well too: for thefortune of vs that are the Moones men, doeth ebbe andflow like the Sea, beeing gouerned as the Sea is, by theMoone: as for proofe. Exeunt ORLANDO and ADAM OLIVER. You are welcome: but my uncle-father and aunt-mother are deceived. Let's then determine With th' ancient of war on our proceeding. Will you go see the order of the course? BRUTUS. [Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS with a trumpet. O Villaine, thou stolest a Cup of Sacke eighteeneyeeres agoe, and wert taken with the manner, andeuer since thou hast blusht extempore: thou hadst fireand sword on thy side, and yet thou ranst away; whatinstinct hadst thou for it? Bard. Fetch hither Richard, that in common view He may surrender; so we shall proceed Without suspicion. Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is notlawful. He would be crown'd: How that might change his nature, there's the question. This disease is beyond my practice: yet I have known thosewhich have walked in their sleep who have died holily intheir beds. This that youheard, was but a colour Shall. Never any did so, though very many have been besidetheir wit. O, no; he goes into Mauritania, and takes away with himthe fair Desdemona, unless his abode be lingered here by some accident; wherein none can be so determinate as the removingof Cassio. I do allow this Wen to bee as familiar withme, as my dogge: and he holds his place, for looke youhe writes Poin. Please it your Grace, on to the state affairs; I had rather to adopt a child than get it. Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes; Our enemies have beat us to the pit; Low alarums. If, sir, perchance She have restrain'd the riots of your followers, 'Tis on such ground, and to such wholesome end, As clears her from all blame. Cassio, I love thee, But never more be officer of mine. How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot? CASSIO. Masters, let him go; He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him. My Lord prepare, the King comes on apace Hot. What cannot be preserved when Fortune takes, Patience her injury a mockery makes. If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body, And give the letters which thou find'st about me To Edmund Earl of Gloucester. Eight yards of vneuen ground, is threescore & ten milesafoot with me: and the stony-hearted Villaines knowe itwell enough. And let those that play your clowns speak no more than is set down for them: for there be of them that will themselves laugh, to set on some quantity of barren spectators to laugh too, though in the meantime some necessary83 question of the play be then I haueseru'd your Worshippe truely sir, these eight yeares: andif I cannot once or twice in a Quarter beare out a knaue,against an honest man, I haue but a very litle credite withyour Worshippe. Ay, or any show that you?l show him: be not you ashamed to show, he?l not shame to tell you what it means. I prethee good Prince Hal, help me to my horse,good Kings sonne Prin. Thou art rash as fire, to say That she was false. I didthat I did not this seuen yeeres before, I blusht to hearehis monstrous deuices Prin. Rightly to be great Is not to stir without great argument, But greatly to find quarrel in a straw When honour? at the stake. The King Yet speaks, and peradventure may recover. Good my lord, put your discourse into some frame, and start not so wildly from my affair. Then give me leave that I may turn the key, That no man enter till my tale be done. Do thy worst; This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven Than thou wast worthy her. A friend should bear his friend's infirmities, But Brutus makes mine greater than they are. This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spar'd At suit of his grey beard Kent. Why, thou Mars! Take good CominiusWith thee awhile: determine on some courseMore than a wild exposture to each chanceThat starts i' the way before thee. What you have said I will consider; what you have to say I will with patience hear, and find a time Both meet to hear and answer such high things. On Bacons,on, what ye knaues? Yong men must liue, you areGrand Iurers, are ye? Wee'l iure ye ifaith. I am affraide ofthis Gun-powder Percy though he be dead. This is an accident of hourly proof, Which I mistrusted not. Yea, and text underneath, 'Here dwells Benedick, themarried man'? Bene. No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she should sodote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in all outward behaviours seem'd ever to abhor. I say to you, I desire deliu'rance from these Officersbeing vpon hasty employment in the Kings Affaires Iust. 'Faith, Sir Iohn, 'tis more then time that I werethere, and you too: but my Powers are there alreadie. Three parts of him Is ours already, and the man entire Upon the next encounter yields him ours. Fie, fie, fie! pah,pah! Give me an ounce of civet, good apothecary, to sweeten my imagination. You have of late stood out against your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace,where it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself. Why stay we to be baitedWith one that wants her wits?VOLUMNIA. O, it offends me to the soul, to hear a robustious periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters, to very rags, to split the cars of the groundlings, who, for the most part, are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb shows and noise: I would have suc I tore it from the traitor's bosom, King; Fear, and not love, begets his penitence. I think he'll be to RomeAs is the osprey to the fish, who takes itBy sovereignty of nature. Yet look up, behold, That you in pity may dissolve to dew, And wash him fresh again with true-love tears. If you shall cleave to my consent,--when 'tis,It shall make honor for you. But, O vain boast! Who can control his fate? 'Tis not so now. A Park or Lawn, with a gate leading to thePalace. This supernatural solicitingCannot be ill; cannot be good:--if ill,Why hath it given me earnest of success,Commencing in a truth? GENTLEMEN. Well, I'll hear it, sir; yet you must not think to fob off ourdisgrace with a tale: but, an't please you, deliver. What, stand'st thou still, and hear'st such a calling?Looke to the Guests within: My Lord, olde SirIohn with halfe a dozen more, are at the doore: shall I letthem in? Prin. Go, get thee to Yaughan; fetch me a stoup of liquor. Attend the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester. And now I will vnclaspe a Secret booke,And to your quicke conceyuing Discontents,Ile reade you Matter, deepe and dangerous,As full of perill and aduenturous Spirit,As to o're-walke a Current, roaring loudOn the vnstedfast footing of a Speare Hot. I beseech you sir,To countenance William Visor of Woncot, against ClementPerkes of the hill Shal. That it should come to this! But two months dead!?ay, not so much, not two: So excellent a king; that was, to this, Hyperion to a satyr; so loving to my mother, That he might not beteem the winds of heaven Visit her face too roughly. Ile so offend, to make offence a skill,Redeeming time, when men thinke least I will. O, he is bold, and blushes not at death! Avaunt, thou hateful villain, get thee gone! HUBERT. Be like they had some notice of the people, How I had moved them. I have rubb'd this young quat almost to the sense, And he grows angry. I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine; The chain unfinish'd made me stay thus long. He call'd me euen now (my Lord) through a redLattice, and I could discerne no part of his face from thewindow: at last I spy'd his eyes, and me thought he hadmade two holes in the Ale-wiues new Petticoat, & peepedthrough Prin. Ay, sooth; so humbled That he hath left part of his grief with me To suffer with him. [To Edgar] Come, sit thou here, most learned justicer. I shifted him away, And laid good 'scuse upon your ecstasy; Bade him anon return and here speak with me The which he promised. Ye fat paunch, and yee call mee Coward, Ilestab thee Fal. Well, sir, the poor distressed Lear's i' th' town; Who sometime, in his better tune, remembers What we are come about, and by no means Will yield to see his daughter. A pickaxe and a spade, a spade, For and a shrouding sheet; O, a pit of clay for to be made For such a guest is meet. No more, I say! for that I have not wash'dMy nose that bled, or foil'd some debile wretch,--Which, without note, here's many else have done,--You shout me forth in acclamations hyperbolical;As if I loved my little should be dietedIn praises sauc'd with lYou lords and noble friends, know our intent. He hath borne himself beyond the promise of his age,doing in the figure of a lamb the feats of a lion. Yet to good wine they do use good bushes;and good plays prove the better by the help of good epilogues. Exceeding well: his CaresAre now, all ended Ch. If I become not a Cartas well as another man, a plague on my bringing vp: Ihope I shall as soone be strangled with a Halter, as another Prince. I care not, a man can die but once: wee owe adeath. How dangerous is it that this man goes loose! CHARLES. Ay, sir, but ?hile the grass grows?the proverb is something musty. His soldiers fell to spoil, Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed. 'Tis pride that pulls the country down; Then take thine auld cloak about thee. Glasses, glasses, is the onely drinking: and forthy walles a pretty slight Drollery, or the Storie of theProdigall, or the Germane hunting in Waterworke, isworth a thousand of these Bed-hangings, and these FlybittenTapistries. Sir Iohn stands to his word, the diuel shall hauehis bargaine, for he was neuer yet a Breaker of Prouerbs:He will giue the diuell his due Poin. The best and soundest of his time hath been but rash; then must we look to receive from his age, not alone the imperfections of long-ingraffed condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bringwith them. Make you a wholesome answer; my wit? This I must do, or know not what to do; Yet this I will not do, do how I can. I should e'en die with pity, To see another thus. Come, come, no longer will I be a fool, To put the finger in the eye and weep, Whilst man and master laughs my woes to scorn. I am not mad; too well, too well I feel The different plague of each calamity. Those, for their parents were exceeding poor, I bought, and brought up to attend my sons. He replied, 'Thou unpossessing bastard, dost thou think, If I would stand against thee, would the reposal Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee Make thy words faith'd? No. It is the firsttime that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport for ladies. Mine innocence and Saint George to thrive! MOWBRAY. If with myself I hold intelligence, Or have acquaintance with mine own desires; If that I do not dream, or be not frantic As I do trust I am notthen, dear uncle, Never so much as in a thought unborn Did I offend your Highness. Good old man, Thou art right welcome as thy master is. [To ELINOR] So shall it be; your Grace shall stay behind, So strongly guarded. For all beneath the moon Would I not leap upright. Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty. You told me you salutenot at the court, but you kiss your hands; that courtesy would be uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds. It did always seem so to us; but now, in the division ofthe kingdom, it appears not which of the Dukes he values most,for equalities are so weigh'd that curiosity in neither can make choice of either's moiety. O, full of scorpions is my mind, dear wife!Thou know'st that Banquo, and his Fleance, lives. Sweet peace conduct his sweet soul to the bosom Of good old Abraham! BRUTUS. You show too much of thatFor which the people stir: if you will passTo where you are bound, you must inquire your way,Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit;Or never be so noble as a consul,Nor yoke with him for tribune. Why, there was a crown offered him, and being offeredhim, he put it by with the back of his hand, thus, and then the people fell ashouting. Caitiff, in pieces shake That under covert and convenient seeming Hast practis'd on man's life. Natures of such deep trust we shall much need; You we first seize on. I think it be no other but e?n so: Well may it sort, that this portentous figure20 Comes armed through our watch; so like the king That was and is the question of these wars. Say you chose himMore after our commandment than as guidedBy your own true affections; and that your minds,Pre-occupied with what you rather must doThan what you should, made you against the grainTo voice him consul. I shall obey you:?And for your part, Ophelia, I do wish That your good beauties be the happy cause Of Hamlet? wildness: so shall I hope your virtues Will bring him to his wonted way again, To both your honours. I will deuise matter enough out of this Shallow, tokeepe Prince Harry in continuall Laughter, the wearingout of sixe Fashions (which is foure Tearmes) or two Actions,and he shall laugh with Interuallums. Will I liue? observe her well with Cassio; Wear your eye thus, not jealous nor secure. If the tagrag people did not clap him and hiss him according as he pleased and displeased them, as they use todo the players in the theatre, I am no true man. Lords, I protest my soul is full of woe That blood should sprinkle me to make me grow. I do not like the office; But sith I am enter'd in this cause so far, Prick'd to't by foolish honesty and love, I will go on. "Glamis thou art, and Cawdor; and shalt beWhat thou art promis'd; yet do I fear thy nature;It is too full o' the milk of human kindnessTo catch the nearest way: thou wouldst be great;Art not without ambition; but withoutThe illness should attend it. My father? spirit in arms! All is not well; I doubt some foul play: would the night were come! Till then sit still, my soul: foul deeds will rise, Though all the earth o?rwhelm them, to men? eyes. I do not doubt But that my noble master will appear Such as he is, full of regard and honor. Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover,they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixthand lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust things; and to conclude, they are lying knaves. Cannot, is false, and that I dare not, falser: I will not come today. With that he gaue his able Horse the head,And bending forwards strooke his able heelesAgainst the panting sides of his poore IadeVp to the Rowell head, and starting so,He seem'd in running, to deuoure the way,Staying no longer question North. But who comes here? My father, poorly led? World, world, O world! But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee, Life would not yield to age. In few; his death (whose spirit lent a fire,Euen to the dullest Peazant in his Campe)Being bruited once, tooke fire and heate awayFrom the best temper'd Courage in his Troopes. A halter pardon him! And hell gnaw his bones! Why should he call her whore? Who keeps her company? What place? What time? What form? What likelihood? The Moor's abused by some most villainous knave, Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow. ExitSHERIFF Our abbeys and our priories shall pay This expedition's charge. Well said, noble woman!Before he should thus stoop to the herd, but thatThe violent fit o' the time craves it as physicFor the whole state, I would put mine armour on,Which I can scarcely bear. Re-enter BIGOT and attendants, who bring in KING JOHN in a chair KING JOHN. The gods have well prevented it, and RomeSits safe and still without him. He may keepe his owne Grace, but he is almost out ofmine, I can assure him. An if you do, you will but make it blush And glow with shame of your proceedings, Hubert. Night hangs upon mine eyes, my bones would rest That have but labor'd to attain this hour. Black spirits and white, red spirits and gray;Mingle, mingle, mingle, you that mingle may. Vnder which King?Bezonian, speake, or dye Shal. Hang 'em! They say!They'll sit by th' fire and presume to knowWhat's done i' the Capitol; who's like to rise,Who thrives and who declines; side factions, and give outConjectural marriages; making parties strong,And feebling such as stand not in their likMy lord? Brutus and Lucilius converse apart. Naughty lady, These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin Will quicken, and accuse thee. But wherefore could not I pronounce "Amen"?I had most need of blessing, and "Amen"Stuck in my throat. Nay, I will: that's flat:He said, he would not ransome Mortimer:Forbad my tongue to speake of Mortimer. Indeed! DESDEMONA. That I should be attach'd in Ephesus, I tell you 'twill sound harshly in her cars. I think that one of them is hereabout, And cannot make away. The tartness of his face sours ripe grapes:when he walks, he moves like an engine, and the ground shrinksbefore his treading: he is able to pierce a corslet with his eye,talks like a knell, and his hum is a battery. ) Where's Wart? you see whata ragged appearance it is: hee shall charge you, anddischarge you, with the motion of a Pewterers Hammer:come off, and on, swifter then hee that gibbets onthe Brewers Bucket. My blood hath beene too cold and temperate,Vnapt to stirre at these indignities,And you haue found me; for accordingly,You tread vpon my patience: But be sure,I will from henceforth rather be my Selfe,Mighty, and to be fear'd, then my conditionWhich hat My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely; Two of the dangerous consorted traitors That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow. If this may please you,Discharge your Powers vnto their seuerall Counties,As wee will ours: and here, betweene the Armies,Let's drinke together friendly, and embrace,That all their eyes may beare those Tokens home,Of our restored Loue, and Amitie Bish. Why didst thou tell me, that thou wer't a King? CASSIO. O Caesar! These things are beyond all use, And I do fear them. And he will bless that cross with otherbeating; Between you I shall have a holy head. It shall be to your good; for my father's house and all therevenue that was old Sir Rowland's will I estate upon you, and herelive and die a shepherd. How am I then a villain To counsel Cassio to this parallel course, Directly to his good? Divinity of hell! When devils will the blackest sins put on, They do suggest at first with heavenly shows, As I do now. May it please your Grace, Antipholus, my husband, Who I made lord of me and all I had At your important letters-this ill day A most outrageous fit of madness took him, That desp'rately he hurried through the street, With him his bondman all as mad as he Then must you speak Of one that loved not wisely but too well; Of one not easily jealous, but, being wrought, Perplex'd in the extreme; of one whose hand, Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away Richer than all his tribe; of one whose subdued eyes, Alb Enter the Earle of Warwicke, and the Lord Chiefe Iustice. If, till the expiration of your month, You will return and sojourn with my sister, Dismissing half your train, come then to me. I do profess to be no less than I seem, to serve himtruly that will put me in trust, to love him that is honest, to converse with him that is wise and says little, to fear judgment, to fight when I cannot choose, and to eat no fish. Yet I wish, sir,--I mean, for your particular,--you had notJoin'd in commission with him; but eitherHad borne the action of yourself, or else To him had left it solely. Thus Kent, O princes, bids you all adieu; He'll shape his old course in a country new. It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, ifshe will not discover it. If every one knows us, and we know none, 'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack and be gone. The Forest of ArdenEnter ROSALIND for GANYMEDE, CELIA for ALIENA, and CLOWN aliasTOUCHSTONE ROSALIND. Most shallow man! thou worm's meat in respect of agood piece of flesh indeed! My train are men of choice and rarest parts, That all particulars of duty know And in the most exact regard support The worships of their name. Blest fig's-end! The wine she drinks is made of grapes. Join not with grief, fair woman, do not so, To make my end too sudden. Thou hast done much harme vntome Hall, God forgiue thee for it. Enter FITZWATER FITZWATER. Let me speak like yourself, and lay a sentence Which, as a grise or step, may help these lovers Into your favor. I tell thee Ned, thou hast lost much honor, that thouwer't not with me in this action: but sweet Ned, to sweetenwhich name of Ned, I giue thee this peniworth of Sugar,clapt euen now into my hand by an vnder Skinker,one that neuer spake other English in  What, will you walk with me about the town, And then go to my inn and dine with me?FIRST MERCHANT. It will be short: the interim is mine; And a man? life is no more than to say One. This Volumnia Is worth of consuls, senators, patricians,A city full: of tribunes such as you,A sea and land full. They say poor suitors have strong breaths; they shall knowwe have strong arms too. 'Tis such fools as you That makes the world full of ill-favour'd children. O thou weed, Who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er beenborn! DESDEMONA. The present wars devour him: he is grownToo proud to be so valiant. Nay you shall finde noBoyes play heere, I can tell you. I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sunWhen the alarum were struck, than idly sitTo hear my nothings monster'd. Well, whiles I am a beggar, I will rail And say there is no sin but to be rich; And being rich, my virtue then shall be To say there is no vice but beggary. Come, manage me your Calyuer: so: very well,go-too, very good, exceeding good. Truly, I would the gods had made thee poetical. In brief: we are the King of England's subjects; For him, and in his right, we hold this town. Would God that any in this noble presence Were enough noble to be upright judge Of noble Richard! Then true noblesse would Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong. What concern they?The general cause? or is it a fee-griefDue to some single breast?ROSS. I will deal in poison withthee, or in bastinado, or in steel; I will bandy with thee infaction; will o'er-run thee with policy; I will kill thee a hundredand fifty ways; therefore tremble and depart. And i haue not forgotten what thein-side of a Church is made of, I am a Pepper-Corne, aBrewers Horse, the in-side of a Church. Fillet of a fenny snake,In the caldron boil and bake;Eye of newt, and toe of frog,Wool of bat, and tongue of dog,Adder's fork, and blind-worm's sting,Lizard's leg, and howlet's wing,--For a charm of powerful trouble,Like a hell-broth boil and bubble. Thy father's father wore it; And thy father bore it. Only we still retain The name, and all th' additions to a king. Nay, then, God buy you, an you talk in blank verse. Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here; Those that will follow Cassius, go with him; And public reasons shall be rendered Of Caesar's death. Falls on the bed, anddies. She did deceive her father, marrying you; And when she seem'd to shake and fear your looks, She loved them most. What, have you got the picture of old Adam new-apparell'd?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man's voice. See else yourself: There is no malice in this burning coal; The breath of heaven hath blown his spirit out, And strew'd repentant ashes on his head. Exeunt [Dogberry and Verges]. Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee. Forgive me this my virtue; For in the fatness of these pursy times Virtue itself of vice must pardon beg, Yea, curb and woo for leave to do him good. I sent you money, sir, to be your bail, By Dromio; but I think he brought it not. Come, sister, willyou go? LEWIS. Should we be silent and not speak, our raimentAnd state of bodies would bewray what lifeWe have led since thy exile. Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursley Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse Is all of her. When I desir'd him to come home to dinner, He ask'd me for a thousand marks in gold. [Exit LUCIANA] This I wonder at: Thus he unknown to me should be in debt. Upon condition Publius shall not live, Who is your sister's son, Mark Antony. Lady, you come hither to be married to this count? Hero. Some sins do bear their privilege on earth, And so doth yours: your fault was not your folly; Needs must you lay your heart at his dispose, Subjected tribute to commanding love, Against whose fury and unmatched force The aweless lion could not wage the  Mowbray, you ouer-weene to take it so:This Offer comes from Mercy, not from Feare. If I had my mouth, I would bite; if I had myliberty, I would do my liking. O gull! O dolt! As ignorant as dirt! Thou hast done a deed I care not for thy sword; I'll make thee known, Though I lost twenty lives. When these prodigies Do so conjointly meet, let not men say "These are their reasons; they are natural": For I believe they are portentous things Unto the climate that they point upon. If your diligence be not speedy, I shall be there afore you. We will before the walls of Rome to-morrowSet down our host. You are welcome, masters; ORLANDO. Love is merely a madness; and, I tell you, deservesas well a dark house and a whip as madmen do; and the reason why they are not so punish'd and cured is that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers are in love too. If again it was not well cut, he disabled myjudgment. The Tide of Blood in me,Hath prowdly flow'd in Vanity, till now. I am trusted with a muzzle and enfranchis'd with a clog; therefore I have decreed not tosing in my cage. Ay; and you'll look paleBefore you find it other. No, Ile be sworne: I make as good vse of it, asmany a man doth of a Deaths-Head, or a Memento Mori. If they wrong her honour, The proudest of them shall well hear of it. No, I'll nor sell nor give him: lend you him I willFor half a hundred years. Why, let the strucken deer go weep, The hart ungalled play; For some must watch, while some must sleep: So runs the world away. This ensign here of mine was turning back; I slew the coward, and did take it from him. Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves? ExitSCENE III. I wonder in my soul, What you would ask me, that I should deny, Or stand so mammering on. I will tell you the beginning, and, if it please your ladyships, you may see the end; for the best is yet to do;and here, where you are, they are coming to perform it. Gods, gods! O that I were as great As is my grief, or lesser than my name! Or that I could forget what I have been! The love of wicked men converts to fear; That fear to hate; and hate turns one or both To worthy danger and deserved death. Bear away that child, And follow me with speed. Lift up thy brow, renowned Salisbury, And with a great heart heave away this storm; Commend these waters to those baby eyes That never saw the giant world enrag'd, Nor met with fortune other than at feasts, Full of warm blood, of mirth, of gossiping. My master preaches patience to him, and the while His man with scissors nicks him like a fool; And sure, unless you send some present help, Between them they will kill the conjurer. Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect By your eyes' anguish. And why should Caesar be a tyrant then? Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf But that he sees the Romans are but sheep. Lucius, I say! I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly. --Hark!--Peace!It was the owl that shriek'd, the fatal bellman,Which gives the stern'st good night. Your hand, and yours:Ere in our own house I do shade my head,The good patricians must be visited;From whom I have receiv'd not only greetings,But with them change of honours. Fie! IAGO. Titus Lartius writes,--they fought together, but Aufidiusgot off. By heaven, I?l make a ghost of him that lets me!?I say, away!?o on; I?l follow thee. If the assassinationCould trammel up the consequence, and catch,With his surcease, success; that but this blowMight be the be-all and the end-all--here,But here, upon this bank and shoal of time,--We'd jump the life to come. --Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars,I'll frame convenient peace. And the creature run from the cur? There thou mightstbehold the great image of authority: a dog's obeyed in office. Will it serve for any model to build mischief on? What is he for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness? Bora. As I stood here below, methought his eyes Were two full moons; he had a thousand noses, Horns whelk'd and wav'd like the enridged sea. Come, Gertrude, we?l call up our wisest friends; And let them know both what we mean to do And what? untimely done: so haply slander,?Whose whisper o?r the world? diameter, As level as the cannon to his blank, Transports his poison? shot,?ay miss our n 
Though it be not written down, yet forget not that I am an ass. Enter King Henrie the Fift, Brothers, LordChiefeIustice. Your worm is your only emperor for diet: we fat all creatures else to fat us, and we fat ourselves for maggots: your fat king and your lean beggar is but variable service,?wo dishes, but to one table: that? the end. Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes. You are plebeians,If they be senators: and they are no lessWhen, both your voices blended, the great'st tasteMost palates theirs. Nay, it is true, or else I am a Turk: You rise to play, and go to bed to work. Nay, good my lord, this courtesy is not of the right breed. O spite of spites! We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites. This inundation of mistemp'red humour Rests by you only to be qualified. You know the character to be your brother's? Edm. I lov'd him, friend No father his son dearer. Is hee so hastie, that hee doth supposeMy sleepe, my death? Finde him (my Lord of Warwick)Chide him hither: this part of his conioynesWith my disease, and helpes to end me. To who? Re-enter Othello. He tells me, my sweet queen, he hath found The head and source of all your son? distemper. How now good Blunt? thy Lookes are full of speed Blunt. You should account me the more virtuous, that I have not beencommon in my love. Now tell me how long you would have her, after youhave possess'd her. And if the diuell come and roare for themI will not send them. Thou hast my love; is not that neighbourly? SILVIUS. No, for I hold him to be unworthy of his place thatdoes those things. Well, God dild you! They say the owl was a baker? daughter. Nell, sir; but her name and three quarters, that's an ell and three quarters, will not measure her from hip to hip. And when you lov'd you were my other husband. I am not mad: this hair I tear is mine; My name is Constance; I was Geffrey's wife; Young Arthur is my son, and he is lost. The other Night I fell asleepe heere behind theArras, and had my Pocket pickt: this House is turn'dBawdy-house, they picke Pockets Prince. Money by me! Heart and goodwill you might, But surely, master, not a rag of money. O poor Orlando, thou art overthrown! Or Charles or something weaker masters thee. Enter KEEPER with meat KEEPER. So, your opinion is, Aufidius,That they of Rome are enter'd in our counselsAnd know how we proceed. This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon; For he was great of heart. When the hurlyburly's done,When the battle's lost and won. [To the BASTARD] Cousin, away for England! haste before, And, ere our coming, see thou shake the bags Of hoarding abbots; imprisoned angels Set at liberty; the fat ribs of peace Must by the hungry now be fed upon. Now, God help thee, poor monkey! But how wiltthou do for a father?SON. Had I your tongues and eyes, I'ld use them so That heaven's vault should crack. But as we often see, against some storm, A silence in the heavens, the rack stand still, The bold winds speechless, and the orb below As hush as death, anon the dreadful thunder Doth rend the region; so, after Pyrrhus?pause, A roused vengeance sets him  The woe's to come; the children yet unborn Shall feel this day as sharp to them as thorn. Milk-liver'd man! That bear'st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs; Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning Thine honour from thy suffering; that not know'st Fools do those villains pity who are punish'd Ere they have done their mischief. O mother, mother!What have you done? Behold, the heavens do ope,The gods look down, and this unnatural sceneThey laugh at. I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul. What gold is this? What Adam dost thoumean?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O that my tongue were in the thunder's mouth! Then with a passion would I shake the world, And rouse from sleep that fell anatomy Which cannot hear a lady's feeble voice, Which scorns a modern invocation. Who, he? I think the sun where he was born Drew all such humors from him. You whorson Candle-myne you, how vildlydid you speake of me euen now, before this honest, vertuous,ciuill Gentlewoman? Host. Your judgments, my grave lords, Must give this cur the lie: and his own notion,--Who wears my stripes impress'd upon him; that must bearMy beating to his grave,--shall join to thrustThe lie unto him. The Leaders hauing charge from you to stand,Will not goe off, vntill they heare you speake Iohn. The liues of all your louing ComplicesLeane-on your health, the which if you giue-o'reTo stormy Passion, must perforce decay. Yfaith, my Lord, they are false: Nay, Ile tickleye for a young Prince Prin. Hee was the veryGenius of Famine: hee came euer in the rere-ward ofthe Fashion: And now is this Vices Dagger become aSquire, and talkes as familiarly of Iohn of Gaunt, as ifhee had beene sworne Brother to him: and Ile be swornehee neuer saw him but once Nay, taske me to my word: approue me Lord Dow. But Margaret was in some fault for this, Although against her will, as it appears In the true course of all the question. --With a kind of smile, Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus,--For, look you, I may make the belly smileAs well as speak,--it tauntingly repliedTo the discontented members, the mutinous partsThat envied his receipt; even so most fitlyAs you malCommend me to one Hubert, with your King; The love of him-and this respect besides, For that my grandsire was an Englishman Awakes my conscience to confess all this. , accompanied by Senators,Patricians, and Citizens. Put up thy sword betime; Or I'll so maul you and your toasting-iron That you shall think the devil is come from hell. I think not of them:Yet, when we can entreat an hour to serve,We would spend it in some words upon that business,If you would grant the time. Be of good comfort, Prince; for you are born To set a form upon that indigest Which he hath left so shapeless and so rude. [Cry within] Hark, hark, I hear him, mistress; fly, be gone!DUKE. O slaves, I can tell you news,--news, you rascals!FIRST and SECOND SERVANT. --Thou marvell'st at my words: but hold thee still;Things bad begun make strong themselves by ill:So, pr'ythee, go with me. There's my gauntlet; I'll proveit on a giant. I would have thoughther spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection. Take not, good cousin, further than you should, Lest you mistake. True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester. Opens the letter and reads. My pride fell with my fortunes; I'll ask him what he would. Go then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and theCount Claudio alone; tell them that you know that Hero loves me;intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as--in love of your brother's honour, who hath made this match, and hisfriend's r Neither; he took this place for sanctuary, And it shall privilege him from your hands Till I have brought him to his wits again, Or lose my labour in assaying it. Cassio's my worthy friend My lord, I see you're moved. Let shame come when it will, I do not call it. For my part, I may speake it to my shame,I haue a Truant beene to Chiualry,And so I heare, he doth account me too:Yet this before my Fathers Maiesty,I am content that he shall take the oddesOf his great name and estimation,And will, to saue the blood on But, how? how satisfied, my lord? OTHELLO. Of a certain knight that swore by his honour theywere good pancakes, and swore by his honour the mustard wasnaught. The tyrant has not batter'd at their peace?ROSS. You thus employ'd, I will go root away The noisome weeds which without profit suck The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers. Heigh-ho, an't be not foure by the day, Ile behang'd. Come all to ruin: letThy mother rather feel thy pride than fearThy dangerous stoutness; for I mock at deathWith as big heart as thou. Let me love him for that; and do you love him becauseI do. It is to be all made of faith and service; And so am I for Phebe. Keepout, che vore ye, or Ise try whether your costard or my ballow bethe harder. God and the rope-maker bear me witness That I was sent for nothing but a rope!PINCH. For when my outward action doth demonstrate The native act and figure of my heart In complement extern, 'tis not long after But I will wear my heart upon my sleeve For daws to peck at: I am not what I am. Thither will I invite the Duke and all's contented followers. Sir Richard, what think you? Have you beheld, Or have you read or heard, or could you think? Or do you almost think, although you see, That you do see? Could thought, without this object, Form such another? This is the very top, The height, the crest, o Dear my lord, if you, in your own proof, Have vanquish'd the resistance of her youth And made defeat of her virginity- Claud. Know thou first,I lov'd the maid I married; never manSighed truer breath; but that I see thee here,Thou noble thing! more dances my rapt heartThan when I first my wedded mistress saw Bestride my threshold. Beleeue me, I am passing light in spirit Mow. Dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee getus some excellent music; for to-morrow night we would have it atthe Lady Hero's chamber window. It is a purpos'd thing, and grows by plot,To curb the will of the nobility:Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule,Nor ever will be rul'd. But if you fondly pass our proffer'd offer, 'Tis not the roundure of your old-fac'd walls Can hide you from our messengers of war, Though all these English and their discipline Were harbour'd in their rude circumference. O that I had him,With six Aufidiuses, or more, his tribe,To use my lawful sword!AUFIDIUS. Parle without, and answer within; then a flourish. If we can dothis, Cupid is no longer an archer; his glory shall be ours, for weare the only love-gods. This last old man,Whom with crack'd heart I have sent to Rome,Lov'd me above the measure of a father;Nay, godded me indeed. O-Sixpence that I had a Wednesday last To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper? The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not. My brother Jaques he keeps at school, and report speaks goldenly of his profit. The spirit that I have seen May be the devil: and the devil hath power To assume a pleasing shape; yea, and perhaps Out of my weakness and my melancholy,?As he is very potent with such spirits,?74 Abuses me to damn me: I?l have grounds More relative tha What's he that speaks for Edmund Earl of Gloucester? KING JOHN. O, she was foul! I scarce did know you, uncle; there lies your niece, Whose breath indeed these hands have newly stopp'd. The one is too like an image andsays nothing, and the other too like my lady's eldest son,evermore tattling. O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note, To drown me in thy sister's flood of tears. I have a kind soul that would give you thanks, And knows not how to do it but with tears. My cue is villainous melancholy, with a sigh like Tom o'Bedlam. Death, traitor! nothing could have subdu'd nature To such a lowness but his unkind daughters. Esperance, bid Butler lead him forthinto the Parke La. Why in that rawness left you wife and child,--Those precious motives, those strong knots of love,--Without leave-taking?--I pray you,Let not my jealousies be your dishonors,But mine own safeties:--you may be rightly just,Whatever I shall think. Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother; I see by you I am a sweet-fac'd youth. Why seek'st thou to possess me with these fears? Why urgest thou so oft young Arthur's death? Thy hand hath murd'red him. Fairies and gods Prosper it with thee! Go thou further off; Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going. What would'st thou think of me, if I shold weep? Poin. Brutus, come apace, And see how I regarded Caius Cassius. Beenot too familiar with Pointz, for hee misuses thy Fauours somuch, that he sweares thou art to marrie his Sister Nell. Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed, Yea, providently caters for the sparrow, Be comfort to my age! Here is the gold; All this I give you. She is ofso free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition, she holds ita vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested. Tell me else,Could such inordinate and low desires,Such poore, such bare, such lewd, such meane attempts,Such barren pleasures, rude societie,As thou art matcht withall, and grafted too,Accompanie the greatnesse of thy blood,And hold their leuell with t Their shadows seem A canopy most fatal, under which Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost. The King, I fear, is poison'd by a monk; I left him almost speechless and broke out To acquaint you with this evil, that you might The better arm you to the sudden time Than if you had at leisure known of this. When workmen strive to do better than well, They do confound their skill in covetousness; And oftentimes excusing of a fault Doth make the fault the worse by th' excuse, As patches set upon a little breach Discredit more in hiding of the fault Than did  The Earle Northumberland, and the Lord Bardolfe,With a great Power of English, and of Scots,Are by the Sherife of Yorkeshire ouerthrowne:The manner, and true order of the fight,This Packet (please it you) containes at large King. And the like tender of our love we make, To rest without a spot for evermore. Now the fair goddess, Fortune,Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charmsMisguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman,Prosperity be thy page!MARCIUS. The shrill-gorg'd lark so far Cannot be seen or heard. Thou whoreson zed! thou unnecessary letter! My lord, if you'll give me leave, I will tread this unbolted villaininto mortar and daub the walls of a jakes with him. Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him. I could interpret between you and your love, if I could see the puppets dallying. Enter BOLINGBROKE and MOWBRAY BOLINGBROKE. Are you yet determin'd To-day to marry with my brother's daughter? Claud. [Within] What a coil is there, Dromio? Who are those atthe gate?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. [Aside to CELIA] I will speak to him like a saucylackey, and under that habit play the knave with him. Through tatter'd clothes small vices do appear; Robes and furr'd gowns hide all. France, hast thou yet more blood to cast away? Say, shall the current of our right run on? Whose passage, vex'd with thy impediment, Shall leave his native channel and o'erswell With course disturb'd even thy confining shores, Unless thou let his silver If he be taken, he shall never more Be fear'd of doing harm. This man hath had good counsel! A hundred knights? 'Tis politic and safe to let him keep At point a hundred knights; yes, that on every dream, Each buzz, each fancy, each complaint, dislike, He may enguard his dotage with their pow'rs And hold our lives Judge me, you gods! Wrong I mine enemies? And, if not so, how should I wrong a brother? CASSIUS. What your wisdoms could not discover, theseshallow fools have brought to light, who in the night overheard me confessing to this man, how Don John your brother incensed meto slander the Lady Hero; how you were brought into the orchardand saw me court Ma Her name, that was as fresh As Dian's visage, is now begrimed and black As mine own face. There is a thing within my Bosome tells me,That no Conditions of our Peace can stand Hast. I will imitate the honourable Romaines in breuitie Poin. That thrust had been mine enemy indeed, But that my coat is better than thou know'st; I will make proof of thine. Hence and avoid my sight! So be my grave my peace as here I give Her father's heart from her! Call France! Who stirs? Call Burgundy! Cornwall and Albany, With my two daughters' dowers digest this third; Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her. Harry of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby, Stands here for God, his sovereign, and himself, On pain to be found false and recreant, To prove the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray, A traitor to his God, his King, and him; And dares him to set forward to the  Fly further off, my lord, fly further off; Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord; Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off. O, by no means! She mocks all her wooers out of suit. Now begin; For look where Beatrice like a lapwing runs Close by the ground, to hear our conference. The best actors in the world, either for tragedy, comedy, history, pastoral, pastoral-comical, historical-pastoral, tragical-historical, tragical-comical-historical-pastoral, scene individable, or poem unlimited: Seneca cannot be too heavy nor Plautus t Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so, Lest child, child's children, cry against you woe. She is importunate; indeed distract: Her mood will needs be pitied. We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns, Which live like venom where no venom else But only they have privilege to live. But on the sight of us your lawful king, Who painfully with much expedient march Have brought a countercheck before your gates, To save unscratch'd your city's threat'ned cheeks Behold, the French amaz'd vouchsafe a parle; And now, instead of bullets wr Some time I shall sleep out, the rest I'll whistle. Spread Dauy, spread Dauie:Well said Dauie Falst. Horatio, thou art e?n as just a man As e?r my conversation cop? withal. But be it as it may be, Iwill marry thee; and to that end I have been with Sir OliverMartext, the vicar of the next village, who hath promis'd to meet mein this place of the forest, and to couple us. But it shall not be so long; thiswrestler shall clear all. Most noble sir,If you do hold the same intent whereinYou wish'd us parties, we'll deliver youOf your great danger. Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under white and black,this plaintiff here, the offender, did call me ass. This Sir Iohn (Cousin) that comes hither anon aboutSouldiers? Shal. Like an unseasonable stormy day Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores, As if the world were all dissolv'd to tears, So high above his limits swells the rage Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land With hard bright steel and hearts harder t The world esteem'd thy father honourable, But I did find him still mine enemy. May it please you, lords, to grant the commons' suit? BOLINGBROKE. From a Prince, to a Prentice, a low transformation,that shall be mine: for in euery thing, the purposemust weigh with the folly. O it is muchthat a Lye (with a slight Oath) and a iest (with a saddebrow) will doe, with a Fellow, that neuer had the Achein his shoulders. That's as much as to say they are fools thatmarry. What might import my sister's letter to him? Osw. Sir, Isay to you, it is thought you are false knaves. Hostesse, my breakfast, come:Oh, I could wish this Tauerne were my drumme. What art thou that keep'st me out from the house I owe?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. The god of soldiers,With the consent of supreme Jove, informThy thoughts with nobleness; that thou mayst proveTo shame unvulnerable, and stick i' the warsLike a great sea-mark, standing every flaw,And saving those that eye thee!VOLUMNIA. O sides, you are too tough! Will you yet hold? How came my man i' th' stocks? Corn. Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself, I find myself a traitor with the rest; For I have given here my soul's consent T'undeck the pompous body of a king; Made glory base, and sovereignty a slave, Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant. I would not deny you; but, by this good day, I yield upon great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I wastold you were in a consumption. I am on fire,To heare this rich reprizall is so nigh,And yet not ours. Must I give way and room to your rash choler? Shall I be frighted when a madman stares? CASSIUS. That's euen as faire, as at hand quoth the Chamberlaine:For thou variest no more from picking of Purses,then giuing direction, doth from labouring. One fire drives out one fire; one nail, one nail;Rights by rights falter, strengths by strengths do fail. I would cure you, if you would but call me Rosalind,and come every day to my cote and woo me. You foolish shepherd, wherefore do you follow her, Like foggy south, puffing with wind and rain? You are a thousand times a properer man Than she a woman. Go hie thee presently post to the road; An if the wind blow any way from shore, I will not harbour in this town to-night. SCENE 1Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUSEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, DROMIO OF EPHESUS, ANGELO, andBALTHAZARANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Pray you speak to 'em, I pray you,In wholesome manner. 'O father, what a hell of witchcraft lies In the small orb of one particular tear! Hear Antony, most noble Antony! ANTONY. An admirable evasion of whore-master man, tolay his goatish disposition to the charge of a star! My father compounded with my mother under the Dragon's Tail, and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it follows I am roughand lecherous. This shows you are above, You justicers, that these our nether crimes So speedily can venge! But O poor Gloucester! Lose he his other eye? Gent. Is he of God's making? What manner of man? Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard? CELIA. In her forehead, arm'd and reverted, making war against her heir. Here I kneel: If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love Either in discourse of thought or actual deed, Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense, Delighted them in any other form, Or that I do not yet, and ever did, And ever will, though he do shak I haue in equall ballance iustly weigh'd,What wrongs our Arms may do, what wrongs we suffer,And finde our Griefes heauier then our Offences. Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally. Faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalf as youhave uttered words in your own, you should not pass here: no,though it were as virtuous to lie as to live chastely. But what art thou That hast this fortune on me?
