DESDEMONA. I play the torturer, by small and small To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken: Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke; And all your northern castles yielded up, And all your southern gentlemen in arms Upon his party. O sir, you are not right; have you not knownThe worthiest men have done't!CORIOLANUS. But why did he swear he would come this morning, and comes not? CELIA. Besides, I will be sworn these ears of mine Heard you confess you had the chain of him, After you first forswore it on the mart; And thereupon I drew my sword on you, And then you fled into this abbey here, From whence, I think, you are come by miracle. Pray heavens he be, For I have served him, and the man commands Like a full soldier. Heaven keep that monster from Othello's mind! EMILIA. If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life, With thine, and all that offer to defend him, Stand in assured loss. Cure her of that:Canst thou not minister to a mind diseas'd;Pluck from the memory a rooted sorrow;Raze out the written troubles of the brain;And with some sweet oblivious antidoteCleanse the stuff'd bosom of that perilous stuffWhich weighs upon the heartLet me but move one question to your daughter, And by that fatherly and kindly power That you have in her, bid her answer truly. He that is robb'd, not wanting what is stol'n, Let him not know't and he's not robb'd at all. He had a fever when he was in Spain, And when the fit was on him I did mark How he did shake. Stick deep; and in his royalty of natureReigns that which would be fear'd: 'tis much he dares;And, to that dauntless temper of his mind,He hath a wisdom that doth guide his valourTo act in safety. Giue me your hand, giue me your Worships goodhand: Trust me, you looke well: and beare your yearesvery well. They have tied me to a stake; I cannot fly,But, bear-like I must fight the course. But, on: six Barbary horses against six French swords, their assigns, and three liberal conceited carriages: that? the French bet against the Danish: why is this all imponed, as you call it? Osr. This tiger-footed rage, when it shall findThe harm of unscann'd swiftness, will, too late,Tie leaden pounds to's heels. It doth me: though it discolours the complexionof my Greatnesse to acknowledge it. I never long'd to hear a word till now; Say 'pardon,' King; let pity teach thee how. Here lay Duncan,His silver skin lac'd with his golden blood;And his gash'd stabs look'd like a breach in natureFor ruin's wasteful entrance: there, the murderers,Steep'd in the colours of their trade, their daggersUnmannerly breech'd with gore: who coul Strike on the tinder, ho! Give me a taper! Call up all my people! This accident is not unlike my dream; Belief of it oppresses me already. Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life Cuts off so many years of fearing death. [To Silvius] I will content you if what pleases you contents you,and you shall be married to-morrow. Signior Montano, Your trusty and most valiant servitor, With his free duty recommends you thus, And prays you to believe him. I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace' In an ungracious mouth is but profane. I have been told so of many; but indeed an oldreligious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was in his youth aninland man; one that knew courtship too well, for there he fell inlove. Pour in sow's blood, that hath eatenHer nine farrow; grease that's sweatenFrom the murderer's gibbet throwInto the flame. This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her tosplinter; and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack ofyour love shall grow stronger than it was before. O, if you raise this house against this house, It will the woefullest division prove That ever fell upon this cursed earth. Marshal, ask yonder knight in arms, Both who he is and why he cometh hither Thus plated in habiliments of war; And formally, according to our law, Depose him in the justice of his cause. For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in a glass. Why, sir, his hide is so tann? with his trade that he will keep out water a great while; and your water is a sore decayer of your whoreson dead body. Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the COURTEZAN, and a SCHOOLMASTERcall'd PINCHANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. For one poor grainOr two! I am one of those; his mother, wife,His child, and this brave fellow toowe are the grains:You are the musty chaff; and you are smeltAbove the moon: we must be burnt for you. Cassius, Be not deceived; if I have veil'd my look, I turn the trouble of my countenance Merely upon myself. And these few precepts in thy memory Look thou character. )Thou hast a better place in his Affection,Then all thy Brothers: cherish it (my Boy)And Noble Offices thou may'st effectOf Mediation (after I am dead)Betweene his Greatnesse, and thy other Brethren. I would we could do so; for her benefits are mightily misplaced; and the bountiful blind woman doth most mistake inher gifts to women. Marry, would the word 'farewell' have length'ned hours And added years to his short banishment, He should have had a volume of farewells; But since it would not, he had none of me. Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath withdrawn her father to break with him about it. ' And then he drew a dial from his poke, And, looking on it with lack-lustre eye, Says very wisely, 'It is ten o'clock; Thus we may see,' quoth he, 'how the world wags; 'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine; And after one hour more 'twill be eleven; AndThey are dissolved: hang 'em!They said they were an-hungry; sigh'd forth proverbs,--That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat,That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent notCorn for the rich men only:--with these shredsThey vented their comI beseech you, peace:Or, if you'd ask, remember this before,--The thing I have forsworn to grant may neverBe held by you denials. How many thousand of my poorest SubiectsAre at this howre asleepe? Modo he's call'd, and Mahu. Let husbands know Their wives have sense like them; they see and smell And have their palates both for sweet and sour, As husbands have. Remember him hereafter as my honourable friend. Which harm within itself so heinous is As it makes harmful all that speak of it. Shall Caesar send a lie? Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come. Ah, but I think him better than I say, And yet would herein others' eyes were worse. Because I would not see thy cruel nails Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs. I pray you, will you take him by the arm? OLIVER. --What's heThat was not born of woman? Such a oneAm I to fear, or none. In wisdom I should ask thy name; But since thy outside looks so fair and warlike, And that thy tongue some say of breeding breathes, What safe and nicely I might well delay By rule of knighthood, I disdain and spurn. But seestthou not what a deformed thief this fashion is? 2. If aught possess thee from me, it is dross, Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss; Who all, for want of pruning, with intrusion Infect thy sap, and live on thy confusion. Hath he never before sounded you in this business? Edm. Why, know'st thou any harm's intended towards him? SOOTHSAYER. What's best to do? If she come in, she'll sure speak to my wife. Counterfeit? P. The noble Duke my master, My worthy arch and patron, comes to-night. '"How mighty then you are, O hear me tell! The broken bosoms that to me belong Have emptied all their fountains in my well, And mine I pour your ocean all among. A villanousCoward, go thy wayes old Iacke, die when thouwilt, if manhood, good manhood be not forgot vpon theface of the earth, then am I a shotten Herring: there liuesnot three good men vnhang'd in England, & one of themis fat, and growes old, God help But men may construe things after their fashion, Clean from the purpose of the things themselves. They are generallyFooles, and Cowards; which some of vs should be too,but for inflamation. Make the doors upon a woman's wit, and it willout at the casement; shut that, and 'twill out at the key-hole;stop that, 'twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney. What, the Commonwealth their Bootes? Willshe hold out water in foule way? Gad. There? another: why may not that be the skull of a lawyer? Where be his quiddits now, his quillets, his cases, his tenures, and his tricks? why does he suffer this rude knave now to knock him about the sconce with a dirty shovel, and will not tell him o Shepherdess, look on him better, And be not proud; though all the world could see, None could be so abus'd in sight as he. I pray you mar no more of my verses with reading them ill-favouredly. This Marcius is grown from man to dragon;he has wings; he's more than a creeping thing. Nay, you may think my love was crafty love, And call it cunning. But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Let him bee damn'd like the Glutton, may hisTongue be hotter, a horson Achitophel; aRascally-yea-forsooth-knaue,to beare a Gentleman in hand, and thenstand vpon Security? The horson smooth-pates doe nowweare nothing but high shoes, and bunches of Keyes  And so did I; and, to say the truth, so did very many of us. Accommodated: that is, when a man is(as they say) accommodated: or, when a man is, beingwhereby he thought to be accommodated, which is anexcellent thing. The Care on thee depending,Hath fed vpon the body of my Father,Therefore, thou best of Gold, art worst of Gold. How doth my Sonne, and Brother?Thou trembl'st; and the whitenesse in thy CheekeIs apter then thy Tongue, to tell thy Errand. Lord Mortimer, and Cousin Glendower,Will you sit downe?And Vnckle Worcester; a plague vpon it,I haue forgot the Mappe Glend. She should have died hereafter;There would have been a time for such a word. We see the very wreck that we must suffer; And unavoided is the danger now For suffering so the causes of our wreck. What I haue done, my safety vrg'd me to,And I embrace this fortune patiently,Since not to be auoyded, it fals on mee King. His roguish madness Allows itself to anything. While they weigh so even, We hold our town for neither, yet for both. I like thy wit well, in good faith: the gallows does well; but how does it well? it does well to those that do ill: now, thou dost ill to say the gallows is built stronger than the church; argal, the gallows may do well to thee. A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuff'd with allhonourable virtues. To be, or not to be,?hat is the question:?Whether ?is nobler in the mind to suffer The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune Or to take arms against a sea of troubles, And by opposing end them??o die,?o sleep,?No more; and by a sleep to say we end The O heinous, strong, and bold conspiracy! O loyal father of a treacherous son! Thou sheer, immaculate, and silver fountain, From whence this stream through muddy passages Hath held his current and defil'd himself! Thy overflow of good converts to bad; And Are these your herd?--Must these have voices, that can yield them now,And straight disclaim their tongues?--What are your offices?You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth?Have you not set them on?MENENIUS. That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold:What hath quench'd them hath given me fire. I would sing my song without a burden; thou bring'st meout of tune. Nay, she must be old, she cannot choose but beold: certaine shee's old: and had Robin Night-worke, byold Night-worke, before I came to Clements Inne Sil. I am now from home, and out of that provision Which shall be needful for your entertainment. Why, we are still handling our ewes; and their fells,you know, are greasy. Doth he still rage? ExitBIGOT PEMBROKE. 'Las, what's the matter? What's the matter, husband? IAGO. Thou hast made me giddy With these in tidings. The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, beingoverjoyed with finding a bird's nest, shows it his companion, and hesteals it. Well, Brutus, thou art noble; yet, I see Thy honorable mettle may be wrought From that it is disposed; therefore it is meet That noble minds keep ever with their likes; For who so firm that cannot be seduced? Caesar doth bear me hard, but he loves Brutu What handkerchief? EMILIA. Come, sir, to draw toward an end with you:?Good night, mother. I'll about And drive away the vulgar from the streets; So do you too, where you perceive them thick. O Lymoges! O Austria! thou dost shame That bloody spoil. Well praised! How if she be black and witty? IAGO. And so had I; but yet, for fashion sake, I thank youtoo for your society. O! let me clip yeIn arms as sound as when I woo'd; in heartAs merry as when our nuptial day was done,And tapers burn'd to bedward. Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shallnot shame me. I thank you, sir; and pray you tell me this: Which of the two was daughter of the Duke That here was at the wrestling? LE BEAU. Now I perceiue the Deuill vnderstands Welsh,And 'tis no maruell he is so humorous:Byrlady hee's a good Musitian Lady. Let him come when he will; I will deny thee nothing. Does't not go well? Cassio hath beaten thee, And thou by that small hurt hast cashier'd Cassio. Discomfort guides my tongue, And bids me speak of nothing but despair. Come-on, come-on, come-on: giue mee yourHand, Sir; giue mee your Hand, Sir: an early stirrer, bythe Rood. Drunk? and speak parrot? and squabble? swagger?swear? and discourse fustian with one's own shadow? O thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let uscall thee devil! IAGO. Go, good partner, go get you to Francis Seacoal; bid himbring his pen and inkhorn to the jail. He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape adoctor to such a man. His man enters with his boots DUCHESS. I am no orator, as Brutus is; But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man, That love my friend, and that they know full well That gave me public leave to speak of him. I wonder much, being me[n] of such great leading as you areThat you fore-see not what impedimentsDrag backe our expedition: certaine HorseOf my Cousin Vernons are not yet come vp,Your Vnckle Worcesters Horse came but to day,And now their pride and mettalMy Lord, I ouer-rod him on the way,And he is furnish'd with no certainties,More then he (haply) may retaile from me Nor. Call it not patience, Gaunt-it is despair; In suff'ring thus thy brother to be slaught'red, Thou showest the naked pathway to thy life, Teaching stern murder how to butcher thee. West of this Forrest, scarcely off a mile,In goodly forme, comes on the Enemie:And by the ground they hide, I iudge their numberVpon, or neere, the rate of thirtie thousand Mow. O, I coulddiuide my selfe, and go to buffets, for mouing such a dishof skim'd Milk with so honourable an Action. Exeunt all but theBASTARD A foot of honour better than I was; But many a many foot of land the worse. I would have had thee there, and here again, Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there. Speak, citizens, for England; who's your king? CITIZEN. Enter Falstaffe, Shallow, Pistoll, Bardolfe, and Page. I take some joy to say you are, because I would betalking of her. Ill-spirited Worcester, did we not send Grace,Pardon, and tearmes of Loue to all of you?And would'st thou turne our offers contrary?Misuse the tenor of thy Kinsmans trust?Three Knights vpon our party slaine to day,A Noble Earle, and many a creature else,What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him; What like, offensive. No, good madam, pardon me; indeed I will not forth. Go to Flint Castle; there I'll pine away; A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey. O, well did he become that lion's robe That did disrobe the lion of that robe! BASTARD. No: Fifteene hundred Foot, fiue hundred HorseAre march'd vp to my Lord of Lancaster,Against Northumberland, and the Archbishop Fal. The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, theDuke's wrestler; which Charles in a moment threw him, and brokethree of his ribs, that there is little hope of life in him. For I will beleeueThou wilt not vtter what thou do'st not know,And so farre wilt I trust thee, gentle Kate La. What seal is that that without thy bosom? Yea, look'st thou pale? Let me see the writing. Enter Othello, Iago, and Attendants with torches. I have given suck, and knowHow tender 'tis to love the babe that milks me:I would, while it was smiling in my face,Have pluck'd my nipple from his boneless gumsAnd dash'd the brains out, had I so sworn as youHave done to this. Exeunt [Gloucester and Edmund]. When from the first to last, betwixt us two, Tears our recountments had most kindly bath'd, As how I came into that desert place In brief, he led me to the gentle Duke, Who gave me fresh array and entertainment, Committing me unto my brother's love; Who And I'll go seek the Duke; his banquet is prepar'd. Henceforth I'll bear Affliction till it do cry out itself 'Enough, enough,' and die. The galleys Have sent a dozen sequent messengers This very night at one another's heels; And many of the consuls, raised and met, Are at the Duke's already. I have almost matter enough in me for such an embassage;and so I commit you- Claud. The former agents, if they did complain,What could the belly answer? MENENIUS. Though that the Queen on special cause is here, Her army is mov'd on. They are worn, lord consul, soThat we shall hardly in our ages seeTheir banners wave again. Nothing but to show you how a king may go a progress through the guts of a beggar. All thy other titles thou hast given away; that thou wast born with. He is already nam'd; and gone to SconeTo be invested. Ay, Casca, tell us what hath chanced today That Caesar looks so sad. How green you are and fresh in this old world! John lays you plots; the times conspire with you; For he that steeps his safety in true blood Shall find but bloody safety and untrue. If that the Turkish fleet Be not enshelter'd and embay'd, they are drown'd; It is impossible to bear it out. I shall do so;But I must also feel it as a man:I cannot but remember such things were,That were most precious to me. I here do give thee that with all my heart Which, but thou hast already, with all my heart I would keep from thee. But doth not theappetite alters? A man loves the meat in his youth that he cannotendure in his age. He's worth no more:They say he parted well, and paid his score:And so, God be with him!--Here comes newer comfort. We are not to stay alltogether, but to come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos,and by threes. What bloody man is that? He can report,As seemeth by his plight, of the revoltThe newest state. Fit to govern!No, not to live!--O nation miserable,With an untitled tyrant bloody-scepter'd,When shalt thou see thy wholesome days again,Since that the truest issue of thy throneBy his own interdiction stands accurs'dAnd does blaspheme his breed?--Thy roFor me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune: I have some rights of memory in this kingdom, Which now, to claim my vantage doth invite me. Three times hath Henry Bullingbrooke made headAgainst my Power: thrice from the Banks of Wye,And sandy-bottom'd Seuerne, haue I hent himBootlesse home, and Weather-beaten backe Hotsp. If, on the tenth day following, Thy banish'd trunk be found in our dominions, The moment is thy death. What can man's wisdom In the restoring his bereaved sense? He that helps him take all my outward worth. Hee greetes me well: (Sir) I knew him agood Back-Sword-man. For, since the mortal and intestine jars 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us, It hath in solemn synods been decreed, Both by the Syracusians and ourselves, To admit no traffic to our adverse towns; Nay, more: if any born at Ephesus Be seen at any Syr They say many young gentlemen flock to him everyday, and fleet the time carelessly, as they did in the goldenworld. O, come, let us remove! The sight of lovers feedeth those in love. We came crying hither; Thou know'st, the first time that we smell the air We wawl and cry. Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf, And tell me truly what thou think'st of him. If you did wear a beard upon your chin, I'ld shake it on this quarrel. This it is: 'Tis better that the enemy seek us; So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers, Doing himself offense, whilst we lying still Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness. By this hand, I say 'tis very scurvy, and begin to find myself fopped in it. Enter YORK BOLINGBROKE. He led our powers, Bore the commission of my place and person, The which immediacy may well stand up And call itself your brother. What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture? CORIN. Most gracious Duke, To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear, And let me find a charter in your voice To assist my simpleness. There is not a white haire on your face, but sholdhaue his effect of grauity Fal. My excellent good friends! How dost thou, Guildenstern? Ah, Rosencrantz! Good lads, how do ye both? Ros. Hear you, sir; What is the reason that you use me thus? I lov? you ever: but it is no matter; Let Hercules himself do what he may, The cat will mew, and dog will have his day. Faith, once or twice she heav'd the name of father Pantingly forth, as if it press'd her heart; Cried 'Sisters, sisters! Reg. Now, most noble Brutus, The gods today stand friendly that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age! But, since the affairs of men rest still incertain, Let's reason with the worst that may befall. Are these, I pray you, wind instruments? FIRST MUSICIAN. Master, go on; and I will follow the To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty. If any such there be, heaven pardon him! EMILIA. Good uncle, help to order several powers To Oxford, or where'er these traitors are. And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee to disgrace her. Of very reverend reputation, sir, Of credit infinite, highly belov'd, Second to none that lives here in the city; His word might bear my wealth at any time. A hundred thousand Rebels dye in this:Thou shalt haue Charge, and soueraigne trust herein. Goe, good Lord Hastings:And ere they be dismiss'd, let them march by. O my dear father, restoration hang Thy medicine on my lips, and let this kiss Repair those violent harms that my two sisters Have in thy reverence made! Kent. Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes every one to the worldbut I, and I am sunburnt. [Enter King, Queen, Polonius, Ophelia, Rosencrantz, and Guildenstern. All the regionsDo smilingly revolt; and who resistsAre mock'd for valiant ignorance,And perish constant fools. O general, Here is the steed, we the caparison:Hadst thou beheld,--MARCIUS. Are they inform'd of this? My breath and blood! Fiery? the fiery Duke? Tell the hot Duke that No, but not yet! May be he is not well. For0his diuisions (as the Times do braul)Are in three Heads: one Power against the French,And one against Glendower: Perforce a thirdMust take vp vs: So is the vnfirme KingIn three diuided: and his Coffers soundWith hollow Pouerty, and Emptinesse Ar. No, Bolingbroke; if ever I were traitor, My name be blotted from the book of life, And I from heaven banish'd as from hence! But what thou art, God, thou, and I, do know; And all too soon, I fear, the King shall rue. What from the cape can you discern at sea? FIRST GENTLEMAN. Caesar goes up to the Senate House, the rest follow. He prays but faintly and would be denied; We pray with heart and soul, and all beside. Fear and be slain-no worse can come to fight; And fight and die is death destroying death, Where fearing dying pays death servile breath. I know our country disposition well; In Venice they do let heaven see the pranks They dare not show their husbands; their best conscience Is not to leave't undone, but keep't unknown. In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it. Here is a letter Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo, And here another. Help, help, help! The murderers, EXTON and servants, rush in, armed KING RICHARD. To cudgel you and make you take the hatch, To dive like buckets in concealed wells, To crouch in litter of your stable planks, To lie like pawns lock'd up in chests and trunks, To hug with swine, to seek sweet safety out In vaults and prisons, and to th Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us:--The Volsces are in arms. T'one is my sovereign, whom both my oath And duty bids defend; t'other again Is my kinsman, whom the King hath wrong'd, Whom conscience and my kindred bids to right. The tyrant custom, most grave senators, Hath made the flinty and steel couch of war My thrice-driven bed of down. [They draw]Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the COURTEZAN, and OTHERSADRIANA. Double, double, toil and trouble;Fire, burn; and caldron, bubble. Why have you not proclaim'd Northumberland And all the rest revolted faction traitors? GREEN. Up, sword, and know thou a more horrid hent: When he is drunk asleep; or in his rage; Or in the incestuous pleasure of his bed; At gaming, swearing; or about some act That has no relish of salvation in?;?Then trip him, that his heels may kick at heaven; To see a reverend Syracusian merchant, Who put unluckily into this bay Against the laws and statutes of this town, Beheaded publicly for his offence. Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man. Is that the elder, and art thou the heir? You came not of one mother then, it seems. When he shall hear she died upon his words, Th' idea of her life shall sweetly creep Into his study of imagination, And every lovely organ of her life Shall come apparell'd in more precious habit, More moving, delicate, and full of life, Into the eye an Why then, depart in peace and let the child wake her with crying; for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baeswill never answer a calf when he bleats. But, hark![Drums and trumpets sound, with great shouts of the people. We all that are engaged to this losse,Knew that we ventur'd on such dangerous Seas,That if we wrought out life, was ten to one:And yet we ventur'd for the gaine propos'd,Choak'd the respect of likely perill fear'd,And since we are o're-set, venture agai Why, to put's head in; not to give it away to hisdaughters, and leave his horns without a case. Myfather charg'd you in his will to give me good education: you have train'd me like a peasant, obscuring and hiding from me all gentleman-like qualities. Findout this villain, Edmund; it shall lose thee nothing; do it carefully. Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,But mantled in your own. The more pity that fools may not speak wisely whatwise men do foolishly. Pray God, your voice, like a piece of uncurrent gold, be not cracked within the ring. If he see aught in you that makes him like, That anything he sees which moves his liking I can with ease translate it to my will; Or if you will, to speak more properly, I will enforce it eas'ly to my love. I remember, when I was in love, I brokemy sword upon a stone, and bid him take that for coming a-nightto Jane Smile; and I remember the kissing of her batler, and the cow's dugs that her pretty chopt hands had milk'd; They are all fire and every one doth shine; But there's but one in all doth hold his place. Well, breath a-while, and then to't againe: andwhen thou hast tyr'd thy selfe in base comparisons, heareme speake but thus Poin. Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and LORDS, likeoutlaws DUKE SENIOR. My gracious lord, I tender you my service, Such as it is, being tender, raw, and young; Which elder days shall ripen, and confirm To more approved service and desert. Me rather had my heart might feel your love Than my unpleas'd eye see your courtesy. Enter on the walls, the KING, the BISHOP OF CARLISLE, AUMERLE, SCROOP, and SALISBURY See, see, King Richard doth himself appear, As doth the blushing discontented sun From out the fiery portal of the east, When he perceives the envious clouds are bent T But harke you Kate,Whither I go, thither shall you go too:To day will I set forth, to morrow you. I cannot now speake, I will heare you soone:Take them away Pist. [TITUS LARTIUS, having set a guard upon Corioli, going with drumand trumpet toward COMINIUS and CAIUS MARCIUS, enters with aLIEUTENANT, a party of Soldiers, and a Scout. I saw it in his hand, It was a handkerchief, an antique token My father gave my mother. And your vnthought-of Harry chance to meet:For euery Honor sitting on his Helme,Would they were multitudes, and on my headMy shames redoubled. I mean not cuckold-mad; But, sure, he is stark mad. If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot at me;and he that hits me, let him be clapp'd on the shoulder andcall'd Adam. O thou Othello, that wert once so good, Fall'n in the practice of a damned slave, What shall be said to thee? OTHELLO. I neuer see thy Face, but I thinke vpon Hell fire, and Diuesthat liued in Purple; for there he is in his Robes burning,burning. What Hal? How now mad Wag, what a Deuilldo'st thou in Warwickshire? My good Lord of Westmerland,I cry you mercy, I thought your Honour had alreadybeene at Shrewsbury West. O, my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall 's dead, Slain by his servant, going to put out The other eye of Gloucester. God help the noble Claudio! If he have caught the Benedick, itwill cost him a thousand pound ere 'a be cured. Judge me the world, if 'tis not gross in sense That thou hast practiced on her with foul charms, Abused her delicate youth with drugs or minerals That weaken motion. If there be cords or knives, Poison or fire, or suffocating streams, I'll not endure it. See whether their basest metal be not moved; They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness. Good gentlemen, let me have leave to speak; 'Tis proper I obey him, but not now. You may do your will, But he's a tried and valiant soldier. For my voice, I haue lost it with hallowingand singing of Anthemes. Exeunt Othello, Desdemona, andAttendants. If Percy be aliue, Ile pierce him: if he do come inmy way, so: if he do not, if I come in his (willingly) lethim make a Carbonado of me. And the Boy that I gaue Falstaffe, he had himfrom me Christian, and see if the fat villain haue not transform'dhim Ape. Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord; Say I am merry. I am glad thou hast set thy mercy and thy honourAt difference in thee; out of that I'll workMyself a former fortune. I haue giuen ouer, I will speak no more,Do what you will: your Wisedome, be your guide North. Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more; I am not partial to infringe our laws. Well then, Colleuile is your Name, a Knight isyour Degree, and your Place, the Dale. I will not trouble you As yet to question you about your fortunes. You cannot, if my heart were in your hand; Nor shall not, whilst 'tis in my custody. I am not onely witty in myselfe, but the cause that wit is in other men. What thegood-yere? One must beare, and that must bee you:you are the weaker Vessell; as they say, the emptierVessell Dol. Varro and Claudio lie down. Heaven would that she these gifts should have, And I to live and die her slave. Hee willfoyne like any diuell, he will spare neither man, woman,nor childe Fang. Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that: for the defenceof a town our general is excellent. And can you, by no drift of circumstance, Get from him why he puts on this confusion, Grating so harshly all his days of quiet With turbulent and dangerous lunacy? Ros. Thy dow'rless daughter, King, thrown to my chance, Is queen of us, of ours, and our fair France. He's a soldier; and for one to say a soldier lies, is stabbing. Come, come, Lord Mortimer, you are as slow,As hot Lord Percy is on fire to goe. Well then, to work! Our cannon shall be bent Against the brows of this resisting town; Call for our chiefest men of discipline, To cull the plots of best advantages. Thus, pretty lady, I am sorry for thy much misgovernment. [To ORLANDO] I will satisfyyou if ever I satisfied man, and you shall be married to-morrow. O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, rail'dat herself that she should be so immodest to write to one thatshe knew would flout her. Ne'er may I look on day nor sleep on night But she tells to your Highness simple truth!ANGELO. Meantime we thank you for your well-took labour: Go to your rest; at night we?l feast together: Most welcome home! [Exeunt Voltimand and Cornelius. If sight and shape be true, Why then, my love adieu! ROSALIND. Thus, after greeting, speaks the King of France In my behaviour to the majesty, The borrowed majesty, of England here. Why did you leaue me here alone (my Lords?) Cla. Marry, sir, she's the kitchen-wench, and all grease; and I know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light. Cry 'Holla' to thy tongue, I prithee; it curvets unseasonably. Let's choose executors and talk of wills; And yet not so-for what can we bequeath Save our deposed bodies to the ground? Our lands, our lives, and an, are Bolingbroke's. Iago hath direction what to do; But notwithstanding with my personal eye Will I look to't. Now Sirs: you fought faire; so did youPeto, so did you Bardol: you are Lyons too, you ranneaway vpon instinct: you will not touch the true Prince;no, fie Bard. If partially affined, or leagued in office, Thou dost deliver more or less than truth, Thou art no soldier. And we create, in absence of ourself, Our Uncle York Lord Governor of England; For he is just, and always lov'd us well. You may relish him more in the soldier than in the scholar. [Tears at his clothes. Here was a Caesar! When comes such another? FIRST CITIZEN. I know you what you are; And, like a sister, am most loath to call Your faults as they are nam'd. Good my mother, peace! I would that I were low laid in my grave: I am not worth this coil that's made for me. Tush, tush, man! never fleer and jest at me I speak not like a dotard nor a fool, As under privilege of age to brag What I have done being young, or what would do, Were I not old. I am eight times thrust through the Doublet,foure through the Hose, my Buckler cut through andthrough, my Sword hackt like a Hand-saw, ecce signum. How like you this wild counsel, mighty states? Smacks it not something of the policy? KING JOHN. O wretched fool, That livest to make thine honesty a vice! O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world, To be direct and honest is not safe. Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in everythinghereafter. No further go in this,Then I by Letters shall direct your courseWhen time is ripe, which will be sodainly:Ile steale to Glendower, and loe, Mortimer,Where you, and Dowglas, and our powres at once,As I will fashion it, shall happily meete,To beare our fo If such a one will smile and stroke his beard, Bid sorrow wag, cry 'hem' when he should groan, Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk With candle-wasters--bring him yet to me, And I of him will gather patience. I did obey, and sent my peasant home For certain ducats; he with none return'd. 1596KING RICHARD THE SECONDby William ShakespeareDRAMATIS PERSONAE KING RICHARD THE SECOND JOHN OF GAUNT, Duke of Lancaster uncle to the King EDMUND LANGLEY, Duke of York uncle to the King HENRY, surnamed BOLINGBROKE, Duke of Hereford, son of John of GauThe several messengers From hence attend dispatch. He is dead and gone, lady, He is dead and gone; At his head a grass green turf, At his heels a stone. The DAUPHIN'S camp at Saint EdmundsburyEnter, in arms, LEWIS, SALISBURY, MELUN, PEMBROKE, BIGOT, andsoldiers LEWIS. O, Signior Balthazar, either at flesh orfish, A table full of welcome makes scarce one dainty dish. What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living? Peto. Yes, if this present quality of warre,Indeed the instant action: a cause on foot,Liues so in hope: As in an early Spring,We see th' appearing buds, which to proue fruite,Hope giues not so much warrant, as DispaireThat Frosts will bite them. Who are the violets now That strew the green lap of the new come spring? IAGO. I was seven of the nine days out of the wonder beforeyou came; for look here what I found on a palm-tree. I do repent; but heaven hath pleas? it so, To punish me with this, and this with me, That I must be their scourge and minister. My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys, Made daily motions for our home return; Unwilling, I agreed. Not to be married, Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton. The accusationWhich they have often made against the senate,All cause unborn, could never be the motiveOf our so frank donation. A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears,And harsh in sound to thine. If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, thisis my answer: Not that I loved Caesar less, but that I lovedRome more. I'd play incessantly upon these jades, Even till unfenced desolation Leave them as naked as the vulgar air. Some holy angelFly to the court of England, and unfoldHis message ere he come; that a swift blessingMay soon return to this our suffering countryUnder a hand accurs'd!LORD. The Duke is humorous; what he is, indeed, More suits you to conceive than I to speak of. It is spoke freely out of many mouths,--How probable I do not know,--that Marcius,Join'd with Aufidius, leads a power 'gainst Rome,And vows revenge as spacious as betweenThe young'st and oldest thing. A pestilence on him for a mad rogue! ? pour? a flagon of Rhenish on my head once. My soul doth tell me Hero is belied; And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince, And all of them that thus dishonour her. God-den to yourworships: more of your conversation would infect my brain, beingthe herdsmen of the beastly plebeians: I will be bold to take myleave of you. Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of SigniorLeonato? Will no man say amen? Am I both priest and clerk? Gent. There? ne?r a villain dwelling in all Denmark But he? an arrant knave. --There's no man in the worldMore bound to's mother; yet here he lets me prate Like one i' the stocks. But age, with his stealing steps, Hath claw? me in his clutch, And hath shipp? me intil the land, As if I had never been such. Read it not, noble lords;But tell the traitor, in the highest degreeHe hath abus'd your powers. That to provoke in him Are many simples operative, whose power Will close the eye of anguish. But fear not yetTo take upon you what is yours: you mayConvey your pleasures in a spacious plenty,And yet seem cold, the time you may so hoodwink. Would I could meet him, madam! I should show What party I do follow. And I pray thee now tellme, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love withme? Beat. But beare me to that Chamber, there Ile lye:In that Ierusalem, shall Harry dye. You break jests as braggards do their blades, which God be thanked hurt not. Moe noble blows than ever thou wise words;And for Rome's good. Ah dear son Edgar, The food of thy abused father's wrath! Might I but live to see thee in my touch, I'ld say I had eyes again! Old Man. [Within] Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb,idiot, patch! Either get thee from the door, or sit down at the hatch. Sir Iohn, thy tender Lamb-kinne, now is King,Harry the Fift's the man, I speake the truth. For Yours, may heauenly glory brighten it:For His, it stucke vpon him, as the SunneIn the gray vault of Heauen: and by his LightDid all the Cheualrie of England moueTo do braue Acts. I am amaz'd, methinks, and lose my way Among the thorns and dangers of this world. Assemble presently the people hither:And when they hear me say 'It shall be soI' the right and strength o' the commons,' be it eitherFor death, for fine, or banishment, then let them,If I say fine, cry 'Fine!'if death, cry 'Death;'Insisting on the old prBefore the eyes of both our armies here, Which should perceive nothing but love from us, Let us not wrangle. The custom of request you have discharg'd:The people do admit you; and are summon'dTo meet anon, upon your approbation. You may:But if he had beene a mans Taylor, he would haue prick'dyou. All's well, and might have been much better ifHe could have temporiz'd. I know thee not, old man: Fall to thy Prayers:How ill white haires become a Foole, and Iester?I haue long dream'd of such a kinde of man,So surfeit-swell'd, so old, and so prophane:But being awake, I do despise my dreame. His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us On every trifle. How brooks your Grace the air After your late tossing on the breaking seas? KING RICHARD. Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?COURTEZAN. Come, sir, what letters had you late from France? Reg. Nay, then, thus: We came into the world like brother and brother, And now let's go hand in hand, not one before another. Why there is it: Come, sing me a bawdy Song,make me merry; I was as vertuously giuen, as a Gentlemanneed to be; vertuous enough, swore little, dic'd notaboue seuen times a weeke, went to a Bawdy-house notaboue once in a quarter of an houre, payd Money t Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made, and the garland too; for the garland he might have worn himself, andthe rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as I take it, havestol'n his bird's nest. Seek out where thy father is, that he may be ready for our apprehension. Thou art so fat-witted with drinking of oldeSacke, and vnbuttoning thee after Supper, and sleepingvpon Benches in the afternoone, that thou hast forgottento demand that truely, which thou wouldest truly know. O heaven, that there were but a mote in yours, A grain, a dust, a gnat, a wandering hair, Any annoyance in that precious sense! Then, feeling what small things are boisterous there, Your vile intent must needs seem horrible. Why, how now, Dromio! Where run'st thou so fast?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm! It is hypocrisy against the devil. Those Prisoners in your Highnesse demanded,Which Harry Percy heere at Holmedon tooke,Were (as he sayes) not with such strength deniedAs was deliuered to your Maiesty:Who either through enuy, or misprision,Was guilty of this fault; and not my Sonne Hot. Alas, what need you be so boist'rous rough? I will not struggle, I will stand stone-still. Feare wee broad-sides? No, let the Fiend giue fire:Giue me some Sack: and Sweet-heart lye thou there:Come wee to full Points here, and are et cetera's nothing? Fal. O, no more, no more!You have said you will not grant us anything;For we have nothing else to ask but thatWhich you deny already: yet we will ask;That, if you fail in our request, the blameMay hang upon your hardness; therefore hear us. I am glad of it, for now I shall have reason To show the love and duty that I bear you With franker spirit. Rowze vppeReuenge from Ebon den, with fell Alecto's Snake, forDol is in. Now sit we close about this taper here, And call in question our necessities. I will resolue for Scotland: there am I,Till Time and Vantage craue my company. Ha? a Bastard Sonne of the Kings? I will not. Strike up the drums; and let the tongue of war, Plead for our interest and our being here. Be comforted:Let's make us medicines of our great revenge,To cure this deadly grief. My bones bear witness, That since have felt the vigour of his rage. And now dispatch we toward the Court (my Lords)I heare the King, my Father, is sore sicke. Since my young lady's going into France, sir, the fool hath much pined away. Euen such a man, so faint, so spiritlesse,So dull, so dead in looke, so woe-be-gone,Drew Priams Curtaine, in the dead of night,And would haue told him, Halfe his Troy was burn'd. But yet my caution was more pertinentThan the rebuke you give it. Somuch was his pleasure should be proclaimed. O, name him not; let us not break with him, For he will never follow anything That other men begin. Who's there, i' the name of Belzebub? Here's a farmer that hangedhimself on the expectation of plenty: come in time; have napkinsenow about you; here you'll sweat for't. And, noble Dauphin, albeit we swear A voluntary zeal and an unurg'd faith To your proceedings; yet, believe me, Prince, I am not glad that such a sore of time Should seek a plaster by contemn'd revolt, And heal the inveterate canker of one wound By maki Thither I must, although against my will, For servants must their masters' minds fulfil. I would have sworn it had, my lord--especially against Benedick. What doth Grauitie out of his Bed at Midnight?Shall I giue him his answere? Something about, a little from the right, In at the window, or else o'er the hatch; Who dares not stir by day must walk by night; And have is have, however men do catch. If he, compact of jars, grow musical, We shall have shortly discord in the spheres. I'll tell thee what, Prince: a college of wit-crackerscannot flout me out of my humour. Their spirits areso married in Coniunction, with the participation of Society,that they flocke together in consent, like so manyWilde-Geese. O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits! TOUCHSTONE. Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault, Assemble all the poor men of your sort, Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears Into the channel, till the lowest stream Do kiss the most exalted shores of all. All studies heere I solemnly defie,Saue how to gall and pinch this Bullingbrooke,And that same Sword and Buckler Prince of Wales. I hope no lesse? Yet needfull 'tis to feare,And to preuent the worst, Sir Michell speed;For if Lord Percy thriue not, ere the KingDismisse his power, he meanes to visit vs:For he hath heard of our Confederacie,And, 'tis but Wisedome to make strong again Say you ne'er had done't,--Harp on that still,--but by our putting on:And presently when you have drawn your number,Repair to the Capitol. O, let thy vow First made to heaven, first be to heaven perform'd, That is, to be the champion of our Church. Andtell mee now, thou naughtie Varlet, tell mee, where hastthou beene this moneth? Prin. Yea, for obtaining of suites, whereof the Hangmanhath no leane Wardrobe. Here let us rest, if this rebellious earth Have any resting for her true King's queen. No more that Thane of Cawdor shall deceiveOur bosom interest:--go pronounce his present death,And with his former title greet Macbeth. What's more to do,Which would be planted newly with the time,--As calling home our exil'd friends abroad,That fled the snares of watchful tyranny;Producing forth the cruel ministersOf this dead butcher, and his fiend-like queen,--Who, as 'tis thought, b Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy: This wide and universal theatre Presents more woeful pageants than the scene Wherein we play in. The King himselfe is to bee feared as the Lyon:Do'st thou thinke Ile feare thee, as I feare thy Father? nayif I do, let my Girdle breake Prin. This fever that hath troubled me so long Lies heavy on me. What tell'st thou me of robbing? This is Venice; My house is not a grange. Love! his affections do not that way tend; Nor what he spake, though it lack? form a little, Was not like madness. Speak, old Aegeon, if thou be'st the man That hadst a wife once call'd Aemilia, That bore thee at a burden two fair sons. Know the gallant monarch is in arms And like an eagle o'er his aery tow'rs To souse annoyance that comes near his nest. Our house (my Soueraigne Liege) little deseruesThe scourge of greatnesse to be vsed on it,And that same greatnesse too, which our owne handsHaue holpe to make so portly Nor. And when it breaks, I fear will issue thence The foul corruption of a sweet child's death. Am I so round with you, as you with me, That like a football you do spurn me thus? You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither; If I last in this service, you must case me in leather. You have obedience scanted, And well are worth the want that you have wanted. Friends both, go join you with some further aid: Hamlet in madness hath Polonius slain, And from his mother? closet hath he dragg? him: Go seek him out; speak fair, and bring the body Into the chapel. No such matter: I will not sort you with the rest of my servants; for, to speak to you like an honest man, I am most dreadfully attended. Die men, like Dogges; giue Crownes like Pinnes:Haue we not Hiren here? Host. We will begin these rites, As we do trust they'll end, in true delights. What foolish Master taught you these manners,Sir Iohn? Fal. They all cry 'Marcius, Marcius!', cast up theircaps and lances. ' For yourbrother and my sister no sooner met but they look'd; no sooner look'dbut they lov'd; no sooner lov'd but they sigh'd; no sooner sigh'dbut they ask'd one another the reason; no sooner knew the reasonbut they sought the remedyand in these degreesSo I did, Fearing to strengthen that impatience Which seem'd too much enkindled, and withal Hoping it was but an effect of humor, Which sometime hath his hour with every man. Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would right her! Bene. Larded all with sweet flowers; Which bewept to the grave did go With true-love showers. 'O, that infected moisture of his eye, O, that false fire which in his cheek so glowed, O, that forced thunder from his heart did fly, O, that sad breath his spongy lungs bestowed, O, all that borrowed motion, seeming owed, Would yet again betray the fo Sweare me, Kate, like a Lady, as thou art,A good mouth-filling Oath: and leaue in sooth,And such protest of Pepper Ginger-bread,To Veluet-Guards, and Sunday-Citizens. Sing it; 'tis no matter how it be in tune, so it makenoise enough. I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown that they praise so. As proper men as ever trod upon neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork. Why, after I have cut the egg i' th' middle and eat upthe meat, the two crowns of the egg. Dost thou prate, rogue? Claud. I would I were senseless, sir, that I might not feel your blows. I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind; for,I protest, her frown might kill me. Sir, heere comes the Nobleman that committedthe Prince for striking him, about Bardolfe Fal. O, I could weep My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger, And here my naked breast; within, a heart Dearer than Pluto's mine, richer than gold. I fear the trust Othello puts him in On some odd time of his infirmity Will shake this island. Who comes here? OLIVER. This to hear Would Desdemona seriously incline; But still the house affairs would draw her thence, Which ever as she could with haste dispatch, She'ld come again, and with a greedy ear Devour up my discourse; which I observing, Took once a pliant hour,  But what neede I thusMy well-knowne Body to AnathomizeAmong my houshold? OTHELLO. Thou say'st true: the Prince once set a Dishof Apple-Iohns before him, and told him there were fiuemore Sir Iohns: and, putting off his Hat, said, I will nowtake my leaue of these sixe drie, round, old-wither'dKnights. If again it was not wellcut, he would answer I spake not true. But what is your affair in Elsinore? O heavy hour! Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse Of sun and moon, and that the affrighted globe Should yawn at alteration. I will ask him for my place again; he shall tell me Iam a drunkard! Glou. Wast not to this end That thou began'st to twist so fine a story? Claud. Is it my fault that I was Geffrey's son? An if an angel should have come to me And told me Hubert should put out mine eyes, I would not have believ'd him-no tongue but Hubert's. Whoe'er he be that in this foul proceeding Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself And you of her, the bloody book of law You shall yourself read in the bitter letter After your own sense, yea, though our proper son Stood in your action. As it were, to ride day and night,And not to deliberate, not to remember,Not to haue patience to shift me Shal. Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me;yet, if you be out, sir, I can mend you. Why, masters, have your instruments been in Naples, that they speak i' the nose thus? FIRST MUSICIAN. The enemy, marching along by them, By them shall make a fuller number up, Come on refresh'd, new-added, and encouraged; From which advantage shall we cut him off If at Philippi we do face him there, These people at our back. I am your shadow, my Lord, Ile follow you Prin. Be it knowne to you (as it is verywell) I was lately heere in the end of a displeasing Play, to prayyourPatien for it, and to promise you a Better: I did meane (indeede) topay you withthi which if (like an ill Venture) it come vnluckily home, I breake;a Wel, heauen send the Prince a better companion Fal. Why, noble lords,Will you be put in mind of his blind fortune,Which was your shame, by this unholy braggart,'Fore your own eyes and ears?CONSPIRATORS. I will makemuch of your voices, and so trouble you no further. And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I; Brutus, my country's friend; know me for Brutus! The one a palate hath that needs will taste, Though Reason weep, and cry it is thy last. I'ld have thee live, For, in my sense, 'tis happiness to die. I lay with Cassio lately And, being troubled with a raging tooth, I could not sleep. Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus, Is it excepted I should know no secrets That appertain to you? BOLINGBROKE. I was hardly moved to cometo thee; but being assured none but myself could move thee, Ihave been blown out of your gates with sighs; and conjure thee topardon Rome and thy petitionary countrymen. Now hath my soul brought forth her prodigy; And I, a gasping new-deliver'd mother, Have woe to woe, sorrow to sorrow join'd. Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. And have not we affections, Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have? Then let them use us well; else let them know, The ills we do, their ills instruct us so. My Lord of Salisbury, we have stay'd ten days And hardly kept our countrymen together, And yet we hear no tidings from the King; Therefore we will disperse ourselves. But do not look for further recompense Than thine own gladness that thou art employ'd. And know it now, the Senate have concluded To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar. Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago, If thou but think'st him wrong'd and makest his ear A stranger to thy thoughts. O my poor Rosalind! HUBERT. Idle old man, That still would manage those authorities That he hath given away! Now, by my life, Old fools are babes again, and must be us'd With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abus'd. Come what come may,Time and the hour runs through the roughest day. I would not there reside To put my father in impatient thoughts By being in his eye. Then would to God that I had never seen't! OTHELLO. The colour of the King doth come and go Between his purpose and his conscience, Like heralds 'twixt two dreadful battles set. Marry, sir, besides myself, I am due to a woman-one that claims me, one that haunts me, one that will have me. I am doubtful that you have been conjunct And bosom'd with her, as far as we call hers. What would you have? He dies that strikes again. Ha, majesty! how high thy glory tow'rs When the rich blood of kings is set on fire! PORTIA. What is this?Your knees to me? to your corrected son?Then let the pebbles on the hungry beachFillip the stars; then let the mutinous windsStrike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun,;Murdering impossibility, to makeWhat cannot be, slight work. No, sir, their hats are pluck'd about their ears, And half their faces buried in their cloaks, That by no means I may discover them By any mark of favor. I'll make you amends next, to give you nothing for something. Their battles are at hand; They mean to warn us at Philippi here, Answering before we do demand of them. They durst not do't; They would not, could not do't. Faith, sir, we were carousing till the second cock: anddrink, sir, is a great provoker of three things. Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, Lest I be laugh'd at when I tell them so. Her worth, being mounted on the wind, Through all the world bears Rosalinde. ?o the celestial, and my soul? idol, the most beautified Ophelia,? I cannot speak enough of this content; It stops me here; it is too much of joy. Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies, Or my sham'd life in his dishonour lies. Stoop, Romans, stoop, And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords; Then walk we forth, even to the marketplace, And waving our red weapons o'er our heads, Let's all cry, "Peace, freedom, and liberty!" CASSIUS. Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself,And so shall starve with feeding. My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care, At eighteen years became inquisitive After his brother, and importun'd me That his attendant-so his case was like, Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name Might bear him company in the quest of him; Whom whils Is 'old dog' my reward? Most true, I have lost my teethin your service. O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius, To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick! LIGARIUS. What's he that hath so much thy place mistook To set thee here? Kent. You, you, ay, you! CHARLES. Her part, poor soul, seeming as burdened With lesser weight, but not with lesser woe, Was carried with more speed before the wind; And in our sight they three were taken up By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought. Come on;Gently my lord, sleek o'er your rugged looks;Be bright and jovial 'mong your guests to-night. He sits in hisstate as a thing made for Alexander. Draw, you rogue! for,though it be night, yet the moon shines. Pindarus ascends the hill. Faith, he tonight hath boarded a land carack; If it prove lawful prize, he's made forever. And when I have heard it, what blessings brings it? Con. My services, which I have done the signiory, Shall out-tongue his complaints. Mine eye hath well examined his parts And finds them perfect Richard. If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it, And I will break with her and with her father, And thou shalt have her. Show his eyes, and grieve his heart;Come like shadows, so depart![Eight kings appear, and pass over in order, the last with aglass in his hand; Banquo following. There's many a beast then in a populous city, And many a civil monster. Sound! First trumpet. Your accent is something finer than you could purchasein so removed a dwelling. Follow your function, go,And batten on cold bits. Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of yourGrace; for trouble being gone, comfort should remain; but when youdepart from me, sorrow abides and happiness takes his leave. See Sonnes, what things you are:How quickly Nature falls into reuolt,When Gold becomes her Obiect?For this, the foolish ouer-carefull FathersHaue broke their sleepes with thoughts,Their braines with care, their bones with industry. Take you this weapon, Which I have here recover'd from the Moor. I am unfortunate in the infirmity, and dare not task my weaknesswith any more. Then let me heareOf you my gentle Cousin Westmerland,What yesternight our Councell did decree,In forwarding this deere expedience West. I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquaintedwith thee. Sir, can you tellWhere he bestows himself?LORD. Up, cousin, up; your heart is up, I know, [Touching his own head] Thus high at least, although your knee be low. And then it started, like a guilty thing Upon a fearful summons. I honour'd him, I lov'd him, and will weep My date of life out for his sweet life's loss. It is the curse of kings to be attended By slaves that take their humours for a warrant To break within the bloody house of life, And on the winking of authority To understand a law; to know the meaning Of dangerous majesty, when perchance it frowns Mor Your uncle must not know but you are dead: I'll fill these dogged spies with false reports; And, pretty child, sleep doubtless and secure That Hubert, for the wealth of all the world, Will not offend thee. Colleuile shallstill be your Name, a Traytor your Degree, and the Dungeonyour Place, a place deepe enough: so shall you bestill Colleuile of the Dale Col. Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord, Than this weak arm. Princes and Counties! Surely a princely testimony, agoodly count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant surely! O that I were aman for his sake! or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into cursies, valour intocompliment, and No, that you shall not till you take her hand Before this friar and swear to marry her. He rais'd the house with loud and coward cries. Be wary then; best safety lies in fear: Youth to itself rebels, though none else near. Heaven and earth! Edmund, seek him out; wind me into him, Ipray you; frame the business after your own wisdom. He hath brought many captives home to Rome, Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill. This is the deadly spight, that angers me,My Wife can speake no English, I no Welsh Glend. Sweet lord, if your lordship were at leisure, I should impart a thing to you from his ma jesty. The Moor is of a free and open nature, That thinks men honest that but seem to be so, And will as tenderly be led by the nose As asses are. This is a poor epitome of yours,Which, by the interpretation of full time,May show like all yourself. Not all the water in the rough rude sea Can wash the balm off from an anointed king; The breath of worldly men cannot depose The deputy elected by the Lord. Therefore, most gracious Duke, with thy command Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help. It were an honest action to say So to the Moor. Then learn this of me: to have is to have; for itis a figure in rhetoric that drink, being pour'd out of cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty the other; for all your writers do consent that ipse is he; now, you are not ipse,for I am he. You follow the yong Prince vp and downe, likehis euill Angell Fal. Nor did you think it follyTo keep your great pretences veil'd till whenThey needs must show themselves; which in the hatching,It seem'd, appear'd to Rome. To a cruel war I sent him; from whencehe returned his brows bound with oak. No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip: she is spherical, like a globe; I could find out countries in her. By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st, I heard thee say, and vauntingly thou spak'st it, That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death. For this, they haue ingrossed and pyl'd vpThe canker'd heapes of strange-atchieued Gold:For this, they haue beene thoughtfull, to inuestTheir Sonnes with Arts, and Martiall Exercises:When, like the Bee, culling from euery flowerThe vertuous Sweetes, our No; it is stopp'd with other flattering sounds, As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond, Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound The open ear of youth doth always listen; Report of fashions in proud Italy, Whose manners still our tardy apish nation 'Nor gives it satisfaction to our blood That we must curb it upon others' proof, To be forbod the sweets that seems so good For fear of harms that preach in our behoof. But for a fine, quaint, graceful, andexcellent fashion, yours is worth ten on't. Exeunt Octavius, Antony, and their Army. Brother by th' mother's side, give me your hand; My father gave me honour, yours gave land. Now Falstaffe, where haue you beene all this while?When euery thing is ended, then you come. Mine honour is my life; both grow in one; Take honour from me, and my life is done: Then, dear my liege, mine honour let me try; In that I live, and for that will I die. How now, sir! Have you that I sent you for?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Your Lordship (though not clean pastyour youth) hath yet some smack of age in you: some rellishof the saltnesse of Time, and I most humbly beseechyour Lordship, to haue a reuerend care of your health Iust. Methinks King Richard and myself should meet With no less terror than the elements Of fire and water, when their thund'ring shock At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven. I saw a smith stand with his hammer, thus, The whilst his iron did on the anvil cool, With open mouth swallowing a tailor's news; Who, with his shears and measure in his hand, Standing on slippers, which his nimble haste Had falsely thrust upon contrary You cast th' euent of Warre (my Noble Lord)And summ'd the accompt of Chance, before you saidLet vs make head: It was your presurmize,That in the dole of blowes, your Son might drop. For whiles this honest fool Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune, And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor, I'll pour this pestilence into his ear, That she repeals him for her body's lust; And by how much she strives to do him good, She shall undo  He that dares approach, On him, on you, who not? I will maintain My truth and honour firmly. ) that came fro[m] thence,A Gentleman well bred, and of good name,That freely render'd me these newes for true Nor. Hee must then to the Innes of Court shortly: Iwas once of Clements Inne; where (I thinke) they willtalke of mad Shallow yet Sil. Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake? What villain touch'd his body, that did stab, And not for justice? What, shall one of us, That struck the foremost man of all this world But for supporting robbers, shall we now Contaminate our fingers with  Trust not those cunning waters of his eyes, For villainy is not without such rheum; And he, long traded in it, makes it seem Like rivers of remorse and innocency. True, who beares hardHis Brothers death at Bristow, the Lord Scroope. Wilt thou rest damn'd? God help thee, shallow man!God make incision in thee! thou art raw. Though no man be assur'd what grace to finde,You stand in coldest expectation. --And is Aufidius with him?--You are theyThat made the air unwholesome, when you castYour stinking greasy caps in hooting atCoriolanus' exile. Your breath first kindled the dead coal of wars Between this chastis'd kingdom and myself And brought in matter that should feed this fire; And now 'tis far too huge to be blown out With that same weak wind which enkindled it. Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful; And pity to the general wrong of Rome As fire drives out fire, so pity pity Hath done this deed on Caesar. Away, they'll kill us!<Exeunt all but ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE andDROMIO OF SYRACUSE as fast as may be, frightedANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Three great ones of the city, In personal suit to make me his lieutenant, Off-capp'd to him; and, by the faith of man, I know my price, I am worth no worse a place. --The nobility are vex'd, whom we see have sidedIn his behalf. Yes, I beseech your Grace; I am not yet well breath'd. O, sir, to wilful men The injuries that they themselves procure Must be their schoolmasters. You men of Angiers, open wide your gates And let young Arthur, Duke of Britaine, in, Who by the hand of France this day hath made Much work for tears in many an English mother, Whose sons lie scattered on the bleeding ground; Many a widow's husband grov Messala, This is my birthday, as this very day Was Cassius born. Looke, looke,Heere comes my Iohn of Lancaster: Iohn. They stand at the door, master; bid themwelcome hither. Shall we go seek Benedick and tell himof her love? Claud. Why, sweet Othello? OTHELLO. Enter MELUN, wounded MELUN. [Drumbeats] The interruption of their churlish drums Cuts off more circumstance: they are at hand; To parley or to fight, therefore prepare. Get thee to a nunnery: why wouldst thou be a breeder of sinners? I am myself indifferent honest; but yet I could accuse me of such things that it were better my mother had not borne me: I am very proud, revengeful, ambitious; with more offences at my be Exton, thy fierce hand Hath with the King's blood stain'd the King's own land. She never yet was foolish that was fair, For even her folly help'd her to an heir. But hearke you Kate,I must not haue you henceforth, question me,Whether I go: nor reason whereabout. I see we still did meet each other's man, And I was ta'en for him, and he for me, And thereupon these ERRORS are arose. See what a ready tongue Suspition hath:He that but feares the thing, he would not know,Hath by Instinct, knowledge from others Eyes,That what he feard, is chanc'd. Heauen send the Companion a better Prince: Icannot rid my hands of him Iust. They choose their magistrate;And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,'His popular 'shall,' against a graver bench Than ever frown'd in Greece. But, for your private satisfaction, Because I love you, I will let you know. It will not be accepted, on my life,The Dowglas and the Hotspurre both together,Are confident against the world in Armes King. Good morrow, Brutus, do we trouble you? BRUTUS. The grand conspirator, Abbot of Westminster, With clog of conscience and sour melancholy, Hath yielded up his body to the grave; But here is Carlisle living, to abide Thy kingly doom, and sentence of his pride. The Theeues haue bound the True-men: Nowcould thou and I rob the Theeues, and go merily to London,it would be argument for a Weeke, Laughter for aMoneth, and a good iest for euer Poynes. Threescore and ten I can remember well:Within the volume of which time I have seenHours dreadful and things strange; but this sore nightHath trifled former knowings. You have pray'd well to-day:This morning for ten thousand of your throatsIed not have given a doit. Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, from the bayDROMIO OF SYRACUSE. He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rockWith rigorous hands: he hath resisted law,And therefore law shall scorn him further trialThan the severity of the public power,Which he so sets at nought. Was it so late, friend, ere you went to bed,That you do lie so late?PORTER. Philip, what say'st thou to the Cardinal? CONSTANCE. This woman lock'd me out this day from dinner; That goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her, Could witness it, for he was with me then; Who parted with me to go fetch a chain, Promising to bring it to the Porpentine, Where Balthazar and I did dine  What work's, my countrymen, in hand? where go youWith bats and clubs? the matter? speak, I pray you. Our Nauie is addressed, our Power collected,Our Substitutes, in absence, well inuested,And euery thing lyes leuell to our wish;Onely wee want a little personall Strength:And pawse vs, till these Rebels, now a-foot,Come vnderneath the yoake of Gouernment Farewell, kind neighbours: we wish'd CoriolanusHad lov'd you as we did. A dearer merit, not so deep a maim As to be cast forth in the common air, Have I deserved at your Highness' hands. O be remov'd from him, and answer well! AUSTRIA. If he be not in love with some woman, there is nobelieving old signs. To his father, that so tenderly and entirely loves him. Dost understand the word? My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago. Why, look you now, how unworthy a thing you make of me! You would play upon me; you would seem to know my stops; you would95 pluck out the heart of my mystery; you would sound me from my lowest note to the top of my compass; and there is much music, exc Now all's his:When, by and by, the din of war 'gan pierceHis ready sense; then straight his doubled spiritRe-quick'ned what in flesh was fatigate,And to the battle came he; where he didRun reeking o'er the lives of men, as if'Twere a perpetual spoil: an How lies their battle? know you on which sideThey have placed their men of trust?COMINIUS. Three proper young men, of excellent growth andpresence. A thousand welcomes!And more a friend than e'er an enemy;Yet, Marcius, that was much. Things that are mouldie,lacke vse: very singular good. I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcomedear. I wish I had a cause to seek him there,To oppose his hatred fully. Our Battaile is more full of Names then yours,Our Men more perfect in the vse of Armes,Our Armor all as strong, our Cause the best;Then Reason will, our hearts should be as good. When you speak best unto thepurpose, it is not worth the wagging of your beards; and yourbeards deserve not so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher'scushion or to be entombed in an ass's pack-saddle. I warrant, her rags and the tallow in them will burn Poland winter. Whose party do the townsmen yet admit? KING PHILIP. --Masters o' the people,We do request your kindest ears; and, after, Your loving motion toward the common body,To yield what passes here. I am nowin great haste, as it may appear unto you. With all my heart; and it doth much content me To hear him so inclin?. --To the market-place:--You have put me now to such a part which neverI shall discharge to the life. Why art thou not at Windsor with him (Thomas?) Clar. I am the second son of old Sir Rowland, That bring these tidings to this fair assembly. He doth, for he did bid Antonio Send word to you he would be there tomorrow. Hail, lords! I am return'd your soldier; No more infected with my country's loveThan when I parted hence, but still subsistingUnder your great command. By this the weary lords Shall make their way seem short, as mine hath done By sight of what I have, your noble company. Yet your good-willMust have that thanks from Rome, after the measureAs you intended well. Thou hast the most vnsauoury smiles, and art indeedthe most comparatiue rascallest sweet yong Prince. I' th' last night's storm I such a fellow saw, Which made me think a man a worm. I, madam? No, I have no reason for it That is my brother's plea, and none of mine; The which if he can prove, 'a pops me out At least from fair five hundred pound a year. The pleasure that some fathers feed upon Is my strict fast-I mean my children's looks; And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt. Tut our horses they shall not see, Ile tye them inthe wood, our vizards wee will change after wee leauethem: and sirrah, I haue Cases of Buckram for the nonce,to immaske our noted outward garments Prin. I did, I saw him dead,Breathlesse, and bleeding on the ground: Art thou aliue?Or is it fantasie that playes vpon our eye-sight?I prethee speake, we will not trust our eyesWithout our eares. Imagination of some great exploit,Driues him beyond the bounds of Patience Hot. It is but foolery; but it is such a kind of gain-giving as would perhaps trouble a woman. Captaine? thou abhominable damn'd Cheater,art thou not asham'd to be call'd Captaine? If Captaineswere of my minde, they would trunchion you out, for takingtheir Names vpon you, before you haue earn'd them. All the contagion of the south light on you,You shames of Rome!--you herd of--Boils and plaguesPlaster you o'er, that you may be abhorr'dFarther than seen, and one infect anotherAgainst the wind a mile! You souls of geeseThat bear the shapes of men, how He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear As Harry Duke of Hereford, were he here. I would not spare my brother in this case, If he should scorn me so apparently. Now to seem to affect the malice and displeasure of thepeople is as bad as that which he dislikes,--to flatter them fortheir love. I may not breathe my censure What he might be: if what he might he is not, I would to heaven he were! LODOVICO. Draw, seem to defend yourself; now quit you well. Hear me speak:--As I do know the consul's worthiness,So can I name his faults,--SICINIUS. Most shallowly did you these Armes commence,Fondly brought here, and foolishly sent hence. The FRENCH KING'S campEnter CONSTANCE, ARTHUR, and SALISBURY CONSTANCE. Get weapons, ho!
