Gonzago: The story is extant, and written in very choice Italian; you shall see anon how the murderer gets the love of Gonzago? wife. Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear, And since you know you cannot see yourself So well as by reflection, I your glass Will modestly discover to yourself That of yourself which you yet know not of. I sent for you (when there were matters againstyou for your life) to come speake with me Fal. Sir Iohn, I sent you before your Expedition, toShrewsburie Fal. Thou speak'st as if I would deny my name Hot. Will you sit down with me? and we two will railagainst our mistress the world, and all our misery. They are in the very wrath of love, and they will together. Good Cinna, take this paper, And look you lay it in the praetor's chair, Where Brutus may but find it; and throw this In at his window; set this up with wax Upon old Brutus' statue. He has it now; and by his looks methinks'Tis warm at his heart. O my good Lord Mowbray,Construe the Times to their Necessities,And you shall say (indeede) it is the Time,And not the King, that doth you iniuries. The dungeon of the CastleEnter KING RICHARD KING RICHARD. But here must end the story of my life; And happy were I in my timely death, Could all my travels warrant me they live. The courtesy of nations allows you mybetter in that you are the first-born; but the same tradition takesnot away my blood, were there twenty brothers betwixt us. Hee is not there to day: hee dines in London King. Now must your conscience my acquittance seal, And you must put me in your heart for friend,127 Sith you have heard, and with a knowing ear, That he which hath your noble father slain Pursu? my life. I do demand,If you submit you to the people's voices,Allow their officers, and are contentTo suffer lawful censure for such faultsAs shall be proved upon you. This fest'red joint cut off, the rest rest sound; This let alone will all the rest confound. For ever may my knees grow to the earth, [Kneels] My tongue cleave to my roof within my mouth, Unless a pardon ere I rise or speak. Good my lord, How does your honour for this many a day? Ham. Such a nature,Tickled with good success, disdains the shadowWhich he treads on at noon: but I do wonderHis insolence can brook to be commandedUnder Cominius. Let the great gods, That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads, Find out their enemies now. Why, it cannot choose but be a Noble plot,And then the power of Scotland, and of YorkeTo ioyne with Mortimer, Ha Wor. Hail, you anointed deputies of heaven! To thee, King John, my holy errand is. Under an oak, whose boughs were moss'd with age, And high top bald with dry antiquity, A wretched ragged man, o'ergrown with hair, Lay sleeping on his back. Where thou wilt Lad, Ile make one: and I doenot, call me Villaine, and baffle me Prin. The common executioner, Whose heart th' accustom'd sight of death makes hard, Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck But first begs pardon. 'Tis three o'clock, and Romans, yet ere night We shall try fortune in a second fight. Upon my honour, Myself, my brother, and this grieved Count Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window, Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain, Confess'd the vile encounters they have had A thousand tim Upon his death-bed he by will bequeath'd His lands to me, and took it on his death That this my mother's son was none of his; And if he were, he came into the world Full fourteen weeks before the course of time. This lies glowing, I can tell you, and is almost maturefor the violent breaking out. But I must goe, and meet with Danger there,Or it will seeke me in another place,And finde me worse prouided Wife. If either of you know any inward impediment why youshould not be conjoined, I charge you on your souls to utter it. <ExeuntSCENE 2The martEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, and FIRSTMERCHANTFIRST MERCHANT. Iago? O, I am spoil'd, undone by villains! Give me some help. So, that skill in the Weaponis nothing, without Sack (for that sets it a-worke:) andLearning, a meere Hoord of Gold, kept by a Deuill, tillSack commences it, and sets it in act, and vse. He was wont to speakplain and to the purpose, like an honest man and a soldier; and nowis he turn'd orthography; his words are a very fantasticalbanquet- just so many strange dishes. That sir which serves and seeks for gain, And follows but for form, Will pack when it begins to rain And leave thee in the storm. Thou art a villain to impeach me thus; I'll prove mine honour and mine honesty Against thee presently, if thou dar'st stand. Then 'tis like the breath of an unfeed lawyeryou gaveme nothing for't. Though this be madness, yet there is a method in?. Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a prettyjest your daughter told us of. Thus far can I praise him: he is of a noble strain, ofapproved valour, and confirm'd honesty. But there is Mordake, Vernon, Lord Harry Percy,And there is my Lord of Worcester,And a Head of gallant Warriors,Noble Gentlemen Arch. , AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF CARNEGIE MELLON UNIVERSITYWITH PERMISSION. Iwill piece out the comfort with what addition I can. Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome. If the deed were ill,Be you contented, wearing now the Garland,To haue a Sonne, set your Decrees at naught?To plucke downe Iustice from your awefull Bench?To trip the course of Law, and blunt the SwordThat guards the peace, and safety of your Person?Nay The fitchew nor the soiled horse goes to't With a more riotous appetite. Go, fellow, get thee home, provide some carts, And bring away the armour that is there. Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did you meanby that same handkerchief you gave me even now? I was a finefool to take it. Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse Full of crusadoes; and, but my noble Moor Is true of mind and made of no such baseness As jealous creatures are, it were enough To put him to ill thinking. Sweet Hero! she is wrong'd, she is sland'red, she isundone. When, Caius, Rome is thine,Thou art poor'st of all; then shortly art thou mine. Those that with haste will make a mighty fire Begin it with weak straws. Well, Ile goe with thee, prouide vs all thingsnecessary, and meete me to morrow night in Eastcheape,there Ile sup. But, soft you, let me be! Pluck up, my heart, and besad! Did he not say my brother was fled? Dog. Good Volumnius, Thou know'st that we two went to school together; Even for that our love of old, I prithee, Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it. Welcome mylittle tyne theefe, and welcome indeed too: Ile drinke toM[aster]. Thou hast taken against me a most just exception; but yet, I protest, have dealt most directly inthy affair. [He kneels down] My gracious lord KING RICHARD. Is not his Brother, Thomas of Clarence, withhim? Glo. She wish'd she had not heard it, yet she wish'd That heaven had made her such a man; she thank'd me, And bade me, if I had a friend that loved her, I should but teach him how to tell my story, And that would woo her. The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls, Are their males' subjects, and at their controls. I serve the King; On whose employment I was sent to you. Re-enter second Gentleman. My lord, the queen would speak with you, and presently. And 'tis no little reason bids vs speed,To saue our heads, by raising of a Head:For, beare our selues as euen as we can,The King will alwayes thinke him in our debt,And thinke, we thinke our selues vnsatisfied,Till he hath found a time to pay vs home. [To Goneril] Thou worse than any name, read thine own evil. Do you know this noblegentleman, Edmund? Edm. If I see anything to-night why I should not marry her to-morrow, in the congregation where I should wed, there willI shame her. Faith, I have heard too much, for your words and performances are no kin together. But which are the offenders that are to be examined? letthem come before Master Constable. Away Varlets, draw Bardolfe: Cut me off theVillaines head: throw the Queane in the Channel Host. [To ANGELO] Get you home And fetch the chain; by this I know 'tis made. Hast thou conspired with thy brother too, That for thine own gain shouldst defend mine honour? What means this scorn, thou most untoward knave? BASTARD. Away, then, with good courage! Yet, I know Our party may well meet a prouder foe. Our dinner done, and he not coming thither, I went to seek him. We breath too long: Come cosin Westmerland,Our duty this way lies, for heauens sake come Prin. Tell Bolingbroke, for yon methinks he stands, That every stride he makes upon my land Is dangerous treason; he is come to open The purple testament of bleeding war; But ere the crown he looks for live in peace, Ten thousand bloody crowns of mothers' son But who comes here? The safer sense will ne'er accommodate His master thus. Most subiect is the fattest Soyle to Weedes:And hee (the Noble Image of my Youth)Is ouer-spread with them: therefore my griefeStretches it selfe beyond the howre of death. Why I do trifle thus with his despair Is done to cure it. You have been always called a merciful man, partner. Not I: I tell thee what, Corporall Bardolph, Icould teare her: Ile be reueng'd on her Page. Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit, And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes, I will be brief:?our noble son is mad: Mad call I it; for to define true madness, What is? but to be nothing else but mad? But let that go. O, would you had had her! Some one way, some another. Sir Iohn, you are so fretfull, you cannot liuelong Falst. Thou say'st true Hostesse, and he slanders theemost grossely Host. Therefore, good mother, To whom am I beholding for these limbs? Sir Robert never holp to make this leg. I do forget:--Do not muse at me, my most worthy friends;I have a strange infirmity, which is nothingTo those that know me. Hold vp thy head vile Scot, or thou art likeNeuer to hold it vp againe: the SpiritsOf valiant Sherly, Stafford, Blunt, are in my Armes;it is the Prince of Wales that threatens thee,Who neuer promiseth, but he meanes to pay. No, he's a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son; forhe's a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him. Now, my good sweet Hony Lord, ride with vsto morrow. --I'll enter; if he slay me,He does fair justice; if he give me way,I'll do his country service. I prest me none but such Tostesand Butter, with Hearts in their Bellyes no bigger thenPinnes heads, and they haue bought out their seruices:And now, my whole Charge consists of Ancients, Corporals,Lieutenants, Gentlemen of Companies, Slaues asragged a L Alas the day: take heed of him: he stabd mein mine owne house, and that most beastly: he cares notwhat mischeefe he doth, if his weapon be out. SCENE 1A public placeEnter SECOND MERCHANT, ANGELO, and an OFFICERSECOND MERCHANT. With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my Rosalind; so, adieu. --Thou old and true Menenius,Thy tears are salter than a younger man's,And venomous to thine eyes. Here's that shall drive some of them to a non-come. So please you, for I never heard it yet; Yet heard too much of Phebe's cruelty. You will take little delight in it, I can tell you, there is such odds in the man. Thereafter as they be: a score of good Ewesmay be worth tenne pounds Shal. But, I beseech you,What says the other troop?MARCIUS. The King is come; deal mildly with his youth, For young hot colts being rag'd do rage the more. Learn, good soul, To think our former state a happy dream; From which awak'd, the truth of what we are Shows us but this: I am sworn brother, sweet, To grim Necessity; and he and Will keep a league till death. By Jove himself,It makes the consuls base: and my soul achesTo know, when two authorities are up,Neither supreme, how soon confusionMay enter 'twixt the gap of both and takeThe one by the other. What's the matter? GRATIANO. I would fainhave it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it if you threewill but minister such assistance as I shall give you direction. I will after straightAnd tell him so: for I will ease my heart,Although it be with hazard of my head Nor. And therefore will hee wipe his Tables cleane,And keepe no Tell-tale to his Memorie,That may repeat, and Historie his losse,To new remembrance. Dost thou hear? Since my dear soul was mistress of her choice, And could of men distinguish, her election Hath seal? thee for herself: for thou hast been As one, in suffering all, that suffers nothing; A man that Fortune? buffets and rewards84 Hast ta?n The castle royally is mann'd, my lord, Against thy entrance. There is more newes:I learned in Worcester, as I rode along,He cannot draw his Power this fourteene dayes Dowg. Part us, Northumberland; I towards the north, Where shivering cold and sickness pines the clime; My wife to France, from whence set forth in pomp, She came adorned hither like sweet May, Sent back like Hallowmas or short'st of day. --Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence;Lest his infection, being of catching nature,Spread further. ' But yet for all that, cousin, lethim be a handsome fellow, or else make another cursy, and say, 'Father, as it please me. Sirra Iacke, thy horse stands behinde the hedg,when thou need'st him, there thou shalt finde him. Ah, none but in this iron age would do it! The iron of itself, though heat red-hot, Approaching near these eyes would drink my tears, And quench his fiery indignation Even in the matter of mine innocence; Nay, after that, consume away in rust But for co Reverse thy doom; And in thy best consideration check This hideous rashness. O that this good Blossome could bee kept fromCankers: Well, there is six pence to preserue thee Bard. [They wrestle] ROSALIND. [To DUKE] You to your former honour I bequeath; Your patience and your virtue well deserves it. Can a weake emptie Vessell beare such a hugefull Hogs-head? There's a whole Marchants Ventureof Burdeux-Stuffe in him: you haue not seene a Hulkebetter stufft in the Hold. Since kings break faith upon commodity, Gain, be my lord, for I will worship thee. Live a thousand years, I shall not find myself so apt to die; No place will please me so, no means of death, As here by Caesar, and by you cut off, The choice and master spirits of this age. Those same Noble ScottesThat are your Prisoners Hot. And so, successe of Mischiefe shall be borne,And Heire from Heire shall hold this Quarrell vp,Whiles England shall haue generation Iohn. Methinks it is very sultry and hot for my complexion. Thus (my Royall Liege)Accusing it, I put it on my Head,To try with it (as with an Enemie,That had before my face murdred my Father)The Quarrell of a true Inheritor. Lord Marshal, command our officers-at-arms Be ready to direct these home alarms. How now, my masters! have you chose this man?FIRST CITIZEN. A man may break a word with you, sir; and words are but wind; Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind. Give thy thoughts no tongue, Nor any unproportion? thought his act. O, my heart is sick! Enter a MESSENGER MESSENGER. Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills Unto the legions on the other side. Do not bid meDismiss my soldiers, or capitulateAgain with Rome's mechanics. All this I see; and I see that the fashion wears out more apparel than the man. Indeed they say the senators tomorrow Mean to establish Caesar as a king, And he shall wear his crown by sea and land In every place save here in Italy. Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have The leading of thine own revenges, takeTh' one half of my commission; and set down,--As best thou art experienc'd, since thou know'stThy country's strength and weakness,--thine own ways;Whether to knock agaI look'd for the chalky cliffs, but I could find no whiteness in them; but I guess it stood in her chin, by the salt rheum that ran between France and it. Something he left imperfect in the state, which since his coming forth is thought of, which imports to the kingdom somuch fear and danger that his personal return was most requiredand necessary. All the stor'd vengeances of heaven fall On her ingrateful top! Strike her young bones, You taking airs, with lameness! Corn. Is't possible that so short a time can alter the condition of aman?MENENIUS. Touch me not so near: I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth Than it should do offense to Michael Cassio; Yet, I persuade myself, to speak the truth Shall nothing wrong him. Of no more force to dispossess me, sir, Than was his will to get me, as I think. There is further compliment of leave-taking between Franceand him. Health to my Soueraigne, and new happinesseAdded to that, that I am to deliuer. How hast thou lost thy breath?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Good sir, say whe'r you'll answer me or no; If not, I'll leave him to the officer. Here am I left to underprop his land, Who, weak with age, cannot support myself. Then you perceiue the Body of our Kingdome,How foule it is: what ranke Diseases grow,And with what danger, neere the Heart of it? War. Now for our Consciences, the Armes is faire,When the intent for bearing them is iust. Me thinks my Moity, North from Burton here,In quantitie equals not one of yours:See, how this Riuer comes me cranking in,And cuts me from the best of all my Land,A huge halfe Moone, a monstrous Cantle out. Pleads he in earnest? Look upon his face; His eyes do drop no tears, his prayers are in jest; His words come from his mouth, ours from our breast. I have words to speak in thine ear will make thee dumb; yet are they much too light for the bore of the matter. Let me go, sir, or I'll knock you o'er the mazzard. Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that Imay be consul, I have here the customary gown. Markeis a long one, for a poore lone woman to beare: & I haueborne, and borne, and borne, and haue bin fub'd off, andfub'd-off, from this day to that day, that it is a shame tobe thought on. Giue me my Sword, and Cloake:Falstaffe, good night. How dearly would it touch thee to the quick, Should'st thou but hear I were licentious, And that this body, consecrate to thee, By ruffian lust should be contaminate! Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me, And hurl the name of husband in my face,  Go you to the city;Learn how 'tis held; and what they are that mustBe hostages for Rome. He's one honest enough; would all the rest were so![Enter MENENIUS AGRIPPA. Out you Rogue, play out the Play: I haue muchto say in the behalfe of that Falstaffe. By heauen, me thinkes it were an easie leap,To plucke bright Honor from the pale-fac'd Moone,Or diue into the bottome of the deepe,Where Fadome-line could neuer touch the ground,And plucke vp drowned Honor by the Lockes:So he that doth redeeme her thenc Both your ma jesties Might, by the sovereign power you have of us, Put your dread pleasures more into command Than to entreaty. In themeantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato's, commend me to himand tell him I will not fail him at supper; for indeed he hathmade great preparation. A jewel in a ten-times barr'd-up chest Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast. Why at our justice seem'st thou then to lour? GAUNT. Done to death by slanderous tongues Was the Hero that here lies. --Go get some water,And wash this filthy witness from your hand. Youcowardly rascal, nature disclaims in thee; a tailor made thee. What, must I come to you With five-and-twenty, Regan? Said you so? Reg. Vpon my Tongue, continuall Slanders ride,The which, in euery Language, I pronounce,Stuffing the Eares of them with false Reports:I speake of Peace, while couert Enmitie(Vnder the smile of Safety) wounds the World:And who but Rumour, who but onely IMake fFor hee is gracious, if hee be obseru'd:Hee hath a Teare for Pitie, and a HandOpen (as Day) for melting Charitie:Yet notwithstanding, being incens'd, hee's Flint,As humorous as Winter, and as sudden,As Flawes congealed in the Spring of day. You say you'll marry me, if I be willing? PHEBE. They have a leader,Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to't. There was no thought of pleasing you when she was christen'd. One of them is well knowne, my gracious Lord,a grosse fat man Car. What is the matter, masters? Honest Iago, that look'st dead with grieving, Speak: who began this? On thy love, I charge thee. Bid them wash their facesAnd keep their teeth clean. What, urge you your petitions in the street? Come to the Capitol. Where be your gibes now? your gambols? your songs? your flashes of merriment, that were wont to set the table on a roar? [Exit. How! Was it we? we lov'd him, but, like beasts,And cowardly nobles, gave way unto your clusters,Who did hoot him out o' the city. If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayest live; If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive. Grace go with you, sir! Exit [Edgar]. Why have my sisters husbands, if they say They love you all? Haply, when I shall wed, That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty. I pr'ythee now, sweet son,--as thou hast saidMy praises made thee first a soldier, so,To have my praise for this, perform a partThou hast not done before. Exeunt with a dead march. And now, good friends, As you are friends, scholars, and soldiers, Give me one poor request. A long flourish, while the KING consults his Council Draw near, And list what with our council we have done. Is Brutus sick, and is it physical To walk unbraced and suck up the humors Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed To dare the vile contagion of the night And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air To add unto hi [Aside] Drawn in the flattering table of her eye, Hang'd in the frowning wrinkle of her brow, And quarter'd in her heart-he doth espy Himself love's traitor. I am tied to th' stake, and I must stand the course. Look, whether he has not turn? his colour, and has tears in? eyes. Why, then, should I be consul? By yond clouds,Let me deserve so ill as you, and make meYour fellow tribune. Not in the legionsOf horrid hell can come a devil more damn'dIn evils to top Macbeth. But thou wouldst not think how ill all? here about my heart: but it is no matter. It seems not meet, nor wholesome to my place, To be producedas, if I stay, I shall Against the Moor; for I do know, the state, However this may gall him with some check, Cannot with safety cast him, for he's embark'd With such loud reason to the Cyprus  Sir, this young fellow's mother could; whereupon she grew round-womb'd, and had indeed, sir, a son for her cradle ereshe had a husband for her bed. He did bewray his practice, and receiv'd This hurt you see, striving to apprehend him. In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base, To come at traitors' calls, and do them grace. O my dear Gertrude, this, Like to a murdering piece, in many places Give, me superfluous death. Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing passionwithout some instruction. I did send To you for gold to pay my legions, Which you denied me. Why then couer, and set them downe: andsee if thou canst finde out Sneakes Noyse; Mistris Teare-sheetwould faine haue some Musique 2. As good as heart can wish:The King is almost wounded to the death:And in the Fortune of my Lord your Sonne,Prince Harrie slaine out-right: and both the BluntsKill'd by the hand of Dowglas. If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I'ld have thee beaten forbeing old before thy time. For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown, God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay A glorious angel. I 'gin to be a-weary of the sun,And wish the estate o' the world were now undone. Confess yourself freely to her; importune her help to put you in your place again. And what's the news, good cousin Lodovico? IAGO. However God or fortune cast my lot, There lives or dies, true to King Richard's throne, A loyal, just, and upright gentleman. There is your Crowne,And he that weares the Crowne immortally,Long guard it yours. Alas, dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours! ORLANDO. All places yield to him ere he sits down;And the nobility of Rome are his;The senators and patricians love him too:The tribunes are no soldiers; and their peopleWill be as rash in the repeal as hastyTo expel him thence. When, Harry, when? Obedience bids I should not bid again. This would have seem'd a period To such as love not sorrow; but another, To amplify too much, would make much more, And top extremity. Let him alone; He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen,The common file,--a plague!--tribunes for them!--The mouse ne'er shunned the cat as they did budgeFrom rascals worse than they. I will do so:My Lord of Westmerland leade him to his Tent West. If you will know my house, 'Tis at the tuft of olives here hard by. Hostesse, I forgiue thee:Go make ready Breakfast, loue thy Husband,Looke to thy Seruants, and cherish thy Guests:Thou shalt find me tractable to any honest reason:Thou seest, I am pacified still. How chance thou art not with the Prince, thy Brother?Hee loues thee, and thou do'st neglect him (Thomas. What is the matter, ho? Who is't that cried? IAGO. Good gentlemen, he hath much talk? of you, And sure I am two men there are not living To whom he more adheres. Weep thou for me in France, I for thee here; Better far off than near, be ne'er the near. But soft! methinks I scent the morning air; Brief let me be. I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness. I have made bold, Iago, To send in to your wife. What, To kiss in private? OTHELLO. Give me to know How this foul rout began, who set it on, And he that is approved in this offense, Though he had twinn'd with me, both at a birth, Shall lose me. Philip of France, in right and true behalf Of thy deceased brother Geffrey's son, Arthur Plantagenet, lays most lawful claim To this fair island and the territories, To Ireland, Poictiers, Anjou, Touraine, Maine, Desiring thee to lay aside the sword Whi You are jealous now That this is from some mistress, some remembrance. The devil take Henry of Lancaster and thee! Patience is stale, and I am weary of it. Hadst thou thy wits, and didst persuade revenge, It could not move thus. ExitBASTARD France, I am burn'd up with inflaming wrath, A rage whose heat hath this condition That nothing can allay, nothing but blood, The blood, and dearest-valu'd blood, of France. And, good lieutenant,I think you think I love you. Parted you in good terms? What, have you writ that letter to my sister? Osw. Thou hast it now,--king, Cawdor, Glamis, all,As the weird women promis'd; and, I fear,Thou play'dst most foully for't; yet it was saidIt should not stand in thy posterity;But that myself should be the root and fatherOf many kings. By thee; and this thou didst return from him That he did buffet thee, and in his blows Denied my house for his, me for his wife. What are you there? Come in and give some help. Thou com'st to use thy tongue; thy story quickly. Lo, citizens, he says he is content:The warlike service he has done, consider; thinkUpon the wounds his body bears, which showLike graves i' the holy churchyard. First-heaven be the record to my speech! In the devotion of a subject's love, Tend'ring the precious safety of my prince, And free from other misbegotten hate, Come I appellant to this princely presence. Dost thou not suspect my place? Dost thou not suspect my years? O that he were here to write me down an ass! But,masters, remember that I am an ass. She that's a maid now, and laughs at my departure, Shall not be a maid long, unless things be cut shorter Exeunt. Who does it, then? His madness: if ? be so, Hamlet is of the faction that is wrong?; His madness is poor Hamlet? enemy. not Charles, the Duke's wrestler, here to speak withme? DENNIS. You show'd your teeth like apes, and fawn'd like hounds, And bow'd like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet; Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind Strooke Caesar on the neck. Discharge my followers; let them hence away, From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day. Till that time Have we ramm'd up our gates against the world. : I would I had the powerTo say so to my husband. Peace be to France, if France in peace permit Our just and lineal entrance to our own! If not, bleed France, and peace ascend to heaven, Whiles we, God's wrathful agent, do correct Their proud contempt that beats His peace to heaven! KING PHILIP. My cousin tells him in his ear that he is inher heart. O worthiest cousin!The sin of my ingratitude even nowWas heavy on me: thou art so far before,That swiftest wing of recompense is slowTo overtake thee. Health to my Lord, and gentle Cousin Mowbray Mow. Ha! Mak'st thou this shame thy pastime? Kent. Was't you that did so oft contrive to kill him? OLIVER. A good Varlet, a good Varlet, a very good Varlet,Sir Iohn: I haue drunke too much Sacke at Supper. But there's no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had stabbed their mothers, they would havedone no less. Let's have a dance ere we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts and our wives'heels. What I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath. That thing you speak of, I took it for a man. He writes me here, that inward sicknesse,And that his friends by deputationCould not so soone be drawne: nor did he thinke it meet,To lay so dangerous and deare a trustOn any Soule remou'd, but on his owne. It is no matter; let no images Be hung with Caesar's trophies. I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken; for my duty cannot be silent when I think your Highness wrong'd. Macduff, this noble passion,Child of integrity, hath from my soulWiped the black scruples, reconcil'd my thoughtsTo thy good truth and honour. Enter the KING, the BISHOP OFCARLISLE,AUMERLE, and soldiers KING RICHARD. If I had a thousand Sonnes, the first PrincipleI would teach them, should be to forsweare thinne Potations,and to addict themselues to Sack. But Priam found the Fire, ere he his Tongue:And I, my Percies death, ere thou report'st it. Now is this golden crown like a deep well That owes two buckets, filling one another; The emptier ever dancing in the air, The other down, unseen, and full of water. Well, thus we play the Fooles with the time, &the spirits of the wise, sit in the clouds, and mocke vs: Isyour Master heere in London? Bard. One thus descended,That hath beside well in his person wrought To be set high in place, we did commendTo your remembrances: but you have found,Scaling his present bearing with his past,That he's your fixed enemy, and revokeYour sudden approbation. How now, Cassio! CASSIO. Will you tell me (Master Shallow) how to chusea man? Care I for the Limbe, the Thewes, the stature,bulke, and bigge assemblance of a man? giue mee thespirit (Master Shallow. Sweet Princes: what I did, I did in Honor,Led by th' Imperiall Conduct of my Soule,And neuer shall you see, that I will beggeA ragged, and fore-stall'd Remission. You are the hare of whom the proverb goes, Whose valour plucks dead lions by the beard; I'll smoke your skin-coat an I catch you right; Sirrah, look to 't; i' faith I will, i' faith. [Enter the King, Queen, Hamlet, Polonius, Laertes, Voltimand, Cornelius, Lords, and Attendant. So let the Turk of Cyprus us beguile; We lose it not so long as we can smile. You, you, sirrah, where's my daughter? Osw. Glendower speakes to her in Welsh, and she answeres him in thesame. For me, by Heauen (I bid you be assur'd)Ile be your Father, and your Brother too:Let me but beare your Loue, Ile beare your Cares;But weepe that Harrie's dead, and so will I. ' When I did hear The motley fool thus moral on the time, My lungs began to crow like chanticleer That fools should be so deep contemplative; And I did laugh sans intermission An hour by his dial. I will in Cassio's lodging lose this napkin, And let him find it. [Enter a Doctor of Physic and a Waiting-Gentlewoman. Rob me the Exchequer the first thing thou do'st,and do it with vnwash'd hands too Bard. They say he is already in the Forest of Arden, and amany merry men with him; and there they live like the old RobinHood of England. Signior Andpholus, I wonder much That you would put me to this shame and trouble; And, not without some scandal to yourself, With circumstance and oaths so to deny This chain, which now you wear so openly. The heat is past, follow no farther now:Call in the Powers, good Cousin Westmerland. I came hither to tell you, and, circumstances short'ned(for she has been too long a-talking of), the lady is disloyal. [To AUMERLE] Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead meforth Of that sweet way I was in to despair! What say you now? What comfort have we now? By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly That bids me be of comfort any more. I will discharge vpon her (Sir Iohn) with twoBullets Falst. If that her breath will mist or stain the stone, Why, then she lives. Lo, as at English feasts, so I regreet The daintiest last, to make the end most sweet. If it be so, as fast as she answersthee with frowning looks, I'll sauce her with bitter words. Besides, I say and will in battle prove Or here, or elsewhere to the furthest verge That ever was survey'd by English eye That all the treasons for these eighteen years Complotted and contrived in this land Fetch from false Mowbray their first head and  By th' law of arms thou wast not bound to answer An unknown opposite. Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me, I'll knock elsewhere, to see if they'll disdain me. Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not? SOOTHSAYER. Get you to bed on the instant; I will be returned forthwith. Let's present him to the Duke, like a Roman conqueror;and it would do well to set the deer's horns upon his head for a branch of victory. Myself the crying fellow did pursue, Lest by his clamoras it so fell out The town might fall in fright. For Sir, at Shrewsbury,As I am truly giuen to vnderstand,The King, with mightie and quick-raysed Power,Meetes with Lord Harry: and I feare, Sir Michell,What with the sicknesse of Northumberland,Whose Power was in the first proportion;And what with Owen  Nay, my good soldier, up;My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, andBy deed-achieving honour newly nam'd,--What is it?--Coriolanus must I call thee?But, O, thy wife!CORIOLANUS. A noble temper dost thou show in this; And great affections wrestling in thy bosom Doth make an earthquake of nobility. O, I should haue a heauy misse of thee,If I were much in loue with Vanity. He's fall'n in love with your foulness, and she'llfall in love with my anger. For thou dost know, O Damon dear, This realm dismantled was Of Jove himself; and now reigns here A very, very?a jock. O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain, Young man, thou couldst not die more honorable. So help me every spirit sanctified, As I have spoken for you all my best And stood within the blank of his displeasure For my free speech! You must awhile be patient. The Prince and Claudio promis'd by this hour To visit me. It is the very error of the moon; She comes more nearer earth than she was wont And makes men mad. If thou deniest it twenty times, thou liest; And I will turn thy falsehood to thy heart, Where it was forged, with my rapier's point. Yet, though I distrust, Discomfort you, my lord, it nothing must: For women? fear and love holds quantity;88 In neither aught, or in extremity. Let me see; what think you of falling in love? CELIA. The noble Brutus Hath told you Caesar was ambitious; If it were so, it was a grievous fault, And grievously hath Caesar answer'd it. [aside] My tears begin to take his part so much They'll mar my counterfeiting. The Duke and all that know me in the city Can witness with me that it is not so: I ne'er saw Syracuse in my life. I will catechize the world for him; that is, makequestions and by them answer. My Selfe, and you Sonne Harry will towards Wales,To fight with Glendower, and the Earle of March. Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home? Osw. His bark is stoutly timber'd, and his pilot Of very expert and approved allowance; Therefore my hopes, not surfeited to death, Stand in bold cure. This morning are they fled away and gone, And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us, As we were sickly prey. Ay, marry, now my soul hath elbow-room; It would not out at windows nor at doors. Yes, my good lord, It doth contain a king; King Richard lies Within the limits of yon lime and stone; And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury, Sir Stephen Scroop, besides a clergyman Of holy reverence; who, I cannot learn. It were a tedious difficulty, I think, To bring them to that prospect. It is a wonderfullthing to see the semblable Coherence of his mens spirits,and his: They, by obseruing of him, do beare themselueslike foolish Iustices: Hee, by conuersing with them, isturn'd into a Iustice-like Seruingman. We are all undone unlessThe noble man have mercy. Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece, Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia, And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus; Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought Or that or any place that harbours men. Re-enter attendant with glass Give me that glass, and therein will I read. O unhappy youth! Come not within these doors; within this roof The enemy of all your graces lives. Neuer, O neuer doe his Ghost the wrong,To hold your Honor more precise and niceWith others, then with him. Why dost not speak?Think'st thou it honourable for a noble manStill to remember wrongs?--Daughter, speak you:He cares not for your weeping. Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes to getmyself into more work. Let him go up into the public chair; We'll hear him. Still it cried, "Sleep no more!" to all the house:"Glamis hath murder'd sleep, and therefore CawdorShall sleep no more,--Macbeth shall sleep no more!"LADY MACBETH. Therefore I'll watch himTill he be dieted to my request,And then I'll set upon him. Go but apart, Make choice of whom your wisest friends you will, And they shall hear and judge ?wixt you and me. Wash your hands, put on your nightgown; look not sopale:--I tell you yet again, Banquo's buried; he cannot comeout on's grave. Enter Gloucester, brought in by two or three. Saving your merry humour, here's the note How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion, Which doth amount to three odd ducats more Than I stand debted to this gentleman. Vse his men well Dauy, for they are arrantKnaues, and will backe-bite Dauy. Fears and scruples shake us:In the great hand of God I stand; and thence,Against the undivulg'd pretense I fightOf treasonous malice. Last scene of all, That ends this strange eventful history, Is second childishness and mere oblivion; Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans every thing. When wee with-drew (my Liege) wee left itheere King. She says enough; yet she's a simple bawd That cannot say as much. No boasting like a fool;This deed I'll do before this purpose cool:But no more sights!--Where are these gentlemen?Come, bring me where they are. Tell him this tale, and from the mouth of England Add thus much more, that no Italian priest Shall tithe or toll in our dominions; But as we under heaven are supreme head, So, under Him that great supremacy, Where we do reign we will alone uphold, Witho To both these sisters have I sworn my love; Each jealous of the other, as the stung Are of the adder. The Arch-Deacon hath diuided itInto three Limits, very equally:England, from Trent, and Seuerne. Marry, he must have a long spoon that must eat with the devil. There's neuer any of these demure Boyes cometo any proofe: for thinne Drinke doth so ouer-cooletheir blood, and making many Fish-Meales, that theyfall into a kinde of Male Greene-sicknesse: and then,when they marry, they get Wenches. ' Are not you The owner of the house I did inquire for? CELIA. Do but start And echo with the clamour of thy drum, And even at hand a drum is ready brac'd That shall reverberate all as loud as thine: Sound but another, and another shall, As loud as thine, rattle the welkin's ear And mock the deep-mouth'd thunder; f Follow, Cominius; we must follow you;Right worthy your priority. Well, ruffian, I must pocket up these wrongs, Because BASTARD. Poor men alone? No, no; thenoblest deer hath them as huge as the rascal. Come, woo me, woo me; for now I am in a holidayhumour, and like enough to consent. Then shall he mourn (If ever love had interest in his liver) And wish he had not so accused her- No, though be thought his accusation true. To your professed bosoms I commit him; But yet, alas, stood I within his grace, I would prefer him to a better place! So farewell to you both. Falstaffe? fast asleepe behinde the Arras, andsnorting like a Horse Prince. And when we have our naked frailties hid,That suffer in exposure, let us meet,And question this most bloody piece of workTo know it further. [To SILVIUS] As you love Phebe, meet;and asI love no woman, I'll meet. So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet. [Enter Duncan, Malcolm, Donalbain, Banquo, Lennox, Macduff, Ross,Angus, and Attendants. 'Twas time to counterfet, or that hotte Termagant Scot,had paid me scot and lot too. If she lives till doomsday, she'll burn week longer than the whole world. I would he had continu'd to his countryAs he began, and not unknit himselfThe noble knot he made. --Tell me not Wherein I seem unnatural: desire notTo allay my rages and revenges withYour colder reasons. My lords of England, let me tell you this: I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs, And labour'd all I could to do him right; But in this kind to come, in braving arms, Be his own carver and cut out his way, To find out right with wrong-it may not be;  Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter--anold man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, I would desire they were; but, in faith, honest as the skin betweenhis brows. I here take my oathbefore this honourable assembly, she kicked the poor King herfather. And when she speaks, is it not an alarum to love? CASSIO. But I doubt they will be too hard for vs Poin. Hold, sir, for God's sake! Now your jest isearnest. We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar, And in the spirit of men there is no blood. Farewell, my lord, securely I espy Virtue with valour couched in thine eye. When she shall hear this of thee, with her nails She'll flay thy wolvish visage. O heavens!that this treason were notor not I the detector! Corn. Antipholus, thou cam'st from Corinth first?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little thief of occasionwill rob you of a great deal of patience: give your dispositionsthe reins, and be angry at your pleasures; at the least, if youtake it as a pleasure to you in being so. Say that I linger'd with you at your shop To see the making of her carcanet, And that to-morrow you will bring it home. You promis'd, when you parted with the King, To lay aside life-harming heaviness And entertain a cheerful disposition. Slanders, sir: for the satirical slave says here that old men have grey beards; that their faces are wrinkled; their eyes purging thick amber and plum-tree gum; and that they have a plentiful lack of wit, together with most weak hams: all which, sir, th Virtue? a fig! 'Tis in ourselves that we are thus orthus. Ay, and brought off the field: your cause of sorrowMust not be measur'd by his worth, for thenIt hath no end. To whom, my lord? with whom? how am I false? OTHELLO. Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions? Lear. Fair cousin! I am greater than a king; For when I was a king, my flatterers Were then but subjects; being now a subject, I have a king here to my flatterer. Some of your function, mistress, Leave procreants alone and shut the door; Cough, or cry "hem," if anybody come. These foils have all a length? [They prepare to play. Good faith, this same young sober-bloodedBoy doth not loue me, nor a man cannotmake him laugh: but that's no maruaile, hee drinkes noWine. [to Edmund] Let the drum strike, and prove my title thine. Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor soold to dote on her for anything. Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, asyou would have it appear he is. Indeed, there is Fortune too hard for Nature, when Fortune makes Nature's natural the cutter-off of Nature'swit. But fare thee well; thou art a gallant youth; I would thou hadst told me of another father. These injuries the King now bears will berevenged home; there's part of a power already footed; we mustincline to the King. What in your own part can you say to this? BRABANTIO. To do that office of thine own good will Which tired majesty did make thee offer The resignation of thy state and crown To Henry Bolingbroke. We did, my lord, weeping and commenting Upon the sobbing deer. These differences shall all rest under gage Till Norfolk be repeal'd-repeal'd he shall be And, though mine enemy, restor'd again To all his lands and signories. I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buriedthy eyes; and moreover, I will go with thee to thy uncle's. My mother: father and mother is man and wife; man and wife is one flesh; and so, my mother. Alack the heavy day, That I have worn so many winters out, And know not now what name to call myself! O that I were a mockery king of snow, Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke To melt myself away in water drops! Good king, great king, and yet not gre I'll write straight to my sister To hold my very course. My owne Knee? When I was about thy yeeres(Hal) I was not an Eagles Talent in the Waste, I couldhaue crept into any Aldermans Thumbe-Ring: a plagueof sighing and griefe, it blowes a man vp like a Bladder. If he be absent, bring his brother to me; I'll make him find him. Ha, you shallsee now in very sincerity of Feare and Cold heart, will heto the King, and lay open all our proceedings. Now, you companion, I'll say an errand for you; you shall knownow that I am in estimation; you shall perceive that a jackguardant cannot office me from my son Coriolanus: guess but by myentertainment with him if thou standest not i' the state ofhanging, Cousin, I thinke thou art enamoredOn his Follies: neuer did I heareOf any Prince so wilde at Liberty. I am not merry, but I do beguile The thing I am by seeming otherwise. I do not know the matter; he is rested on thecase. Provoke him, that he may; for even out of that will I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qualificationshall come into no true taste again but by the displanting ofCassio. A strange beginning'borrowed majesty'! KING JOHN. Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I call'd thee? Beat. Cassio confess'd it, And she did gratify his amorous works With that recognizance and pledge of love Which I first gave her. His life was gentle, and the elements So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, "This was a man!" OCTAVIUS. Touching this vision here,?It is an honest ghost, that let me tell you: For your desire to know what is between us, O?rmaster? as you may. Your voice shall be as strong as any man's In the disposing of new dignities. If the Prince put thee into my Seruicefor any other reason, then to set mee off, why then Ihaue no iudgement. O God, counterfeit? There was never counterfeit ofpassion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it. Enter Caesar, Brutus, Cassius, Casca, Decius, Metellus,Trebonius, Cinna, Antony, Lepidus, Popilius, Publius, and others. Ere we were two days old at sea, a pirate of very warlike appointment gave us chase. Trumpets, speak! Alarums. I'll give you a verse to this note that I madeyesterday in despite of my invention. Speak you so gently? Pardon me, I pray you; I thought that all things had been savage here, And therefore put I on the countenance Of stern commandment. None of these rogues and cowards But Ajax is their fool. Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing, quarrelling, Drabbing:?ou may go so far. There roar'd the Sea: and Trumpet Clangoursounds. Giue me a Cupof Sack, I am a Rogue if I drunke to day Prin. I know thee well enough; thy name is Gloucester. All things that you should use to do me wrong Deny their office; only you do lack That mercy which fierce fire and iron extends, Creatures of note for mercy-lacking uses. Now, good Aufidius,Were you in my stead, would you have heardA mother less? or granted less, Aufidius?AUFIDIUS. Adam |Carson |Aimee|Echo|Alan|Moore|Albert|Schweitzer|Albert|Einstein|Alec|Baldwin|Alexandra|Paul|Alice|Walker|Alicia|Silverstone|Alison |Lohman |Ally|Sheedy|Alyssa|Milano|Amber|Valletta|Amber |Benson|Amy|Ray|Anastasia|Ashley|Andre |3000|Andreas|Cahling|Croak not, black angel; I have no food for thee. My strange and self-abuseIs the initiate fear that wants hard use:--We are yet but young in deed. Hubert, away with him; imprison him; And on that day at noon whereon he says I shall yield up my crown let him be hang'd. Know, good mother,I had rather be their servant in my wayThan sway with them in theirs. If any wretch have put this in your head, Let heaven requite it with the serpent's curse! For if she be not honest, chaste, and true, There's no man happy; the purest of their wives Is foul as slander. Merciful heaven!--What, man! ne'er pull your hat upon your brows;Give sorrow words: the grief that does not speakWhispers the o'er-fraught heart, and bids it break. I'll have the work ta'en out, And give't Iago. Yet you mustbe saying, Marcius is proud; who, in a cheap estimation, is worthall your predecessors since Deucalion; though peradventure someof the best of 'em were hereditary hangmen. To approue my youthfarther, I will not: the truth is, I am onely olde in iudgementand vnderstanding: and he that will caper with meefor a thousand Markes, let him lend me the mony, & haueat him. [within] Fathom and half, fathom and half! Prin. Things past redress are now with me past care. Nay, it perchance will sparkle in your eyes, And, like a dog that is compell'd to fight, Snatch at his master that doth tarre him on. Grandam, I will pray, If ever I remember to be holy, For your fair safety. But he, sir, had the election; And I, of whom his eyes had seen the proof At Rhodes, at Cyprus, and on other grounds Christian and heathen, must be belee'd and calm'd By debitor and creditor. By all the gods that Romans bow before, I here discard my sickness! Soul of Rome! Brave son, derived from honorable loins! Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up My mortified spirit. That young swain that you saw here but erewhile, That little cares for buying any thing. Dost thou think I care for asatire or an epigram? No. Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders Prepare to lodge their companies tonight. Kind uncle York, the latest news we hear Is that the rebels have consum'd with fire Our town of Ciceter in Gloucestershire; But whether they be ta'en or slain we hear not. I dare not confess that, lest I should compare with him in excellence; but to know a man well were to know himself. Is not tomorrow, boy, the ides of March? LUCIUS. I wish your horses swift and sure of foot;And so I do commend you to their backs. We hear our bloody cousins are bestow'dIn England and in Ireland; not confessingTheir cruel parricide, filling their hearersWith strange invention: but of that to-morrow;When therewithal we shall have cause of stateCraving us jointly. Briefely to this end: Wee are all diseas'd,And with our surfetting, and wanton howres,Haue brought our selues into a burning Feuer,And wee must bleede for it: of which Disease,Our late King Richard (being infected) dy'd. Since when, I pray you, Sir? what, with two Points onyour shoulder? much Pist. For ever will I walk upon my knees, And never see day that the happy sees Till thou give joy; until thou bid me joy By pardoning Rutland, my transgressing boy. I am a Rogue, if I were not at halfe Sword witha dozen of them two houres together. I would you would accept of Grace and Loue Hotsp. Doubt not my Lord, he shall be well oppos'd Arch. I cannot say your worships havedelivered the matter well when I find the ass in compound withthe major part of your syllables; and though I must be content tobear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they liedeadly that tell you have good An if I have not, sir, I hope you have; Or else you may return without your money. Away! The tribunes do attend you: arm yourselfTo answer mildly; for they are prepar'dWith accusations, as I hear, more strongThan are upon you yet. Why hopest thou so? 'Tis better hope he is; For his designs crave haste, his haste good hope. The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up Safe at the Centaur, and the heedful slave Is wand'red forth in care to seek me out. My parts, my title, and my perfect soul Shall manifest me rightly. This prophecy Merlin shall make, for I live before his time. James Gurney, wilt thou give us leave awhile? GURNEY. Let us do so, for we are at the stake, And bay'd about with many enemies; And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear, Millions of mischiefs. And, speaking it, he wishtly look'd on me, As who should say 'I would thou wert the man That would divorce this terror from my heart'; Meaning the King at Pomfret. Letters from him?Why comes he not himselfe? Mes. She that so young could give out such a seeming, To seel her father's eyes up close as oak He thought 'twas witchcraftbut I am much to blame; I humbly do beseech you of your pardon For too much loving you. Some of vs loue you well: and euen those someEnuie your great deseruings, and good name,Because you are not of our qualitie,But stand against vs like an Enemie Blunt. Wherefore? For my dinner; I have not din'd to-day. There's millions now alive That nightly lie in those unproper beds Which they dare swear peculiar. His purse is empty already; all? golden words are spent. I have known when there was no music withhim but the drum and the fife; and now had he rather hear thetabor and the pipe. He found it then; I never gave it him. Who, then, shall blameHis pester'd senses to recoil and start,When all that is within him does condemnItself for being there?CAITHNESS. I thank you, sir Exit [Gentleman]. I can call Spirits from the vastie Deepe Hotsp. Faith, and so wee should,Where now remaines a sweet reuersion. Why, how could'st thou know these men inKendall Greene, when it was so darke, thou could'st notsee thy Hand? Why, say they are vile and false; As where's that palace whereinto foul things Sometimes intrude not? Who has a breast so pure, But some uncleanly apprehensions Keep leets and law-days, and in session sit With meditations lawful? OTHE That you do love me, I am nothing jealous; What you would work me to, I have some aim. Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires; Men so disorder'd, so debosh'd, and bold That this our court, infected with their manners, Shows like a riotous inn. O Richard!
