Bene. Acquaintmy daughter no further with anything you know than comes fromher demand out of the letter. I think he be transform'd into a beast; For I can nowhere find him like a man. Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of beauty. For my part, I have walk'd about the streets, Submitting me unto the perilous night, And thus unbraced, Casca, as you see, Have bared my bosom to the thunderstone; And when the cross blue lightning seem'd to open The breast of heaven, I did present myse Hark, how these instruments summon to supper! The messengers of Venice stay the meat. Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot; Right noble is thy merit, well I wot. The Duke does greet you, general, And he requires your haste-post-haste appearance, Even on the instant. All the world's a stage, And all the men and women merely players; They have their exits and their entrances; And one man in his time plays many parts, His acts being seven ages. You are too great, to be (by me) gainsaid:Your Spirit is too true, your Feares too certaine North. Too much of water hast thou, poor Ophelia, And therefore I forbid my tears: but yet It is our trick; nature her custom holds, Let shame say what it will: when these are gone, The woman will be out. Enter NORTHUMBERLAND attended NORTHUMBERLAND. All friends shall taste The wages of their virtue, and all foes The cup of their deservings. And, madam, there is order ta'en for you: With all swift speed you must away to France. The Forest of ArdenEnter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or three LORDS, like foresters DUKE SENIOR. My lord, his ma jesty commended him to you by young Osric, who brings back to him that you attend him in the hall: he sends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will take longer time. Art thou not, fatal vision, sensibleTo feeling as to sight? or art thou butA dagger of the mind, a false creation,Proceeding from the heat-oppressed brain?I see thee yet, in form as palpableAs this which now I draw. It is my son, young Harry Percy, Sent from my brother Worcester, whencesoever. How easy dost thou take all England up! From forth this morsel of dead royalty The life, the right, and truth of all this realm Is fled to heaven; and England now is left To tug and scamble, and to part by th' teeth The unowed interest of proud-swelling Call me a fool; Trust not my reading nor my observation, Which with experimental seal doth warrant The tenure of my book; trust not my age, My reverence, calling, nor divinity, If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here Under some biting error. [Exeunt Don Pedro and Claudio. Look here upon thy brother Geffrey's face: These eyes, these brows, were moulded out of his; This little abstract doth contain that large Which died in Geffrey, and the hand of time Shall draw this brief into as huge a volume. My life upon her faith! Honest Iago, My Desdemona must I leave to thee. Very well! go to! I cannot go to, man; nor 'tis notvery well. Yet, I beseech you, If you think fit, or that it may be done, Give me advantage of some brief discourse With Desdemona alone. Besides, to be demanded of a sponge!?hat replication should be made by the son of a king? Ros. ) Come,giue me some Sack, Si fortune me tormente, sperato me contente. Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her. I know not whether Heauen will haue it so,For some displeasing seruice I haue done;That in his secret Doome, out of my Blood,Hee'le breede Reuengement, and a Scourge for me:But thou do'st in thy passages of Life,Make me beleeue, that thou art onely mark'If there be more, more woful, hold it in; For I am almost ready to dissolve, Hearing of this. Stand thee close then under this penthouse, for itdrizzles rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee. A traveller! By my faith, you have great reason to be sad. Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered yourletter. Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear In the rare semblance that I lov'd it first. Break not your sleeps for that:?ou must not think That we are made of stuff so flat and dull That we can let our beard be shook with danger, And think it pastime. <ExeuntSCENE 3The martEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSEANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Mary, beshrew my hand If it should give your age such cause of fear. Whether hadst thou rather be a Faulconbridge, And like thy brother, to enjoy thy land, Or the reputed son of Coeur-de-lion, Lord of thy presence and no land beside? BASTARD. Then your hose should be ungarter'd, your bonnet unbanded,your sleeve unbutton'd, your shoe untied, and every thing aboutyou demonstrating a careless desolation. He had no Legges, that practic'd not his Gate:And speaking thicke (which Nature made his blemish)Became the Accents of the Valiant. If I were mad I should forget my son, Or madly think a babe of clouts were he. Another word, Menenius,I will not hear thee speak. O curse of marriage, That we can call these delicate creatures ours, And not their appetites! I had rather be a toad, And live upon the vapor of a dungeon, Than keep a corner in the thing I love For others' uses. Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face? BRUTUS. Question: why, an hour in clamour and a quarter in rheum. The princes, France and Burgundy, Great rivals in our youngest daughter's love, Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn, And here are to be answer'd. What, courage, man! What though care kill'd a cat, thouhast mettle enough in thee to kill care. Or of a courtier, which could say ?ood morrow, sweet lord! How dost thou, good lord??This might be my lord such-a-one, that praised my lord such-a-one? horse when he meant to beg it,?ight it not? Hor. Feare you not, that if wee can make our PeaceVpon such large termes, and so absolute,As our Conditions shall consist vpon,Our Peace shall stand as firme as Rockie Mountaines Mow. Yea, or the Drone of a Lincolnshire Bagpipe Prin. I fear I wrong the honorable men Whose daggers have stabb'd Caesar; I do fear it. I conjure you, by that which you profess,--Howe'er you come to know it,--answer me:Though you untie the winds, and let them fightAgainst the churches; though the yesty wavesConfound and swallow navigation up;Though bladed corn be lodg'd, and trees blown O, how it ern'd my heart, when I beheld, In London streets, that coronation-day, When Bolingbroke rode on roan Barbary That horse that thou so often hast bestrid, That horse that I so carefully have dress'd! KING RICHARD. Enter Lodovico, Desdemona, and Attendants. You doe not counsaile well:You speake it out of feare, and cold heart Vern. Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine Worth seizure do we seize into our hands, Till thou canst quit thee by thy brother's mouth Of what we think against thee. For my brother,I think he holds you well and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage--surely suit ill spent andlabour ill bestowed! Pedro. What are you here that cry so grievously? CASSIO. Thy wish was Father (Harry) to that thought:I stay too long by thee, I wearie thee. Enter the BASTARD and PETER OF POMFRET Now! What says the world To your proceedings? Do not seek to stuff My head with more ill news, for it is fun. I would have daff'd all other respects and made her half myself. I could be well moved, if I were as you; If I could pray to move, prayers would move me; But I am constant as the northern star, Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality There is no fellow in the firmament. My friend is dead, 'tis done at your request; But let her live. Why, man, they did make love to this employment; They are not near my conscience; their defeat Does by their own insinuation grow: ?is dangerous when the baser nature comes Between the pass and fell incensed points Of mighty opposites. You must think, if we give you anything, we hope to gain by you. Publius, good cheer, There is no harm intended to your person, Nor to no Roman else. Marry, I prithee, do, to make sport withal; but love noman in good earnest, nor no further in sport neither than withsafety of a pure blush thou mayst in honour come off again. There is nothing done, ifhe return the conqueror. Exeunt Othello andDesdemona. I will drain him dry as hay:Sleep shall neither night nor dayHang upon his pent-house lid;He shall live a man forbid:Weary seven-nights nine times nineShall he dwindle, peak, and pine:Though his bark cannot be lost,Yet it shall be tempest-tost. Enter a Herald with a proclamation; people following. She's like a liar gone to burning hell; 'Twas I that kill'd her. You speak o' the peopleAs if you were a god, to punish, notA man of their infirmity. 'I took no more pains forthose thanks than you took pains to thank me. Your voices: for your voices I have fought;Watch'd for your voices; for your voices bearOf wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice sixI have seen and heard of; for your voices haveDone many things, some less, some more: your voices: Indeed, I would be cons Thou wilt not? thouwilt not? Do, do thou Rogue: Do thou Hempseed Page. May these same instruments which you profaneNever sound more! When drums and trumpets shallI' the field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be Made all of false-fac'd soothing. Who knowes, on whom Fortune would then haue smil'd?But if your Father had beene Victor there,Hee ne're had borne it out of Couentry. You shall not in your funeral speech blame us, But speak all good you can devise of Caesar, And say you do't by our permission, Else shall you not have any hand at all About his funeral. What's the news in Rome? I have anote from the Volscian state, to find you out there; you havewell saved me a day's journey. Come you thinne Thing:Come you Rascall Off. I can speake English, Lord, as well as you:For I was trayn'd vp in the English Court;Where, being but young, I framed to the HarpeMany an English Dittie, louely well,And gaue the Tongue a helpefull Ornament;A Vertue that was neuer seene in you Hotsp. This istrue, on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us. There's not a man I meet but doth saluteme As if I were their well-acquainted friend; And every one doth call me by my name. Thus hath he sworn, And I with him, and many moe with me, Upon the altar at Saint Edmundsbury; Even on that altar where we swore to you Dear amity and everlasting love. The Second Part of Henry the Fourth, Containing hisDeath: andthe Coronation of King Henry the Fift. He's worth more sorrow,And that I'll spend for him. Have I, my lord? Assure you, my good liege, I hold my duty, as I hold my soul, Both to my God and to my gracious king: And I do think,?r else this brain of mine Hunts not the trail of policy so sure As it hath us? to do,?hat I have found The very cause  There is division betwixt theDukes, and a worse matter than that. 'Gainst nature still:Thriftless ambition, that wilt ravin upThine own life's means!--Then 'tis most like,The sovereignty will fall upon Macbeth. Sit, Coriolanus; never shame to hearWhat you have nobly done. Haste me to know?, that I, with wings as swift As meditation or the thoughts of love, May sweep to my revenge. May they perceive's intent! He will require themAs if he did contemn what he requestedShould be in them to give. I neuer dealt better since I was a man: all would not doe. Alas, how fiery and how sharp he looks!COURTEZAN. Now, what my love is, proof hath made you know; And as my love is siz?, my fear is so: Where love is great, the littlest doubts are fear; Where little fears grow great, great love grows there. The one of them imports The death of Cassio to be undertook By Roderigo. I marvel why I answer'd not again; But that's all one: omittance is no quittance. And when I liv'd I was your other wife; [Unmasks. Nor I neither by this heavenly light; I might do't aswell i' the dark. Nay, good lieutenant; I pray you, sir, hold your hand. Must you with hot irons burn out both mine eyes? HUBERT. If she be a traitor, Why so am I: we still have slept together, Rose at an instant, learn'd, play'd, eat together; And wheresoe'er we went, like Juno's swans, Still we went coupled and inseparable. My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk'd, And more convenient is he for my hand Than for your lady's. This Doll Teare-sheet should be some Rode Poin. Say, wherefore didst thou lock me forthto-day? And why dost thou deny the bag of gold?ADRIANA. Fie on thee, wretch! 'tis pity that thou liv'st To walk where any honest men resort. Benedictus? why benedictus? You have some moral in this 'benedictus. O, full of careful business are his looks! Uncle, for God's sake, speak comfortable words. He is drown'd in the brook; look but in, and you shallsee him. This counter-caster, He, in good time, must his lieutenant be, And IGod bless the mark!his Moorship's ancient. What! in a town of war, Yet wild, the people's hearts brimful of fear, To manage private and domestic quarrel, In night, and on the court and guard of safety! 'Tis monstrous. She that I spake of, our great captain's captain, Left in the conduct of the bold Iago, Whose footing here anticipates our thoughts A se'nnight's speed. Good my lord! [Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. --Toad, that under cold stone,Days and nights has thirty-oneSwelter'd venom sleeping got,Boil thou first i' the charmed pot!ALL. I would not hear your enemy say so; Nor shall you do my ear that violence, To make it truster of your own report Against yourself: I know you are no truant. His weary joints would gladly rise, I know; Our knees still kneel till to the ground they grow. And thou followd'st him like a Church: thouwhorson little tydie Bartholmew Bore-pigge, when wiltthou leaue fighting on dayes, and foyning on nights, andbegin to patch vp thine old Body for Heauen?Enter the Prince and Poines disguis'd. Enter the BASTARD with AUSTRIA'S head BASTARD. Why thou Globe of sinfull Continents, whata life do'st thou lead? Fal. ' We that are true lovers run into strangecapers; but as all is mortal in nature, so is all nature in lovemortal in folly. Hast any philosophyin thee, shepherd? CORIN. If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue ofyour office, to be no true man; and for such kind of men, the lessyou meddle or make with them, why, the more your honesty. I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no suchmatter. So shall I liue, to speake my Fathers words:Happy am I, that haue a man so bold,That dares do Iustice, on my proper Sonne;And no lesse happy, hauing such a Sonne,That would deliuer vp his Greatnesse so,Into the hands of Iustice. I thank you for your company; but, good faith, I had as lief have been myself alone. If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty business in hand. The French, my lord; men's mouths are full of it; Besides, I met Lord Bigot and Lord Salisbury, With eyes as red as new-enkindled fire, And others more, going to seek the grave Of Arthur, whom they say is kill'd to-night On your suggestion. Marry, God forbid! Worst in this royal presence may I speak, Yet best beseeming me to speak the truth. Sir, praise me not;My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well;The blood I drop is rather physicalThan dangerous to me: to Aufidius thusI will appear, and fight. O, giue me alwayesa little, leane, old, chopt, bald Shot. It ill beseems this presence to cry aim To these ill-tuned repetitions. A strange one as ever I looked on: I cannot get himout o' the house. You know since Pentecost the sum is due, And since I have not much importun'd you; Nor now I had not, but that I am bound To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage. Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house, I will discharge my bond, and thank you too. So he doth you, my Lord, and sayde this otherday, You ought him a thousand pound Prince. Is not this true? Enter Roderigo. Thou hast never in thy lifeShow'd thy dear mother any courtesy;When she,--poor hen,--fond of no second brood,Has cluck'd thee to the wars, and safely home,Loaden with honour. And how, Audrey, am I the man yet? Doth my simplefeature content you? AUDREY. Ten masts at each make not the altitude Which thou hast perpendicularly fell. Fare thee well at once! The glowworm shows the matin to be near, And ?ins to pale his uneffectual fire: Adieu, adieu! Hamlet, remember me. I have of late,?ut wherefore I know not,?ost all my mirth, forgone all custom of exercises; and indeed, it goes so heavily with my disposition that this goodly frame, the earth, seems to me a sterile promontory; this most excellent canopy, the air, look O, me alone! Make you a sword of me?If these shows be not outward, which of youBut is four Volsces? none of you but isAble to bear against the great AufidiusA shield as hard as his. This England never did, nor never shall, Lie at the proud foot of a conqueror, But when it first did help to wound itself. Briefness and fortune, work! Brother, a word! Descend! Brother, I say! Enter Edgar. Two nights together had these gentlemen, Marcellus and Bernardo, on their watch In the dead vast and middle of the night, Been thus encounter?. Go to: I stand the push of your one thing, thatyou'l tell Prin. Forever and forever farewell, Brutus! If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed; If not, 'tis true this parting was well made. Must he be depos'd? The King shall be contented. O heauen, they did me too much iniury,That euer said I hearkned to your death. But now the blood of twenty thousand men Did triumph in my face, and they are fled; And, till so much blood thither come again, Have I not reason to look pale and dead? All souls that will be safe, fly from my side; For time hath set a blot upon my prid Orlando, my liege; the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys. My plenteous joys,Wanton in fulness, seek to hide themselvesIn drops of sorrow. Mine eyes do itch; Doth that bode weeping? EMILIA. These often bathed she in her fluxive eyes, And often kissed, and often 'gan to tear; Cried, 'O false blood, thou register of lies, What unapproved witness dost thou bear! Ink would have seemed more black and damned here! This said, in top of rage the l I could well wish courtesy would invent someother custom of entertainment. Meantime but ask What you would have reform'd that is not well, And well shall you perceive how willingly I will both hear and grant you your requests. My lord, Before I freely speak my mind herein, You shall not only take the sacrament To bury mine intents, but also to effect Whatever I shall happen to devise. If heart's presages be not vain, We three here part that ne'er shall meet again. Oh my most worshipfull Lord, and't please yourGrace, I am a poore widdow of Eastcheap, and he is arrestedat my suit Ch. Revenges burn in them; for their dear causesWould to the bleeding and the grim alarmExcite the mortified man. Alas, alas, put vp your naked Weapons,put vp your naked Weapons Dol. By Jupiter, forgot:--I am weary; yea, my memory is tir'd. Pray be counsell'd;I have a heart as little apt as yours,But yet a brain that leads my use of angerTo better vantage. So, fare you well at once, for Brutus' tongue Hath almost ended his life's history. YOU are deceiv'd, sir; we kept time, we lost notour time. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bay'd, brave hart, Here didst thou fall, and here thy hunters stand, Sign'd in thy spoil, and crimson'd in thy Lethe. Are these things then Necessities?Then let vs meete them like Necessities;And that same word, euen now cryes out on vs:They say, the Bishop and NorthumberlandAre fiftie thousand strong War. The sight is dismal; And our affairs from England come too late: The ears are senseless that should give us hearing, To tell him his commandment is fulfill? That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead: Where should we have our thanks? Hor. But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born, And hath been tutor'd in the rudiments Of many desperate studies by his uncle, Whom he reports to be a great magician, Obscured in the circle of this forest. Thanks, sir: the like to you![Exeunt Banquo and Fleance. Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turn'd down Where I left reading? Here it is, I think. I will neuer beare a base minde: if it be my destinie,so: if it be not, so: no man is too good to serue hisPrince: and let it goe which way it will, he that dies thisyeere, is quit for the next Bard. The copy of your speed is learn'd by them, For when you should be told they do prepare, The tidings comes that they are all arriv'd. You should ask me what time o' day; there's no clockin the forest. Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the eels whenshe put 'em i' th' paste alive. Now hear our English King; For thus his royalty doth speak in me. I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure I count myself in nothing else so happy As in a soul rememb'ring my good friends; And as my fortune ripens with thy love, It shall be still thy true love's recompense. I hate the Moor, And it is thought abroad that 'twixt my sheets He has done my office. No; bear it with you, lest I come not timeenough. Wherefore should I Stand in the plague of custom, and permit The curiosity of nations to deprive me, For that I am some twelve or fourteen moonshines Lag of a brother? Why bastard? wherefore base? When my dimensions are as well compact, My mind as gener I do loveMy country's good with a respect more tender,More holy and profound, than mine own life,My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase,And treasure of my loins; then if I wouldSpeak that,--SICINIUS. Are you not hurt i'th' Groyne? me thought heemade a shrewd Thrust at your Belly Fal. Therefore be merry, Cassio, For thy solicitor shall rather die Than give thy cause away. In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shallcome over it; for in most comely truth thou deservest it. Before OLIVER'S houseEnter ORLANDO and ADAM, meeting ORLANDO. Madam, my former suit: I do beseech you That by your virtuous means I may again Exist and be a member of his love Whom I with all the office of my heart Entirely honor. 'His browny locks did hang in crooked curls; And every light occasion of the wind Upon his lips their silken parcels hurls. 126 I do not know from what part of the world I should be greeted, if not from Lord Hamlet. Ever note, Lucilius, When love begins to sicken and decay It useth an enforced ceremony. Honest Bardolfe, welcome: If thou want'st anything, and wilt not call, beshrew thy heart. Re-enter EXECUTIONERS, With cord, irons, etc. What is the matter here? MONTANO. What news from Oxford? Do these justs and triumphs hold? AUMERLE. Where is the Crowne? who tooke it from myPillow? War. Come, for the third, Laertes: you but dally; I pray you pass with your best violence: I am afeard you make a wanton of me. People and senators, be not affrighted, Fly not, stand still; ambition's debt is paid. Speak truly on thy knighthood and thy oath; As so defend thee heaven and thy valour! MOWBRAY. Exeunt DUKE and LORDS CELIA. Heaven guard my mother's honour and my land! KING JOHN. Ay, Marcius, Caius Marcius! Dost thou think I'll grace thee with that robbery, thy stol'n nameCoriolanus, in Corioli?--You lords and heads o' the state, perfidiouslyHe has betray'd your business, and given up,For certain drops of salt, your city Rome,--ILet all the Teares, that should bedew my HearseBe drops of Balme, to sanctifie thy head:Onely compound me with forgotten dust. Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence! Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will. The tempest in my mind Doth from my senses take all feeling else Save what beats there. O mistress, mistress, shift and save yourself! My master and his man are both broke loose, Beaten the maids a-row and bound the doctor, Whose beard they have sing'd off with brands of fire; And ever, as it blaz'd, they threw on him Great pails of puddle Go you to the Prince your brother; spare not to tell him that he hathwronged his honour in marrying the renowned Claudio (whose estimationdo you mightily hold up) to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero. Consider you what services he has done for his country?FIRST CITIZEN. Enter the BASTARD BASTARD. Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth with akiss and let not him speak neither. There's villanous Newes abroad; heere was Sir IohnBraby from your Father; you must goe to the Court inthe Morning. Please it your GraceTo goe to bed, vpon my Life (my Lord)The Pow'rs that you alreadie haue sent forth,Shall bring this Prize in very easily. And then I stole all Courtesie from Heauen,And drest my selfe in such Humilitie,That I did plucke Allegeance from mens hearts,Lowd Showts and Salutations from their mouthes,Euen in the presence of the Crowned King. He searcheth his Pockets, and findeth certaine Papers. That handkerchief which I so loved and gave thee Thou gavest to Cassio. This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit, Which gives men stomach to digest his words With better appetite. Poor Queen, so that thy state might be no worse, I would my skill were subject to thy curse. Now know you, Casca, I have moved already Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans To undergo with me an enterprise Of honorable-dangerous consequence; And I do know by this, they stay for me In Pompey's Porch. It is apparent foul-play; and 'tis shame That greatness should so grossly offer it. I will not hence and leave my husband here; And ill it doth beseem your holiness To separate the husband and the wife. He is as like thee as a man may be Not like to me, or any of my kin, And yet I love him. --Come, let's go:Leave this faint puling and lament as I do,In anger, Juno-like. Bring me no more reports; let them fly all:Till Birnam wood remove to DunsinaneI cannot taint with fear. MarkI say, instantly; and carry it so As I have set it down. Sirrah, your father's dead;And what will you do now? How will you live?SON. I will take your counsaile:And were these inward Warres once out of hand,Wee would (deare Lords) vnto the Holy-Land. Faine would I goe to meet the Arch-bishop,But many thousand Reasons hold me backe. Down with him, thief! They draw on bothsides. Winter's not gone yet, if the wild geese fly that way. Be not too tame neither; but let your own discretion be your tutor: suit the action to the word, the word to the action; with this special observance, that you o?rstep not the modesty of nature: for anything so overdone is from the purpose of playing, w The bay trees in our country are all wither'd, And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven; The pale-fac'd moon looks bloody on the earth, And lean-look'd prophets whisper fearful change; Rich men look sad, and ruffians dance and leap The one in fear t We'll send Mark Antony to the Senate House, And he shall say you are not well today. What's the matter, lady? EMILIA. I have as much of this in art as you, But yet my nature could not bear it so. These kind of knaves I know which in this plainness Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends Than twenty silly-ducking observants That stretch their duties nicely. [The music plays] Music do I hear? Ha, ha! keep time. He did command me to call timely on him:I have almost slipp'd the hour. What wouldst thou write of me, if thou shouldst praise me? IAGO. Come, come; for thou shalt thrust thy hand as deep Into the purse of rich prosperity As Lewis himself. I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and thengo I toward Arragon. Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for hisbad verses. Three or four wenches where I stood cried, "Alas, good soul!" andforgave him with all their hearts. Pr'ythee, see there! behold! look! lo! how say you?--Why, what care I? If thou canst nod, speak too. What? a yong knaue and beg? Is there not wars? Isthere not imployment? Doth not the K[ing]. No, it is Casca, one incorporate To our attempts. Must I go show them my unbarb'd sconce? must IWith my base tongue, give to my noble heartA lie, that it must bear? Well, I will do't:Yet, were there but this single plot to lose,This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it,And throw't against the Now lies he there, And none so poor to do him reverence. I'll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay; If any ship put out, then straight away. I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter andthe Moor are now making the beast with two backs. Sir, I am made Of the selfsame metal that my sister is, And prize me at her worth. Call it my fear That keeps you in the house and not your own. '"Lo, this device was sent me from a nun, Or sister sanctified, of holiest note, Which late her noble suit in court did shun, Whose rarest havings made the blossoms dote; For she was sought by spirits of richest coat, But kept cold distance, and did the Hamlet return? shall know you are come home: We?l put on those shall praise your excellence And set a double varnish on the fame The Frenchman gave you; bring you in fine together And wager on your heads: he, being remiss, Most generous, and free from a You all did see that on the Lupercal I thrice presented him a kingly crown, Which he did thrice refuse. Who deserves greatness Deserves your hate; and your affections areA sick man's appetite, who desires most thatWhich would increase his evil. --It is heldThat valour is the chiefest virtue, andMost dignifies the haver: if it be,The man I speak of cannot in the worldBe singly counterpois'd. We did traine him on,And his corruption being tane from vs,We as the Spring of all, shall pay for all:Therefore good Cousin, let not Harry knowIn any case, the offer of the King Ver. Be lion-mettled, proud; and take no careWho chafes, who frets, or where conspirers are:Macbeth shall never vanquish'd be, untilGreat Birnam wood to high Dunsinane hillShall come against him. Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for mysimple true judgment? or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex? Claud. It pleas'd your Maiesty, to turne your lookesOf Fauour, from my Selfe, and all our House;And yet I must remember you my Lord,We were the first, and dearest of your Friends:For you, my staffe of Office did I breakeIn Richards time, and poasted day and ni This is the end of the charge: you, constable, are topresent the Prince's own person. Good Lord! you use this dalliance toexcuse Your breach of promise to the Porpentine; I should have chid you for not bringing it, But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl. O, that's a brave man! He writes brave verses, speaksbrave words, swears brave oaths, and breaks them bravely, quite traverse, athwart the heart of his lover; as a puny tilter,that spurs his horse but on one side, breaks his staff like anoble goose. Good nuncle, in, and ask thydaughters blessing! Here's a night pities nether wise men nor fools. Exit [Cornwall, led by Regan]. With Pointz, and other his continuall followers King. Why, he hackt it with his Dagger, and said, heewould sweare truth out of England, but hee would makeyou beleeue it was done in fight, and perswaded vs to doethe like Bard. Dolphin my boy, my boy, sessa!let him trot by. And 'twere not as good a deede as todrinke, to turne True-man, and to leaue these Rogues, Iam the veriest Varlet that euer chewed with a Tooth. Look, where he comes! Edm. Gone to be married! Gone to swear a peace! False blood to false blood join'd! Gone to be friends! Shall Lewis have Blanch, and Blanch those provinces? It is not so; thou hast misspoke, misheard; Be well advis'd, tell o'er thy tale again. What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doubletand hose and leaves off his wit! Enter Constables [Dogberry and Verges, with the Watch, leading] Conrade and Borachio. As confident as is the falcon's flight Against a bird, do I with Mowbray fight. These fellows have some soul, And such a one do I profess myself. The bounty and the benison of heaven To boot, and boot! Enter [Oswald the] Steward. Ile make it greater, ere I part from thee,And all the budding Honors on thy Crest,Ile crop, to make a Garland for my head Hot. Thy state is the more gracious; for ?is a vice to know him. It is nota confident brow, nor the throng of wordes, that comewith such (more then impudent) sawcines from you, canthrust me from a leuell consideration, I know you ha' practis'dvpon the easie-yeelding spirit of this woman Host. If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it shouldbe otherwise. When I came back For this was briefI found them close together, At blow and thrust, even as again they were When you yourself did part them. By heaven, I had rather coin my heart And drop my blood for drachmas than to wring From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash By any indirection. Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of her favours? Guil. Is it but thisa tardiness in nature Which often leaves the history unspoke That it intends to do? My Lord of Burgundy, What say you to the lady? Love's not love When it is mingled with regards that stands Aloof from th' entire point. Ay, but, lady, That policy may either last so long, Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet, Or breed itself so out of circumstances, That I being absent and my place supplied, My general will forget my love and service. If you call me Jephthah, my lord, I have a daughter that I love passing well. Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile, and I gave him usefor it--a double heart for his single one. On this Ascension-day, remember well, Upon your oath of service to the Pope, Go I to make the French lay down their arms. Make your own purpose, How in my strength you please. I protest Maugre thy strength, youth, place, and eminence, Despite thy victor sword and fire-new fortune, Thy valour and thy heartthou art a traitor; False to thy gods, thy brother, and thy father; Conspirant 'gainst this high illustrious prince; And fr --We'll attend you there:Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceedIn our first way. For a taste: If a hart do lack a hind, Let him seek out Rosalinde. Of your philosophy you make no use, If you give place to accidental evils. Now comes in the sweetest Morsell of thenight, and wee must hence, and leaue it vnpickt. We?l e?n to? like French falconers, fly at anything we see: we?l have a speech straight: come, give us a taste of your quality: come, a passionate speech. Tullus Aufidius,The second name of men, obeys his pointsAs if he were his officer:--desperationIs all the policy, strength, and defence,That Rome can make against them. There is besides in Roderigo's letter, How he upbraids Iago, that he made him Brave me upon the watch, whereon it came That I was cast. Trumpet answers within. Why, God will send more if the man will be thankful. Enter CHARLES CHARLES. My dear lord, You know the fiery quality of the Duke, How unremovable and fix'd he is In his own course. I vnderstand thy Lookes: that pretty WelshWhich thou powr'st down from these swelling Heauens,I am too perfect in: and but for shame,In such a parley should I answere thee. Doe thou stand for my Father, and examine meevpon the particulars of my Life Falst. They'llhave me whipp'd for speaking true; thou'lt have me whipp'd forlying; and sometimes I am whipp'd for holding my peace. And daily new exactions are devis'd, As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what; But what, a God's name, doth become of this? NORTHUMBERLAND. Say thou 'no,' This sword, this arm, and my best spirits are bent To prove upon thy heart, whereto I speak, Thou liest. I meane, thou shalthaue the hanging of the Theeues, and so become a rareHangman Fal. Shall the Sonne of England proue a Theefe, andtake Purses? a question to be askt. Tell me, was he arrested on a band?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Let him be regardedAs the most noble corse that ever heraldDid follow to his um. Then am I the prisoner, and his bed my jail; from the loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supplythe place for your labour. I hope you will consider what is spoke Comes from my love. But look to it: Find out thy brother wheresoe'er he is; Seek him with candle; bring him dead or living Within this twelvemonth, or turn thou no more To seek a living in our territory. No, hath not? Rosalind lacks, then, the love Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one. And further, I haue learn'd,The King himselfe in person hath set forth,Or hither-wards intended speedily,With strong and mightie preparation Hotsp. Let nobody blame him; his scorn I approve-" Nay, that's not next. Thou'dst shun a bear; But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea, Thou'dst meet the bear i' th' mouth. "Sing willow, willow, willow-" Prithee, hie thee; he'll come anon [Sings. Peace (good Dol) doe not speake like a Deathshead:doe not bid me remember mine end Dol. I saw him hold Lord Percy at the point,With lustier maintenance then I did looke forOf such an vngrowne Warriour Prin. Are you there, wife? You might have come before. An honest man sir,is able to speake for himselfe, when a Knaue is not. Friends all but now, even now, In quarter, and in terms like bride and groom Devesting them for bed; and then, but now (As if some planet had unwitted men), Swords out, and tilting one at other's breast, In opposition bloody. You haue deceiu'd our trust,And made vs doffe our easie Robes of Peace,To crush our old limbes in vngentle Steele:This is not well, my Lord, this is not well. I would have told you of good wrestling, which you have lost the sight of. Excepting one, I would he were the best In all this presence that hath mov'd me so. Come, you look paler and paler; pray you draw homewards. It seems his sleeps were hind'red by thy railing, And thereof comes it that his head is light. Stay! speak, speak! I charge thee speak! [Exit Ghost. [Coming forward] Sweet masters, be patient; for yourfather's remembrance, be at accord. What neuer-dying Honor hath he got,Against renowned Dowglas? whose high Deedes,Whose hot Incursions, and great Name in Armes,Holds from all Souldiers chiefe Maioritie,And Militarie Title Capitall. Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm Invades us to the skin. Peace!We need not put new matter to his charge:What you have seen him do and heard him speak,Beating your officers, cursing yourselves,Opposing laws with strokes, and here defyingThose whose great power must try him; even this,So criminal and in such capWould you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?FIRST CITIZEN. I pray you, speak not; he grows worse and worse;Question enrages him: at once, good-night:--Stand not upon the order of your going,But go at once. As the time, theplace, and the condition of this country stands, I could heartilywish this had not befallen; but since it is as it is, mend it foryour own good. O, sit my husband's wrongs on Hereford's spear, That it may enter butcher Mowbray's breast! Or, if misfortune miss the first career, Be Mowbray's sins so heavy in his bosom That they may break his foaming courser's back And throw the rider headlong in t Thy rage shall burn thee up, and thou shalt turn To ashes, ere our blood shall quench that fire. If I speak like myselfin this, let him be whipp'd that first finds it so. France is a bawd to Fortune and King John That strumpet Fortune, that usurping John! Tell me, thou fellow, is not France forsworn? Envenom him with words, or get thee gone And leave those woes alone which I alone Am bound to under-bear. What thinke you CozeOf this young Percies pride? The PrisonersWhich he in this aduenture hath surpriz'd,To his owne vse he keepes, and sends me wordI shall haue none but Mordake Earle of Fife West. --Come, let us go:This fellow had a Volscian to his mother;His wife is in Corioli, and his child Like him by chance. O good Iago, What shall I do to win my lord again? Good friend, go to him, for by this light of heaven, I know not how I lost him. And that were much he should, for he is given To sports, to wildness, and much company. Come, Ile drinke no Proofes, nor no Bullets: Iwill drinke no more then will doe me good, for no manspleasure, I Pist. Now, 'mongst this flock of drunkards, Am I to put our Cassio in some action That may offend the isle. The instances that second marriage move Are base respects of thrift, but none of love. So, sir, heartily wellmet, and most glad of your company. O Jephthah, judge of Israel, what a treasure hadst thou! Pol. Then, England's ground, farewell; sweet soil,adieu; My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet! Where'er I wander, boast of this I can: Though banish'd, yet a trueborn English man. I have seen drunkards Do more than this in sport. I thank you for this profit, and from hence I'll love no friend sith love breeds such offense. 'Tis Cinna, I do know him by his gait; He is a friend. Mother, for love of grace, Lay not that flattering unction to your soul That not your trespass, but my madness speaks: It will but skin and film the ulcerous place, Whilst rank corruption, mining all within, Infects unseen. Go bid thy mistress, when my drink is ready,She strike upon the bell. Happy in that we are not over-happy; On fortune? cap we are not the very button. Prince Henry, afterwards Crowned King Henrie the Fift. These letters give, Iago, to the pilot, And by him do my duties to the Senate. Now neighbor-Confines, purge you of your Scum:Haue you a Ruffian that will sweare? drinke? dance?Reuell the night? Exit Silvius ROSALIND. Which is the villain? Let me see his eyes, That, when I note another man like him, I may avoid him. I Will debate this matter at more leisure, And teach your ears to list me with more heed. I say she never did invent this letter: This is a man's invention, and his hand. But if that I am I, then well I know Your weeping sister is no wife of mine, Nor to her bed no homage do I owe; Far more, far more, to you do I decline. Alas, how shall this bloody deed be answer?? EMILIA. Here are the angels that you sent for to deliveryou. I could bee well contented tobe there, in respect of the loue I beare your house. I have heard Where many of the best respect in Rome, Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus And groaning underneath this age's yoke, Have wish'd that noble Brutus had his eyes. He is not yet arrived, nor know I aught But that he's well and will be shortly here. There is a kind ofmerry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her. Master Gower, if they become mee not, hee was aFoole that taught them mee. You have said; but whether wisely or no, let theforest judge. I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee. I shall th?effect of this good lesson keep As watchman to my heart. Here stand a pair of honourable men- A third is fled--that had a hand in it. Why, then, 'tis hers, my lord, and being hers, She may, I think, bestow't on any man. Doe, if thou dar'st for thy heart: if thou doo'st,Ile canuas thee betweene a paire of Sheetes. Do ye not loue me? Do ye not indeed?Well, do not then. Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief Shore his old thread in twain; did he live now, This sight would make him do a desperate turn, Yea, curse his better angel from his side, And fall to reprobation. Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I would speak of concerns him. That such a slave as this should wear a sword, Who wears no honesty. I will weary you, then, no longer with idle talking. What said our cousin when you parted with him? AUMERLE. Back do I toss those treasons to thy head; With the hell-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart; Whichfor they yet glance by and scarcely bruise This sword of mine shall give them instant way Where they shall rest for ever. These may be counterfeits; let's think't unsafe To come in to the cry without more help. I haue vizards for youall; you haue horses for your selues: Gads-hill lyes tonight in Rochester, I haue bespoke Supper to morrow inEastcheape; we may doe it as secure as sleepe: if you willgo, I will stuffe your Purses full of Crownes: if you willnot, t Doubtful it stood;As two spent swimmers that do cling togetherAnd choke their art. Adieu, and take thy praise with thee to heauen,Thy ignomy sleepe with thee in the graue,But not remembred in thy Epitaph. Therefore use thy discretion: I had as lief thou didst breakhis neck as his finger. I ran from Shrewsbury (my Noble Lord)Where hatefull death put on his vgliest MaskeTo fright our party North. With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord; notwith love. My boy a bastard! By my soul, I think His father never was so true begot; It cannot be, an if thou wert his mother. Within these ten days if that thou beest found So near our public court as twenty miles, Thou diest for it. What, Brutus, are you stirr'd so early too? Good morrow, Casca. What committed? Impudent strumpet! DESDEMONA. It shall be to him then, as our good wills,A sure destruction. And here's another, Writ in my cousin's hand, stol'n from her pocket, Containing her affection unto Benedick. For loe, within a Ken our Army lyes,Vpon mine Honor, all too confidentTo giue admittance to a thought of feare. It is more worthy to leap in ourselves Than tarry till they push us. Accommodated, it comes of Accommodo:very good, a good Phrase Bard. 'Your (wife, so I would say) affectionate servant, 'Goneril. But I have none: the king-becoming graces,As justice, verity, temperance, stableness,Bounty, perseverance, mercy, lowliness,Devotion, patience, courage, fortitude,I have no relish of them; but aboundIn the division of each several crime,Acting it many waHow chance the King comes with so small a number? Fool. I will leave younow to your gossiplike humour. Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA ORLANDO. Tell your Nephew,The Prince of Wales doth ioyne with all the worldIn praise of Henry Percie: By my Hopes,This present enterprize set off his head,I do not thinke a brauer Gentleman,More actiue, valiant, or more valiant yong,More daring, or more bold, is His Highness yet doth speak, and holds belief That, being brought into the open air, It would allay the burning quality Of that fell poison which assaileth him. He did: and with an absolute "Sir, not I,"The cloudy messenger turns me his back,And hums, as who should say, "You'll rue the timeThat clogs me with this answer. Sure her offence Must be of such unnatural degree That monsters it, or your fore-vouch'd affection Fall'n into taint; which to believe of her Must be a faith that reason without miracle Should never plant in me. I think thou dost; And for I know thou'rt full of love and honesty And weigh'st thy words before thou givest them breath, Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more; For such things in a false disloyal knave Are tricks of custom; but in a man tha O good old man, how well in thee appears The constant service of the antique world, When service sweat for duty, not for meed! Thou art not for the fashion of these times, Where none will sweat but for promotion, And having that do choke their service u Opens the letter, andreads. Knavery cannot, sure, hide himself in such reverence. How now, my lord? OTHELLO. Vncle, adieu: O let the houres be short,Till fields, and blowes, and grones, applaud our sport. But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale, And feeds from home; poor I am but his stale. --Yet my heartThrobs to know one thing: tell me,--if your artCan tell so much,--shall Banquo's issue everReign in this kingdom?ALL. Why so can I, or so can any man:But will they come, when you doe call for them? Glend. Why, I tell thee, it is not meet, that I should besad now my Father is sicke: albeit I could tell to thee (asto one it pleases me, for fault of a better, to call my friend)I could be sad, and sad indeed too Poin. Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be aman. Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald, and therefore to the world's end will have bald followers. These tardie Tricks of yours will (on my life)One time, or other, breake some Gallowes back Falst. These flags of France, that are advanced here Before the eye and prospect of your town, Have hither march'd to your endamagement; The cannons have their bowels full of wrath, And ready mounted are they to spit forth Their iron indignation 'gainst your w [Within] A woman, and thine aunt, great King; 'tis I. Thou losest labour:As easy mayst thou the intrenchant airWith thy keen sword impress, as make me bleed:Let fall thy blade on vulnerable crests;I bear a charmed life, which must not yieldTo one of woman born. The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleas'dTo make thee consul. Our Newes shall goe before vs, to his Maiestie,Which (Cousin) you shall beare, to comfort him:And wee with sober speede will follow you Falst. To't, luxury, pell-mell! for I lack soldiers. Along with them They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-fac'd villain, A mere anatomy, a mountebank, A threadbare juggler, and a fortune-teller, A needy, hollow-ey'd, sharp-looking wretch, A living dead man. You are there follow'd by a faithful shepherd; Look upon him, love him; he worships you. Anon, anon sir; looke downe into the Pomgarnet,Ralfe Prince. Can no man tell me of my unthrifty son? 'Tis full three months since I did see him last. Sweet soul, take heed, Take heed of perjury; thou are on thy deathbed. For that our kingdom's earth should not be soil'd With that dear blood which it hath fostered; And for our eyes do hate the dire aspect Of civil wounds plough'd up with neighbours' sword; And for we think the eagle-winged pride Of sky-aspiring and ambit Not so (my Lord) your ill Angell is light: but Ihope, he that lookes vpon mee, will take mee without,weighing: and yet, in some respects I grant, I cannot go:I cannot tell. There is my gage, the manual seal of death That marks thee out for hell. In sooth Ileknow your businesse Harry, that I will. Let no face be kept in mind But the fair of Rosalinde. 'Well could he ride, and often men would say, "That horse his mettle from his rider takes: Proud of subjection, noble by the sway, What rounds, what bounds, what course, what stop he makes!" And controversy hence a question takes Whether the horse by hi The Prince of Cumberland!--That is a step,On which I must fall down, or else o'erleap,For in my way it lies. 'Tis thoughtThat Marcius shall be consul:I have seen the dumb men throng to see him, andThe blind to hear him speak: matrons flung gloves,Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers,Upon him as he pass'd; the nobles bendedAs to Jove's statue; and the Because their Legges are both of a bignesse: andhee playes at Quoits well, and eates Conger and Fennell,and drinkes off Candles ends for Flap-dragons, and ridesthe wilde-Mare with the Boyes, and iumpes vpon Ioyn'dstooles,and sweares with a good grace, a [To Kent] You are o' th' commission, Sit you too. --There's husbandry in heaven;Their candles are all out:--take thee that too. Nay, by'r lady, I am not such a fool to think what I list; nor I list not to think what I can; nor indeed I cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that youare in love, or that you will be in love, or that you can be inlove. There is a man haunts the forest that abuses our young plants with carving 'Rosalind' on their barks; hangs odesupon hawthorns and elegies on brambles; all, forsooth, deifyingthe name of Rosalind. Ecstasy! My pulse, as yours, doth temperately keep time, And makes as healthful music: it is not madness That I have utter?: bring me to the test, And I the matter will re-word; which madness Would gambol from. Truly, thou art damn'd, like an ill-roasted egg,all on one side. Let's have no more of this;let's to our affairs. A greater pow'r than we denies all this; And till it be undoubted, we do lock Our former scruple in our strong-barr'd gates; King'd of our fears, until our fears, resolv'd, Be by some certain king purg'd and depos'd. [A dance]ExeuntEPILOGUE EPILOGUE. Now go we in content To liberty, and not to banishment. Now the good gods forbidThat our renowned Rome, whose gratitudeTowards her deserved children is enroll'dIn Jove's own book, like an unnatural damShould now eat up her own!SICINIUS. His hands were guilty of no kindred blood, But bloody with the enemies of his kin. Tomorrow with your earliest Let me have speech with you. Your Maiestie hath beene this fort-night ill,And these vnseason'd howres perforce must addeVnto your Sicknesse King. [To ARTHUR] Cousin, look not sad; Thy grandam loves thee, and thy uncle will As dear be to thee as thy father was. The service of the foot,Being once gangren'd, is not then respected For what before it was. You foure shall front them in the narrow Lane:Ned and I, will walke lower; if they scape from your encounter,then they light on vs Peto. He that will give good words to thee will flatterBeneath abhorring. So, nobles, shall you all, That knit your sinews to the strength of mine. Can it be possible that no man saw them? It cannot be; some villains of my court Are of consent and sufferance in this. Cudgel thy brains no more about it, for your dull ass will not mend his pace with beating; and when you are asked this question next, say ? grave-maker;?the houses he makes last till doomsday. Then up he rose and donn? his clothes, And dupp? the chamber door, Let in the maid, that out a maid Never departed more. --If I could shake off but one seven yearsFrom these old arms and legs, by the good gods,I'd with thee every foot. Enter Othello and Iago, at a distance. But if it did infect my blood with Ioy,Or swell my Thoughts, to any straine of Pride,If any Rebell, or vaine spirit of mine,Did, with the least Affection of a Welcome,Giue entertainment to the might of it,Let heauen, for euer, keepe it from my head,And mCome:Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius,Though Marcius earn'd them not; and all his faultsTo Marcius shall be honours, though, indeed,In aught he merit not. I cannot chuse: sometime he angers me,With telling me of the Moldwarpe and the Ant,Of the Dreamer Merlin, and his Prophecies;And of a Dragon, and a finne-lesse Fish,A clip-wing'd Griffin, and a moulten Rauen,A couching Lyon, and a ramping Cat,And such a Have at you now! ROSALIND. Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well, For he went sickly forth; and take good note What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him. What will you do? Let's not consort with them:To show an unfelt sorrow is an officeWhich the false man does easy. What, man! I know them, yea, And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple, Scambling, outfacing, fashion-monging boys, That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander, Go anticly, show outward hideousness, And speak off half a dozen dang'rous words,  Those wicked creatures yet do look well-favour'd When others are more wicked; not being the worst Stands in some rank of praise. Say from whenceYou owe this strange intelligence? or whyUpon this blasted heath you stop our wayWith such prophetic greeting?--Speak, I charge you. I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head, And too impatiently stamp'd with your foot. Rich sheshall be, that's certain; wise, or I'll none; virtuous, or I'llnever cheapen her; fair, or I'll never look on her; mild, or comenot near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall be of what co God's benison go with you; and with thoseThat would make good of bad, and friends of foes![Exeunt. This Apoplexie is (as I take it) a kind of Lethargie,a sleeping of the blood, a horson Tingling Iust. This ague fit of fear is over-blown; An easy task it is to win our own. You'll see your Rome embrac'd with fire beforeYou'll speak with Coriolanus. Nay, 'tis in a manner done already; For many carriages he hath dispatch'd To the sea-side, and put his cause and quarrel To the disposing of the Cardinal; With whom yourself, myself, and other lords, If you think meet, this afternoon will post To consum But since all is wel, keep it so: wake not a sleeping Wolfe Fal. A Crownes-worth of good Interpretation:There it is, Boy Poin. When were you wont to be so full of songs, sirrah? ELINOR. What a Frosty-spirited rogue is this?Why, my Lord of Yorke commends the plot, and thegenerall course of the action. Now Esperance Percy, and set on:Sound all the lofty Instruments of Warre,And by that Musicke, let vs all imbrace:For heauen to earth, some of vs neuer shall,A second time do such a curtesie. Is 'a not approved in the height a villain, that hath slandered, scorned, dishonoured my kinswoman? O that I were a man! What? bear her in hand until they come to take hands,and then with public accusation, uncover'd slander, unmitigated rancour--O God, He's to make his requests by particulars, whereinevery one of us has a single honour, in giving him our own voiceswith our own tongues; therefore follow me, and I'll direct youhow you shall go by him. Yet he's gentle; never school'dand yet learned; full of noble device; of all sorts enchantingly beloved; and, indeed, so much in the heart of the world, and especially of my own people, who best know him, that I am altogether misprised. But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak? ORLANDO. O, bravely came we off, When with a volley of our needless shot, After such bloody toil, we bid good night; And wound our tott'ring colours clearly up, Last in the field and almost lords of it! Enter a MESSENGER MESSENGER. This and much more, much more than twice all this, Condemns you to the death. Our father's love is to the bastard Edmund As to th' legitimate. What trick? what deuice? what startinghole canst thou now find out, to hide thee from this openand apparant shame? Poines. Ha, ha, false to me? IAGO. What committed! Heaven stops the nose at it, and the moon winks; The bawdy wind, that kisses all it meets, Is hush'd within the hollow mine of earth, And will not hear it. O constancy, be strong upon my side! Set a huge mountain 'tween my heart and tongue! I have a man's mind, but a woman's might. What shall I call thee when thou art a man? ROSALIND. Can I bear that with patience And not my husband's secrets? BRUTUS. Sweet sir, sit: Ile be with you anon: most sweetesir, sit. Knock,knock! Who's there, in the other devil's name? Faith, here's anequivocator, that could swear in both the scales against eitherscale, who committed treason enough for God's sake, yet could notequivocate to heaven: O, come in, equivocator. If that come short, Our substitutes at home shall have blank charters; Whereto, when they shall know what men are rich, They shall subscribe them for large sums of gold, And send them after to supply our wants; For we will make for Ireland presently. I will not eat my word, now thou art mine; Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine. 'Od's my will! Her love is not the hare that I do hunt; Why writes she so to me? Well, shepherd, well, This is a letter of your own device. My woeful self, that did in freedom stand, And was my own fee-simple, not in part, What with his art in youth, and youth in art, Threw my affections in his charmed power Reserved the stalk and gave him all my flower. O, beware, my lord, of jealousy! It is the green-eyed monster, which doth mock The meat it feeds on. It is the stars, The stars above us, govern our conditions; Else one self mate and mate could not beget Such different issues. Yet this my comfort: when your words are done, My woes end likewise with the evening sun. Father, father! Stop, stop! No help? With mine own tears I wash away my balm, With mine own hands I give away my crown, With mi I am the cygnet to this pale faint swan Who chants a doleful hymn to his own death, And from the organ-pipe of frailty sings His soul and body to their lasting rest. My father lov'd Sir Rowland as his soul, And all the world was of my father's mind; Had I before known this young man his son, I should have given him tears unto entreaties Ere he should thus have ventur'd. Our general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona; wholet us not therefore blame. I will leere vpon him, ashe comes by: and do but marke the countenance that heewill giue me Pistol. And do but see his vice; 'Tis to his virtue a just equinox, The one as long as the other. --O, welcome home;--and welcome,general;--and you are welcome all. By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it,but that she loves him with an enraged affection. Meantime let wonder seem familiar, And to the chapel let us presently. There are many Complaints Dauy, against thatVisor, that Visor is an arrant Knaue, on my knowledge Dauy. [Servants bind him. There are a kind of men so loose of soul, That in their sleeps will mutter their affairs; Bora. My honour? lord, you know right well you did; And with them words of so sweet breath compos? As made the things more rich; their perfume lost, Take these again; for to the noble mind Rich gifts wax poor when givers prove unkind. If thou wert any way giuen to vertue, I wouldsweare by thy Face; my Oath should bee, By this Fire:But thou art altogether giuen ouer; and wert indeede,but for the Light in thy Face, the Sunne of vtter Darkenesse. --Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!MENENIUS. Hark!--Who lies i' the second chamber?LADY MACBETH. Ha! 'Tis double wrong to truant with your bed And let her read it in thy looks at board; Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed; Ill deeds is doubled with an evil word. Health, and faire greeting from our Generall,The Prince, Lord Iohn, and Duke of Lancaster Bish. The Prince hath ta'ne it hence:Goe seeke him out. Why, you are so fat, Sir Iohn, that you mustneedes bee out of of all compasse; out all reasonablecompasse, Sir Iohn Falst. Exeunt from above BOLINGBROKE. All hail, Macbeth! hail to thee, Thane of Glamis!SECOND WITCH. My Lord of Burgundy, We first address toward you, who with this king Hath rivall'd for our daughter. You have kill'd a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you. Depose me: if thou do'st it halfe so grauely, somaiestically, both in word and matter, hang me vp by theheeles for a Rabbet-sucker, or a Poulters Hare Prin. Away, you fool! It more becomes a manThan gilt his trophy: the breasts of Hecuba,When she did suckle Hector, looked not lovelierThan Hector's forehead when it spit forth bloodAt Grecian swords contending. Which is the natural man, And which the spirit? Who deciphers them?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Come, go; I will fall prostrate at his feet, And never rise until my tears and prayers Have won his Grace to come in person hither And take perforce my husband from the Abbess. Harry of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby, Am I; who ready here do stand in arms To prove, by God's grace and my body's valour, In lists on Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk, That he is a traitor, foul and dangerous, To God of heaven, King Richard, and to m The Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick,Don John, and all the gallants of the town are come to fetch youto church. Ay, sir; to be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man picked out of ten thousand. Icome but in, as others do, to try with him the strength of myyouth. Our watch, sir, have indeed comprehendedtwo aspicious persons, and we would have them this morningexamined before your worship. Exeunt Antony and Trebonius. Give me the cups; And let the kettle to the trumpet speak, The trumpet to the cannoneer without, The cannons to the heavens, the heavens to earth, ?ow the king drinks to Hamlet. Norfolk, for thee remains a heavier doom, Which I with some unwillingness pronounce: The sly slow hours shall not determinate The dateless limit of thy dear exile; The hopeless word of 'never to return' Breathe I against thee, upon pain of life. [To Edgar] Thou, robed man of justice, take thy place. We are not ourselves When nature, being oppress'd, commands the mind To suffer with the body. SO was I when your Highness took his dukedom; So was I when your Highness banish'd him. I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd Than what I fear, for always I am Caesar. Fie, now you run this humour out ofbreath! Come, where's the chain? I pray you let me see it. Can such things be,And overcome us like a summer's cloud,Without our special wonder? You make me strangeEven to the disposition that I owe,When now I think you can behold such sights,And keep the natural ruby of your cheeks,When mine are blanch'd with feO Corin, that thou knew'st how I do love her! CORIN. Nicholas as trulyas a man of falshood may Gad. Where is thy leather apron and thy rule? What dost thou with thy best apparel on? You, sir, what trade are you? SECOND COMMONER. If we shall be merry, now comes in the sweete ofthe night Fal. We will proceed no further in this business:He hath honour'd me of late; and I have boughtGolden opinions from all sorts of people,Which would be worn now in their newest gloss,Not cast aside so soon. Was that done like Cassius? Should I have answer'd Caius Cassius so? When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous To lock such rascal counters from his friends, Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts, Dash him to pieces! CASSIUS. Icharge you, O women, for the love you bear to men, to like as muchof this play as please you; and I charge you, O men, for thelove you bear to womenas I perceive by your simp'ring none ofyou hates themthat between you and the women the play mayplease. --Brings a victory inhis pocket?--The wounds become him. O that I were a fool! I am ambitious for a motley coat. Urge them while their souls Are capable of this ambition, Lest zeal, now melted by the windy breath Of soft petitions, pity, and remorse, Cool and congeal again to what it was. Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air, So many fadom down precipitating, Thou'dst shiver'd like an egg; but thou dost breathe; Hast heavy substance; bleed'st not; speak'st; art sound. What manner of man, and it like your Maiestie? Falst. 'Tis the Duke's pleasure, Whose disposition, all the world well knows, Will not be rubb'd nor stopp'd. To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight; Give her this key, and tell her in the desk That's cover'd o'er with Turkish tapestry There is a purse of ducats; let her send it. Marry (my Lord) Althea dream'd, she was deliuer'dof a Firebrand, and therefore I call him hir dream Prince. YOU sent me for a rope's end as soon You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark. I take it up; and by that sword I swear Which gently laid my knighthood on my shoulder I'll answer thee in any fair degree Or chivalrous design of knightly trial; And when I mount, alive may I not light If I be traitor or unjustly fight! KING RICHARD. What a blunt fellow is this grown to be! He was quick mettle when he went to school. But I prythee sweet Wag,shall there be Gallowes standing in England when thouart King? and resolution thus fobb'd as it is, with the rustiecurbe of old Father Anticke the Law? Doe not thouwhen thou art a King, hang a Theefe Prin. Ipress in here, sir, amongst the rest of the country copulatives, toswear and to forswear, according as marriage binds and bloodbreaks. What Horse? A Roane, a crop eare, is it not Ser. An he had been cannibally given, he might have broiled and eatenhim too. Angels and ministers of grace defend us!?Be thou a spirit of health or goblin damn?, Bring with thee airs from heaven or blasts from hell, Be thy intents wicked or charitable, Thou com?t in such a questionable shape That I will speak to thee: I?l call t Seuen, by these Hilts, or I am a Villaine else Prin. A sceptre snatch'd with an unruly hand Must be boisterously maintain'd as gain'd, And he that stands upon a slipp'ry place Makes nice of no vile hold to stay him up; That John may stand then, Arthur needs must fall; So be it, for it cannot be but so. Avaunt, you curs! Be thy mouth or black or white, Tooth that poisons if it bite; Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim, Hound or spaniel, brach or lym, Bobtail tyke or trundle-tall Tom will make them weep and wail; For, with throwing thus my head, Dogs leap  My heart is sorry for your daughter's death; But, on my honour, she was charg'd with nothing But what was true, and very full of proof. I muse your Majesty doth seem so cold, When such profound respects do pull you on. Alas, poor Yorick!? knew him, Horatio; a fellow of infinite jest, of most excellent fancy: he hath borne me on his back a thousand times; and now, how abhorred in my imagination it is! my gorge rises at it. Why, what a madcap hath heaven lent us here! ELINOR. Howe'er it be, I cannot but be sad; so heavy sad As-though, on thinking, on no thought I think Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink. Where is the enemy? are you lords o' the field?If not, why cease you till you are so?COMINIUS. Either consent to pay this sum for me, Or I attach you by this officer. Worcester get thee gone: for I do seeDanger and disobedience in thine eye. There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, Than are dreamt of in your philosophy. I was a poor groom of thy stable, King, When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York, With much ado at length have gotten leave To look upon my sometimes royal master's face. Like to the Pontic Sea, Whose icy current and compulsive course Ne'er feels retiring ebb, but keeps due on To the Propontic and the Hellespont, Even so my bloody thoughts, with violent pace, Shall ne'er look back, ne'er ebb to humble love, Till that a c Some devils ask but the parings of one'snail, A rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin, A nut, a cherry-stone; But she, more covetous, would have a chain. How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse! If I dare eat, or drink, or breathe, or live, I dare meet Surrey in a wilderness, And spit upon him whilst I say he lies, And lies, and lies. They say I willbear myself proudly if I perceive the love come from her. Hell and night Must bring this monstrous birth to the world's light. What comfort to this great decay may come Shall be applied. If here you hous'd him, here he would have been; If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly. This, thou would'st say: Your Sonne did thus, and thus:Your Brother, thus. Yes, every man of them, and no man here But honors you, and every one doth wish You had but that opinion of yourself Which every noble Roman bears of you. If heaven be pleas'd that you must use me ill, Why, then you must. Iever said we were i' the wrong when we banished him. Up once again; put spirit in the French; If they miscarry, we miscarry too. Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but, as you would say, a cobbler. For all the World,As thou art to this houre, was Richard then,When I from France set foot at Rauenspurgh;And euen as I was then, is Percy now:Now by my Scepter, and my Soule to boot,He hath more worthy interest to the StateThen thou, the shadow of Succe To none of these, except it be the last; Namely, some love that drew him oft from home. When a man's verses cannot be understood, nor aman's good wit seconded with the forward child understanding, it strikes a man more dead than a great reckoning in a littleroom. But it would better fit your honour to change your mind. Say to the king, I would attend his leisureFor a few words. And what wit could wit have to excuse that? ROSALIND. I prayyou tell Benedick of it and hear what 'a will say. In cities, mutinies;in countries, discord; in palaces, treason; and the bondcrack'd 'twixt son and father. I do agnize A natural and prompt alacrity I find in hardness and do undertake These present wars against the Ottomites. No worse then they are bitten, sir: For theyhaue maruellous fowle linnen Shallow. Prithee, who is't that thou mean'st? TOUCHSTONE. O, pardon, sir, it doth, and yongrey lines That fret the clouds are messengers of day. She give it Cassio? No, alas, I found it, And I did give't my husband. Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her torise. Here comes a pair of very strange beastswhich in all tongues are call'd fools. Give not me counsel, Nor let no comforter delight mine ear But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine. Exeunt PERCY and LORDS What is the matter with our cousin now? AUMERLE. Sir, you shall understand what hath befall'n, Which, as I think, you know not. These things indeed you haue articulated,Proclaim'd at Market Crosses, read in Churches,To face the Garment of RebellionWith some fine colour, that may please the eyeOf fickle Changelings, and poore Discontents,Which gape, and rub the Elbow at the newes He'll but break a comparison or two on me; which peradventure, not marked or not laugh'd at, strikes him into melancholy; and then there's a partridge wing saved, for thefool will eat no supper that night. I do beseech you To understand my purposes aright. And did not I in rage depart from thence?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick, my lord, Suddenly taken; and hath sent poste-haste To entreat your Majesty to visit him. Youth, you have done me much ungentleness To show the letter that I writ to you. Well, and say that MarciusReturn me, as Cominius is return'd,Unheard; what then?But as a discontented friend, grief-shotWith his unkindness? Say't be so?SICINIUS. Down from the waist they are Centaurs, Though women all above. THOU drunken slave! I sent the for a rope; And told thee to what purpose and what end. For them?--I cannot do it to the gods;Must I then do't to them?VOLUMNIA. I know not, gentlemen, what you intend, Who else must be let blood, who else is rank. But, cousin, what if we assay'd to steal The clownish fool out of your father's court? Would he not be a comfort to our travel? CELIA. --Think upon what hath chanc'd; and, at more time,The interim having weigh'd it, let us speakOur free hearts each to other. (reads) 'This policy and reverence of age makes the world bitter to the best of our times; keeps our fortunes from us till our oldness cannot relish them. I, when, canst tell? Lend mee thy Lanthorne(quoth-a) marry Ile see thee hang'd first Gad. Away toward Bury, to the Dauphin there! PEMBROKE. Well, sir, by this you cannot get my land: Your tale must be how he employ'd my mother. While I remain above the ground, you shall Hear from me still; and never of me aughtBut what is like me formerly. I had a mighty cause To wish him dead, but thou hadst none to kill him. Alas, what danger will it be to us, Maids as we are, to travel forth so far! Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold. Villainousthoughts, Roderigo! When these mutualities so marshal the way, hard athand comes the master and main exercise, the incorporateconclusion. --Let me twineMine arms about that body, where againstMy grained ash an hundred times hath brokeAnd scar'd the moon with splinters; here I clipThe anvil of my sword, and do contestAs hotly and as nobly with thy loveAs ever in ambitious strength I didContI had forgot myself; am I not King? Ant. Hear us, great kings: vouchsafe awhile to stay, And I shall show you peace and fair-fac'd league; Win you this city without stroke or wound; Rescue those breathing lives to die in beds That here come sacrifices for the field. Come, let me take my Horse,Who is to beare me like a Thunder-bolt,Against the bosome of the Prince of Wales. Master, if you do, expect spoon-meat, or bespeak a long spoon. No, Caius Marcius;I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with the otherEre stay behind this business. My Lord, I will not vndergo this sneape withoutreply. Come on, assayThere's one gone to the harbor? IAGO. The service and the loyalty I owe,In doing it, pays itself. But if you be afear'd to hear the worst, Then let the worst, unheard, fall on your head. Renowned Duke, vouchsafe to take the pains To go with us into the abbey here, And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes; And all that are assembled in this place That by this sympathized one day's error Have suffer'd wrong, go keep us company, And w All furnisht, all in Armes,All plum'd like Estridges, that with the WindeBayted like Eagles, hauing lately bath'd,Glittering in Golden Coates, like Images,As full of spirit as the Moneth of May,And gorgeous as the Sunne at Mid-summer,Wanton as youthfull What motive may Be stronger with thee than the name of wife? CONSTANCE. O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early, Who, having some advantage on Octavius, Took it too eagerly. Be stirring as the time; be fire with fire; Threaten the threat'ner, and outface the brow Of bragging horror; so shall inferior eyes, That borrow their behaviours from the great, Grow great by your example and put on The dauntless spirit of resolution. I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep; It may be I shall raise you by and by On business to my brother Cassius. Pronounce it for me, sir, to all our friends;For my heart speaks they are welcome. ' Speak to me, son:Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour,To imitate the graces of the gods,To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' the air,And yet to charge thy sulphur with a boltThat should but rive an oak. Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, and DROMIO OF EPHESUS, from theCOURTEZAN'SOFFICER. O, that we then could come by Caesar's spirit, And not dismember Caesar!
